Sequel dari The Witcher ini cukup membawa Improvment yang banyak dari seri sebelumnya, Side-Quest yang lebih menarik bahkan disini kita akan dibagi menjadi dua-kubu yang dimana itu berpengaruh pada Story kedepannya, nah itu sesuai dengan pilihan kita yang dimana ada Roche Path dan Ioverth Path, disitu kita akan ditekankan bakal bela siapa, ini bikin gua main dua-kali karena dua path story yang berbeda, tapi gua akhirnya pun lebih prefer ke Roche Path dibanding Ioverth Path dan itu tergantung pilihan kalian, dengan Gameplay yang semakin menarik, Choices yang makin banyak dan bakal berpengaruh buat kedepannya maupun Game Selanjutnya, Mekanik RPG yang lebih Modern dibanding sebelumnya, Pokoknya ini Game bener-bener bagus banget dari berbagai Aspek, meskipun ini masih Semi Open-World, Berbagai ragam Senjata dan Armor yang sering gua koleksi dari awal, pokoknya semua fiturnya diperbagus disini, apalagi disini ada Secret Boss yang dimana kalian akan dapat Senjata Yang Unik sebelum kita masuk ke Final Gamenya, Puzzle danMini-Game yang menarik buat gua, pokoknya ini Game cukup bikin gua betah.

If you have avoided playing Witcher 2 due to the first game, I highly suggest you just start a playthrough. The new third person combat style improves on everything that has aged the first game poorly. The narrative is great, it offers decisions with actual consequences and two stories that offer different quest and narrative experiences. It's worth a playthrough if you're a fan of the Witcher universe or third person combat games.

p.s. if your game is crashing, make sure to delete old save files as having too much will cause the games load times to increase and eventually lead to crashes.

For me there were times where I hated this game just because of some combat encounters. But overall I still recommend this for people who are interested in what happened before Witcher 3, but only if you are committed to learning Witcher 2's combat.

First off, this is the shortest Witcher game out of the trilogy, even when I took my time and did a large majority of the side quests. My first play through (dark difficulty, 2nd hardest) took about 17-20 hrs. However, the story that is here is really well written and the characters stand out as living beings with real motivations. The game starts off with a prologue, has three acts (with your faction choice in Act 1 impacting where you are in Act 2), and an epilogue. I personally preferred Roche as I found him more enjoyable than Ioverth, but to each their own.

Combat is the main reason there were times I hated this game. The combat once mastered can feel really satisfying, but I think combat falters in two main areas. 1) Whenever the game confines you into a small space with numerous enemies and 2) The prologue (first time play throughs). In small spaces you can see more prevalent how animations and damage do not sync up correctly. Even though it does not appear on your screen that an enemy hit you, the damage will often times still register on the battle log. This can be extremely frustrating on Insane difficulty as you only have one life, but it just teaches you that for most combat encounters, rolling and Quen are your friends. And as for the prologue, it's only really a problem when you first play the game because you're still trying to get accustomed to Witcher 2's combat. Just be prepared to restart your last checkpoint a lot during this part of the game.

Unfortunately, this game seems to crash more often than I would have liked. I think part of this is that if you have too many save files and try to go through them, the game will crash after like 3-4 saves deleted. Other than that, the game occasionally crashes during/after cutscenes and sometimes during gameplay.

Overall Witcher 2 is a good game and I did enjoy a vast majority of my time in this game. But again. for people who want to get into the Witcher franchise I would recommend Witcher 3. For many people they may be turned off by the combat and its a shame, because they should still at least read up on the story because it is a good one. Unless you want to play through Witcher 2 and see the events of the game for yourself, you can just look up the plot of the game and watch some videos from sections of the story.

TL;DR : The story is interesting, something you would expect from CDPR. Except for that, it's pretty mediocre in all levels (gameplay wise).

The witcher 2 saw huge improvement compared to the first installment of the game;  upgraded graphics, you can meditate whenever and wherever you want, dialogue decisions matter more....... and ..... I thinks that's it.
Now to the downsides of the game, which are a lot. 
I completed the game in dark mode, and I can clearly say that combat in this game is utter garbage. The sign cast animation nullifies your reflexes. Back-stab damage can one shot you. I don't know who set the hit-boxes in this game but he clearly did a poor job, you take hits even though you dodged and escaped, so you always have to keep a safe distance when fighting, cause the dodge is not a complete invulnerability.
Pebbles can block Geralt's advancement and deny rolls, so even if you see an empty space you can escape to when in a pinch, don't get your hopes up, a rock on the path may think otherwise.
Acquiring armor sets and such can be a tedious and annoying task because of the huge sums of money you have to collect in order to buy the patterns, buy or craft the missing ingredients you need and paying the absurd commission to craft an item.
Acquiring money in this game is quite delicate, since merchants won't pay good prices for your goods and will tore apart your pocket and suck you money dry when you try to buy something. The most effective method I found is arm wrestling.
Now that you have the armor set, every time you fight with a life-steal weapon, the game will put a black filter on the screen. Why ? I have no idea.
I won't rant about the quests/journal system, I did worse (*wink* *wink* morrowind players ;) ), but what I can say is that the game won't show you quests locations, so you have to talk to every NPC you encounter.
Traveling in this game is slow.

My recommendation would be to avoid dark mode, play on normal difficulty or less and just enjoy the main story.

[h1]  English/Español [/h1]
[h1]  English [/h1] 
In this second part of the The Witcher saga we are going to find ourselves in a different situation: the plot becomes more political and strategic than in the previous game with the aggravating circumstance that our witcher suffers from amnesia, a situation that will complicate the decisions when choosing whom to trust.

It begins with the murder of King Foltest and his killer, to whom we will persuit until the end of the game.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1887028187
This story will put us in uncomfortable situations where we will be forced to choose which friend to betray just to reveal a tiny part of a spider web made of magic and swords.

The characters that we will find will be more severe and cruel than the ones we've already meet, they will makes us feel that killing the Grand Master was just childs play.

Again we will have to choose a side: Iorveth and the Elves or Vernon Roche and his group of spies to the service of the king; both resentful beings and full of secrets. 

Each decision we make will make us reach only one of the 16 different endings that this game offers.

If you follow the path of Iorveth, you'll have the chance to play the story among magical beast and for more hours, while chosing the path of Roche you'll play less hours but the gameplay will be harder and enganging to the story line.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1475597979
The best thing to do is to play it twice, choosing each time a different path this way you'll get to know the story of the characters that you find in each way.

This time Geralt is tired of the political arguments and the deceiving plans of the sorceresses, exhausted to try to stay aside of the neverending problems.

Remember this: everything that you did in the first game has its consecuences in the second and it will them on the third. The witcher personality is the one you build with your choices, forging his character and destiny. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2745413557
[h1]  Español [/h1] 
En esta segunda parte de la entrega de la saga The Witcher vamos a encontrarnos en una situación diferente: la trama se vuelve mas política y estratégica que en la entrega anterior con el agravante que nuestro brujo sufre de amnesia, problema que complicará el desarrollo de los hechos al momento de elegir en quien confiar.

Comienza con el asesinato del Rey Foltest y a cuyo asesino perseguiremos hasta el final de la historia.

Esta historia nos pondrá en situaciones incomodas, forzándonos a elegir a que amigo traicionar para revelar solo una pequeña parte de la telaraña que se teje entre espadas y magia.

Los personajes con los que nos encontraremos serán mas severos y crueles que los que ya habíamos conocido, haciéndonos sentir que enfrentar al Gran Maestre fue solo un juego de niños.

De nuevo tendremos que elegir un bando: Iorveth por el lado de los Elfos y Vernon Roche por el lado de su majestad. Ambos seres resentidos y llenos de secretos.

Cada decisión que tomemos hará que lleguemos solo a uno de los 16 finales diferentes que este juego ofrece.

Seguir el camino de Iorveth nos brindara la posibilidad de vivir la historia entre bestias mágicas y tener mas horas de juego, mientras que al elegir el camino de Vernon Roche, el tiempo de juego sera mas corto pero también sera mas duro y comprometido en cuanto a la trama.

Lo mejor es jugarlo dos veces al menos para obtener ambos puntos de vista y conocer las historias ocultas de los personajes que rodean a cada uno de los lideres de bandos.

Esta vez te encontrarás con un Geralt harto del manejo político y las trampas de las hechiceras, agotado por intentar mantenerse al margen de los problemas que parecen nunca terminar.

Recuerda: todo lo que hiciste en el primer juego tuvo consecuencias en el segundo y las tendrá en el tercero. La personalidad del brujo es la que vos le das, son tus elecciones, tus decisiones las que forjan su carácter y su destino.

This definitely is Game of the Year 2011. The single best RPG I have played since Planescape: Torment. The characters are deep and complex, the storyline develops depending on your actions and choices. It takes what was good from every single RPG released in the last 15 years and makes it into something better. The graphics are simply the best ever seen in an RPG to date, if not the best that we have so far in any game (compare to Crysis if you want to). The flaws are few if any. The stealth sections are not the best, but they are optional, and there are a few bugs and such. There is no ACTUAL character customization, but you can change what the protagonist is wearing with quite a bit.
The combat system works quite well. It may not be the best combat system in gaming history, but it does exactly what is is supposed to do. But all that is just beside the point. The atmosphere, the music and the character lines are just amazing, combining to create one of the best RPG's of all time.

The first time I played this game, I put about 3 hours into it and never came back. The next time I tried it, it felt like one of the best games I've played and I can't put it down. Two things that really changed my experience with the game: 

1) The combat system is horrible at once. It feels clunky and awkward. Then you become skilled at it and it feels wonderful and dynamic. Stick with it. You're going to be constantly involved in 5 on 1 type scenarios where a few hits can kill you. You need to hit and run, immobilize, use traps, and generally be more creative in combat. Running in balls out will end up being face down every time, at least on higher difficulties.

2) The story will be overwhelming and nonsensical (at least at first) if you haven't played Witcher 1 first. The story is a direct continuation of the events from there including with the ability to import saves and your decisions. Basically, play Witcher 1 first.

The Witcher 2: The Kings Assassin is a continuation of the story of the Wild Hunt from the original Witcher while creating a new account with the fall of kings in the North. 

The game from the start tells well, allowing you to integrate your save from The Witcher and find out where some previous characters left, and current ones remain. You will be subtly reminded of your past through NPC's, reminding you of who you are and what you have done throughout the world. Although it was a great story, it did feel short compared to the Original and like it lacked much depth, but overall, it was delightful. 

The gameplay mechanics are fantastic; continue with a similar levelling system as the original, meaning you can choose if you want to be more assertive with the sword, wise with your signs or strategic with your portions. The fighting mechanics were great. Being able to pick your targets, place traps, and be sneaky was a fantastic feeling that made you feel a part of the moment. 

The graphics for a 10-year-old game are fantastic, considering this is the enhanced edition. The game felt well optimised, playing on my laptop with a GTX1650 on my 55" HD TV. Also, with the combination of the Nvidia GeForce Experience,  it was immersive. 

The main fault I could quickly point out is the map on the game. It lacked detail and was confusing when trying to find your way around the cave in Chapter 1 and the entire map of chapter 3. But overall, once you do some exploring, you get used to the layout and find your way. 

I played using the Steam Controller. Switcher this to the gamepad mode and change the game controls to focus on a controller. The simplicity was fantastic. It took a while to get used to a touchpad as a thumbstick. However, it gave an advantage in combat after a while. 

Based on the gameplay, graphics and story, I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Lore and is new to the Witcher series. 8/10.

Overall great experience for the player, even with it being as old as it is. Loved every second of it. Makes you think and does not just lead you down the path for sidequests unless you've done proper research in game.

Now it's an awkward mess of a game, so if you can't stand to play a difficult to control game with a poor pacing, read the book.

Before I start this review, I want to everyone to know that I played this game in January 2022 more than a decade after its release & mind you I have done 2 full playthroughs of the its Sequel the Witcher 3. I shall try my best to be unbiased and avoid any kind of fanboyism. Also, will NOT compare it to the latest gen games released in the previous 8 to 10 years.

[h1] TL ; DR [/h1]
[h1] Watch the Video Review Instead with the link below [/h1]
[url=youtu.be/GDYZDeBhF7A] The Witcher 2 : Assassins of Kings REVIEW [/url]

A decade ago back in 2010 & 2011
the AAA games of the RPG category were

[b] 2010: [/b]
i) Red Dead Redemption 
ii) Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood
iii) God of War 3
[b] 2011: [/b]
i) Batman Arkham City
ii) The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
iii) Darks Souls
iv) Uncharted 3
v) Assassin's Creed: Revelations

[b] Introduction: [/b]

Now let’s come to the actual review it leaves me utterly shocked that The Witcher 2 had to compete with such a list of legendary games of their time back in 2010-2011, each one of the games mentioned above were major hits, minus one or two.

Being a crazy Witcher 3 fan in the back of my mind I kept on comparing it with its sequel obviously which is unfair, I kept on telling myself NO just NO, but the more I played the more I wanted to play it further. 

[b] Story: [/b]

The story of Witcher world is without any doubt one the best fantasy stories written from its lore to its smallest character. The same is the case of The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings. It seems as if you are actually living the journey and believe me playing its sequel beforehand numerous times, it makes so much sense. It's mind blowing, almost like huge blanks of the Witcher 3 story are getting filled in your brain, From the origins of The Wild Hunt to the rarity and dying professions of Witchers. Then something which boggles your mind in TW2, is the two extreme sides of Witchers, one being Geralt a chivalrous Witcher who is all for good deeds and as he claims choosing the lesser evil, then we have Letho, Auckes & Serrit ex Witchers from the School of Viper who have become assassins &  puppets of the power players of the Continent i.e. Kings & Mages etc.

I would give the story a solid 10 of 10.

[b] Gameplay: [/b]

When it comes to gameplay mechanics in the beginning repeatedly I would keep on telling myself again and again, stop comparing it with The Witcher 3 and the newer RPG games which came after it. The gameplay to my surprise was quite good actually, you get used to Geralt kind of playing dance with his sword and whirling. The way Geralt ran / Walked it seemed a tad bit unrealistic, the Witcher signs and how they worked seemed even better than TW3. The monster attacks were almost at par to that of the TW3 I would say way less annoying. I like the random TW2 monsters they're way less aggressive and deadly, especially the Drowners. It's kind of a let-down how Geralt doesn't jump, which RPG games of 2010 & 2011 RPG characters did jump, also I missed not having roach and no fast travelling, which meant a lot time was spent just walking but at the same time it is not a full open world game like the countless games which came after it. A flaw which used to frustrate me was that Geralt would use the wrong sword and you had to switch to your other sword mid fight / combat.

I would give the gameplay 7.5 out of 10

[b] Interface: [/b]

The interface of TW2 is probably the worst things about this game, don't even get me started how badly the map sucked. You literally had to zoom in and then it would be of no use would leave the player further confused and the legends / markers on the map made no sense what so ever. When it came to Alchemy, brewing & drinking potions it was not as easy as it should have been. Now let’s talk of the loot and crafting items. There was loot with you which made no sense what so ever as they were quests items which you needlessly held on even though that quest line was over ages ago. Thankfully crafting your gear was quite easy and not that complicated.  The journal was quite simple and easy to navigate, to figure out your Quests and other important stuff.

I would give the interface a 4 out of 10

[b] Optimization: [/b]

When it comes Optimization it's not just the stability it’s the entire graphical as well the technical aspect which I could understand or think off. My opinion is games and their stability / optimization should only be given a judgment upon on their initial release like a month or two Max, which is pointless after a decade. I have an i9 9900k, RTX 3070Ti & 32GB Ram, I play all my games at native 4K with G - Sync on. The game worked perfectly but in certain situations it felt as if it had a clash going on with my multiple monitor setup, then it has a bug in which after the end of chapter 1 the game gets stuck on the loading screen, it only gets resolved when you play that same quest on the windowed mode, then it never occurs again. Talking about the graphics they're really good for 2011. I am not going to dwell on the fact what I didn't like about the graphics as it's irrelevant my assumptions are totally based on my minds comparison with latest games. I would end by talking about the sound a bit, the Background music was truly artistic and never went out of synchronization with the visuals. A job well done by the creative and sound team.

I would give the Optimization 7 out of 10

[b] Conclusion: [/b]

I would recommend this game to every RPG player especially if they looking for both a storyline and gameplay. Mind you, if you play this then you have to play TW3 which is something else entirely. The TW3 players who haven't played TW2 you have to try it out but mind you, tune your mind and please think you live in 2011 otherwise you will compare it with newer games and would fail to enjoy. I am definitely going to go for another TW3 playthrough.

I am going to give the The Witcher 2 : Assassins of Kings a total of 7 / 10. I wish I could give it more but there are certain things which can't be ignored.

Such an amazing story-line; haven't grinded a game like that in a while. The Witcher 3 and its two expansions were amazing, and I unfortunately played them 6 years ago before finishing this off. I'm going to play TW1 now as well, and will replay TW3 once the complete edition drops in Q2 (I hope). 

The character development, dialogue, and quests are all so fulfilling and engaging. There were a few quests that felt tedious, but I honestly feel as though this game's pacing is on point. I almost feel like games have lost sensible pacing. This is definitely up there for me. It's firmly next to TW3, GTA V, RDR2, Quantum Break, AC Odyssey, and AC Origins. Those games to me are master pieces and are undeniably some of the best games ever created. There are very few games that I've absolutely dreaded completing, and this was one of them. For its current price, there's honestly 0 reason not to buy this. 

Just to note though; it ran exceptionally well on a 12900K+D5 Samsung B-die+6900 XT, but ran like crap on a 9900K+D4 Samsung B-die+RTX 3080. The game's optimisation is a bit wonky, but I hope that everyone at least has a decent enough performance level so as to not ruin the experience.

The Witcher 2. An ambitious project with a complex plot, beautiful graphics, but inconvenient mechanics. That's how I could describe this game in a nutshell. Of course, if you start playing Witcher 2 after completing the Witcher 1, then those stylish modern animations could easily distract you during the tutorial. But allow me to explain you what I liked about this game and what I dislike about it.

So, what I like about the game:
[list]
    [*]Plot. The game is incredibly ambitious. Despite its focus on Geralt's personal quest and not so much on a global conflict it still remains grandiose. Obviously it still is the good ol' Witcher with its critical choices. Those choices play the main role in the story as the entire Chapter could differ completely;
    [*]Locations. Every location is unique and rich with its visual storytelling and quests they have. You'll spend a great amount of time walking around and exploring every single turn. Each location in each chapter has its own atmosphere, its own colour-grading and its own "landmark", something you can remember about it;
    [*]Characters. They are incredibly complex. Every character you meet is played and portrayed as an actual human being with their own beliefs (Unlike some characters from the previous Witcher game). There are no good or bad people, they all have a story and you can and/or will explore.
[/list]
And what I did not like about the game: 
[list]
    [*]Mechanics. At first, I wanted to include only swordfighting, but then I remembered those horrendous hitscans, which connect when they shouldn't and don't when they should. It makes dodging absolutely pointless (It can be useful is you're speedrunning the game as those rolls are faster than running). And if you're playing the game on higher difficulties this can prove absolutely impossible to play with;
    [*]Skill-tree. Character levelling, sometimes, can prove pointless. I don't remember spending many skill-points into alchemy and oftentimes I resorted to only using Igni and Yrden most of the time, so I had no reason to upgrade most of those signs whatsoever; 
    [*]Bloom. Even though I kinda liked the graphics in the game, this ugly bloom effect is everywhere and its blinding. My light-sensitive eyes were oftentimes in pain, so I had to download the mod that could decrease the amount of bloom, but I, honestly, didn't see many changes. 
[/list]

I do recommend the game, but it is, definitely not perfect. Get ready to curse at those hitscans if you're willing to play. 

7/10

It is a shame that I can't recommend this game. I liked the overall story, the visuals and the sound. The consequences of your choices were ok, though it was't feeling as tense in Witcher 1. I also liked the general fighting mechanic. The following design choices I did not like, but are mostly forgivable if the rest was brilliant and not a total BUG FEST: 
- bad tutorial/prologue (similar to W1 many people don't play past the very beginning, although I even liked the W1 beginning better)
- the potion timer does not stop at dialogues (you can just skip-click through it, but if you actually care about the story you are left without your buff if you have to fight right afterwards, because drinking in combat is not possible)
- the dark outfits (only available in dark mode). a few things: 1.  too expensive for the benefits; 2. not obtainable anymore after certain progress (if you bought only parts because it was too expensive to buy all at once you will have wasted your money); 3. the last one is literally for one fight (unless you enjoy farming, i.e., arm wrestling, it is useless to get just for W2); 4. the obscured visuals as soon as you draw your weapon even after wearing the whole set (very annoying because fastest travel is by rolling after upgrading the skill, which is only possible with a drawn weapon).
- I HATED every second of playing some NPC instead of Geralt

But the main problem is that this game is highly bug infested. Reasons I died: 1 % got attacked while in cut scene; 9 % bad player choices; 90 % because Geralt did not want to use signs with full vigor!!! This was the most annoying thing ever, especially on dark mode where you have to time your damage output before everything one-hits you. "Oh I know this enemies move set, hit - hit - Aard sign and I should be fine. Or not, let's just stand here and do nothing while I smash all the buttons on my keyboard..." I couldn't find a pattern. Sometimes they worked sometimes not. Sometimes moving a meter or rolling would "fix" it, sometimes not. When you rely on your signs (like when using the mage path) and you are in range of an enemy, just consider yourself dead. And according to several posts on the internet I am unfortunately not the only one with this problem.

Same goes for bugs that will make any further progress impossible. Like, how the hell should I know that somebody programmed Triss to not talk to me if I do not kill the last guy with  sword blow? The game told me the kill was fine but just deleted the option to progress any further...

The minor "you or a NPC get stuck somewhere and can't move anymore" things don't even seem worth mentioning now.

Very sad, I really wanted to like this game but there are just too many fatal flaws...
A classic worthy of replaying

Too jank for it's own good. I've complained with Witcher 3 how clunky just moving feels. It's way worse in this game. Even just something as simple as going up or down a ledge requires a prompt, an animation, then a camera snap back into place. Then there's how delayed every button press feels, how you navigate the menus, & the combat. Oh the combat. Better than the original game sure but you will get stomped on normal difficulty & potions aren't something you can just chug in a fight. You have to drink potions before combat to have these bonus boosts going as you play. Maybe it's trying for realism but it makes combat a lot harder than it should be. Then there's the monsters. With nekkers, you can get swarmed & slaughtered by them very very early into the game. Then once you get into the Karyn bossfight, you have to deal with attacks that have hitboxes the size of a barn. Watch a playthrough if you want to experience this game's story.

This game is good. Not great, but good. It's a hugely ambitious upgrade over the first one in many ways, although it does take some steps back as well.

The Witcher 2 is much shorter than the first game, which is likely due to how much higher the production values are per area. The visuals are vastly improved, and there's a great attention to detail in the environments. They feel extremely realistic and fully envisioned. That said, I do miss the amount of content present in the first title. This game's 3 chapters left me wishing for more, particularly in the side quest department.

I played on easy because I had heard bad things about the combat system, and I'm glad I did. The combat sucks and is stupid, so playing on easy minimizes the amount of time you have to waste on it. I guess trivializing the combat sections might mean that I missed out on some hidden depth that comes with higher difficulty, but I really doubt it.

On a similar note, I used a mod to remove the weight of all items because the inventory management system also looked horrible.

The story is decent. It's certainly well thought out, but it often gets very confusing. It has a ton of names and places to remember, frequently of characters that are only seen once or simply mentioned in passing, but whom you're later expected to be able to identify instantly. This sometimes left me totally lost. The dialogue can also be rather dry in parts, particularly from geralt himself. His voice actor always seems incredibly bored by everything, which I assume is their attempt at making him sound "cool" or whatever. I don't think it works very well. The writing is quite good when it gets going, but those moments are sometimes far removed from one another.

There's also the caveat that you can really only experience half the story in one playthrough because of a huge storyline split partway through that completely changes the rest of the game. This is cool in some ways but just annoying in others, since there are a lot of unresolved questions after an entire playthrough.

So yeah, it's pretty good. Not a glowing review, but I'm glad I played it, if only as preparation for the Witcher 3.

Probably one of the best rpg stories I've ever played. Upon completing this game I immediately replayed it several times to see every possible story path. And there is a significant amount of different content depending on your choices. In fact if you make a particular set of decisions you might entirely miss a huge reveal that changes the emotional impact of some other significant portions of the game.

This is not a paragon vs. renegade mass effect sort of decision, this is access to whole different areas and characters and quests.

Now this however comes with a price, perhaps you have played Witcher 1, or heard of how bad the combat was in it. The combat here is better, much better, however holy crap does it still have a long way to go. It is playable but it is not good, it is very bad. It is frustrating and awful and crappy, however it is worth it. The story is so damn good that it is worth slogging through the shitty combat.

Luckily the get they combat right by Witcher 3, but think of Witcher 2 as sort of the testing ground for their ideas for witcher 3 combat. it will be pain, but you can get through it. And you will be rewarded with a main story even better than witcher 3 imo.

HOW COULD HE GIVE THIS A THUMBS DOWN!? 
I get it. A ton of people have an undying love The Witcher 2 that will never be equalled. Let me tell you why, at least on PC, but probably console too, this game is TRASH!

Firstly, its just a terrible port to PC. Here's some of the things you will encounter.
-Game Crashes
-telling you it saved when it hasn't
-corrupted saves
-Freezing
-File integrity compromised
-I don't care if you have a top end PC you're gonna run this on all the lowest settings because REASONS
-Other misc glitches like cut scenes not going how they should, hair glitches, tons of other garbage.

so as if these issues don't make this steaming pile unplayable, there is a HUGE core game issue, that I understand is very divisive. Here it is:

Anyone who tells you the combat isnt COMPLETELY broken is a bold faced liar. They are too in love with the game to admit its faults. Obviously combat more or less IS the game so this is a giant problem. And yes, its possible to overcome the broken comabt system and get through the game. Does not mean its not busted. You'll read stuff online like "roll around, quick strike and roll away. Think like a Witcher!" Gimme a break friends. Imagine watching a Witcher or any other person roll around that much in combat. 
It would be ridiculous, and theyd quickly be killed dead. The reason rolling around so much is a must is because its busted ok. Broken. Just accept it.

The menus in this thing, the inventory and equip screens, are just a mess. You're gonna go into that screen to.. whatever.. read a book or equip a new sword, and first thing that happens is you're gonna accidentally unequip your gloves. Every time. Trust me.

The quest organization, mostly in Chapter 2, is super clunky. Different quests overlapping at different times to progress... sometimes resulting in missed steps and broken quests you can't complete cause you didnt do it at just the right time... needlessly confusing and not well set up. The little side quest I pulled off the bounty board shouldn't be able to be half done right away, but I need to progress a little more to finish the last half. I shouldn't need to question a person, thats in a completely different location, but if i stay where I am and question those people first... I lose my chance and cant complete that quest.... sound confusing? It truly is.

The game is backwards too. I'm not sure if this was intentional or not, but the start of the game is way harder than the end. Probably because you learn you have to basically roll your way through every fight more than a snowball rolls down the hill to hell.

The story is fine its whatever its Witcher story. I got through one playthrough on one path (theres two paths that are quite different from what I understand) but I just CANNOT go through the PC challenges you must overcome to get this thing to run and make it all the way through again! I can't do it! I shouldn't have to!

I even read most people can run The Witcher 3 better than this! Its just a hot broken mess with way too many PC issues and a terrible combat system. And yeah I checked the box to allow comments. I bet eventually I'll hear it...  "its not broken just GITGUD you mofo" I DID OK!? I DID IT! ITS STILL BROKEN FRIEND! KEEP ROLLING AROUND TELLING ME ITS ALL GOOD! It's not. And even if you do figure out the combat and progress, the other issues are just way too much to make this an enjoyable experience.

Gameplay is good, but the amount of blatant sexism made the game unenjoyable for me.. Some examples:

- The game seems to take a stand on racism but sees misogyny as unavoidable in the context of the Witcher world. This is shown through various instances of Geralt's choices and actions towards women in the game, but also the portrayal of female NPC's and the scripts.
- The only interactable women in the game are mostly prostitutes and sorceresses, both of them Geralt can use for sexual purposes. The sorceresses seem utterly helpless once Geralt arrives and even need to be rescued at times (arrival in Flotsam where Triss's dialogue, of course, makes mention of Roche touching her ass while being rescued from the ship).
- Male NPC's have a variety of faces and body types, ranging from ugly to attractive. For the female NPC's they seem to have copied the same face and body for literally every character: they are always attractive, big tits, small waist, big ass. The ONLY females that are remotely unattractive or ugly have their main focus point of their interaction based around their appearance. 
- Many dialogues are FULL of sexual and degrading remarks towards women. It gets tiring. Really, it seems like it's the only joke they could come up with in the whole game. 
- NPC's and at times Geralt's dialogue is hateful and sexualizing towards female NPC's in the game. NPC's mention enjoying raping innocent women, countless degrading insults towards prostitutes are being made, also by Geralt. At one point it just becomes annoying.
- The cutscene with Phillipa and Cynthia.... I can't even begin saying how disgusted I am. And this cutscene is proof of CD Projekt Red having utterly no respect for women and dehumanizing them to a point of every woman in the game only existing for sexual purposes. Really, this scene made me sick. It didn't even have any purpose for the lore, am I playing an RPG or a soft porn game??

All in all, a waste of a great game. No wonder so many women get put off from playing video games. And don't say 'oh but it's a medieval fantasy world, misogyny was normal!' because the game actively takes a stance against racism and lets Geralt choose a side on that. But the hatred towards women is something normal? It's a goddamn fantasy world, they could have literally chosen how to portray women in this context.
 
Only side note is that it was released in 2011, luckily the game industry has since then realised that their treatment of women for the past decades has been completely wrong. It's changing slowly. But even with the Witcher 3 there are instances of misogyny that are off-putting.

Weren't the gameplay and technical issues, this would've been the best Witcher game.
I love the story, the choices and the characters, and the fact that some choices matter so much that the middle chapter plays completely differently, and you need at least 2-3 playthroughs if you want to know the full story is genious. The length of the game also supports this, it is shorter than the first episode and much shorter than the third. This can be a negative thing for some people, but I prefer smaller worlds and shorter stories than the quantity over quality approach of the Witcher 3 and open world games in general. Yeah, the maps are smaller but greatly designed and dense with points of interests without being crowded. Yeah, you don't have 2154 quests, only a few dozen, but almost all of them are memorable.

The concept of fighting mechanics are really good (unlike the first episode). The character progression leaves room for many playthroughs and really enjoyable. The dialogues and characters are well-written, and  no matter what some people says the game is beautiful even in 2021.

The problem is the technical issues and the clunky controls. 
There are tons of animations that you can't skip / turn off, and makes some gameplay elements frustrating, like the dice poker animations, drinking potions, climbing rocks, disarming traps. There are simply bad design choices like inventory management, waiting after battle so you can grab the loot, interacting with shopkeepers, et cetera.
The main gameplay mechanic is the fighting, which has a lot of possibilities (using traps, bombs, throwing daggers, magic, swords) but is a struggle to learn and it is really easy to mess up due to Geralt not doing what you want him to do. I blame the controller support for this, the developers didn't have enough experience to do it perfectly, but committed to some design decisions which limits the keyboard+mouse controls too (like autolocking, clunky targeting, etc.). The game could've been much more if it was PC-exclusive, but I get it, at the time of the release that would've been a suicide note.

My biggest problems are with the technical issues. From minors like disappearing/teleporting/appearing actors/monsters, to moderate ones like crashes or a few quest bugs to really serious ones: on my third playthrough, I've reached to around 70% of the story, and the game didn't allow saving games anymore after crashed during a load. I've tried deleting saves because I had tons of save files, but that didn't help. I've noticed that if I delete a save slot in the load menu, I can save once, but I need to delete one slot after every save, and the quicksaves/autosaved didn't work. I've reinstalled the game without success. I've tried some steam suggestions and in the end I've lost my entire progress. And no, it wasn't insane difficulty where the save files are locked if you die, I've just started a new game to get the last 3 achievements I've missed on my first 2 run.

So whom I recommend the game to?
- You simply love witcher 3, and want more? You'll most likely find this inferior, or even unenjoyable.
- You've played witcher 3, liked it, but stopped playing because the megalomaniac world size / respawning monster hordes / lacklusting quests? You'll love this game.
- You haven't played with any of the witcher games, but love RPGs+action, or watched the series and wants more of this world with more Geralt and no Ciri? This is the best episode for you.
- You play RPGs mostly for the world/story? Play witcher 1 then continue with this one.
- You are an open world game fan? This isn't for you.

Technically it mostly still holds up 10 years later. The only visual issues which you might notice are common to games of that era. There are various mods to fix bugs and the combat if you really dont like it. This game was fully 3D when released but that may not be functional anymore.  

It's a 3 act game, with a prologue and an epilogue, which tells a tale of fantasy political intrigue. There is a faction choice in act 1 which chooses one of two act 2's. That choice also heavily changes act 3. To really get the most out of this game you would need to replay it twice. It isnt a minor replay where you see some other outcomes, you are playing totally different quests in a different zone so dont skip that because it will flesh out the characters and their motivations. 

this game is not to be missed for any RPG or witcher fans despite it's age.

[h1]The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings[/h1]
The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings picks up shortly after the events in The Witcher and follows from the attempt on King Foltest's life which occurred in the final cutscene at Witcher 1. Geralt will once again face the mysterious witcher-like assassins, who appear to be connected with a character named in previews as the Kingslayer. After the events that took place in the prequel, Geralt serves under Foltest the king of Temeria as a royal protector or simply as a bodyguard. However, due to an unexpected turn of events, the witcher was unable to prevent the king's assassination, and thus he became accused of the crime. Nonetheless, Geralt manages to escape with the help of Vernon Roche - the commander of a Temerian special forces unit known as the Blue Stripes. After escaping from prison, Geralt needs to go in search of the Kingslayer to clear himself of all charges.

[h1] The Paths [/h1]
In the second part, you have to follow the path of Iorveth or the path of Roche. The characters of the places and the story you see change according to your choice. As someone who has played on both sides, I suggest you choose the Iorveth path first.

[h1] My Thoughts [/h1]
It is an important event that the first game came out quietly and appreciated by the RPG audience, but Witcher 2 was the game that took it to the next level after the first game. Witcher 2 introduced the witcher series to a wider audience. The main thing that makes this game special for me is that it is the game that changes my standards regarding games. Witcher 2 shows me what to expect from an action RPG game. It is a game that you should not miss, especially if you want to learn more about the Lodge of Sorceresses and the political side of the Witcher universe.

A great addition to the Geralt Saga. Improving on many of the shortcomings of the first chapter, while maintaining what made it a great game. Deep lore, A captivating story, and pressing the player to make difficult choices.

Combat is fun and unforgiving at higher difficulties. Though potions are difficult to use, as you can only ingest them before combat, making surprise fights difficult to prepare for.

The story is linear; leaving little room for the player to explore at will and closing off gameplay area after finishing a line of quests, never to return.

Providing a save file, the actions you take in Witcher 1 impact what happens in Witcher 2, which is awesome, and the actions in this game will impact events in Witcher 3. 

For this reason, and to better understand the characters and events that take place in each subsiquent story, it is still rewarding to play through 1&2 before embarking on the Wild Hunt. 

9/10

If you're a fan of story driven rpg games, well, you will love this game. It certainly is a lot more of a crude experience than Witcher 3, but as long as you know a couple of things ahead of time you will enjoy the game immensely.

First thing you need to understand is that the game effectively has two worthless difficulties that do nothing but turn the gameplay experience into hot garbage. I'm talking about the Easy and the Hard difficulty. If you think "Oh, dark difficulty looks a little too extreme, and insane is probably even worse" then you're wrong, but it's not your fault but the devs. Think of the difficulties like this, the developers created three actual difficulties. Normal, Dark and Insane. Dark came later and is my personal recommendation.
The issue with the balancing is that Easy, Normal and Hard are effectively the same difficulty, but stretched in either direction. Easy is way too simple and not the intended difficulty of the game. Normal is fine if you're not that strong of a action game player. Hard is a literal balancing criminal offense, it should not have seen the light of day. It was certainly never playtested and makes Dark and Insane look like easymode. That is the issue of number stretching, if you're curious about why Hard is such a horrible difficulty, let's put it this way. In hard, you take a ton more damage, but the game never provides you with the tools to deal with it properly (only dark mode does that) and so you will pretty much die in two or one hit throughout the entire game, until you reach max level and the strongest armor in the game, even then you will only survive about one or two hits. Enemy health gets upscaled, but your damage remains the same as it does in Easy or Normal, and you can't effectively increase it a substantial enough amount to pair with the increased health pools.
TL;DR: Play either Normal, Dark or Insane (which is a hardcore difficulty, meaning you only have one life and you can not save the game).

Anyway, you probably didn't come here to hear about the negatives. Witcher 2 is the most interesting of the three games. It has a beautiful way of never taking sides. If you side with the seemingly bad side, you will learn that the choice you made may have a more positive impact in the grand scheme of things. If you side with the seemingly good side at first, sticking to judgement based on moral characteristics, you may find that you made the worse choice in the bigger picture. The game never truly tries to put you in a box, never tries to preach about right or wrong. In that way, it does something unique that many other choice based games don't do.

Additionally, the game deserves two playthroughs to get the full experience. In chapter 2, you make a decision to side with the Scoia'tel or the Blue Stripes. Depending on your choice, the entire rest of the game becomes different, the story develops differently and you learn different things about your own past as well as the world around you and its history. If you want to play the entire game, I recommend that you try both paths for yourself.

Overall, I've always felt like Witcher games are the type of games you wish you got to play with a guide next to you, not the cheating walkthrough kind, but a friend who's just sitting beside you and already knows the pitfalls of the game. There are problems in this game, as well as the first and third title of Witcher, and usually you have to make a mistake to know what to watch out for. The second playthrough is always more giving and always more satisfying, and that applies to the entire trilogy. I wish there was some kind of advice available to avoid feeling that way, but it's just true. All of the Witcher games are better on a second playthrough, because you get a sense of what impact your decisions may end up having, and you know how prepared you're expected to be at certain points in the game.

Overall, this game is incredible and my favorite in the series by a long shot. If not just because Ves is the hottest babe in all of videogame history (in my opinion) and you get to flirt and romance her.

I haven't delved into this game too much to give detailed criticism (6.3 hours as of writing this review), but I do want to say that in this short time period of playing, I really love the story that is developing. The game-play and combat mechanics are fun, the story itself is a bit linear but still gives you room to explore and loot areas to a certain extent, visuals are really, really good especially for a nearly 11 year old game, and overall I had a blast.

But I do want to point out that playing this game in the beginning was a slow/laggy experience for me, especially combat. If anyone experience some form of minor lag while playing, try disabling Steam Overlay for this game (easily done by finding the game in Library, selecting the Manage wheel, selecting Properties, and deselecting the option that mentions Steam Overlay), and on lower-end PCs you will find significant increase in FPS. It worked for me, and hopefully this minor solution will help others reading this.

Pros:
- Amazing storytelling
- Combat greatly improved over the first game
- Enough diverse content to keep you fully engaged in all the quests you do and not feeling like you are just grinding
- The decision making feel like it really has an impact on the story
- Never felt repetitive or tedious
- Easy to mod 

Cons:
- Some stability issues (having a lot of saves and the steam cloud ON seems to be reason for it)
- Some bugs (can be patched for the most part with mods)

I recommend you install some mods for graphical improvements and bug fixes, there are also some that will offer quality of life improvements to the gameplay and eliminate some minor outdated design choices as well. Also make sure to use nvidia's DSR (or similar feature) instead of ubersampling since it really kills the FPS.

[h1]The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition[/h1]

[b]Rating: 6/10 - fine[/b]

This is the sequel to one of my favorite games ever. Sadly it doesn't fare quite as well as the first witcher game did. The story is good, very good at some moments, and while I only rushed through one of the two possible paths in order to get the achievements I can say that both are worth your time.
The world is beautiful as well with a lot of gorgeous locations and set pieces. Exploration may be limited due to the game not being truly open world but all three of the major locations you visit during the three chapters of the game have many locations worth checking out.
Side quests are pretty well done in this game with many of them having quite interesting and sometimes bizarre stories to tell (looking at you Elthon). Completing them is a lot of fun and doesn't feel like a chore.

The main problem I have with this game is the gameplay itself. Especially combat. Controlling Geralt feels clunky and weird, he will often get stuck on the ground (at least for me). If you play or have played the game you will quickly notice of shitty controlling Geralt feels, especially in combat where unsheathing your sword feels as responsive as a dead cat and where you sometimes attack an enemy you didn't even mean to target at the moment. Thrown on top of that is the piss poor balancing of the game. Even at a higher level and with the best armor in the game fully upgraded you will die in two or three hits from some enemies like the gargoyle. And that's on normal. Now, this wouldn't be a problem if the game wouldn't force you into battles against multiple of them at times. This and many other things make playing on normal or any higher difficulty fairly unenjoyable, at least for me and I do usually play games on the highest difficulty available.
Playing the game on the highest difficulty, Insane is an absolute nightmare since your health bar seems to sometimes just disappear because an enemy hit you with an attack that didn't look like one (happens regularly with some monsters) or because you were hit from behind during a swing.

The only reason why I recommend this game is because it is part of the witcher trilogy and because the story and characters, especially Geralt, are really enjoyable.

It is 2021 and I finished the game for the second time. The first time was in 2014 and I was very happy with the game. 
Now in 2021 - I cannot recommend it anymore. It is a good game, but before you invest money and time you have to consider it.
Yes, it is fun. The story and the characters are very good. Geralt is an awesome character who follows his own agenda and nearly all decision are based on his view of the world. You can quickly become the Witcher. 

But the gameplay is bad. The balance is very, very bad. The combat itself is boring or frustrating. They tried to implement a Dark Souls like mechanic (the roll HAVE to be from the game!), but without the deepth or the interesting enemies. You have multiple stats - but at the end I don't know if anyone had an effect. 

The overall story is confusing - so confusing that the final dialog contains a dump of ALL information you need to understand everything. You lost your memory - but your best friends don't talk about the love of your life or your children of suprise at all. They only mention it in one or two sentences. But nothing more! If you read the books or watched the TV series, every main character had someting to do with them. IN this game? Just a small word. 

All in all it is a mess that could be much more. There were multiple crashes, bugs and not completable quests. In the enhanced edition. With some community patches.

Witcher 2 is very enjoyable.  I tried Witcher 1 and the gameplay was just too tedious, I bailed after 10 hrs.  Witcher 2 is much, much better, it's basically Witcher 3 minus a few of the more refined aspects of fighting and the UI.  If you played 3 and want more, I'd recommend trying 1, if you can't hang with it just watch the 3 hr cut scene movie version on youtube and then move onto TW2, which is quite a bit better in every way.

As far as story goes this is better than the witcher 1, however the combat is not as good. You have to meditate to drink a potion which is bad IMO. I think there are mods to get around its few flaws, but anyone who loves the witcher books and series will love this game its a must play.

There are a few bugs that at some points may force you to have to re load a previous save from farther back in order to progress, one that happened to me for example was during one of the flotsam missions. I had to load a few saves prior and lost maybe an hour or less of progress, not the biggest loss in the world, but before discovering that reloading was the solution, a rather aggravating time being sent to a cutscene followed by insta-death and the Load game / game over screen repetitively.... The gameplay on normal difficulty was more than challenging at some points and required using a different tactic to complete. Geralt caps at level 35 so spend points accordingly...  The witcher 2 is more cinematic than most games, so if you enjoy a cinematic game with somewhat challenging combat, the witcher 2 is a great choice. There is what i would call a "gratuitous" amount of sexual scenes, which are completely skippable if desired. I think i slept with a total of 7 different women in my playthrough. Overall i would give this game a 9/10. Im going to take my save into the witcher 3 and see where it leads me.
Combat is a little tough at first but alright once you get the hang of it.

This game isn't bad, it's The Witcher, if you like the books/other games/tv show you will probably like the story of this game. Graphics are also pretty good, though the game is a decade old so manage your expectations a bit. That's about all the good I have to say about this game though. 

Combat isn't very fun. Enemies that have shields or can block don't take damage while blocking (but you do when you block which makes no sense), nor do they have any stamina that would lead them to dropping their block. Most fights that have a lot of enemies in them just devolve into you running in circles and trying to single one out. It's not hard, it's tedious. 

And on the topic of running around to kind of get the enemies in more favorable positions, it's very annoying how Geralt can't walk over roots or small rocks that happen to get in the way, instead he just gets stuck on them. 

Some quests just don't tell you where to go, which is like a major sin for me with RPGs like this. I don't mind a little exploration, but the world is large enough that there should be giant circles on the map telling you to explore this area to progress or whatever, like Witcher 3 has. You will want to have a quest guide opened up in the side for it.


This game has very bad windowed mode & no borderless fullscreen. Bad windowed mode because hitting tab on basically most games fullscreen or windowed will cause your cursor to appear over the window so you can tab out and do other things. This game was made during a time when most people weren't multitasking while gaming so I understand somewhat, but I don't understand why this isn't something that has ever been added. 


  
Overall so far in 8 hours of gameplay I'd rate this like a 4/10.

Okay I was completely blown away at how different Witcher 2 is compared the first game, and i mean i a very good way. The graphics detail are a day and night difference, the combat style is miles above the first game and the story and dialog are fucking amazing!! I enjoyed this game threw and threw till the end. I wish it was as long as the first game was but still. The downsides hmmmm the combat tho improved still is not perfect, then again what is really. The difficulty is all over the place at times and if you don't get used to saving a lot you will start getting a big head ache. Other then that all in all, solid fucking sequel had some hiccups long the way but a great game!!! Can't wait to try the third game in the trilogy!!!!

I want to start by saying this is the game of the Witcher trilogy that i enjoyed less, BUT, overall, it's a good game indeed. Definitely it isn't worth a Metacritic score of 88, mainly because it has lots of cons.
Cons:
-bad potion/oils system, that is really annoying and not user friendly
-combat system, which is too simple, and isn't really satisfaying, nor expecially challenging, even without using the aformentioned potions
-vitality regeneration, even using potions you have to wait a lot to restore your vitality, so quite often i was just standing there using my phone and waiting for my health to regenerate
-this one is more subjective but i don't like Geralt's appearence
-boss fights, basically every boss fight is really annoying, they were conceived from a bad idea, and turned out even worse, I can't even describe with words how much i hate them
Pros:
-side quests, even if you spend a lot of the time running around the map because the side quests are really far from the 'hub', they are really fun (basically every quest) and add to the story/lore
-really interesting story, between the 3 games it's the closer to the books, expecially in terms of politics (which is really well done); it's also really intriguing
-envoironment, cities, forests and basically everyting you see is soooo good, I think it's the best in the series, and it really helps a lot the player's immedesimation (even though there are some points that are really too oversaturated)
-ending, I really appreciated the ending and basically the whole last act, expecially after a certain boss fight

In the end i definitely recommend the game, expecially if you are playing the Witcher trilogy because this story is a really nice addition

Witcher 2 is a fun game.  Playing it I immediately felt nostalgia for it like other dark fantasy games I had played in the past like Diablo or Dragon age origins.  The story is great and weaves both a tapestry of mystery and a sense of urgency.  Combat gives you many options for what kind of character you want to play, the side quests are rewarding and the characters intriguing.  However this game comes with its fair share of problems.  Throughout the game are weird difficulty spikes which hinder the experience, for example when you arrive in floatsom the games first real town after the tutorial level you'll find yourself utterly unequipped to go after any of the side quests save for maybe some of the more mundane quests like arm wrestling and bar room brawling.  You should be able to go after the nekkers (the little goblin guys) however every pack of them contains an elite minion called a "warrior nekker" who will literally one shot you.  Other starter side quests are similarly harder than necessary and filled with cheap one hit or near deaths.  The first real big boss is also EXTREMELY difficult and then the game gets easy again, so much so there were only a few spots here and there that gave me trouble and ending with a ridiculously easy final boss.  without spoiling anything its a kind of "round 2" with a previously fought boss that had an INSANELY difficult round one, but the final encounter with this boss is a joke that can be won by exploiting cheap tricks and taking advantage of the terrine. Some challenges I feel weren't fun to overcome just tedious endurance rounds one was a castle siege you fight off that you are forced to repeat 3 times in a row in the same area with the same variables nothing changed.  Another is when you fight a massive squadron of knights that although less mindless than the siege is much harder, the camera fights you the whole way, you are forced to fight cheaply and cowardly or risk fighting the whole gauntlet over again.   I also encountered glitches galore, items i picked up would sometimes not spawn in my inventory, prices would not match in stores, music would cut out, the game would crash, if i paused the game some times dialogue would skip. The worst was when an entire quest disappeared from my quest log as well as the monster knowledge i paid to learn via a book to fight said monster.  Items would often be overpriced at stores which I felt was a hindrance.  It didn't make things unplayable but if certain items like armor were 500-1000 gold less they could be attainable  as is if I wanted the best armor in each towns stores I'd have had to spend hours grinding out gold doing the same bar fight mini game over and over, or sell items valuable for crafting and alchemy.  I get that your SUPPOSED to make money doing monster slaying quests, but I feel the game didn't offer enough of these to properly feed your character so to speak.  Certain combat actions felt sluggish or unpolished, i never found out how to raise my mana over 2 charges (luckily I rarely play a mage in games like this) the block/parry doesn't nullify all damage and the timing mechanic feels VERY "janky" and "off" hence I was forced to rely on the quen spell and dodge roll for most of the game instead.  the auto lock on mechanic also leaves a lot to be desired as at feels like I often hit the wrong target and swing my sword at air more often than I should.  I'm very harsh on this game, but also overall enjoyed it.  I hear Witcher III is a MUCH more enjoyable and polished game I look forward to playing.  Given when this game goes on sale it's usually only 3 dollars so I'd have a hard time not recommending this game, but at full price its hard to recommend unless your a die hard fan who loves the witcher and likes to play the previous games before picking up the next/newest entry in a franchise like me.

So apparently this product is a total scam. 
The product won't work at all no matter what I do, from launching steam as Admin to creating reg entries. 
Witcher 1 Enhanced Edition does work, but for some reason on a brand new pc (3080Ti 11900k 64gb 3200 ram and WD ssd black) it just doesn't work. I'm on windows 10 if it helps to know as well. 
It's a shame though, the entire franchise doesn't exist if the middle isn't there. Bought this only because friends told me it's one of the best games of a decade. What an awful experience. Maybe it would work on older hardware? Hopefully this will get resolved soon or I will be forced to refund this broken product. 

Edit1: After waking up having some unconventional ideas in my mind to solve this issue, the game just seemed to be working as intended with and without changing launcher settings. It's highly important to know that I have reverted back any change or adjustment I have made trying to fix this problem. And as it turns out, I'm still convinced it was an issue with the game not being able to register itself through using the steam platform for some reason. I have tried every single solution I found online, and tired my own ones. None worked. And yes I have tried hard reboot, that bios and cpu settings, restarting, that incompetent official registry fixer. But for some strange unexplained miracle, after a night sleep the game just works. I'm not sure what made it to get solved without me doing anything different, but I truly hope it holds and I won't have to go through this nonsense ever again. Also it seems after researching, that there is a fair amount of costumers that have this same exact issue and some still not solved. So while I'm still convinced it's something to do with the game not being able to communicate in order to register properly, please make sure to recheck every single possibility before offering it to be sold. After all the work you have done, and people are well willing to pay for it (Me for example) It wouldn't be the end of the world to invest in a team that would create possible problematic scenarios with the product and solve them, so that you know for 100% the costumer won't come back with your product asking for a refund because it doesn't work. 
Still going to be weary about this entire franchise, since I plan to be doing a livestream in the future (After checking if it's legal to begin with as all titles have different rules). 
Thank you mysterious force that seemed to fix this issue, and no thank you for the one that made it possible. A question for steam: Why there is no option for Neutral recommendation? I can't recommend it after all of this without even experiencing it yet. This shouldn't have happened in the first place. But know that the issue is solved. I think we are entering a very dark era of the costumers having to go through so many checks right after buying a service or product. Will come back to recommend after finishing the game, when I actually start to play.

Just finished the game for the first time (Roche's storyline), and here's what I have to say:

The game is Great!
It contains Boobs, Monsters, Epic swordfights, Geralt of Rivia and all of this is put together into an epic storyline... What more is there to ask for?!

It of course has its flaws, but I would still really recommend this game, if you've atleast heard of "The Witcher" before, or just love RPG-games in general.

The game is not that long either, and you can easily complete one of the storylines, (Iorveth/Roche) in under a week.

So yeah, good game, I would reccomend buying it :)

Don't be warded off by people saying the combat is bad. Not only has the combat been improved dramatically since the first game but there's a balancing mod by one of the game devs that really fixes a lot of the issues. Very easy to mod as well. The game really shines with just about half an hour of modding (even if you don't know much about modding).

It is hard to navigate, I got lost in more than half the levels. Battles are hard enough, but to spend time running in circles figuring out how to advance is super frustrating, and the maps aren't much help since they don't clearly mark exits and entrances. The whole UI is annoying as well; looting is painstaking and time consuming, crafting is a chore, and even the plot is hard to follow and not very interesting. And its buggy, crashes frequently, takes too long too load.

The best thing about this game is that you can import save files from the Witcher 1, and it effects the story and your starting gear.

A tip: At higher resolutions the text is TOO SMALL. So I set it to a lower resolution and then it ran much better.

Combat tip: watch for the ORANGE SLASH of Geralt's sword, hit attack then to add on a combo attack. It's similar to combat on hard mode in Witcher 1.

Having gone straight from Witcher 1 into Witcher 2, this game was a significant improvement.  While there are certainly still some issues with the combat system (or more specifically some of the fight designs), no longer was I distracted by terrible art direction and visuals, women are no longer only sexual objects, and the combat and movement systems are no longer pure jank.

You can finally settle in and focus on the story, and they do such a good job at telling a complicated, political story. Their ability to tell a compelling, sophisticated narrative, at the same time as making it appear you are making decisions that are changing that outcome, is a great thing.

The game turned out to be a bit shorter than I expected, but I hear they make up for that in the third one.

It took me quite a while to get around to this game. I'll preface with this: I've attempted to play this one multiple times in the past, but never did the game grasp me in the first hour to hook me in.

I've got to say: I'm glad I finally got past that part. The rest of the game really ramps up and gets more and more interesting. 

The newfound hype around Sapkowski's world did a lot to get me interested again (the second season of the netflix show coming soon, which prompted me to read the book series summer last; though I'm still yet to finish Tower of the Swallow and the final book).

I never finished Witcher 1. I tried all the suggestions; the mods and whatever other means I could find to make it less tedious (especially in regards to the fighting), but I never really could get past how... wrong? Or rather, how off-putting, it feels to fight, move and interact in the game.

I can confidently say, you do *not* need the first under your belt to get a kick out of this one. Though, I did watch a more or less thorough story recap and picked a suitable endgame save that matched how I would've RP'd it, so that this game would start from a basis I was familiar and satisfied with. I recommend you do that too, if you, like me, choose to skip the first game in the series.

I played the game with the FCR2 mod and the fix/QoL patch for it, as well as a mod that made the HUD less intrusive and immersive. I actually think this decision was part of why I kept going past the intro and didn't feel tired with the game. The combat gets a lot more interesting and fluid with this one, so I really suggest you at least test that out too. Be warned, however: I did experience occasional crashes, which I think always happened upon saving. It wasn't that bad for me, so I never got around to investigate and fix it, but your mileage may vary. If it's even caused by the mods, that is.

This is also the first full game I played with my Steam Controller, despite buying the thing on launch and making extensive use of it in my living room when streaming (but never a full game from start to finish). I can wholeheartedly recommend testing it out -- much more enjoyable to play a game like this from a comfy couch, rather than sitting in front of your desk. It's very easy to get comfortable with the controls, though my config did end up being fairly weird in the end.

Now, this game shows its age from time to time, but in general it looks gorgeous. It's almost surprising how good it can look, especially in certain areas of the game. I installed a few mods that enhanced the visuals, most notably with upscaled and/or upgraded textures, as well as an applied shading filter (it was a bit finicky to get working and made the steam controller overlays laggy/glitchy, so I recommend either skipping this entirely, or carefully reading the instructions with each mod).

And, of course, I had a mod that made Triss' hair less red and more of a natural shade of orange/auburn, but I don't think most people would care enough to go there.

But, let's get to the meat -- I'll start with the negatives:

The maps are a bit too big. In general, you'd suspect a big map would be preferable (as one could deduce from the wild success of the third game with its open world and very large maps), but it's not working here in the way it would have to work to be enjoyable and exciting.

The main problem is the fact that there is no horse, and there are no quick travel options. This is fine for the first 10 hours you spend in an area, but after 10 hours of running back and forth in the same areas, it can get tiring. This is especially true for act 1, though I think I did things in a weird order there and could have been less tedious had I known beforehand that I could optimize things by doing multiple things at the same time.

However, this is another negative to the game; You can't view more than one quest in the map at any given time, so it's unreasonable to plan ahead for this sort of optimizations. In addition to this, the game does not present all the quests in one area at the same time (which of course it shouldn't do at any rate), so you'd have to know this and do certain quests before going to the area, to unlock another quests that could be done there. You could do this if you had an idea of what will happen, but if you go in to experience the story, you'll have zero idea of what's going to happen or when, so you can't really optimize there.

So, you end up running back and forth. A lot. How much, exactly, likely depends on how well you follow the order the game designers intended you to go through the quests.

Luckily, it's not that bad, because the quests and adventures you go through are generally inspired and interesting enough. There's some fluctuation between the quests, but in general, the quality of both writing and execution is very commendable.

Another thing you'll probably notice fairly quick, is one example of the age this game shows: The constant loading screens and rigid systems, and breaking immersions caused by those. If you are a neurotic collector of sea shells like me, you'll have to go through each and every building, door, path... everywhere you go. This means a lot of doors to open, even to the the smallest of apartments. Which means *a lot* of loading screens. Every time you go through a door, it's either loading screens *or* if you're lucky, a slow and rigid animation during which you lose control of the character. Feels wonky, either way, and rips you from the experience for that brief moment.

Luckily, this isn't a big deal either, because the load times aren't that bad, and the losses of control, while decidedly annoying, are something you get used to.

Then there's the fighting. I'm not a huge fan of 3rd person or 1st person fighting in RPGs, so I can't really say whether this is good for someone who likes those, but for me, it's all a bit boring. Don't get me wrong -- with the mods, it feels fluid and often very good to slash and leap and pirouette through the fields, but ultimately it doesn't offer much to the experience. The fighting just feels like the necessary evil you have to go through to get to the actual meat of the game; the story and the decisions and the characters.

Boss fights, especially, felt both uninspired and unnecessarily punishing at times. You play the game and have no problem dealing with the enemies, be they "elite" or not, but once you hit a big story point battle, suddenly you keep dying and restarting a lot. But, this might just be me, since I do not much care for the fighting in RPGs anyway. It's also not that bad, since there aren't many boss fights and certainly enough actual content in between to keep even players like me going. At times, I had to lower the difficulty to easy, despite being no stranger to games or fighting mechanics in general. At first it felt a little cringey, but I quickly found it was much better to get past the occasional tedious fight and continue the actual story. But this is entirely subjective, and you should probably read reviews from those that do actually care for the fighting aspect of games like this, too.

But, I think that's most of the bad stuff out of the way.

The story is great. There are some references to the books (though could've been even more, since I have the last book yet to read), but mostly it's very self-contained. Geralt is still suffering from amnesia, which is a great hack for the writers to really get a good story going without clashing too much with the source material.

Some characters are like I imagined or "felt" them in the books, but then some... not so much. I'll leave this to your own judgement, but if you haven't read the books, it doesn't matter one bit. All the characters are very well written and delivered, so it doesn't really matter even if you have some dissonance with the images you had had.

I ran out of characters here, but it's a great game. Do yourself a favor and give it a try

So yeah, despite others advising otherwise, I made the decision to play the Witcher games in order and I've just finished 2.

The storyline is interesting and really does get you involved and thinking about how you respond and the decisions you make.

The 2nd Chapter in Geralt's story, Witcher 2 is quite the journey. The story is rock solid as always, with excellent characters and decent voice acting(Dont wanna spoil anything), but the gameplay certainly shows its age.......some may say its a product of its time but i personally felt it needed to be more responsive. I would highly recommend getting the "Full Combat Rebalance 2 v1.2" mod, i cannot stress this enough but this mod truly makes the game so much better especially for those coming from witcher 3. Other than that the gameplay is decent enough, the graphics and art style still hold up (can be customised to taste with mods) but don't forget to turn off certain options like ubersampling and cinematic depth of field, these settings can be pretty system intensive hence causing unnecessary performance loss. 

The Story-choices do have a substantial consequences and carry forward to witcher 3 so choose wisely, and certain characters and events in witcher 3 are much more easier to understand since they are given context in witcher 2. Overall if you liked witcher 3, fan of the books or like narrative-rich rpgs this one's for you. (Also its ridiculously cheap on Sales, so its a no brainer)

This game is more than amazing, and I was already a fan of Geralt's adventures before playing the games
