Later in the game, specially in Loc Muinne, the game suddenly takes a different turn, the third chapter is extremely short and the entire story thus far feels not only inconclusive, but pointless, as if it had been nothing but a wild goose chase. Not to mention the game feels extremely short in regards to character progression -- near the end of the game you feel as if you hadn't really had the chance to try out your most recently unlocked abilities

The game branches out and thus has good replayability, but with no New Game+ it's a little less exciting, and I wish the game was longer per playthrough. I Invested almost as much time as with the first game, but it still FELT as if it had fallen short

All in all, great game and will play again with a new playthrough, but with a few mods to compensate for the lack of New Game+

[h1] My Review for The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition [/h1]

[b] Positives [/b]
[list]
    [*] Great RPG to make you feel like the Witcher.
    [*] A true feel of the surroundings and the people in the game.
    [*] Choices matter and will alter the game.
[/list]

[B] Negatives [/B]
[list]
    [*] Easy can feel too easy, Normal can start to feel to hard. Seems no middle ground (maybe just me)
    [*] Navigation is a little rough it just points and at times I have headed the wrong way.
    [*] Picking things up or using a door or ladder may be annoying sometimes you have to find the correct way to view it.


[B]Overall[/B]

[i]The game has around 24 hours or more depending how fast you play, the story is very good and even with it being an older game that doesn't have much open world to it. I am sure most people have played Witcher 3 and if you haven't played Witcher 2 it still definitely is worth it. 8.5/10[/i]

Story: Great.
Graphics: Good.
Gameplay: mostly good
Menus: Okay

The story is great. There's twists, drama, magic, politics, risks and stakes, mystery, eroticism (though unfortunately very little for those who prefer men), etc. It's not difficult to suspend disbelief and enjoy it. There are several choices that really change the flow of the story as well as the side you end on and let you see situations from different perspectives. This adds to replayability. The characters you spend time with are fleshed out with personalities, motives, competences, flaws, and pasts.

I have no complaints about the graphics nor the animations. They make the world feel alive. Environments seem varied enough. Monsters look monstrous. Characters feel real as opposed to everyone inexplicably having the same ripped body like in some games. Check the game's hardware requirements on the store's page and some gameplay videos for more info. Voice acting is convincing enough. Dialogues fit their characters. Multiple languages are available.

The gameplay is mostly good. Character development tree allows for change in fighting style, there's plenty interesting loot and crafting. The game makes you do more to win a battle than bash buttons. However, if you invest a lot of points into potions there may be a fight or two where you won't be able to drink them beforehand. You may also prefer some repetitive animations to be shorter, such as climbing ladders or otherwise. What frustrated me the most was that often during combat the main character simply wouldn't execute certain commands until one moves him a bit first. Losing battles and having to reload due to a bug is very frustrating. I also didn't like the dice poker side quest as it is too luck oriented. To complete it I made myself watch the (re)loading screen a lot. Don't be a completionist, skip those as soon as you don't enjoy them. There's less repetitive side quests to get good equipment.
I also didn't like the mutagens system. For one, it acts just like equipment, which is boring. Except it won't let you unequip, which makes it worse as when you equip a weak mutagen you're stuck with it. You can instead wait to see how good they can get, but then you're just waiting and hoarding, not using them until game end. It's not fun either way.

One thing I would complain about is that menus could be a bit faster to navigate. I don't want to have to exit one menu to enter another one nor wait for the fade out / fade in effects. I also don't want to wait several seconds for the same animation everytime I drink potions. All these things could be better done instantly or have animations only the very first time. Loading screen also takes a while to show up after a lot of saves are made.

Btw: If you go the alchemist way, ingredients can be important as you'll do a lot of damage with bombs, but I ended up with 150+ excess in many ingredients at the end. If you see yourself hoarding 100+ of something, don't go out of your way to pick more, you very likely won't need that much.

The Witcher 2 is unique. All three of these games are very different from each other as well as all other video games (for better and worse). In terms of this series, this entry is probably the best *looking*. It's got a more defined style with the light and the environments. I don't necessarily think that's a bad thing about 3 though, considering 2 is still a linear game. I would also say that this game's combat is flashy but untrustworthy. Some enemies (Elementals being the biggest offenders) will take half your vitality on a swing that didn't connect. The combat has a ridiculous difficulty curve in Chapter 3 that honestly takes a lot of the fun out of it. The more scripted boss fights (like the Kayran in chapter 1, to avoid spoilers) are uncomfortable and hard to navigate. All that being said, the writing and the quests are strong. Considering how much of a mess even the best parts of the first game are, 2 still feels like an incredible step up. And now I get to play 3 again, with all my fancy new context and choices.

Part two of my journey through all the Witcher content. After playing both and starting Witcher 3 I cannot stress enough how you should play the games in order. However. There are a few caveats. Witcher 2 departs from the monsters, mystism and folklore of Witcher 1 and goes more into politics and socio-cultural events. This makes it so you actually feel less like a Witcher and more like an Assassin's Creed protagonist. You do not kill monsters that much here, which is a pity but perhaps politics are an equally important part of a Witcher's job - I do not know, I did not read the books yet. 

While the combat is Witcher 1 is weird but fun in its own way, the combat in Witcher 2 feels off. The hitboxes and damage frames are laughably misaligned with what you see on screen and the RPG progression is weak at best. The game is completely carried by the story and the characters. It makes up for it 100% though.

It should be played twice for best enjoyment and I propose you go with Roche on your first and Iorveth on your second. 

Building emotional attachement with all of the characters in Witcher 1 and 2 will massively improve your experience with Witcher 3. Meeting Yennefer after playing 60 hours of previous games instead of 5 hours of Witcher 3: I recommend it. You cannot make up for that with a 10min story recap video on YouTube.

The second part of the amazing RPG trilogy, which will definitely not disappoint. The biggest disadvantage of the combat system itself, which otherwise has no faults, it is  drinking potions, which unfortunately cannot be operated during combat, I understand the intention of the developers with this mechanism, but it does not fit very well into the dynamics of the entire combat system. Otherwise, we have a wonderfully processed main story and side tasks, which, thanks to their elaboration, will not even seem like side quests, where you just have to bring something or kill something somewhere, as is usual with other RPG titles.

82/100.  Good, but not as good as the original The Witcher (which I played just prior to this, and gave 90/100).  It feels like it's changed from a PC RPG to a console Action-Adventure.

Triss is not as hot (and is missing most of the game), the graphics are more modern but blurry and hard to look at, the controls are dumbed down for console/gamepad (I used KB+M) with awful default key bindings for selecting and casting spells, and the combat is worse, plus they've added QTEs.

The lore and setting is fantastic, everything is more polished (the surround sound is fantastic), and there are less bugs, but Act 3 just suddenly brings it all to an abrupt close.  It's like they ran out of money and just needed to wrap it up one or two acts sooner than they planned - I had hardly touched the skill trees, with a lot I still wanted to open up (and I hadn't used a single mutagen yet, outside the tutorial).

It's a good game with high production values that is easier to get into than the first Witcher and goes by quickly.  It ticks a lot of boxes, but it lacks soul.

a masterpiece, that's it.

Pros -

- Stellar writing. Plot is great, fun to watch unfold. Always kept me on my toes. Characters are compelling as well, coupled with quality voice acting to match.

- Your choices do have a great deal of effect in your experience which is what matters. Yes you can change major story beats and yes, the ending is still binary in it's nature which I usually am against because most systems with binary ending play the good ending bad ending game. Here they're all just outcomes, you may like one over the other but there is no good or evil result. Just equally feasible scenarios.

- Good soundtrack overall. Some excellent stuff, a few meh tracks but mostly better than "above average".

- Hmmm... nice combat. Honestly, I don't get what the fuss about TW2 combat is but I got used to it quick and thoroughly enjoyed it. No I did not use the FCR mod. Moments of frustration do arise from the controls themselves being very dodgy at times but nothing because of the combat system. I think it's fine.

- Great level design, very reminiscent of classical fantasy literature. Flotsam is immediately what comes to mind when I think of a human settlement surrounded by a magical forest, all other locations befit their tropes as well which I believe to be quite endearing in.

- Has the single best boinking scene in all of video game history.

- Extensive mod support. I made Triss's eyes blue, Dandelion a blond and gave Geralt a more modern face.

Cons-

- In terms of bugs, we have two bugs. The game has a tendency to crash when you tab out, and that it makes every save, quick-save and auto-save in a separate new slot and when you pass a certain number of save files the game becomes unresponsive in the menus, you can delete the excess save slots to prevent the engine from crumbling under the weight.

- On the graphical side, I'd say the game has some stunning art direction but is held back by the texture and mesh work. Image looks way over-sharpened and if you said you had a headache from just looking at it I would be inclined to believe you.

Conclusion: Good game, excellent narrative. Controls can be wonky and graphics can be ugly, some of which can be fixed by mods. Recommend everyone to play this at least twice. [spoiler]Roche always best bro, fuck Iorveth. All my homies hate the squirrel.[/spoiler]

I wanted to play the first two Witcher titles before playing the third one. I played the first title -- more than once now. I enjoyed the characters, the world environment and lore. I enjoyed even the strange combat system. Once you got comfortable with the combo chaining and picking the right fighting stance, you could defeat just about any enemy, with or without mutagens. Of course, if you went through the extra effort of preparing mutagens and oils, you would be able to accomplish the task much more efficiently. But it wasn't necessarily required.

The Witcher 2 however -- forget about it. Yeah, the story is great, the graphics are beautiful even in 2021. The engine is well optimized, and all the other surface level things are great. But the combat system *sucks*. It is one of the most unfriendly combat systems even by this title's vintage I have ever encountered. Don't get me wrong, I can understand where they were going with the new engine at the time. Trying to build in more freedom of movement and control while retaining the traits that made combat in the earlier title unique. But they clearly didn't invest enough time into it.

You might wonder, how could this game have a worse combat experience than the original? Well, if you played the original you might remember that the combat kind of on rails. However, once you got used to chaining swordplay combos, using the right combat stance and sword, it never felt like it was in your way. Mutagens and oils/stones were not necessarily required to win, but they made the task much more efficient. Trying to win without them was sometimes quite brutal, but as long as you were consistent with combo chaining and stance you could grind your way through whatever was in your path.

This game, on the other hand, attempted to give the player more freedom of movement and completely removed the isometric movement/combat system. The result is, however, a combat system that constantly feels like its in your way. Movement up and down obstacles that doesn't work in combat. Punishing pure swordplay combat -- something that makes early game very frustrating, as you will have few resources available to plow through the jungle with the traps, bombs, etc. Instead, you'll find yourself cheesing most mobs by poking them here and there, maybe throwing a fireball or two, and rolling around repeatedly until they are all dead. This is also important, even with mutagens, as Geralt is very squishy and vulnerable and a mob in great numbers can easily trap Geralt, stun him with a glancing blow, or inflict fatal damage by getting a little too close to a mob.

The stealth mechanic is also clunky, I'd even say worthless. Geralt in "stealth" missions will automatically choose to enter "stealth mode", but sometimes choose not to at all or seemingly exiting it at the worst times. You can seldom if ever move slowly enough to not alert guards in these sessions even with all the light sources extinguished, and end up beating them down anyway. There is an early game stealth mission where you'll probably find yourself killing everyone in your path and getting chastised by your friends for it as a result of this problem. Maybe this worked better with console controls, I don't know.

I would give this title a hard pass. Not worth your time or money. Find a TL;DR for the story online and go on to the third title instead.

The Witcher 2 seems to be a game that is chasing the trends of the mid-late 2000s games of it's time. Combat is clunky and slow with a long delay between certain actions making it impossible to follow up on some attacks. The combat also doesn't seem to be designed well for multiple encounters as unless you have certain perks unlocked you will have three other enemies smacking you around while you try and hit one of them. This leads to encounters where you either have to run around and occasionally poke one of the enemies until they die, set up a trap before hand and lead them into it, or throw several stunning bombs making it so they can't retaliate. I tried the combat in the beginning areas on easy, normal, and hard with easy making you tank through most attacks, normal being the most "balanced", and hard and above having Geralt be nothing more than a role of wet tissues vaguely in the shape of a man.

One obnoxious part of the game is the out of nowhere QTEs that could have easily been replaced with a button prompt. There are parts where I have to spam left click on my mouse like a clicker game for a brief moment just to get Geralt to do something. The only saving grace with them is that you can disable the QTEs that kill you if you fail them. This has the side effect of having the parts where the a QTE is suppose to pop up become an interactive cutscene. 

The advertisement from the game that your choices matter is only half-true. For major story sections like the pivotal choice that splits the story down two different paths that is true. But for minor decisions that's not always that case. An example is in the prologue you have the choice to either fight and kill a certain character or to spare him. Not wanting to deal with combat and fight multiple opponents I decided to spare him. Near the end of the prologue the character I decided to spare chose to blow himself up at the end. This example is not the case for every decision in the game but it left a sour taste in my mouth for every decision after it. 

For those that say that my experience with this game would be better if I installed certain mods I would partially agree. Installing mods to fix certain graphical errors or bugs I have no problem with but installing mods to fix entire aspects of the game shouldn't be necessary. If you are interested in the story this game has to offer before or after playing The Withcer 3 I would recommend reading a summary online or watching some of the cutscenes. As for me this game did not hold my interest long enough to complete it. If you are still interested in this game despite reading this review I would recommend getting this game during a sale or just buying it outright as the game is not that expensive and is on sale for almost every sales event.

[h3][i]"My favorite type of magic, [b]Lesbomancy.[/b]" - Skalen, a horny dwarf[/i][/h3]
After enacting his judgment on the Salamandra organization and saving the king from a witcher assassin, Geralt sought to spend his remaining years with his face firmly planted in the majestic bosom of the sorceress Triss Merigold, turned adviser for the king of Temeria, Foltest. But stuff happens, red-haired booba gets abducted, and many people die as a result. The reason? Well, the title of the game pretty much gives you a clue - [i][b]kings die.[/b][/i] But why are heads rolling? I guess that's a mystery only a professional monster slayer can solve.

Personally, I really enjoyed this story more than that of the first game. There was political intrigue, romance, the sex, and lots of revelations for our dear Geraldo. But above that, it's the characters and their personalities that give the story that [i]it[/i] factor. They feel unique, and it's super fun to interact with and listen to their wisdom. My favourite is the furry and the troll couple. Their dialogue was simply gold.

But, [i][b]your decisions also impact the path Geralt's story takes.[/b][/i] And believe me, they actually matter. While the overarching plot is the same, some characters, stories, revelations and events are "gone" depending on what path you walk. This gives the game great replayability, as you won't see everything nor experience the full story with a single playthrough.

[h3][b][i]Bombs away![/i][/b][/h3]
A drastic departure from its predecessor; From automatic attacks with a simple mouse click, stiff movement, combos tied to pressing the left mouse button at the right moment, to the 3rd person action RPG combat many mainstream games employed. [i][b]And, it's decent.[/b][/i] It's too reliant on rolling away and the restricted motionless guard for my liking. And yes, you heard correct - [i][b]you aren't able to move while blocking incoming attacks.[/b][/i] Thus, combat was more challenging because of the poor gameplay decisions made. The stances are also gone, and in their place, we got [i][b]light[/b][/i] and [i][b]heavy attacks.[/b][/i] Disappointing, not gonna lie. The system in the first game provided combat with more depth than simply pressing a light or heavy attack button, with the only difference being how hard you hit.

But, it's not all bad. I liked the way they executed sign combat. It's fast, easy to use, and switching between them doesn't interrupt the flow. They feel more actiony and no longer take half a minute to cast. Prep time is now crucial since [i][b]potions can't be drank mid-combat.[/b][/i] So to come out on top, you must use the bestiary and study your opponent before engaging them. Find their weakness and exploit them. But Geralt can now employ many different bomb variations in his monster-slaying career without needing skill points, which is nice. They can come in clutch when you are getting swarmed, especially those that provide a huge blast.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2654203759

As for exploration, it's still pretty limited; Each level is a small semi-open area with plenty of NPCs to talk to, play dice with and complete notice board quests. There are a few points of interest in each area, all part of quests, so there is zero chance of you missing them. One new "[i]addition[/i]" is the sporadic stealth segments. They are pretty wonky, and you'll most likely get spotted on your first try. 

The equipment variety greatly improved. Geralt only [i][b]carries two swords,[/b][/i] one for humans, both for [i]monsters[/i]. You can find most of them through quests, but the best ones need a master craftsman who knows how to work a shaft. Besides new weapons, the armour department offers plenty in the way of customization. You can select individual parts that cover your head, shoulders, knees and toes, knees and toes. There are special [i][b]Dark items[/b][/i] tied to the new difficulty in the enhanced edition - [i][b]Dark difficulty.[/b][/i] I really liked them. They inflict passive penalties to your stats if you arent wearing a complete set. Sometimes even with those penalties using them might be beneficial, as they are quite strong. They are costly and require rare material, so wisely spend your hard-earned orens. And lastly, quests. They were excellent. Even the most mundane looking ones were a joy to complete, thanks to the games exceptional writing. I never felt like skipping a quest because they were boring or uninteresting. Each was like a small piece of lore revealed to me, and I simply couldn't get enough.

[h3][i][b]UberSaturation[/b][/i][/h3]
Looking at the time between the first game and this one, it's still mind-blowing what [i]CDPR[/i] achieved in such a short time. They weren't a powerhouse back then, and yet, they built their very own engine, [i]RED Engine[/i], and produced visuals that could rival some of the biggest AAA games at that time. And boy did they melt GPUs in 2011, especially that UberSampleing option. Like, who was that even for? There are some issues tho; Many faces are the same for fodder NPCs, pop-in is very noticeable, not just for textures, but colours as well, on grass most of all. And since it's, well, everywhere, it can be an eyesore. Saturation also seems to be turned to eleven, with colours way too bright at times, making certain situations appear cartoonish. But, the game still holds up great, even with some rough edges here and there. And I prefer its tone to that of the newer entry, [i]The Witcher 3[/i]. [i][b]It feels more gritty.[/b][/i]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2655235408

The soundtrack and voice acting also improved, especially the latter. I can't even begin to explain how much this impacted my enjoyment of the first game. It felt wooden, emotionless. But here, the voice actors finally made these characters their own. Doug Cockle did an excellent job as Geralt, delivering an "[i]emotionless[/i]" performance. The supporting cast was great as well. Dandelion, Zoltan, Letho and Dethmold were the most noteworthy of the bunch. And with the games improved animations, combining these two produced great cinematic cutscenes. There is one tiny nitpick; Due to their budget, many NPCs had to be voiced by the same person. It wasn't that significant or immersion-breaking for me, but your mileage may vary. As for the soundtrack, it's fine. It's an improvement from the first game, but still, I don't remember many of its tracks. There is some nice combat and ambient music, but nothing that stuck with me, even after three playthroughs.

[h3][i][b]Final Thoughts[/b][/i][/h3]
Look. I am approximately 10 years late to the praise Geraldo party. But you know what they say about those fashionably late to the party: That's right, they didn't leave on time, and that's why they were late. So thanks for reading, sweat dreams and buy the game.

[quote]If you enjoy this review, come and read more wisdom from the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40407656-Gospel-of-Sv.-Prolivije/]Gospel of Sv. Prolivije[/url].

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a good action RPG. Unlike the previous game it has more action focused combat with higher pacing but still retains of the previous game's RPG charm.  Relative to the first Witcher game I genuinely feel like this game is a step back in terms of storytelling, but two steps forward in terms of graphics, environments, focus and combat. You are pretty much railroaded  down certain decisions in this game, and although you can shift some minor aspects your impact feels lessened since the first game. On the plus side the combat isn't awful like the first game, and with the exception of a few fights in the game is overall serviceable (one is outright bugged, another just  bad design). All this being said the game is still a good game and worth your time to play as it continues the story of witcher Geralt and company in proper sequel to the first, full recommend.
Perfect sequel that updates mechanics etc. Some quests are more inspired then others and there is a steep difficulty curb, but ultimately well worth your coin, especially on a sale.

CD Projekt Red clearly didn't know what it was doing yet when this game was made. They had all the setting, characters, and story, but the gameplay is rough--unplayable for me. It's not because I played The Witcher III first, and it's not because the game is 10 years old now that I'm playing it.

I can't play this game because of the movement and the controls. Geralt has no agility, owing to the fact that he can't interrupt his current movement to do another. If you swing, you can't do anything else until that swing animation is finished. His moves are sluggish, the camera is chaotic, and little things are just so janky, like how he teleports to open a door because the animations are hideous and jumpy. Fights in tight spaces are pure madness because the camera is fast and accelerates too quickly.

The Witcher III had all the polish this game should have had. No wonder it shook the world, and very few people talk about The Witcher I or II.

I recommend playing W2 if you're a fan of the witcher series and need some more content, but to be totally honest, the gameplay does not hold a candle to W3. The same elements are there, just in a more unrefined state. It can feel very clunky and unfair at times, but the combat does have a similar flow to W3. Without going into too much detail, there are aspects of the game that are superior to releases today, but there are also some not so savory aspects, and playing the game on the hardest difficulty is not the way to go on your first time. One thing that I can commend the game for in spades is the writing and the narrative. It is so well written and the characters are as vibrant and fleshed out as the best TV miniseries. It really shines in the story department and also has many key decisions that actually felt like they had weight in the story. CDPR should have used some of this cleverness in Cyberpunk for god's sake. The writing in W2 compared to Cyberpunk is miles better, and that's saying something for me because I really enjoyed the Cyberpunk story (just not the linearity). All in all, the gameplay was mid but the story and characters keep you going. Could have used more side-content but the stuff that is there was pretty good for the most part.

This was the first Witcher game I've played. I recommend playing the first game before you play this game because on my first playthrough of TW2, I was very confused on what was going on the whole time. I just finished my 2nd playthrough of this game and I can say that I have definitely enjoyed it a lot more than my first playthrough. 

I realised that this game was designed to be played at least 2 times to get the full experience of the game which was the reason why TW2 is the shortest of the trilogy. Your choices actually matter. Literally 20+ hrs of the game is locked out (includes quests and the locations you primarily play on) depending on the choices you make.

About the combat system:
The combat system is kinda broken. As in the hitboxes and character models does not match the animations of attacks of many characters in the game including Geralt. For example, attacks could register right at the start of an animation which could be very annoying. However, I found these issues still manageable and I still found the combat fun at the end of the day. 

If you are looking for an RPG and I definitely recommend playing this game. The writing and the dialogue is very solid. Please note that this game is not an open world and is pretty linear. 

Overall Rating: 8.4/10

Update**

Played and Finished on Hard difficulty, can say that there is a huge improvement of graphics from the first game. Many bugs and Glitches, less crashes than the first game. Game style similar to Witcher 3 without sprinting and horse. Game became a Hit and Run, you can counterattack but that will equally deal you some damage even if you are a Witcher so i much prefered the first game. 

In the first game you were able to avoid fighting by jumping over a foe with a jump, here instead you can only avoid horizontally by going around the enemy. You can't deal with group with enemies you have to escape then plan your strategy using Witcher's signs. You can craft bombs oils and traps a huge improvement from the first game. Game is not Open World but a more linear Open Map, full of choices and consequences. And implementation of quick time events only during special boss fights. I still think that the first game combat was much better but we go towards a more realistic approach.

I am one of those people who played Witcher 3 first, fell in love with it and then explored rest of the witcher universe as a whole. I can honestly say I enjoyed this game way more than Witcher 3. The combat was fast paced and enjoyable for me even though the controls were clunky but I got use to them. The special cutscenes during combat are way better than those animations which just play in the third time in between fights. Geralt is far more brutal in this version combat and story wise. Also why are people complaining about magic being OP? Don't you eggheads know how OP rend, whirl and euphoria is in witcher 3? You can literally one shot a group of people with a single whirl, so why the hell does that matter? I loved the animated sequences of this game during Geralt's flashbacks especially the Rivia Massacre one along with the animated movies made for this game. YOU CAN PAUSE IN BETWEEN CUTSCENES IN THIS GAME which you can't in the third game. One time I had to take a leak during an important cutscene in witcher 3 but I had to sit and hold it in >_>. How did CD Projekt go backwards in this regard? The story is also amazing and well done in Witcher 2 along with the dialogue. The dialogue feels way more natural and human in this game as Geralt has so many options to have a fluid conversation with a person as compared to witcher 3 where he is just stuck with very limited options which are either insulting, joking or exposition but in this game when people talk, it feels like an actual conversation instead of being a robot. I enjoyed my conversation with Ves the most as each dialogue gave an additional dialogue during chapter 2.(Also we shagged ;3)  In Witcher 3, the main story line feels rushed and blood/wine also feels rushed with the exception being Hearts of stone. Witcher 2 has a much better storyline which feels more polished than the third one. Did they fire the writers of witcher 2 or something?
 I also love the sex and erotica in this game which was missing in the third one. Dice poker was way more fun than gwent as It actually feels like gambling than just playing a watered down version of magic the gathering. The game is dated but the graphics look visually stunning along with the character models especially with mods. If I played this game in 2011, I would've definitely been blown away. The game is also optimized extremely well. I only had one crash in my 25 hour playthrough which was loaded with mods and my FPS was 57-60. You can also mod your characters to look like their selves in Witcher 3 which I did and it made geralt and triss look so much better. 
If you want to have the time of your life, please follow this mod guide: https://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/969?tab=description . You won't regret it.

Witcher 2

Back in the mid 2010s, The Witcher 3 was announced. In preparation for the hype, I played The Witcher 1, The Witcher 2, and read some of the book material. I was, for lack of a better term, a nerd. 

My old ass computer could easily handle The Witcher 1 (a janky ass game that had decent plot, questionable porno cards, and YMMV combat), but it could not handle The Witcher 2. It could run it, at low graphics, at 15 FPS. 15 FPS! It was like playing a PowerPoint slideshow.

And I still finished it. The game was that good. It got to me at the right time, so to speak. Game of Thrones was popular (so dark, gritty fantasy was in vogue) and I was a horny, edgy teen. So the combination of The Witcher 2's grim world + Triss motivated me like nothing else. 

I now have a better computer, I can hit modern AAA games at 100+ fps or more, but this game has aged well. Sure, there's still some jank. It has weird difficulty spikes. The graphics and textures show their age. Controls could be better. And Witcher 3 had better dodging. 

But The Witcher 2 had a more focused plot, had more use for its cast. And surprisingly, the dialogue funny as hell. Seriously, it's a riot. I never realised how funny this game was because I was playing it in 15fps (pain). Now when I think about it, this game has more one-liners than a Marvel film. And it's all the better for it. 

Play this damn game.

Overall, not bad. Elements key to the Witcher RPG feel are present, and the story, like with both TW1 and TW3, is very immersive. My main issues are with the combat system, and the inconsistencies with hit detection and areas of effect. Some auto cue moments for story segments are strangely placed, and the potion drinking mechanism makes the combat situations just that little bit more unnecessarily difficult.

As a result, I am currently still trying to add this game to my perfect games collection by beating the insane difficulty. Hats off to those who have done so and good luck to anyone attempting to do so.

Incredible story and characters. A huge step down in combat fluidity as well as general item interaction/menu interaction. Could only play on easy because the combat is so clunky that even on normal it's too hard because Geralt can't handle several enemies at once with such a basic combat system. On easy mode you can just spam attack and win everything so it wasn't very fun in that respect. Loved Witcher 3 and bought this in bundle with Witcher 1, but I don't think I'll try to tough it out and play Witcher 1 also.

***UPDATED REVIEW***
   I Humbly retract my earlier review of the game. This game is my Witcher 3 Prequal story. And I am truly invested in the world of the witcher now and have a renewed perspective on it. The story is more streamlined and unidirectional compared to TW3 And the politics is engaging.

The graphics inherently are good in the enhanced editions but some re-texture mods should elevate it. I still stand by that the combat and movements are clunky- if you are playing using a controller that is. I found on reddit by the community that I should play using the Keyboard and mouse setup and boy I was very surprised and glad. The war torn backdrop of TW3 makes so much sense now that I have finished this. Motivated me to stop B&W and restart the Base game. 

This game is very cool, it has a stealth mechanic, a mission with a troll as a battle buddy and entire quest lines that you divert from based on dialogue choices. That affect Witcher 3

Verdict: Play Witcher 2 Assasins of Kings if you are tired of waiting for TW4

The absolute ambition on display from CDPR's second game, in what might possibly be the most difficult universe to create a believable action based branching story, is history  foreshadowing the ungodly success this studio would go on to amass. The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings may have an overall rushed and burnt feeling, but still boast some of the best writing, atmosphere, lore, and surprisingly graphics that rivals most of this generation today. The multiple branches of story leads to insane levels of re-playability, and levels of consequences set up for the award winning Witcher 3.
         It may not be a must play, but after playing it is a must study.

Definitely a fun game with high replay value. This one, like the previous Witcher, has a somewhat confusing plot. It has the charm that i see when i played a bit of The Witcher 3. Interesting side quests taking unexpected turns makes them unpredictable, Big fantasy world with many different kind of monsters etc.

I wanted to visit the older witcher games before playing much of The Witcher 3, to see where the franchise had come from. The 1st game had a much too dated style of gameplay so i abandoned that quickly, but this game is much closer to what i remember from the little i played of 3.

This game however is crap. Crashes every few hours, horrible gameplay all around. Big environments that you navigate with a light jog makes travel a snore. An awful map that opens up zoomed out too much and not even on your location, so you have to zoom in, and find yourself on the map first, every time. 

Combat overall is a nightmare. Game automatically draws your sword, which prevents other actions from taking place, and even entering a cutscene with your sword drawn still makes you draw it afterwards, so when the enemies that you waltzed up to in the cutscene charge at you, ready to kill, youre standing still, drawing your sword, already taking hits. The has a roll button but forces the "Double tap to roll" movement that some other games have. It's not an option, you have to live with it. Rolling is also extremely slow and will rarely help you dodge an incoming attack. If you try to roll away, you may get hit "in the back" resulting in double damage taken. The game also has no sprinting. "Blocking" called parrying "reduces damage but not all of it, also takes vigor away, which you use to cast spells. Casting signs is also a slow action. You can "Riposte" and counter an enemy attack but you can still be injured during the animation. if you Riposte enough times, you get a passive that gives you a chance to auto counter on block. YES, it can and will, auto counter, sending you into an animation leaving you vulnerable to attack, and you will die from this. I feel trapped in my own idiot witcher character.
You pretty much have low mobility, few defensive options, nearly no crowd control unless you make a bunch of bombs. It's not like you can just freely Respec your talant points either, in case you wanted to try a different approach. 
The screen shake is next level, like being on a pogo stick, making it near impossible to have any idea what youre looking at.

Bosses are even more miserable. loading up from your checkpoint, you slowly draw your sword while the boss that you spawn in front of gets a free hit. Has many unblockable attacks, your slow rolling will likely not dodge them.

AI is terrible. Often times when you have to "follow NPC to destination" you have to give the NPC a nudge every now and then because they just forget what theyre doing. Sometimes you can just walk into an area with people and look around, you'll see NPCs just stuck on each other tripping out.

Game is riddled with typos, from misspelled words to near entire paragraphs being repeated.

TLDR; The world is nice, the dialogue and characters are good and funny, the quests are interesting. But with crap movement, combat, and controls, I just dont wanna....ya know......play any of it.

Uma ótima continuação, possui uma boa narrativa, os mapas são muito detalhados, a trilha sonora é boa e possui gráficos bons para época. Apesar da jogabilidade em si ser muito superior ao do primeiro jogo, ainda assim não é das melhores, em diversos momentos aparece uma coisa ou outra que incomoda, como não conseguir pular ou nadar, mas nada que atrapalhe na experiência do jogo em si. O jogo também possui alguns problemas de save, quando estes se acumulam passando de 10 mais ou menos, o jogo pode começar a crashar sem aviso de erro algum. No mais é isso, vale muito a pena jogar antes do seu sucessor mais famoso.

Great game, one of the best I have ever played, and really humbling experience for those who think that they will be able to easily glide through just because they have played "harder" games. Your choices, be it on quests, money spending (especially this), skill point allocation, whether you will craft a potion or pick a trap or let it there will have an impact on your gameplay, no matter what. I have cleared the DS trilogy, the ES series from Morrowind to Skyrim, Divinity 2, and frankly, this game has exceptionaly good storyline, balancing, combat and ambient lore, even when compared to the abovementioned titles. Definately recommended, especialy if you happen upon the bundle discount.

Solid game, though the gameplay I think could have been more refined but considering this was CDPR's second still very impressive. 

The story is really where this game shines with multiple paths and choices, the main characters are layered and very well written.
 I'm personally not a fan of insane mode even after completing it mainly because perma-death in general kinda take the fun out of actually playing but this was mainly a thing of the time and isn't really done much anymore. 

Anyway overall solid game and I'd recommend playing to the people who've only played Wild Hunt

This game is an absolute masterpiece. If you are a true RPG fan you must play this game.

[h1]Pros[/h1]

[list]
[*]Great Combat Mechanics
[*]Choices you make have an immense effect on the world around you.
[*]Amazing Soundtrack
[*]Beautiful Places
[*]You need to do at least 2 playthroughs to get the whole story.
[*]Triss <3
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]

[list]
[*]This game uses a terrible save system. Each save uses its own file and game can't handle many files resulting in frequent crashes. So you should disable the Steam Cloud and remove your old saves regularly.
[/list]

I originally pre-ordered this game, waited for release and then played for 2 hours and threw it aside because the combat was so punishing. I picked it up again in preparation for WIld Hunt and I definitely regretted leaving it aside for so long. 

Yes, the combat is difficult and very different, especially if you come from Witcher 1 but its feels its the most punishing during the intro-section of the game. Once you're past that and levelled up a bit to get some good skills, its definitely managable. 

Graphics are absolutely stunning, even all these years after release. And like all Witcher games, the story and lore is top-notch. My only remark in that department is that Chapter 3 feels really rushed compared to the rest of the game. And that is most noticable in the playtrough time: where Witcher 1 was easily 30-40 hours, you're through this one in around 25, including all (or most) sidequests. 

Of course that doesn't take away to much, and you'll still have a good time with this one.

There is no reason to rate it badly, but for me W2 is the weakest part of the chain. There are reasons:
- magic is OP (not equal to fencing skills or alchemy)...and Operator´s staff is like godmode...
- the terrain is terrible (you can't jump)
- choices are a problem here: in Chapter 1 you choose path - and almost 60 % of the game is completely different, it means different maps, different quests, different story, different consequences, so I recommend playing twice. Elven path is much better to enjoy, but with less affect to W3. 
- not fully compatible with W1 (in W1 I was neutral and Yeavinn and Siegfried were both alive) and some dude from the Order told me: "Hey! Killer of Siegried and de Aldersberg! I kill you!". What the f*ck?

But it's the Witcher, so thumbs up!

Yeeees ... but only to see the whole series.
Witcher 1 is a good 'old style' RPG, dated and flawed but nevertheless an engaging and interesting story.  Witcher 3 is, of course, a masterpiece.  (I played 1, 3, 2, then 1, 2, 3 and finally 3 again).
Unfortunately Witcher 2 tries a lot of experimental things and while it succeeds with most of them, it ends-up as a very confusing mess.  You really have to play through it twice, to take each of the two main paths, to make much sense of it at all.  It's short enough to tempt you but frustrating enough that it's hardly worth it.  That ***** kayran boss-fight is awful and blocks the action very early on, while later there is much too much going backwards and forwards across a battlefield.
I enjoyed 1 and loved 3, but merely tolerated 2.

9/10. The Witcher 2 is a masterpiece of RPG storytelling. There's a ton of stuff here that everyone should see. It's overlooked a lot because of its successor, but The Witcher 2 is just as worthy of your time. And it still looks great today.

I mean, sure, the game is a bit dated, dialogues aint the best and the game itself is a bit linear. But what I enjoy about it the most is that it is a nice balance between story telling and gaming. It's like a movie that you have an option to enhance. Plus I think the combat system in this game is really good. I've used all of it (swords, daggers, traps). Definitely recommend!

This is definitely my least favourite Witcher game but there are a few classic moments in it I will always remember.

I didn't really like the changed art style compared to the other two games in the series and the lighting too. The fighting is alright but one part in the end missions has you just repeating moves over and over again, spamming left click and swinging your sword as you fight off wave after wave of a whole army. The relationship with Triss is a thing of beauty and what the game does well also is, having multiple scenarios to experience in different playthroughs, that are more split completely off in terms of the direction your story heads. Whether good or straight evil. Meaning you will experience complete new locations and a path and choices that have great impact not only on the end of the game but in the middle and also carry over, as characters will remember and reference events in the past when you play The Witcher 3. This is really incredible when you break it down and some characters you can even wipe from even existing in the next game.

I really liked an interaction that happened between two npc's you speak to that leads to a dungeon that has a really nice and dark setting. It was really gloomy and dark at the entrance and it was raining and I just loved that whole quest. These characters from this side mission are even referenced in the Witcher 3, [spoiler] by the characters giving you an elixr to cure your side effects of being a witcher, should you choose to take it, and not being able to have kids, [/spoiler] in a note on the ground if you happen to find it in a broken down library in that game. Which just explains the depth to the experience. 

Also I may be dumb but there were multiple times I didn't know how to solve a Quest and Failed a few from the first Troll mission and to not knowing from which vendor I had to buy a book that was a quest item. I felt like certain things were not explained correctly or I just didn't get them but I never experienced this in the witcher 3. Also, maybe I just legged it for the finish, but this was the only time I didn't care to even attempt the boxing missions that I've played in all the other games and even in cyberpunk 2077. But, maybe the way the mission/Quest was delivered to you was just really dry and uninteresting. Like, [i]'hey there's these three dudes, if you beat them you become champion, woopee.'[/i] Oh and you can also miss out on good loot if you are unable to or forget to/skip looting a monster, and you miss out on the best sword in the game. But even still that's really at the end of the game so what's the point.

In the end I realised why this was such a beloved title from the xbox 360 days and after hearing about this game being talked about in that light, this just before or after playing the witcher 3 for the first time, I found it funny that I never really heard about it growing up.

Like many people, The Witcher 3 was my entry into this series. TW3 is one of my favorite games of all time and, because of that, I decided to give this game a shot. I am so glad I did. The gameplay is challenging (at least at first), and I definitely felt that using my full arsenal (signs, bombs, potions, oils, etc.) was necessary at higher difficulties, whereas this is untrue in TW3. As far as the atmosphere and world are concerned, due to the world being relatively contained (it is divided into three Acts, each given a unique location and plot), the devs were able to put more effort into making the world feel alive. I remember in Act 1 specifically when the villagers gathered around a fire at night and the leader started telling stories. That was pretty epic. Finally, the game in general is very dialogue centric. I loved spending time talking to characters and listening to what they had to say. This is especially important considered just how political this game is. In that, it definitely has the Witcher 3 beat.

As for the cons, at least when compared to the Witcher 3. Well, there are a lot of obvious ones due to this game being older: combat is less fluid, the graphics are worse, etc. To me, all of those things were secondary.   Personally, my largest complaints lie with the characters and the story. That is not to say that they weren't good (they were), but this game falls far short of TW3 in those categories (imo). I found the political subplots to be pretty engaging, but there was no point in this game where I was just 100% invested in what was happening. I never reached the point where I was like "I gotta know what happens next". The story just didn't do it for me. As for the characters? Atm, I find that I cannot really articulate all the reasons they fell short, but needless to say they did. I liked a lot of the characters, righteously disliked a lot of villains, and genuinely enjoyed almost everyone in this game. BUT, I never loved them. No one ever felt as real, complex, or alive as many of TW3 characters. The characters in this game were good, but far short of what CDPR was able to accomplish in the next one. 

Overall, I think this is a great game. If you are at all into the Witcher series then 100% give this game a shot. And if you are not currently a fan, 100% still give it a shot. Then go play TW3. 8/10.

Not a lot I can complain about considering what I paid for it and how much I enjoyed it. Recommended.

TLDR: Played after watching a deep dive into the story of Witcher 1 and after 100% Witcher 3, and honestly is an option I'd recommend over the obvious chronological order.

After playing the Witcher 3 there were a few questions left unanswered due to their inclusion in the prior games, playing in this order I was able to have questions then seek answers which I ended up preferring over the alternate option.

To some up the game in comparison to the Witcher 3, it's mechanics are overall less refined although, present unlike the previous title, whereas the overall game loop I feel is much better, yes, it's much shorter than the Witcher 3, but, I feel as it's design is less repetitive, versus the exploration and looting loop found in The Witcher 3, while it's mechanics aren't quite as in depth nor as grandeur the link between the two games is quite clear. 

Some mistakes were made in the sequel, but overall, is an major improvement, story-line, and quest-wise. The scope of the branching story-lines present in the base game and its expansions is not even remotely close, I do feel they took effort away from pursuing Geralt's main pastime of clearing nests and killing monsters, to an extent, with the new system introduced in the sequel, I much prefer this games alternative approach to quality over quantity, this game felt less like the ever so common Action RPGs available today, and felt like a more classic take on Action RPG genre, unlike the third instalment which admittedly set the tone for copycats that followed its creative loop at the time, which has now become the standard for any game with RPG tagged on it regrettably, tainting the once unique and innovative genre.

I never got to finish Witcher 2 and now I see why. I think I had started it four or five times, 8 or 9 years ago, but never got beyond the first chapter. Even if at that time it was a graphical marvel, there`s something intrinsically flawed with the whole experience and light years away from the brilliance of the third instalment. Sure, the story is good, but the game mechanics is dreadful. Here`s why: there`s no open world, just paths you have to take. There`s no swimming, riding or some form of teleportation, so you lose a ton of time just by endlessly walking around. The camera is too close to the character and it can`t be changed. Mouse it`s either too fast or too slow, even after carefully selecting sensitivity. But the thing that I hate the most is the fact that the character reacts so slowly to keyb/mouse inputs that all battles become unbelievably frustrating. The animation when entering meditation is particularly slow and annoying.  The game just feels sluggish and unresponsive. Add to this, various glitches (notably, some quests not working and more so, the game itself makes it impossible to complete sidequests if a special random order is not followed) and a ton of bugs (for me, every one hour or so the game just crashes). It all makes up to a painstakingly boring experience and I think I`m better off just by watching the rest of the story on Youtube.

What I enjoyed about the Witcher 2 is that it required you to decide for yourself what Geralt's personality should be. The game offers a lot of choices, nearly all of which have an impact on the rest of the game, or are at least reflected later on.

Kill or spare? I've watched movies. Kill, obviously. Kill or spare again? Kill. And kill again. Kill everyone you can, no one can be trusted, they're all part of a grand conspiracy against you. Just because you're paranoid doesn't mean they aren't out to get you. Have sex with her, or her, or her, or not? I view love naively with rose tinted glasses so no, I didn't cheat on a fictional character in a video game as another fictional character in a video game. 

But yes, decisions. A non-linear plot. And a compelling storyline with well developed characters in general. That's the strongest aspect of the Witcher 2. Geralt's a cool enough, likeable MC, albeit having been painted on a somewhat generic mannequin in the world of fantasy fiction.

The boring part of the review: graphics were great (for my standards), ost was fine, and the voice acting was quite good. All in all, the world was pleasant to play in and the cutscenes were extremely well done.

Now, the gameplay itself has its flaws. You wield the power of 5 magical signs, ooooooh, except you'll be using the same one for 95% of the game. I didn't use Axii a single time. Maybe I don't have the experience or full knowledge of their uses to have a significant opinion, but no one is going to spend ten hours experimenting with the signs and recording frame data as if this were smash melee, so face value and first impressions are more important when it comes to practicality. 

The sword fighting is pretty simple. For the most part after using quen, potions and oils in preparation, you roll then attack, repeat and use quen every time it gets used up. You do have a strong attack and a light attack, but the light attack felt inferior in every way, so I pretty much used the strong one exclusively. Not much to think about. The few oils in the game had very basic effects and offered really nothing to experiment with. It's a ghost? Use the ghost oil. It's a bug? Use the bug oil. Some of the potions had a bit more depth to them, but there's not much to talk about. Those are the downsides, the upsides being that combat feels fair and hitting an enemy makes a very satisfying sound. I mean that counts for something.

All the above considered, I'd give this game a 8/10. BUT there's one more thing. The game crashed frequently. Like 8 times in total. That's a crash every 5 hours, which is one more crash than should be happening in 5 hours. The game autosaves often enough and I quicksaved enough such that they weren't much more than a mild annoyance, but I'm still penalizing the game for it.

TLDR 7/10 great story, non-linear with lots of choices, ok combat and it tends to crash. This game to video games is what The Red Jumpsuit Apparatus is to music; good, but when someone asks for music recommendations, it's not the first thing to come to mind.

Targeted review to those stuck between playing Witcher 2 first, or jump straight into Witcher 3. Or if playing them backwards is acceptable.

Given my hours in both games (W2=125+hr & W3=1,250+hrs), I can tell you, with certainty, that playing W2 first will give you a better gaming experience. Many characters and items in W2 make their way into W3. This way you'll have a better understanding of their backstory. You'll actually take part in these stories, rather than just reading about them in some journal(W3).

I'll give 3 points:
1)W2 is definitely harder than W3 (both on hardest setting).. W2 on 'insane' mode gives you ONE life, and no in-game saves. The combat mechanics in W2 is a little clunky, and less forgiving. But I personally liked W2 more, because you have to be more calculating.
*one note: you're not bound to weapon/armor levels like in W3, but to obtain the 'optional' cursed weaponry (only avail on dark difficulty).. be prepared for a serious grind.

2)Alchemy in W2 is more realistic, you can't drink potions during combat(W3). You need to pick and choose prior to combat, and need to factor in 'side-effects'.. something not present in W3.

3)Finally, W2 'decisions/choices' transfer over to W3. If certain characters die in W2, they won't make an appearance in W3. Playing W3 first, you'll just get the 'default' setting.

So yes, W2 is a must(regardless of order) if you enjoy these type of lifting curses/monster hunting adventure RPG's.. and playing W3 first will tone down the experience(just don't nitpick everything in W2 afterwards, obviously W3 is more refined and polished). Hope this helps!

Writing my review after achieving 100% in this game. 

Pros:
1 - In my opinion the combat isn't as bad as everyone says it is. Still miles ahead of Witcher 1's combat
2 - Story and Characters (what else could you expect from a Witcher game?)
3 - Graphics are okay for 2011 and most of the scenery and architecture is beautiful to look at
4 - Choices matter
5 - Most non-linear Witcher game of the entire trilogy
6 - Playing this game makes you understand The Witcher 3 more

Cons:
1 - The tracking for quest objectives can be non-existent forcing you to look up a tutorial on YouTube which is annoying (this problem is awful in Iorveth's path which is one of the many reasons why I prefer Roche's path)
2 - The Kayran boss fight is awful when you're first learning how to beat it
3 - Lack of auto saves. There was times where the game didn't allow me to save in a long combat scenario and I end up dying or crashing before I could manually save

Personally I'd wait for a sale to buy this game. it's around 3$ which is very cheap!

One of the best RPGs I've ever played. It's a shame it had to end. My thoughts:

I loved the graphics (all the details and the way the game looked).
I loved the steep learning curve, making combat rewarding.
I loved the length of the game (wish it was longer).
I loved the voice acting.
I loved that it wasn't 100% linear (I'd say 75% open, 25% linear).
I liked the fact that some quests sent you into the right direction from the start and others you had to discover by yourself (no hand holding).
I disliked the ending (no, I won't spoil it).
I hated that it ended.
And I wish an expansion comes soon, or that they're working hard on The Witcher 3 already.

After playing through The Witcher 3 numerous times, I finally decided to put my fear of slightly dated games behind and I installed Assassins of Kings. I was pleasantly surprised by the graphics, and just like #3, the game is visually beautiful. Your movement is a bit more limited, but I found myself loving the fact that I couldn't yeet myself off of cliffs while wildly swinging at harpies, no matter how hard I tried (plus, it was lowkey sweetly nostalgic). The story is captivating - I've just finished my first play-through, and I already know I'm going back in there soon to make some different choices. If you are considering this game, take the plunge. A huge thanks to the devs for a wonderful experience. Va fáill, Gwynbleidd.

This game can clearly be seen as a precursor to what would become the Witcher 3.  Not just numerically, but in the way the game is formed and played.

The combat is leagues better then its predecessor.  It plays like an actual game which was a nice change of pace.  The game plays most akin to Dark Souls but a lot jankier.  You have a light and heavy swing along with a dodge roll and a block.  The block doesn't do much as you can still take damage while you block so you'll be predominately rolling across the battlefield.  The game has you only focus on one enemy at a time and I mean this quite literally.  A small cross appears on the enemy of which you will be attacking, this sounds fine until you have to fight more then one person.  Sometimes Geralt will become so infatuated with a target he won't attack another enemy even if you change the cross to someone else.  At times it feels inconsistent, really it feels like a worse version of the Witcher 3's combat.  All in all it isn't bad but I wouldn't call it great either.

The game itself is absolutely gorgeous.  Sure some of the textures and lighting can be off in places but for 2011 it looks really good.  Comparing it to modern titles isn't really fare but if it had come out 5 years ago rather then 10 you'd probably not notice.  This, however, seems to cause problems with the game.  As good looking as the engine is it has quite bit of jank.  Most noticeably with the characters.

The Witcher 1 had this same problem, where when the characters just feel off.  Let me be clear the voice acting in this game is top notch, save a few side characters all the actors do a very good job, that's not what throws me off.  In fact as the game goes on you sort of get used to it, just like in the Witcher 1.  Its just how they interact in cut scenes, it's very hard to explain you'd have to see for yourself.

The last thing I wanted to mention here was the story which is the games saving grace.  I find the gameplay mediocre and the game itself is pretty linear.  The story is what makes you want to play on.  I could go on about what happens but I think it's worth it to just plunge in, I promise if you enjoy a good story driven game you will love this.

Overall a solid game that, despite some awkward decisions, has still aged remarkably well.

It's certainly worth two playthroughs since chapter 2 takes place in different towns depending on the choice you make at the end of the previous chapter.

[h1] A beautiful disaster. [/h1] 

Since I couldn't fit my entire review here I uploaded it to google drive, link here; https://drive.google.com/file/d/1cP346pm-hPqvk0xTIoxWZzHWTLSrF4nV/view?usp=sharing

Out of my 70 hour game time I'd say that at least 25 % of that went to loading screens, crashes, backtracking due to weird glitches, corrupt saves and design in quests and general unnecessary downtime. If I spent a quarter of a game just waiting in frustration and another 25 % working around the problems with Dark mode, then indeed I am only half enjoying the game for what it was meant to be.

You may pick it up on sale and enjoy it for what it is, but I genuinely don't recommend Dark mode as it shows more of the game flaws than the other difficulties. The fact that it was only added in a later patch should tell you enough, the game was not designed for it.

I did not play the first witcher game even then I thoroughly enjoyed this game. If you are not going to play the first witcher game in fact I suggest you not to instead just watch the story of the first game from youtube. It's not very necessary but it won't hurt.

Graphics- This game looks very beautiful at times. It gives you the feel of being there. It has some flaws like some walls or stones are way too much bright for their own liking. I think devs were going for that mystical vibe. Playing around with the gamma and brightness setting may somewhat fix it. I have also used some mods to improve the game, Better Texture Environment, Full Combat Rebalance 2 v1.2, FCR2 Fixpack and QoL compilation.

Gameplay- The gameplay itself is very good. Every item in your inventory has a use. It's up to the player to find a use for that item. Going to fights without potions has some serious punishment especially in the harder difficulties. The AI is good all around the game but sometimes some last enemy will totally lose hope and stand there giving up. This does break some of the imersion.

Story- the story 7/10. Done.
I mean it is all over the place. They are making references which can only be found in notes and books hoping you can find those. Overall the story is good but not the best. It had to be good when you can have sex with a Succubus. The story did keep me interested to finish the game. Some of the side quests have a really good plot.

Overall I give this game a solid 8/10.

This is a long but rewarding experience, The Witcher 2 has been a joy to play through again and again, though lets start with the issues, the game will crash and for no reason from time to time, after playing this game for about 200 hours there have been at least 25 or more crashes that I have experienced and they are not fun, especially if you have not saved in a while, next the achievements. I have unlocked all 52 achievements for this game, and if you are going for them too you will have to train your mind and body for the rage that will ensue, and as the achievement says if you are among the 1.6% of people who have done this you are a madman, good luck fellow completionists.  
But with all of the negatives out of the way. This game is incredible, the story is really well written, a lot of the times while I was replaying the game I would still sometimes listen to the dialog because it was so good.
The characters are so well written and the dialog and voices were so memorable even the side characters were so interesting fun, and sometimes on the path I can still feel the faint scream of "OOODDDRRIIIINNNN" as I now walk in the Witcher 3 world.
finally the gameplay is good but not great, the amount of options they give you in this game on how to approach combat is impressive but needed some polish, this has very standard combat of light/heavy attacks and a sprinkle of magic, great stuff but I feel as if something is missing a small bit of pizazz to somethings and a be less from others, but what makes it good and not great is how the enemies are in combat, there are no invincibility frames in this game, which is fine as you do get something to compensate for it and it is more to the games style, but the problem comes when you have to deal with the fact the attacks are determined before they strike, so you can see the enemy that is about to attack and before the animation is even done 
 damage has been calculated and you have already lost half of your HP, and this gets extra frustrating when you have already dogged your way out of an attack and you still die, this was so especially frustrating in my dark mode playthrough. At the end of the day the combat is alright and still learnable, even exploitable if you know what you are doing.
Over all my final thoughts on this game are that, the story, characters, and combat are amazing, definitely leagues ahead of the first game though I have already said my piece on that, if you want a new world to dive into I would highly recommend The Witcher 2: Assassin of Kings.

Targeted review to those stuck between playing Witcher 2 first, or jump straight into Witcher 3. Or if playing them backwards is acceptable.

Given my hours in both games (W2=125+hr & W3=1,250+hrs), I can tell you, with certainty, that playing W2 first will give you a better gaming experience.  Many characters and items in W2 make their way into W3.  This way you'll have a better understanding of their backstory.  You'll actually take part in these stories, rather than just reading about them in some journal(W3).  

I'll give 3 points:
1)W2 is definitely harder than W3 (both on hardest setting).. W2 on 'insane' mode gives you ONE life, and no in-game saves.  The combat mechanics in W2 is a little clunky, and less forgiving.  But I personally liked W2 more, because you have to be more calculating.
*one note: you're not bound to weapon/armor levels like in W3, but to obtain the 'optional' cursed weaponry (only avail on dark difficulty).. be prepared for a serious grind.  

2)Alchemy in W2 is more realistic, you can't drink potions during combat(W3). You need to pick and choose prior to combat, and need to factor in 'side-effects'.. something not present in W3. 
 
3)Finally, W2 'decisions/choices' transfer over to W3. If certain characters die in W2, they won't make an appearance in W3.  Playing W3 first, you'll just get the 'default' setting.  

So yes, W2 is a must(regardless of order) if you enjoy these type of lifting curses/monster hunting adventure RPG's.. and playing W3 first will tone down the experience(just don't nitpick everything in W2 afterwards, obviously W3 is more refined and polished).  Hope this helps!

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#3 out of 500+)... it's time for The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings.

The Witcher 2 is an excellent RPG that manages to be both better and worse than its predecessor. It tells a much tighter, more personal story with much better narrative reactivity (to the point where an entire third of the game will occur in a different location--with different characters, quests and stories--depending on player choices--at the expense of some of the "witching charm" of the first game. One of the best elements of the first Witcher game were all the sidequests, typically involving interesting monsters, interesting dialog, and interesting characters.... those are all gone. In Witcher 2 you spend very little time being a witcher, and most of the quests are simple fetch quests.

But on the other hand, combat is a lot more fun.

The environments are also MUCH smaller in Witcher 2 than Witcher 1, and more linear--you won't be spending much time exploring... anywhere. But the improved action combat, stellar writing and narrative reactivity more than make up for these deficits, and easily propel Witcher 2 to "classic" status. It's no exaggeration to call this one of the very best CRPGs of all time, right up there with Baldur's Gate II, Planescape Torment, Ultima VII, and so on.

Keep in mind, however, that the game is rather poorly optimized, so expect framerate and texture issues on anything less than a top-of-the-line machine.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.
very hard and time consuming

Holy fart, this game is rubbish. I will assume that all the people out there overyhyping this piece of garbage are fans of the franchise, fans of the books, characters, themes, and/or lore. Quite honestly, awesome things this series has to offer. I loved the Netflix take on the material, I haven't read the books but I hear they are very good. Now, back to the game. 

If I wanted to absorb all those things I mentioned before, in the best way possible, a game built like this is not going to cut it. The GAMEplay part is awful. There are plenty of other action RPGs that surpass it in so many ways. The mechanics, combat, levelling up, improving gear, inventory management, all of these things, in a GAME of this kind, are what should keep you hooked alongside the story (because the story can be hit or miss depending on whether you get into the narrative or not, it is too subjective). Obviously, if we were talking about a more classic RPG style of game, with lots of dialogue, choices and turnbased combat, perhaps it could get away with a mediocre gameplay mechanic while keeping you really hooked in with the story. But this is not the case. 

Definitely would not recomment this to anyone. Graphics look ok but are a mess when taken as a whole, there's this surreal feel to it and it's not Lynchian, it's the bad kind of surreal. Combat is dreadful, you basically need a large area or it will get very hard. Aside from difficulty, its boring. Even if you use all your crap to prepare and cast spells all the time, it doesn't feel like there's a weight to the encounters. Animations, well, they're just annoying, Geralt making random moves with no control over them.

Overall, I see a great game lying beneath all this terrible amateurish execution and it makes me long for the day they adapt the Witcher series into a proper RPG where they truly let the story rise and dominate over everything. And where basically everything is up to choices that matter, permadeaths, omniscient storytelling, getting all the sides with all the lore seeping out of every hole. THAT is a GAME I would love to play. 

PS: There's no need to keep trying to defend this piece of garbage after CDPR last sci fi disaster. I get that Witcher 3 moved a lot of people and it is by far a superior game. But let's not idolize any developers, cause they can always assume they are near perfect and delivery rubbish in their next attempt to woo us.

[b]★★★★☆

The Witcher 2 is a narrative virtuoso missing a combat hallmark it absolutely deserves.[/b]

One of the most elaborate stories in a game driven by consequential player choices and your classic RPG elements. The majority of the game's side quests are written with serious attention to detail which makes the overall progression really busy while being substantial instead of the usual long and bland experience in similar games. It's like you're really Geralt, suffering from amnesia, uncovering everything about the world — it's fictional facts, where and who you actually were in the compelling chronicle. The game's lore is that engrossing, keeping you engaged in its circumstantial storyline. 

The game unfortunately suffers from a poorly-designed fighting mechanics and a sloppy enemy AI. It can be so bad for you, you may drop it way too early and regrettably miss a good [i]Witcher[/i] story because the combat is that bad very early in the game so I suggest to give it time — a serious amount of time. It's one of those titles which could've been so much more if weren't for such horrible combat. It's a really good game if you manage to get past that. The intriguing characters, the meticulous story-telling, and a cohesive mythology that really caters to its theme. Plus the graphics is pretty nice for its age. Really give this a go. It's good.

I enjoy RPG games, albeit the sandbox type more so than the round-based ones. I've also completed Witcher 1, which used a combat system I was not used to but which was intuitive enough.
Enter Witcher 2. I started it on normal and played for about an hour. After 2 minutes after the first cinematic, I was already cursing the legendary Witcher, seemingly unable to back out of a camp fire because he moves like a hamster on speed. I told myself it was probably my mistake: it had been a while since I'd played W1 and I'd been playing games with more dynamic controls.
Ten minutes later and Geralt stumbles onto the battlefield, only to be mowed down. Again, I tell myself it's my mistake. I'm simply not used to the combat system. I tell myself it'll be no problem since I tend to pick up on game mechanics reasonably quickly.
Nope.
After one hour, I've had it with the clunky controls, terrible camera, both in terms of Geralt taking up about 1/3 of the screen, thus making peripheral vision a luxury, as well as the camera angle - what fun rolling into the swing of an enemy because you have no idea where you're going! Add horribly limited hitboxes for actions like climbing - unless you stand in the exact centimetre, our master of combat will simply run into the wall time and again. Reaction times (remember, Geralt's supposed to have superhuman reflexes) are lousy, which means that dynamic combat is all but impossible. Wait for your opponent to strike, roll, strike, wait. Much fun, so action. Oh wait, there is action - because there are 2 or 3 more baddies waiting to smack you. Better keep rolling, then. Chamillionaire might sue, though. Oh, and for reference - I highly enjoyed Dark Souls, and I do appreciate a well-timed roll or two - providing there's a halfway decent combat system in place.
So yeah, I can't say much story-wise (although I was initially excited for it), but simply in terms of controls this is not the game for me. The inventory interface doesn't exactly help either. I'm typically willing to invest a fair amount of time into learning game mechanics, however counter-intuitive they might be, but I haven't yet had the displeasure of a game as unwieldy as this one.
