Read my TW1 review for more insight.
This is comparatively the worst game in the Witcher franchise.(TW3>TW1>TW2) But that does not mean it's a bad game...

Pros which The Witcher 1 didn't have:
• Combat was fixed from TW1
• Achievements
• Gamepad Support
• Story choices affect outcome in TW3

Cons:
• Generic Soundtrack
• Item Collection is terrible
• Completely Useless Map (no manual location tracking)
• Menu Navigation (everything is out of sight)
• No Bestiary Entry System (need to carry all scrolls and formulas at all times)
• Placing bets slider is slow
• Inventory and shop are annoying to search through (everything is out of sight again)

Since the game saves every autosave and manual save (which don't get over-written, it takes too long to load when you die and sometimes even crashes the game when you try to save/load more than 4 times a session. And everytime you close the game, the steam cloud saves sync takes hours to upload...

The save file import from TW1 barely affects any outcome in TW2, which I was disappointed to find out too.
Worth playing if you enjoyed Geraldo and the Witcher 3.

I actually went into this universe with Witcher 3 which is one of the few games which is closest to perfection. Went ALL THE WAY BACK to Witcher 1 and was mind blown with the vision they have had in their minds for decades. Still are blowing my mind with their vision. Bravo CDPR!

25 hours in and I've only completed Chapter 1. Compared to Witcher 1, the difference is night and day, an overhaul of everything. Verticality in environments, better 3d models and environments, better animation and cutscenes, better combat (except with the signs), better dialogue and more varied dialogue. I don't know what major/minor choices I'm making half the time cause it's so interwoven to track properly. Overall a beautiful overall and you can see the details they were able to add with the switch to their own independent engine.

Skill tree wise, I personally prefer Witcher 1 (and I see how they've amazingly refined and redone the W1 style skill tree in W3). The fact that signs are all under one skill tree triggered me a lil bit. The mini games are the same except for the QTE in fist fights. Looks cool but doesn't feel as cool, but much better than W1 by a long shot. Not exactly a fan of the dark items video and audio filter, but that's only cause the game looks amazing and their music always be banging. I genuinely miss Roach in this as well. It's fine to jog around if it's just the main quests, with side quests and contracts it got a little annoying. Would've liked the sprint option at least. 

Overall amazing game (so far) and a definite must play if you love the Witcher universe. And it's a lot more manageable than W1 so you don't have to worry all that much. 

P.S: You can basically play Demon Souls kinda game if you put in dark mode. If you hate yourself even more, try the insane mode.

As in 'go to the right' ended up being about a 20 minute hike for no particular reason; there were a couple of funny bits - do the quest "A bag of fluff" if it comes up.
As it's an old game at most I could give it a 5/10 and tbh I don't think I'd have given it much more than that if I'd played it at the time, but since I wanted some more background to Witcher 3 it's 'adequate'.

Oh and one last thing - there's a small piece at the end of the credits - you can left click your mouse to make them move faster - I swear the credits were longer than the game but as a first run through I wanted to see what that entailed when the message came up onscreen.

Now I need to slap myself around the head with a wet herring to go do the other perspective....*sigh*.

But if you're truly desperate, here is the only real way to play:

There's a mod that lists all the character abilities, 'Weightless Enhanced Edition', that has a folder that (supposedly) stores a character abilities file from an earlier version. If you you know how to check files you probably should, personally I don't give a shit there's enough on my computer. Just copy the abilities folder into CookedPC (directory to steam game data: [drive Steam's installed on]/x86/Steam/steamapps/common) and it's done. Edit it in the magic of Notepad, or something fancy if you're into that. What you want is midway down, under the Various group. Change that max_weight to whatever the fuck you want, up to 999999. Fuck inventory. 
You can also go to story_s8, changing price_mult to 'true'. This decreases shop prices from ridiculous to slightly less so, at least for a short while since games are more complicated than that. You're supposed to unlock it by haggling and using Axi in the kayran: a matter of price... and at no other point. How're you supposed to know that? Fuck you, that's why. Fuck this shit.

Great story, great music, great voice acting, great aesthetics, great immersion, great game.

Lets start with the positives, the story, the environments, the enemies and the npcs are all very detailed. The world itself feels real. The main story-line is fantastic and most of the side quests are fascinating. The choices you make do matter. I read somewhere that there are a total of 16 endings. In summary, you can play this for hours and not get   bored.   
Now the cons. The combat itself is bad (in my opinion). I feel like it's certainly showing its age a bit. It's not horrible to the point of unplayable, but it's just not fun. Add the fact that enemies have weird hitboxes and magic users having the ability where you can't hit them for a few second, it just becomes unfair at times. Other issues involve inventory management, I found it tedious, though if might not effect you as much. And finally, the game has some graphical issues. I'm not talking about the graphics in general. It struggles to reach 60 fps and sometime colours get oversaturated. From what I learned, when this game was made, the Red Engine wasn't as powerful, and CDPR pushed the engine to it's limits to make this. It's commendable, sure, but there are still some issues. 
In summary, the rpg stuffs are fun, exploring the world in enjoyable, and the story is fantastic. On the otherhand, the combat is showing it's age and there are some graphical issues though not to the point of unplayable. I do recommend this game, specially at a sale. If you want to get into the witcher series, this is a good place to start.

The GOG version is better. This version has achievements, but it also crashes all the time. The GOG version has no achievements, but it is more stable. I only put not recommended because the GOG version is better. This is a good game.

The Witcher 2 has an incredibly engrossing story but the gameplay has not aged particularly well. The combat is clunky, it has the same rubbish QTEs that were rampant in most action games post-God of War, and the areas are not designed in a way that makes going back and forth through them particularly fun (and you will be going back and forth a lot). That said it still looks pretty good, and the way the quests weave together is incredibly well done. If you find yourself engaged early on, it will see you through to the end.
It has a lot of jank, but I think it's a solid game.

Ah, The Witcher 2. This is probably my first, and perhaps only, game that has really required me to Get Gud---and I say that as someone Who Actively Does Not Like Hard Games. But here I am, on the other side of the portal, and I'm In Love. I am only sadden now that it is over. I continue to love my Witcher journey and would change very little about it.  I've listened to about a thousand folks way smarter than me talk about how the combat is difficult (but trash), the potions are tedious (and often not needed), and the writing is dense-- but honestly, this is one of the few games in my life that genuinely made me proud of myself for doing so well at it. Did I finally Get Gud? Did I finally unlock my Hardcore Gamer status? Does this mean I can finally Not Be Depressed? 

Nah. But this game certainly made me feel better about life. 14/10, would play again and again for Geralt's continued monotone sass, beautiful hair styles, and drunken neck tattoo.

After playing The Witcher, The Witcher 2 felt very weird. The graphics are much more realistic, which most people prefer - I on the other hand am more torn between Witcher 1 & 2. The first games more game-like graphics appealed to me quite a bit. The fighting mechanics of the first game, albeit quite easy, were fun. Which is the total opposite for The Witcher 2, in my opinion. The inventory system is also much more tedious in The Witcher 2, as you constantly have to manage the weight of your backpack instead of having inventory slots and an easier access to an overlook of everything in your inventory, à la The Witcher.

The story is much more deep and filled with betrayal after betrayal and it somehow feels much more darker. The choices were also harder than in the first game and affected the story on a whole new level. Your choices even decide to which places you go and who you do quests for. The beginning was not completely engaging, but after a while the story really picks up pace. After all the build-up, the last chapter is truly superb.

The combat on the other hand... After starting the game I quickly became frustrated with the combat system. It was quite hard, but manageable, to fight an enemy. When faced with two enemies, at least the other one could quickly get a backstab at you, and take you down in a hit or two. And more often than not, you were fighting multiple enemies. The parrying system and especially the counter attacking part of it was the worst. It all had to be timed so precisely that I could barely do it in the tutorial, and never tried it again after that. I got the feeling that to survive combat, one had to roll and resort to only using hit-and-run tactics. I almost quit the game in chapter 1 already, but then I decided to set my pride aside and lowered the difficulty to easy - so I mostly just played through the game because of the excellent story. On easy mode the Witcher's opponents become, well, quite easy. Luckily it made the game quite fun though.

Excluding the combat, there were few big things to complain about. One very frustrating bug that comes to mind though, resides in chapter 2. The quests have a very specific order in which they need to be completed in order to get the outcome that I desired - and even though I loaded a saved game from quite a while back and did everything in the order stated on the wiki and the quests got the completed status, the quests were still marked as failed in my journal at the start of chapter 3...

Overall though, the game is very much worth a playthrough; if nothing else, then for the excellent story. I highly recommend playing through The Witcher & The Witcher 2 before starting The Witcher 3, because it gives you a whole lot of immersion compared to directly jumping into The Witcher 3 - especially regarding the characters.

I'd give this game an 6.5/10 if you're more into gameplay, and a 9.5/10 if you're in it for the story - like I was.
If nothing else, then quickly play through the main story to better understand all the characters and events taking place in The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt.


[b]EDIT (8.8.2021):[/b] After four years I now decided to replay the Witcher 2. This time my experience differed quite drastically from the last time. Instead of 'Easy' I decided to try out the 'Dark' difficulty, which turned out to not be too bad. Apparently I have gotten quite a bit better in four years. :P

This time I chose a different path for Chapter 2, which made it feel like a whole new game. Even on this second playthrough and having completed The Witcher 3 since I last played, I still think the story is amazing. Afterwards I was missing only one achievement, so I decided to do a third run of the game on the 'Insane' difficulty (no dying). I managed to complete the game on my first attempt without too much abuse of the load button, so now I think I can certainly say that I have indeed gotten better since 2017. :)

All in all, as the combat system felt much better this time around, I will also give The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings an even higher score than I did based on my last experience.

Now that I have completed the game I thought this review requires a bit of an update.

SHORT REVIEW
PLOT:  Quite deep and involved but not easy to follow at times.  You can be following a plotline and run up against “Wait for things to unfold” and have to come back to the plot later.  This can make things rather disjointed.

COMBAT:  The controls are awful (might be better with a controller but with a keyboard / mouse it's pretty terrible).

GRAPHICS & SOUND:  Graphics and sound wise the game is now 10 years old but doesn't seem to have aged too badly.

REPLAY VALUE:  Excellent for second play through (actually essential to experience the whole game).  There is a major plot split at the end of Chapter 1 and dependant on the path taken Chapters 2 & 3 are very different.  Beyond the second play through its more questionable.

ISSUES AND BUGS:  Relatively bug free but innumerable graphics options which can cause trouble.  There is also a warning on the Steam page itself which says “Requires file system support for files up to 8 GB”.

ACHIEVEMENTS AND TRADING CARDS:  Full integration with the Steam platform, Steam achievements and trading cards for those interested.

VALUE FOR MONEY:  Pretty good as there are effectively 2 plots here so the replay value is excellent.  The game is very reasonably priced and there is no cash grab via DLC.  It does tend to get heavily discounted in sales so best to wait for a sale before purchasing.

LONG REVIEW
Now that I have completed the game I thought this review requires a bit of an update as, during the course of the game there are a few things I have come across which people need to be aware of in the way of game play and, what in my opinion at least, are a couple of really bad design decisions.

1:  Quick Time Events:  The game uses way too may quick time events.  These are basically a reaction test of “click now or die”.  These rapidly become tedious and are extremely frustrating.
2:  The game expects you to prepare for a fight by taking potions etc. beforehand.  This is fair enough as a style of play and rewards the player who plans ahead but, if the game then throws you straight into a major boss fight from a cut scene this is impossible.  You take potions in the “Resting” screen and oddly enough you can't rest while someone is beating you to death with a sword!

I completed the original Witcher game a number of years ago and got Witcher 2 but never actually got round to playing it so when it came up at 85% off in the Steam sale decided to treat myself to a copy already updated for Windows 10 rather than battling with an old disk copy.  I also wanted to play this before Witcher 3 which I have on PS4 as the plot from the three games is very strongly interlinked.

As I say the plot is very strongly interlined and follows on from the original Witcher game.  The continuity allows for much deeper immersion and characterisation than if this was a stand alone game but for those who haven't played the original game I would strongly recommend playing that game first to get the back story or as a minimum at least reading a potted summary on the internet.

The game is quite dark and definitely “adult” in nature.  These days nearly everything seems to end up with (18) stuck on the box but in the case of this game it is warranted as it contains both nudity and strong language.  Doesn't bother me but the politically correct might find this offensive so you have been warned!

This brings me onto my biggest gripe which is a problem I have with Steam in general and not this game in particular.  The original game came with both an instruction manual (33 pages if you discount the foreign language sections) and a 97 page game guide.  Why can't Steam bundle a .pdf of the instructions with the game?  Okay, the manual can be downloaded form the site but that requires a work around as the download function doesn't work properly (right click, copy / paste the url into your normal web browser and then save the .pdf file from there).  The game guide is nowhere to be found.

Graphics and sound wise the game is now 10 years old but doesn't seem to have aged too badly.  Provided you have a reasonably modern machine play about with the settings to get the best performance as the defaults are quite low.  This can lead to problems though!  I had an issue with the game hanging at the end of Act 1 and the cut scene not playing.  I resolved this by setting the graphics back to the defaults and disabling the full screen mode.

PLUS
1:  Plot:  A strong non-linear plot where actions in the earlier parts of the game have consequences and change the later parts of the game.  Results in good opportunities for re-play as there is a complete split in the plot at the end of Act 1.
2:  Storytelling:  Great storytelling and strong links to the world background.  (Also links back to the previous game which could be a MINUS if you haven't played it).
3:  Characters:  Again strong characters linked to the world background.  (Also links back to the previous game which could be a MINUS if you haven't played it).

MINUS
1:  Controls:  The controls are awful (might be better with a controller but with a keyboard / mouse it's pretty terrible).  I don't recall having any problems with the original Witcher game once you got used to swapping styles it was quite simple and never really caused me any problems although I know some people complained about it a lot.
2:  Difficulty:  The power curve is way off.  There is one VERY difficult fight in towards the end of the prologue.  This one has caused quite a few people to rage quit early on (just look on the internet).  Best solution is to drop the difficult to “Easy” for this fight, at least for your first play through as the controls (see above) really don't help.
3:  System Requirements:  The game is a bit of a resource hog.  Not too much of a problem on a newer PC but the game is from 2011 and back then it could be a real problem to get decent performance (or any performance) out of it.
4:  Crashes:  The game can hang instead of playing the cut scenes.  Seems to be dependant on the graphics settings which are unnecessarily complex.

CONCLUSION
Definitely worth playing and a great RPG but be prepared for frustrating combat due to the controls and the quick time events can really wear you down.  It is however the “weak” game in the trilogy.

The game continues where the first game ended but also the big war begins.
During the first chapter, the story starts slowly, but the second chapter is what gives this game that shine.
There are two totally different chapters and you can get them by choosing whose side you will be on.

- There are a lot of interesting things in the game, and one of them is a little funny and strange thing that I don't want to spoil, but I'll just say that you will be surprised by something strange on your body. Of course, you can avoid that "surprise", but discover for yourself what possibilities the game offers.

- There are a lot of mini games such as dice poker, arm wrestling and fist fighting.

- The combat system got a big improvement from its predecessor and I personally like the way the combat system works. It is though sometimes. The downside is that signs are useless except Quen and you will use it in 99% of cases.

- All side quests and contracts are interesting and very well done.

- The surroundings are diverse, so you will find yourself in a situation where you just walk around the city and do nothing but just look at the surroundings.

- Drinking potions has changed a lot, so you will not be able to drink potions during the fight. You will have to think of every move and drink each potion before the fight. That gives a bigger challenge.

- Horse riding is still not a thing in the game but it is not a big problem because this game is not open world either so it's not really necessary.

- You will often be rewarded with various things through research, so I suggest you to sit down and enjoy the game while playing slowly and in detail.

- The game is much shorter than its predecessor in terms of the main story, but the side quests are very original and well thought out, so the length of the game itself lasts almost the same as The Witcher: Enhanced Edition.

All in all, a great game and must-play for all The Witcher fans.

I love Witcher and played and loved Witcher 1, but this game is just so much unpolished. Dozens of mechanics just don't make much sense and are straight-up stupid. For example:

- When you upgrade a talent with a mutagen, it is stuck there for the rest of the game. Same with upgrades for weapons, armor, ...
- You can not reset your skill tree. Good luck when you are just learning the game and choose something bad.
- On Dark difficulty, you can get exclusive armor. But, bosses on this difficulty are more difficult than bosses at Dark Souls, plus the unpolished combat is just infuriating. I often get spawned and insta-killed. Wtf? So when I want to lower the difficulty for the story, I can't, because it would take away my whole outfit and leave me naked I guess. And naked Gerald cant punch a dragon to death, can he?
- Crafting is kind of solid, but at the same time, weird? You have to get so much silver for a new sword that the only option is to just go in and out of zones so your veins/vendors respawn. 
- Potions, oh god. Brewing potions is much better than in Witcher 1, but drinking them is just a pain in the f*cking ass. It takes like a minute to do and since you can not drink in combat, I often got suddenly thrown into a fight without the ability to drink potions with the last autosave 10 minutes ago. Just plain-ass stupid. 
- Merchants buy everything and have an unlimited amount of gold. Witcher 1 had it much more immersive.
- The UI is sh*t, probably because of consoles

[b]In conclusion, enjoy the story, f*ck everything else. Fortunately, none of these problems exist in Witcher 3.[/b]

As someone who bought The Witcher 3, and didn’t play it thinking it would be best to play this game first, I don’t know where I was going with this. This game is very much a, you’ll get as much enjoyment out of this as you allow it too. It has a very deep and methodical combat system, but spamming left click will kill everything and you will never be punished for it. The story is captivating and really builds the world around you, but all of it can be skipped with no repercussion. So many side missions and optional objectives that allow you to lose yourself in the world, none of which matters. If you are the kind of person who optimizes the fun out of things, you will fucking despise this game, if you are the kind of person who can tolerate a few a hours of dullness if it means playing a world full of wonder and imagine, then you'll have a fun time… I think, I’m apart of the first camp.

The Witcher 2 has a focused plot and is semi-open world, with each chapter consisting of a large explorable area with lot's of running about and backtracking. I won't say anything about the story, for those that have the interest in revisiting this after forgetting or those that want to experience before 3, or after. 

The combat is rough, very rough but it is something that can be easily picked up and you can easily become overpowered.

A GREAT GAME. Everything one expects from a big budget AAA game is present here. Just add phenomenal dialogue writing, excellent art direction and a bold and unhinged tone and you get The Witcher 2. So, the story of the game is good with a lot of possible endings and excellent surprises.Moreover, it is supported by excellent dialogues, a vast journal, and quite real human characters , all of whom draw inspiration from the vast amount of Witcher lore which was introduced in the original Witcher novels. This particular factor proves to be quite beneficial as it helps in giving the player the feel of freshness throughout the campaign.Keep in mind if you play this carefully crafted gem be in store for some of the greatest dialogues ever heard in a video game. Other than that the world of the game is just big,beautiful and sufficiently detailed for its time. The Gameplay mechanics are similarly awesome with no significant blunt edges. The Inventory system and the other Witcher mechanics like brewing potions and meditating are also simple to use. The Skill Tree is vast and layered and is supported by a system where it is easy to add your newly earned levels to existing skills or get new ones entirely. The Combat is quite fluid and fun once you manage to master it but before that its a nightmare,no two ways about it. Other than that the enemy AI and the musical score are not as good as they should be. At least the musical score is surely a step down from the excellent music of The Witcher 1. Great game. I'm currently playing the franchise in order and I have got to say that I love the overall grayness of this story world. Most people you meet are some flavour of mildy to terribly despicable, and the fact Geralt's the kind of guy who doesn't take shit from anyone makes it all the more hilarious. Combat takes a while to acclimatise to when not a super-experienced gamer, but flows fluidly once you get the hang of it. Also it's always nice to play a game where decisions--even some rather insignificant-looking ones--can come back later to bite you in the behind. Overall, very enjoyable, and I get the impression that this series will probably ruin a lot of videogames for me.
If you like games with a story this one is for you.

This game changes the whole perspective of Witcher 3. 
It's a pitty that most of the decisions outcome here were cut from the third installment.

Originally planned on skipping the first two Witcher games and going straight into the third, but after watching some positive reviews of this game, decided to let Wild Hunt wait and start from this one. And boy, what a great decision it was.

From the beginning, I was hooked. The story was interesting, the voice acting was great, and even after 10 years, the game still looks pretty good. And don't get me started on the gameplay, oh my, what a masterpiece. There were some annoyances, like everything from swinging your sword, looting chests and opening doors being assigned to just one key, and the slow animations when jumping down ledges or going through doors, but otherwise the gameplay was smooth and very fun.

The combat was smooth, sometimes a bit button mashy, but still very fun and flashy. There was a nice oomph when hitting someone with a sword, and the sound design complimented that well.

You can get this game very cheap on sales, but it would be worth otherwise as well. All in all a great game, would recommend to any RPG or Witcher fan, or someone wanting to get into the series.

[8 out of 10] 
The Witcher 2 was my introduction to The Witcher franchise, I played it at launch on Xbox 360. I played through it once, not knowing of the different story paths. When The Witcher 3 launched I immediately picked it up and have played through it four times. Upon hearing about a next-gen release of The Witcher 3 I decided to pick up where I had neglected to ever begin, The Witcher: Enhanced Edition. I played through The Witcher 1 and eventually completed it, albeit with the help of mods, and found it rather lackluster. Despite this, I waited a short period of time and then began playing The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings to complete the story path I hadn't experienced before. 

The Witcher 2 is a total upgrade from The Witcher 1. The combat, voice acting, musical score, graphics, and pacing have all been vastly improved since the first game and unlike its predecessor it's actually fun to play. The story is told eloquently in The Witcher 2 and the player is never left feeling like they aren't on the same page as Geralt, a problem The Witcher 1 faced throughout its story. The combat is fluid, dynamic, and responsive. In The Witcher 1 I would constantly find myself avoiding combat encounters simply because the combat wasn't fun but in The Witcher 2 I found myself actively seeking enemies solely because I found the combat to be enjoyable. That word sums up The Witcher 2 rather well, enjoyable.
There are two different paths for this game and unlike The Witcher 1 they are actually very different. Because of this, one would miss out on nearly 40% of the content present in The Witcher 2 if they played through only once. This could be seen as a con but I list it as a pro because it adds replay value, something The Witcher 1 struggled to warrant. 

Overall, The Witcher 2: Assassin of Kings is a strong RPG with a compelling story and gripping combat. The characters, gameplay, and tone of The Witcher 2 are all vastly improved since the previous game while still maintaining the core elements of what it takes to be a Witcher game. Much like the first game The Witcher 2 revolves around three things: monsters, people, and choice. Unlike the first game, The Witcher 2 finds a way to make all of these elements compelling in their own way. I bought this game for $60 at launch and thought that it was worth it even back then. At $20 or less, The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a steal today and a real pleasure for RPG and Witcher fans alike. I highly recommend giving this game a try whether it's your first time playing a Witcher game or if you played it on Xbox like I did and wanted to relive the story.

To put it simply I could never recommend Witcher 1 to someone who just liked Witcher 3, but I would recommend Witcher 2 in a heartbeat.

I've played through The Witcher 2 twice now, and I definitely enjoyed it more on the 2nd time through. The story is very complex and ambitious, which is simultaneously the game's biggest strength and biggest flaw. I played this game before reading the books or playing The Witcher 1, and it kinda assumes that you've done both (which I did end up doing in between my first and second playthroughs). The game doesn't do a very good job of introducing newcomers to the series into the whole world of the Witcher. I would recommend either just skipping straight to the 3rd game in the trilogy (because it's the best and probably the easiest to understand for newcomers) or reading the books first then playing through the games in order. It's not incomprehensible if this is your first Witcher experience, but there's a lot you'll be wondering about. But if you do have a decent grasp on the in-game universe, the story is much more digestible and very, very good, save for a few continuity errors. CD Projekt Red's writing is top notch as always. 

People give this game's combat too much hate. Is it flawless? No, but it's more than serviceable. Joseph Anderson does a phenomenal job in his WItcher 2 Critique video of breaking down exactly why many people hate the combat, but it essentially boils down to two main things: 

1. It's not true action combat. The damage isn't dealt by the attack animation itself; rather, it's a damage cone that appears in front of you with an attack animation (hopefully) synced up with it. This causes a myriad of issues that I won't delve into here, but that you'll probably experience if you play the game

2. The rules are different for the enemies than for you. They get invincibility frames, you don't. They can cancel attacks to block, you can't. If you try to attack an enemy in a group, they can block your attack even if they were in the middle of attacking themselves, leaving you stunned and open for the rest of the horde to fall onto you. 

These are obvious issues, but it really doesn't affect you all too often (save for a few sections that come to mind which are undeniably very frustrating). I have come to enjoy the combat in The Witcher 2 quite a bit. Does it stack up to the combat in the 3rd game? No, but is it fun when you realize the limitations of the system and learn how to get around them? In my opinion, definitely. 

Overall, the graphics have aged very well, especially compared to other 2011 games. There are some minor bugs, but nothing game breaking. The sides quests are very well incorporated into the main quest, which makes them feel much less like chores. A pretty good experience. 7/10.

Geez this was a tough one. Witcher 2 completely changes in gameplay compared to the first game. Now the question is does it make it better? Well, yes and no. There is some strategy in the swordfight, unlike before where you have to choose the appropriate fighting style to kill an enemy fast and effective. This time it has the strong and fast attack thing like Mortal Kombat. The enemies also seem to block your attacks more often than the previous game. That would be fine. But. The enemies block your attacks ALL THE TIME. No matter what you do to them there is like 70% maybe they will block it. Are they on flames? No doesn't matter, parried. These are normal soldiers we are talking about. Attacked by a witcher who is a mutant and is super powerful. So in summary the swordfighting is midly shitty at times. Enemies block your attacks way too many times and it kinda ruins the fun. It's ok for them to block but the thing is they do it way too many times. I don't know if it's because I played on a huge difficulty but this is what happened to me. Now let's also talk about the signs. They were present in the first game as well. Now let me give you an advice. Make sure to max your vigor all the way, you will need it. Witcher 2 is more about sign spam rather than actually swinging a sword around. So yeah, they focused the gameplay more into signs. To clarify the best signs are quen and aard. Ignis was nerfed in this game as it appears to do shit damage and even when it incinerates enemies the enemies don't care they will still block your attacks. So only use ignis if there is a lot of enemies. Aard is probably the best one for offense. Use it at any chance you will get. If you see it's not working then time to play defense and use Quen. So it goes like this: Aard, Strong, Strong, Roll back. And just keep repeating till the thing is dead. It's different for every enemy which is what might make this interesting, but it's not fun when all you do is just spam your signs and attack every now and again and roll back again and again. Talking about the story. It's definitely not as interesting as the previous game and I got bored of listening most of the time. Also the whole item system was confusing as well. Way too many unnecessary items. Speaking of items, the potions. You cannot use potions in a battle. Who came up with this idea? What kind of moron decided to do that? It's really inconvenient for the player because you can't tell when you might fight something strong. And you need potions in this game because of the difficulty.

So in conclusion: 
The game is kinda cool in trying to create something new to the original game but the ideas didn't work out as good. If you want to play witcher 3 which at the time I am reviewing this I haven't played I guess you can decided to skip or play this game as well.

In the end, The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a visually impressive game that contains a very sturdy gaming engine. If you haven't played a traditional RPG in awhile, the learning curve is a little steep and challenging at the start but once you have the experience under your belt and selected a direction for your character, battles will slowly become easier but fortunately there is always something along the way to challenge you. This is what RPG's are all about and I sincerely hope that this game will become the template for games to come on the PC.

The Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings is the sequel to the Witcher. It is not a perfect sequel or a perfect game. It improves on a lot of things from the first game but also regresses on other things. First of all I would like to mention it is shorter than the the first game which is quite surprising but for me quality counts more over quantity. If you use no guides and try to do everything the game has to offer you could probably bump up the overall playtime to around the same as the first game. 

When you first play this game you may be deceived into thinking it is a much better game than The Witcher and whilst that is true in some regard they are about equal. This game should have been an upgrade from the first game in every way but it really does go back in some areas.

Some good things this game does:

The visuals: The graphics are very good in this game. It looks beautiful. This is one area where this game is 100% better than the first game. One moment in particular where I was really stunned at how good the game looks was when I arrived in Loc Muinne in Chapter 3. All of this considering this game is a decade old really shows how impressive and dedicated the team were into making the game look as good as possible especially with their limited budget. In a nutshell this game's visuals will still hold up today for most people.

The story: I won't get too much into it to avoid spoilers but this game has a really intriguing story. There are so many characters with their own problems and backgrounds that weave into the main experience and I love that about this game. It is also super complex and arguably you need context from the books to understand this game entirely. However if you invest that time into doing your research and finding out the lore then this game's story is really rewarding. The story isn't about Geralt. It's about the world and how it is changing and as far as I'm concerned Geralt is just along for the ride. It also has a decision about 1/3 of the way through which changes the rest of the game and you see an entirely new side of the story which is unique. I've never seen any other game do this or at least do it this well and have this many changes. 

Performance: Unlike the first game that had a few performance issues (not many but still a few) this sequel ran very well. With my rig I was running the game usually anywhere between 70 - 100 frames and had very few drops in framerate. In a nutshell the game is very well optimised with the only setting I had to turn off being the ubersampling since it was a little too taxing on my rig but I barely noticed a difference with the game's visuals. I also didn't run into many glitches and never crashed as opposed to the first game so kudos CDPR. 

Exploration: I really enjoyed exploring the world of the Witcher 2. There are 3 chapters that give you large areas to explore with monsters to kill and quests to pick up as well as talking to a lot of NPC's that have their own quests or services to offer. The Witcher 2 doesn't tell you where to go for every quest which encourages exploration and it ends up being worth it since this world is packed full of details and interesting things to find. Sometimes this could be to the games detriment since you would spend a lot of time running around looking for this or that and not feel like you are making enough progress but it feels really rewarding once you do. I tried to avoid guides and online help as much as possible and enjoyed the game a lot more for it even if it meant dragging out playtime to find the answers to riddles or certain areas. This is how I recommend you play any game.

The Quests: The quests in this game similarly to the previous game are all really engaging. They usually all have a story to them unlike other games that have generic fetch quests littered throughout them. The Witcher games don't feel that way to me. You can choose to ignore them but you would be doing yourself no favours if you choose to do that.  

Now I would like to move on to the bad stuff

Combat: This is by far the most deceptive thing about the Witcher 2. It's combat looks a lot better than the combat in the first game and whilst that is true in some regard I can confidently say that this game has terrible combat. The main reason for that is because the combat relies a lot more on player input than just standing there and timing your attacks. There are so many problems however that I can't list them all but some are: Hitboxes are broken to shit, they were gang raped by the developers, enemies have iFrames whilst you dont, you will usually get hit by enemies even if you dodge perfectly, even with the upgraded dodge you will still get hit. Enemies can turn 180 degrees in a single second and enemies can block your attacks at any moment even canceling their attacks or other animations to block you. This can be so sudden that they will do this before their animation catches up. The point is there are so many things that bring the combat down in this game that I dont have enough space to point all of them out. Sometimes I wish we still had the combat for the first game, theres some perspective as to how broken this combat is. All I can say is it is improved to an extent with upgrades but I will get to that next.

Upgrades: Witcher 2 boasts 4 skill trees for the 3 components of gameplay. Combat, Signs and alchemy. The fact that you have to upgrade the dodge in the first place is absurd. If you dont have the upgraded dodge it simply wont work, no matter what you do you will always get hit by the broken hitboxes until you upgrade this dodge. The combat is improved by getting the upgrades but you have such a limited amount of talents that you cant get all the upgrades in even one skill tree let alone all 3 of them. This game should have had an NG+ mode to fix this but alas no. Side quests rewards are pitiful not only in terms of money but XP. The lowest I got was 50 whereas main quests give up to 2000 XP which is enough  for two whole levels which gives you two talent points. There is also a fourth smaller tree for some reason that expands on the other 3 trees but they felt the need to have it seperate. You also cant unlock the other 3 trees until you have spent a few talents in this first small one. Overall the skill tree system is one of the most confusing gameplay decisions the developers made when making this game. 

Bosses: This kind of expands on the problem with the combat but the best way to describe the bosses in this game is to say that they are very frustrating and suck the fun out of the game. Two of the worst being both Letho fights and the Dragon boss. Fortunately there aren't many bosses in this game, around 5. The Kayran tries to be unique but also ends up being frustrating due to bad hitboxes and overall awkwardness with trying to trap it. 

Lack of instructions: I know earlier I mentioned this as a positive but it goes both ways. It can also be a negative for some. This game sometines refuses to help you with finding certain items for quests the best example being the mosnter contracts that you have to find on your own. I don't mind this too much since it encourages exploration but some people many find it annoying and resort to using guides online.

Last but not least since I'm running out of space, inventory: This game has an arbitrary inventory limitation. You start out with 250 capacity and can upgrade it but very rarely. I usually had to put everything away in the stash due to running out of space constantly which became very annoying. There is no realism to this limitation either if you're trying to defend it with that excuse, if Geralt can hold all this stuff then why not just make the inventory unlimited?

I have many more things to say about the Witcher 2 which I unfortunately can't fit into this review but know that this game is still worth going over for context and story and the combat is bad but tolerable. Play it once and done.

I absolutely loved how much of an upgrade this game was compared to the first Witcher, everything from graphics, to the story, to game-play, to the characters, and most importantly, the impacts of the decisions you make throughout the game. I will try to refrain from making an overused joke about Geralt hating politics but in this game it's mostly all about politics, but the sheer amount of outcomes for decisions regarding different characters, specifically political figures, arguably most notably King Henselt, and Saskia, which can indirectly dictate the course of entire kingdoms. I also approve how starting off on the main quest-line if you've imported your save from the 1st Witcher, then you get to use the same weapons you had when you finished the 1st game. I read some of the reviews mostly from back then about this game, and to be able to really enjoy this game, make sure you have at least a decent computer/laptop and keep steam cloud disabled on the main menu, also try not to have an influx of saves, i played through the game really only keeping saves a little before a major decision was coming up and i got through it fine. Pardon me being an extreme fan a little more, but the fact that Geralt remembers a little more about his past the more the story goes on is a perfect set-up to the Witcher 3 in my opinion. Last thing i swear, but since i helped the Order in the 1st game i absolutely loved being able to see Siegfried again, he is such a bro.

In my opinion, you cannot just be satisfied with 1 of the 8 endings I've heard you can get, i personally have 4 and i think that is a good amount of endings to have. I chose to go with Roche on my first play-through and got the ending with me helping Roche with Temeria, but also the one with my saving Triss instead, and similarly, with me either helping Iorveth at the end or Triss. I think this game deserves at least 2 play-through's, one where you go with Roche and the other where you go with Iorveth, in my mind that is the minimum to truly get the most out of this story.

After being pleasantly surprised about the second half of The Witcher 1 and though the clunky combat and bad animations it was still an enjoyable experience and i was looking forward for the second installment of the series.
So let's dive in shall we to one of the greatest sequals i've played.

prologue:
So the game really kicks of with a good start in the prologue as you are involved in the siege for La Valette castle. Geralt and Triss are still in the court of king Foltest from the first game and you act as a bodyguard of sort for him. So you take the castle and either kill or make Aryan La Valette surrender this acting as the first decision of the game. After this you and foltest go to the castle tower where Foltest's basterd children are being held captured but on the way the castle gets attacked by a dragon. This sepirates you and Foltest from the rest of the soldiers.
It's a real shame Foltest was one of the first games best characters but as the title of the game states he doesn't stick around to long. So as Foltest meets his children he is assassinated by someone who also appears to have the eyes of a witcher, the killer escapes and you are framed for the murder. You are later being questioned by Vernon Roach the leader of Temerias special forces, you tell him that it wasn't and he believes you then you sneack out of the castle and you're of too find the kingslayer. 

Chapter 1:
You arrive near the small town of Flotsam which is the location of where Iorveth a memeber of the scoia'tael from the first game is and who might have ties to the kingslayer. Upon entering the city you meet youre best friends Dandelion and Zoltan about to be hanged so you negotiate with the town leader Loredo to set them free. While in town you learn about a monster terrorising the locals this is also where you meet Silé de Tanserville a sorcerres who's also plans out to take out the beast know as a kayran. So you set out to slay the kayran and on the way learn more of Iorveth and the kingslayer. Having dealt with the monster you find Iorveth via Zoltan who later leads you too the kingslayer himself Letho someone who knows you very well but you don't reconise him due to youre amnesia so a fight ensues between but he leaves you behind after sparing youre life. Later you find out that Letho has kidnapped Triss and is heading to Vergen, this is where the real big decison start you can either go with roche or Iorveth which changes how the rest of the game playes out.

Chapter 2:
Upon arriving in Aedirn right before king Henselt (king of Kaedwen) attacks the dwarven city of Vergen to gain control of Aedirn a mist appears and separetes the two groups. You learn that this mist is happening because of a curse cast during a battle which took place at this place three years ago, so you must lift the curse before finding Triss. So you lift the curse 
through finding different artifacts representing things like courage or death and enter the mist and using these artifacts as a sort of reliving the battle. After lclearing the mist you learn more of Letho and where Triss is and that Silé is behind the kingslaying. This all ends with the battle for vergen and you leaving for Loc Muinne to find Triss. Overall this chapter is a bit of a exposition dump atleast at the beginning and the mist battle is a bit of a let down ending very quick after being hyped up so much.

Chapter 3: 
You arrive in Loc Muinne where all the kings and sorcereses will decide the fate of the northern kingdoms. Here many decisions can be made either to find Triss or depending on what decisions you've done before resulting in different quests. 
At the summit you barge in and frame Silé for the king slaying this all ends with the dragon from the prologue attacking and burning down the city. You later fight the dragon but you can spare it or kill it in the end. 
All and all this chapter is really short and there's a real lack of quests and it's actually more of a set up for the next game and it's a bit of a disappoinment really.

Epilogue:
You face Letho and talk with him and find out that Nilfgaard are the ones who are really behind all this and that they chose Letho so that chaos could ensue in the northern kingdoms for an easy attack. You can then either kill or spare Letho.

Overall the story is great and really lends it self to multible playthroughs.

Gameplay: 
The combat is great and can seem a bit sloppy at first but really opens up for many oppertunities as you level up. It's really fun to be in combat and try diffrent moves and such. Magic is a bit useless in my opinion just like in the first game i really only use Aard to stun enemies. A much more improved inventory from the first game now allowing you to carry mutible weapons and armor at the same time. The game really needs a mount or a way of fast travel it feels at times that youre just running back and forth.
It suffers a bit like the first game of at the beginning of a chapter just dumping you with a 1000 quests at once this specially is in chapter 2.
Almost all boss battles are bad they basically stun you with the smallest hit and then take away most of youre health with a chain attack.

Characters:
There's a lot of great characters and this is a massive imrovment of the first game, almost all are well voiced this really shows in Geralt who's now more likeable in dialogue and not boring and uninterested like in the first game. Dialogue for the most part is very well written though sometimes it drags on for way to long. Letho serves as a good antagonist making good use of Geralts amnesia. 
Most of the main characters are good though i would have liked to see more of Zoltan and Dandelion:

Summery: 
The witcher 2 is a great RPG with multible playthroughs being recommended, great combat, good characters and soundtrack. Though it is a bit short for my liking i suppose quality over quantity, at the core it's an epic story with high stakes and more.

Huh have played through this multiple times but always forgot to write a review.
Anyways, lets get all the negatives out of the way-

- Very clunky, shitty combat. I mean it- I have played my fair share of games with bad combat ans oh boy this one's up there. My suggestion- just keep the difficulty at medium, when u seem to be in a gangbang situation just turn difficulty to easy.There's no shame in it, there's no achievement for beating at higher difficulty so really you'll not be missing much. And if you're coming first hand from Witcher 3 then you're probably gonna have a rough time, but srsly, just stick with it. 
A lot of mechanics will seem underwhelming like potions, oils etc which are significantly easier to handle in W3 but remember this is a decade old game.
- Graphics is pretty good, many high res textures and good looking environments and models BUUUUT- the contrast is tuned to 100, and it physically hurts my eyes- it might not be same for everyone but keep in mind, if you face similar ordeal, just use a reshade mod.
- A lot of boring side quests, you know- typical rpg fetch quests, kill stuff, etc
- No gwent!

A lot of negatives huh? But don't worry- the positives far outweigh
+ An amazing, grandiose story with a deep emphasis on war, politics and conspiracies.
I'm gonna be honest, and it might sound controversial but I'm not really a fan of W3's main storyline- It felt just a thin string just to attach all these smaller mini arcs. Sure, the side stories are interesting, and Geralt himself is very charming in W3 but the overall story felt pretty bland with characters just constantly appearing/disappearing so it was really difficult to care for most of them.
W2 on the other hand, is very less focused on Geralt himself but the world and characters- You'll really feel attached to them in whatever screen time they have.
Based on your choice you get to explore 1 out of 2 completely exclusive area to that playthrough. And trust me when I say this- the ending, the story, it completely changes from this- you won't even realise you're missing half half the story untill you play a 2nd time with the other path and then you'll get that 'AAAH I SEE' moment.
Really, incredible work.
+ A very much tight experience, since it's not openworld the main story is always in focus and so game can be finished relatively quickly.
+ Runs very smooth and can be played on low end hardware, with 0 to very minimal bugs (I'm playing W3 it has a lot of bugs- from small graphical stuff to potentially game breaking that can absolutely ruin your save file if you just use 1 save)
+ Official Mod Support via W2 Launcher.

So basically if you're coming from W3, or this is your first game- you're most welcome. It's a very good RPG, I've played through it back in 2011 and then 2 more times- and each time the story felt to differnt but my experience was really good.
Just keep in mind, the combat is absolutely horrible- better keep the worse expectations from combat so you won't feel disappointed. 
Anyhow, I give Witcher 2 is very nice 8.5/10 and I absolutely recommend it.

The Witcher 2 is a great entry into the Witcher franchise with a great deal to offer. If this is your first entry into the series, you'll more than likely be fine to jump right into it. All that's really needed to know is that Geralt of Rivia, our protagonist, has amnesia and is a professional monster hunter whose mutant abilities and appearance are often grounds for open discrimination by the general public. Story-wise the plot itself can get complex and is intended for a mature audience. What I mean by this is that the characters are often morally grey and may be working for many different reasons and/or have ulterior motives to whatever they may be asking you to help with or whether they are working in opposition to your own goals. The combat is average in my opinion. You obviously have your light attacks, heavy attacks, block, parry, and dodge. Throw in 5 magic spells for you to cast and that's the basics to fighting. If you do decide to play this game on hard and above or whether you are just facing a tougher enemy, meditating and drinking and crafting potions turns this basic combat system into a strategy game. Since you can only down 3 potions at a time, choose wisely for whatever kind of enemy you are facing and also for whatever fits to aid your preferred offensive skill. The choices involved in this game are almost entirely based on your own perception on the subject or action at hand. Some choices will change the entire course of the game and where you go in certain chapters. All in all, a solid entry into this well deserved and well received franchise. 8/10.

An amazing game both for its time and in current day. The story is amazing and keeps you constantly wanting more, even the side quests are amazing mini stories in themselves. The combat can be a bit rough and unforgiving in the early game especially, but it gets way more fun after first chapter id say. The graphics were probably amazing for its time, now they are still quite good, but not incredible and the age is starting to show. Only issues i've had were some dramatic difficulty spikes, quite limited equipment and lack of fast travel. I do enjoy exploring the areas for the first time yes, but when you have to walk across half an area few times just to get all the objectives done it gets a bit tedious. I'll start off by saying that i really really wanted to like this game and consider the witcher series on of my favourite.
Having said that, i unfortunately have to say that this game is "fine". 
The story is compelling and, while the writing could be better at times, it delivers a really interesting experience;
the graphics are overall way better than the witcher 1 (duh...) and even years after release they hold up quite well.
The thing that bothers me is the way Geralt "feels": i don't mean to say that he is bland or anything, it's just that the controls are GOD AWFUL.
Some will say "but the combat system in the witcher 1 is bad": first of all, no, the witcher 1 had a combat system that was perfectly fine and serviceable even at the hardest difficulty; secondly while a direct comparison can't be made between the two because of obvious reasons, you could compare the combat of this game with other games.
The first thing is that the controls feel "sticky"whenever i push a button there's always a small but noticeable delay and every action feels like you are controlling a 90 years old man rather than a monster killer mutant, i still don't understand why there must be an animation that lasts for seconds and stops you whenever casting a sign.
Potions in this game are a joke, the effects of the potions are shorter to balance the fact that now you don't need an alchemical base and the toxicity lasts way less, however potions seem to do basically nothing and if they do something it's worthless, might as well save yourself the trouble and skip the whole animation of  someone getting on their knees and drink a swig, might have been cool to prepare first if the whole potion/buffs thing was worth the trouble.
The dodge button is wild, it either does nothing or it shoots you in the next town over from where the enemy is standing, also enemies can still hit you sometimes even if you dodge.
To conclude, this could have been a favorite for me, but it isn't, the controls are just too frustrating.
I gave a thumbs up only because steam doesn't allow for a third option of "it depends", get it for the story i guess, but be warned that if you want to play the witcher 3 you can just simulate a save.

If you, too, are garbage at games, don't despair! It's doable* as long as you're prepared to repeat boss fights and die a lot.  The story is compelling and forces you to make meaningful choices between two evils, just as you'd expect from good Witcher content. Definitely worth it if you're a Witcher fan.

* except for the secret boss. You're gonna try it a million times, tear your hair out, lose your grip on reality, then give up and accept the non-combat option.

The game is terrible. The combat system is awful. Even worse than in the first Witcher. The system doesn't encourage you to use all of your witcher's resources but instead just quen, hit, roll and repeat. Extremely boring. To make matters worse, in some boss fights you'll realize that it doesn't even work with that strategy and you take damage, even if you don't see on your screen when you are being hit with anything. Difficult games are great, but not artificial difficulty because of a poor design. All in all, the combat system and the design of some parts and battles ruins this game and prevents any enjoyment. Skip this game, look up the lore somewhere if that's the reasong you'd consider to play it and play The Witcher 3 instead. Cannot recommend. You'll thank me for saving you some money.

In many ways, The Witcher 2 hasn't aged particularly well for a 2021 audience. Combat feels cumbersome, maps are small and feature lots of backtracking, quick time events often lead to unanticipated failures, and some stretches of the game are flat out buggy (looking at you, "Blue Dream").

All that said - the story is fantastic and well worth the price of admission alone. It's an epic tale filled with interesting and often outrageous characters, and I'm glad I stuck around for it.

Bottom line. pick up the game. If you like the combat, have fun; if you don't, turn it to Easy and enjoy the story.

The third game is without doubt the most accessible, so this one can be skipped unless one finds the story captivating enough. Unfortunately the story of the second game is not developed further in the third, so the player might end up a little underwhelmed if they took their decisions seriously. 

This game is linear with three hubs to explore without the ability to jump or swim. Attacking can be a little unpredictable because here a press of a button may result in one to three swings of the sword, but one can get used to this later on in the game. Enemies are pretty forgiving and wait patiently for multiple backstabs after their attack animation had ended. On top of that, Yrden can be used to trap them in place for easier backstabbing action, which unfortunately is not so in the third game, where it only slows them down. In general the combat is unlikely to satisfy a souls-like fan as even the bosses are few and fairly trivial (especially once trapped with the Yrden), but if one is captivated by the story, characters and dialogue, this instalment is still adequately playable.

I overall enjoyed this game a lot. Compared to the first game it's insanely better. The camera is a bit claustrophobicly close to Geralt, but It's a lot better than the first game's camera. It's not as restricting, feels more natural. The menus are better too, though the trading and selling, talking to people is a bit obnoxious at times, how you have to keep clicking on them to discuss something else after they're done talking about one topic you chose. The graphics are obviously very impressive after the first game. Some of the facial animations are wonky, but it is what it is. It doesn't stop you from enjoying the game. The pacing is a lot better in this game, feels like it doesn't overstay its welcome, and even though it doesn't have fast travel I didn't miss it as much as I had in the first game. I feel like the locations were designed much better. The writing is phenomenal as always, I always find myself wanting to hear the charaters talk more. It's a really immersive game. A lot of the annoying little things I'd complain about have been fixed in the third game. I just felt like sharing my thoughts after finishing this one. Overall, great game. Would recommend.

I started playing The Witcher 2 for the story, but that was the only thing that kept me playing through the end. The game has occasional bugs and much of the interface/controls feel clunky. Fortunately, mod support means that some quality-of-life mods take most of the tedium out of the game and let you focus on the fun parts.

For me, the fun parts were not the combat but the exploration and side-stories that flesh out the larger picture. The story stands up on repeated plays as you identify hidden meanings behind the dialog that you missed the first time around. The combat was uninspired and painfully frustrating. The combat does not scale well: certain enemies (or bosses) will crush new players until the player discovers the "trick" to win. When the trick is learned, the fights can become overwhelmingly easy but that learning process is not fun.

If you're a Witcher fan, try the game out, play on easy or normal mode, and enjoy the story. As a standalone game, take a pass to save yourself some frustration and play something else.

женщина с бородой

This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

The odd middle child in the Witcher trilogy. Where the first game was a scrappy underdog and Wild Hunt became a swaggering juggernaut of role-playing, Assassins of Kings is the series trying to find its voice. While its graphics and overall presentation are a massive improvement from the first game, its gameplay is a clunky, restrictive, and rough-edged prototype of Wild Hunt. But Assassins of Kings has the strongest and most intriguing main plotline of the series, filled with political and personal complexities and a second act that's completely different depending on your choices. I love Wild Hunt, but Assassins of Kings is all the more unique for its focused story and branching narrative.

The Witcher 2 is less about Witchering and more about how a Witcher is trapped around the political machinations of the Northern Kingdoms, It's Sorceresses and how it intertwined with the Third Nilfgaardian War.

Throughout the campaign you are forced to take a side either, first it's either team Blue (Roche) or team green (Iorveth), then in support of ruler A or ruler B, or help a sorceress or not, but thankfully the player is given an opportunity to maintain the stance of neutrality as a true Witcher and that taking sides was merely choosing the lesser evil rather than wholeheartedly support one kingdom after the other, however all depends entirely to your chosen dialogue. In terms of gameplay this makes the ending showcases a different outcome depending on the results that unfold because of your choice, which might carry different dialogues on Witcher 3. 

In terms of story I say this is a brilliant, in my opinion. People most likely don't like W2 story because it's rather confusing for newer players and full of political intrigues and conspiracy, key events that shaped the story in W2 (like the Battle of Brenna, Thanedd coup, the dissolving of the Brotherhood of Sorceress and lastly the formation of The Lodge of Sorceresses) isn't shown in-game, and explained either by text or by a bit of dialogues with certain key characters which can easily be missed.

Gameplay wise, is a quantum leap from W1 but a step behind W3. It's a proper action now rather than point and click action Diablo style of W1. The world isn't open like W3, but one medium sized map each chapter (there are 3), but still interesting because it has quality quests, every quest has its own twists rather than uninteresting filler quests (like AC:Odyssesy) but the same cannot be said for contract quests because they are are not interesting not like Witcher 3, it's only for making money. Potions have to be taken outside battle, by meditating (a bit more realistic but more hassle), signs especially Quen is needed because you often had to fight in cramped space, other than quen, Igni is the most useful along with axii (for cutscene), Aard for shielded enemy and Yrden is basically useless (you can slash Wraiths without Yrden).

The story and writing is excellent, dialogues and voice acting are excellent, these are what I like most about the game.
 
I have more hours than what is shown, by playing on another platform. So 40 hours is about the length of a single playthrough (all quests done on one story branch).

So if you're a fan of Witcher 3 (most likely the entry point game for new Witcher fans) and liked the lore, and never played the other , buy this, recommended. Just wait for sales (Witcher Series are often on sale including W1, if it's not on Steam, other platform like gog) if you're in doubt.

Graphic    = Good 
Story        = Best
Gameplay = Never Get Boring

Only played through the tutorial, but what a disappointment. I enjoyed Witcher 1, but the controls and combat system in this sequel are ridiculous. Overly console-oriented UI and controls yet frustrating to figure out what to press for what spell or quickslot, and no apparent way to rebind (or see the key map) in-game. The final tutorial fight was just inane with no chance to figure out the mechanics. Regardless of how interesting the writing & plot may be, the gameplay doesn't make it worth it. I've read elsewhere this should be skipped and go right to Witcher 3, so I'll try that. Life's too short for this.

Toda una experiencia de rol. 

Logra elevar el molde narrativo instaurado por BioWare y que para la fecha de estreno de este juego representaba la créme de la créme en cuanto a WRPG's, dándole  una textura étnica, sabor y una atención al detalle apabullante que sigue destacando hoy en día.

Todas las elecciones ofrecidas  de cara a construir un hilo narrativo multinivel de primera categoría, resultando en un juego de rol e intriga política a la altura del universo concebido por Sapkowski, además de mantenerse mecánicamente interesante de principio a fin.

El sistema de combate, aunque polarizante, me ha resultado divertidísimo y sorprendentemente respetuoso con la agencia del jugador. De buenas a primeras podrá parecer algo simplón, a la vez que se las arregla para resultar obtuso: esto culpa de una interfaz que si bien no es terrible, si deja mucho que desear. Una vez superada la (penosa) fase tutorial, el juego se abre de cara a una multitud posibilidades de interacción sistémica que mantuvieron fresco el combate de principio a fin, aunque ciertamente no se trate de un juego al que se vuelve una y otra vez por su hack & slash.


Se trata de una experiencia increíblemente inmersiva: NPC's con rutinas creíbles, quizás recibiendo inspiración del trabajo de Piranha Bytes con su franquicia Gothic y su peculiar fórmula. Todo su universo construído y sosteniendo una de las ilusiones jugables más creíbles que he tenido el placer de disfrutar. Altísimos valores de producción (gráficamente muy vistoso, incluso para el 2021), buenas interpretaciones de voz y un sentido del gusto considerable.

Assassins of Kings es un juego denso. Narrativamente, las intrigas que nos presenta son difíciles de seguir; aunque sumamente satisfactorias, en especial para los seguidores del universo literario. Pocos juegos presentan conflictos tan matizados, con tantas decisiones y tantas resoluciones posibles mientras mantiene un sentido del espectáculo completamente AAA.

Sin más ni menos, uno de los mejores y más memorables clásicos del rol moderno.

I played all 3 Witcher games and this one would be the third if I must rank them. I felt too much like an "already made" hero in this one. It was too linear and short for my taste. I didn´t feel the immersion as in other two. But it was also full of story on the other hand. I feel like the developers were trying a different approach from the first one and it wasn´t always the best approach. But overall it is balanced, you can make a lot of visible decisions and the story was really interesting.

I liked: all minigames (controls really suited me and the animations were nice),
visual side of the game,
story was interesting and well explained in the end,
characters were convincing and I really cared about them.

I didn´t like:
map - navigating and map were horrible,
inventory - names instead of pictures (I somehow got used to it after time but still didn´t like it),
you don´t have a free movement, it is the same movement system as in 1st Witcher,
music was not bad but also not really memorable,
story choices could be more "explained" I would like to have more evidence to base my decisions on,
there is no Yennefer, still only Triss (I feel that she would deserve to be there. Geralt could go to find her after the final talk with Letho. It could also make the game longer as I find it really short.)

Like its predecessor, this game is full of moral ambiguity and mature plot lines. Great graphics (for the time), soundtrack, character depth and background story make this game a true gem. The combat system is challenging and fun. Mid game, the story splits in two separate directions, so if you want to experience all of it, you need two playthroughs, at the very least. Absolutely worth it, even at full price.

Great story, not just black and white, Geralt's world is chaotic and sometimes it is so hard to take a side. Amazing soundtrack. Choices matter. Fun combat, a bit clunky and in your first time playing you'll be overwhelmed by the amount of options at your disposal to deal with enemies (weapons, magic, bombs, daggers, traps). Level cap is 35. You can choose between three paths: magic, sword, alchemy. There are three chapters after the prologue. It is an adult game, which means if you're a teenager you'll probably find the political and existential discussions to be rather boring. But it also tries to please teenagers by showing boobs frequently. It also has some violent cut scenes, one of which impressed even me (I'm almost thirty seven). It takes 30-40 hours to finish. Hard difficult is easy, if you didn't choose alchemy path you can just ignore potions (they may have some use in dark and insane mode). Geralt runs like a snail, you can travel faster by putting two points on "Feet Work" ability. You can fail quests (and you probably will fail some without wiki). The game is graphically beautiful, Floatsam is the best "in-the-forest-by-the-river" village I ever saw in a video-game. A satisfying reference to two famous philosophers. Too many saves and the game starts to crash when loading or saving. PS: I don't mind having a insane mode, but locking an achievement behind it is simply unfair.

I like the way CD Projekt Red adapted the Witcher story and transformed it to a video game. The story is well paced, well told with no obvious plot holes, and not at all overloaded with meaningless side quests that exclusively serve the purpose of grinding the player's character.

The variety on how to develop the character is enormous and I am tempted to say there's a bit too much of that considering the length of the game.

The inventory management UI feels a bit overloaded and would require simplification. Thus I consider it a UI that requires getting used to. 

The graphics are nice considering Witcher 2 celebrating it's 11th anniversary. The voice acting (in English) is good.  The sounds in cities and woods are sterile. The places feel empty.

I played Witcher 3 before starting with Witcher 2. The more I see the effort they put into Witcher 3, by how much they learned from Witcher 2 and improved Witcher 3. 

30 hours well spent. I had my fun. Thank you.

The Witcher 2,
I have played this game on PC and Xbox and to be honest it's amazing! 
+
there are things unique to this game like, the Design, Mechanics, Combat, Attributes and replay-ability.
the design is very distinct from the rest of the games, though it's now 10 years old it's still very good looking (at least on pc).
the mechanics like, the medalion and it's cooldown, the potions, effect, places of power and the items. *every* single items looks amazing and distinct, armors are beautiful, swords intimidating, and the rest of the items believeable.
The Combat leaves a bit to be desired but it's fun, the talent builds you can make and specialise your geralt is huge, it's also permanent (depending on path).
now attributes are cool, from +10% exp on everything and +30% resistance to fire to quen explodes with fire and aard is freezing. sometimes it's worth it to look up which you can get and making sure you do.
replay-ability, the game has 2 paths with one common one [/spoiler save triss instead of helping roche or iorveth]. which itself is enough to play both, but these have variations themselves. When you count in the builds and unique choices and quests, it becomes truly visible that to get to expierence the game in full, you must play at least twice.
there are also many refrences and easter eggs in the game, try, asassins creed, lord of the rings. 
there is also a quest which is not named in the journal, the wild hunt, you can find notes on it in [/spoiler claws of madness - flotsam. the notes of an mistrel in the crypts - looking for the dunbanner flag - vergen. the sword ann deirrha (i believe that's the name) and the speech with it, - gargole contract and looking for best armor in game (no dark mode) - loc muinne.]
- 
the only negatives are "bad" combat, and technical issues.
the combat could be better but if you play on normal, you won't be punished as badly for inconsistances.
and the technical issues are, the max amount of saves, voice cutting out in memories and reflections, crashes and quests locking for no reason, but these don't happen too often.

all and all, it's a fairly good game. i would give it (keeping in mind it's 10 years old) a 9.5/10
