Classic, and underrated compared to 3.

Finally some good, free flowing combat. Phew! Okay, so Witcher 2 is basically Witcher 1 keeping all the amazing storytelling systems intact with a complete overhaul on the movement, camera, u.i., inventory/skill management systems. Yeah, all the things that sucked in the first part are greatly improved in the sequel. Albeit, some issues still persist, but quite less in regard to the prequel. 

10 seconds into the game (this applies for players who played witcher 1) you'll find yourself drooling with disbelief at the drastically redone u.i. I mean it. IT'S SO MUCH CLEANER AND ORGANISED. I know where the health bar is, my eyes could instantly spot the main objective, I could see where I was on the map, god! Yeah all this, in 10 seconds. Not joking. Leaving aside the pleasant interface, Geralt's face, oh my, he doesn't look like a dumbass clown anymore. (again, for Witcher 1 players) 
Am not gonna bore you with the good and bad for this one. Yes there are some flaws like the permanent weapon/armour modding, lame Poker mini game, unnecessary QTEs. ugh why, just why and my goodness, no sprint yet just a small increase in movement speed, Smart guys made the base movement a sprint animation to hide the absence of a mechanic. Ingeniuos. 

Anywho, I really enjoyed the overall gameplay, I completed most of the side quests, and they're truly engaging please do as many as you can. This was where the grey universe of Witcher started to carve itself. Most of the choices you make wouldn't feel good or bad. And that's the beauty of role-playing in Witcher 2. Your choices will define your ending but it will be a balanced one keeping in mind the decisions you made. The game finally encourages you to use potions and oils before combat and yeah you can mediate anywhere you wish, unlike dedicated meditation spots in Witcher 1. The story has high stakes, bonds are created, you learn to care for some characters and understand the true nature of others. Loyal Triss fans are born here.

Fluid combat with well crafted dodge and parry mechanics which fit perfectly together and overall a proper synergy between every system. This time over, you wouldn't need as much courage you required to play Witcher 1, but again, if you are a player who loves narrative games and enjoy role-playing then it's your love for them that'll make you appreciate this game. For these players I highly recommend it and for players who are new to this genre, I'd say give it a go! Although if you're a newbie I don't suggest Witcher 1 cause that might just create a bad first impression for you.

P.S. - Roche is an interesting character, but I don't care what you think, Iorveth is by far one of the coolest ally and side character I've encountered in any game.

-- Oringinal Review -- 
●Was in the game for about an hour, but played maybe 10 minutes. The rest of the time is between the tutorial notes freezing on the screen and not allowing me to go any further in the game. 
●After beating the arena tutorial it wants me to open the character screen and spend my point for leveling up, but I had already done that ("LEVEL UP" rolled across the screen so obviosly I went there immediately) before the tutorial note popped up and this locked up the game. 
●Controls are a pain in the butt with either Keyboard & Mouse or a Controller. 
                                         **NOT RECOMMENDED** 

-- 2nd Review (decided to give it another go) -- 
●Got passed the Tutorial mess and into the full game, but there's SO much talking. It's all mono-toned and boring. I'm just glad there's an option skip it for my next play-through (if it turns out to be good). 
●Fighting has it's own issues. Using options like throwing daggers and dropping bombs is such a chore with how clunky and slow it makes combat that I never use them. 
●Interaction with anything except doors is a pain. 
●Controls are Still a pain in the butt using either Keyboard & Mouse or a Controller. 
          STILL                     **NOT RECOMMENDED**

The Witcher 2 gave me a bitter-sweet ending, This game is ultimately one of the best RPG I've ever played besides Skyrim and Dark Souls . Here are the pros and cons: 
[h1] Pros[/h1]
-Beautiful graphics.
-Runs smoothly even with toasters ( Like mine)
-Good storyline.
-A lot of choices and ways to play to choose from.
-Nudity and Sex: 100%
-Open world though limited
-Smooth combat system.
-Badass Geralt.
[h1] Cons[/h1]
None, play this before Witcher 3.

Overall I recommend this game to those who are new to The Witcher Saga, It's really an epic game to play. I'm so looking forward to play The Witcher 3 when I grab a PS4.

A beautiful game once again from CD Projekt. This time with improved visuals, more refined character models and UI, should I mention it also has controller support unlike the first one. The controls are great, the only off thing about them in this game is Geralt's square movement and that he cannot move diagonally it is understandable for the game's release time. The Witcher 2 continues on the first instalment story with Geralt still searching to find his memory and finding who he is. I appreciate this game for not only its' storytelling but how the characters are so alive in their parts, although their animations might get repetitive at times, the overall telling of the story and difference in characters and their motivations stands out from the start. As far as the graphics go I was really blown considering when this game came out, a little before Far Cry 3 yet they managed to model beautiful green forests and filled the maps with different kinds of monsters and fighting them is so satisfying. I would gladly recommend this game as a whole collective bundle of fun, that's if one enjoys complex stories such as The Witcher series provides. 
First Gameplay (Oct 12, 2020): https://youtu.be/0xcfpyzr9sE

This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

A really good game, worth buying and playing.

The fighting is good, the game still looks great, the music is fine, but more importantly, the story is interesting and well written (which is sadly pretty rare in video games). This is not the usual "all's well that end well", there is good and bad guys in both sides, and you will have to choose who you will help.  You don't have the boring "good vs evil" usual BS.

Overall, the game is raw and dark, but that is what making so different from the rest of games, who just feels blande in comparision.

This game suffers from being half-formed. 

Besides the constant unfinished jank in form of bugs (many of them game breaking) the core of the game doesn't know if it wants to be a straight-laced action game, or a complex action-less RPG. It's like two people couldn't decide what direction to take, so they took both, and accomplished neither. And this is unfortunately felt outside the tedious combat and idiotic leveling system. Some of my favorite games are slow and clunky messes, but this game isn't worthwhile.

Despite that, it is a Witcher story. It's hard to completely fuck up the world of Witcher, though it feels like someone tried. I imagine the good enough story is a nice experience in the backseat, if you skip the majority of atrociously dull side-quests, the grinding fetch bore that are the main quests, and the repetitive nature of it all.
You might as well just read the books, though. The audiobooks narrated by the amazing Peter Kenny are stellar, and the writing is easily digestible, yet satisfyingly intricate, something the games couldn't quite match.

It's like a toy made of glue and toothpicks that looks like a cool Gundam. Once you start actually playing with it, it will break constantly and get splinters in your hand. It's still a cool looking toy, but... just buy a Gunpla.

Big improvement to the first game. Enjoyable. Recommended to play this, before you start the Witcher 3.

So I know this game is now 10 years old, but jeez, I enjoyed it lots. Despite obviously not looking as good as the 3rd instalment (which I played on a PS4), it definitely has a way deeper story. Whereas TW3 I see as a smart but obvious recycling of the novels (and recycled Faust in the Hearts of Stone), The Witcher 2 bears an original fanfiction storyline, with great character development. I also think it's way more brutal and gory, and not trying to please the masses as much. I had great fun with the combat mechanics and the RPG element of preparing for the battle (it makes way more sense to me that Geralt should drink all his potions BEFORE, and is not able to eat 50 cheese wheels during the combat).
I used to think I am team Yennefer, but it turns out I am team Iorveth after all.

There's a quest where you have to relive a dead guy's memories, but if you stray one or two feet off the intended path, the screen slowly fades to white and you have to go through the same dialogue and watch the same unskippable cutscene of you going into this dead guy's head like 50 times in a row. I nearly uninstalled the game right there.

Besides horrible quest design, the combat is really bad. When you draw your sword, you stand there like a moron catching your breath for three seconds. When Geralt finally decides to respond, he might thrust, slash, or do a gigantic wind-up pirouette at the worst possible moment. I love not knowing what kind of attack my character is going to perform, or how long it's going to take.

It's not a horrible game, but flawed and overrated for sure.

It was a bit more confusing at times and difficult than the first, though it has graphical improvements. There were some interesting and exciting moments in the story, though it felt mostly political with monsters just being dropped in here and there. 
I'd say play it if you are a hardcore Witcher or RPG fan, because it takes some effort to get through. There are a lot of choices and endings, so the game isn't particularly long, beckoning for replays. I am glad I finished it and would say it is still very playable after the years.

The Witcher 2: Assasins of Kings tells the story of Geralt of Rivia in what it seems to be the after Vizima period, where our hero thought that he can finally work on restoring his memory and have some peace for once but life never been kind to him, although he was invited to spend some time with King Foltest himself and to uh... 'relax' in his companionship and to enjoy his royal hospitality yet our Witcher knew it can never be that simple,
From an honorable guest to a bodyguard to an accused murderer, it seems like everyone has forgotten that our Geralt is just a simple Witcher and no men killer
Freedom then raised it's price greatly and Geralt found himself forced to get the real murderer to prove himself guiltfree or just flee this land but he couldn't do that, for many reasons, there are many an answered questions remain to be answered and more importantly his friends, his memory and... his Yennefer

The Witcher 2: Assasins of Kings takes a big leap from its predecessor the Witcher one in almost all aspects, visually, voice acting, gameplay-wise too its mechanics, combat, inventory management, abilities usage and so on, I, actually, find it very impressive that there are only 3-4 years between the two games and the difference between them is massive!
...yet nothing can be flawless and this game is no exception, two main issues this game faces, the skills tree and the economy in-game
in the previous game, Orens were perfectly balanced when it comes to selling/buying items so and so but you could manage to save and buy expensive stuff, etc. but in this game, it's almost impossible though worth mentioning that looting provides a lot of loot and items to sell but again, the buyers pay little next to nothing, oh well
Second, the skills tree, there is no major problem with it really other than the fact that you can never reach top levels in it, heck, you can't even reach medium ones across all of its 4 branches, there are many things to work on and develop but the game is too short to give you enough points to go through it, it is just a flaw in the design, plain and simple, unfortunately.
now other than that^, Everything I said regarding the first game in its review can be applied here too with one extra note: it all works better.

The Witcher 2: Assassins of kings deliver an if not equal but a very genuine and enveloping storytelling on its own terms and I enjoyed it greatly. It introduces new faces and lifts the veil from others, all in all to create a spectacular continuation to an already spectacular story.

Ten years after release, (and after owning it for nearly 8) I have finally completed The Witcher 2. 

I wouldn't say it's a great game, but it's by no means a bad game, hence the recommendation. The combat has the flexibility of the third game and the repetition of the first. Some missions are enticing, others are monotonous. The story definitely benefits from knowledge of the books and the first game. Such knowledge isn't necessary but it definitely enhanced my experience. Choosing your friends and enemies is probably the best part of it all for me. As well as unlocking insane difficulties beyond your first playthrough, there is a large temptation to see what was going on the other side of the fight. However my eagerness to pick up the third game kills my desire to replay this game. 
The beginning of the game is the slowest and most frustrating aspect of it. There are some segments of the first act that are absurdly difficult even on normal (and this is coming from a hardened Dark Souls veteran), which definitely hindered me from playing it through it entirely several times over the years. You find that character animations and NPCs faces are copy-pasted several times throughout the game, making immersion in the story a bit difficult. The side games (brawling, dice rolling, arm wrestling) are boring as hell and don't progress in difficult at any point in the game. 

Tl:dr - It's more playable than the first game, but found myself longing to return to the third.

Superb storytelling and narrative, outstanding level design that doesn't hold your hand or limit you as much as Witcher 3, and magnificent dialogues. God, the dialogues and political hints to real life events are just perfect. The characters are also so real, and not one-dimensional at all, there's no truly evil or purely good character in the game. The choices you have to make in game also are not most of the times black and white, and you can always count on Geralt to comment his neutral cold truth view on things. If you care about a rich story and great narrative in a game more than anything, definitely play this game!

On the other hand, some outdated gameplay mechanics, plagued with issues both technical and in gameplay sometimes show themselves too much. I played the enhanced edition, and it really runs so bad, although it looks so good for a game this old. The in-game menus like the inventory, the journal/missions, etc are sometimes so annoying. The bugs are plenty, and about the outdated gameplay mechanics, one of the most annoying things is the interaction button, which you have to use a lot, and every time you are going to wish the game doesn't ask you to interact with anything again anytime soon!

All in all, the game is amazing, BUT...
If you are going to buy this game because you liked the gameplay of Witcher 3 and want to play something similar, unfortunately it's not enough to buy this game. BUT, if you liked the Witcher's world, the superb complex political story and narration of Witcher games or books, and the characters, then definitely buy this amazing game!

In the sense that there is no big open world, rather there are a couple (story)chapters with their own small world. Every chapter has its own sidequests, although it's a limited amount. The game is just small and a lot smaller than The Witcher 3. Nonetheless, it is a very good story with sidequests and appropriate difficulty. It is a just prequel to The Witcher 3.

I am writing this review as a true fan of the Witcher book and game series. A big fan, actually (I even have tattoo dedicated to it). And I absolutely cannot imagine my life without Witcher games. So, speaking of The Witcher 2 - it was first game of CD Projekt Red which achieved not just vastly major success but really mainstream success. It mostly happened because of switch to the new engine (made by CDPR themselves and later used in "The Witcher III: Wild Hunt" and "Cyberpunk 2077"), called "Red Engine", and such changes in gameplay like the change of combat systems. So, the combat system of Witcher 2 is not so extra-ordinary like of Witcher 1 but can easily described with one sentence - easy to learn, hard to master. Yep, this game actually hard, even on normal difficulty. But it is absolutely worth playing, of course. There isn't much so good single-player games like the games from CDPR. And while The Witcher III Wild Hunt is legendary game and a must play for everyone, the whole experience will be much more solid and full if you will also play The Witcher and The Witcher II first. At least, The Witcher II.

P.S. If you completed the Witcher I and still have your save, the Witcher II will see it and in beginning of the campaign you will get improved armor set instead of the one given by default.

This is a strange game, you are Geralt or Rivia, a famed or infamous witcher with abilities to kill monsters, detect magic anamolies and generally get the job done. Your quest is to find the kingslayer. You will meet familiar characters along the way from the first witcher too. You pretty much start in the fire and continue on from there quest wise. The initial first hour of the game has you knee deep in a battle while you learn your key layouts. It certainly throws you in at the deep end. Once you have started the game properly you get a few more options and can explore a bit. questing in this game is fairly standard stuff, but there are some timed quests which will fail should you leave them too long. Leaving the first chapter may prematurely end most minor quests. I dunno if you can go back after I have not gotten that far. 
As a witcher you have plenty of abilities, and hexs/signs you can cast to help you fight against your opponents. You can also buy or craft armor and weapons should you have the money to do so. You can loot plenty of armor in the game, but modding it requires crafting pieces. If you want top notch stuff, be prepared to pay for the parts. You can also mutate your skills to some degree, but these require top mutagen dna. Most of it can be looted.  You can also make potions, but you can only consume one or two at most otherwise Geralt will get poisoned.

The game does not really hold your hand so you are left to discover much about your own predicament. That being you seem to have lost your memory (helpful). Your companions tend to spend a lot of time around inns, so if you cant find them, try there first.  You also have other skills at your disposal, such as being able to block/parry blows, shield yourself from harm, breakdown walls, cast traps. Lots of stuff to explore and try. You tend to carry two weapons, one is silver for monsters, the game will remind you if you are using the wrong sword, but the text can be tiny on a ultrawide screen.

The game does suffer a few issues. It does have some peculiar mechanics, lot of them irritating at times. For example, the game can force you into a pretty linear path at certain points and if you do not do exactly what your supposed to, you will just die no matter how skilled you are. It has happened a few times. Stealth is mediocre at best and perilous should you stray from the scripted path.  This can be very frustrating but there are some chances to explore areas for reward loot and some un marked quests, some are quite funny and worth checking out.

Geralt apparently can light torches on the walls, but cant cast his own torch to see in the dark, for that you need a potion to see.  In several instances i am stuck in the dark and cant light a flame to see my way unless its a scripted moment or torch.  Your forced to drink a potion to compensate for this (cat).

Also some cut scenes will interrupt some combat and prevent you from looting some monsters. luckily this does not happen very often.

Some of the quest locations are marked correctly, but often to get to them you must go the long way round. There are few sign posts and some times you can walk straight over a quest marker only to realise its really not there at all. It does not always make this so obvious and I found myself getting lost even though the quest location is right ontop of me. (it doesnt indicate multi level quests, you just have to figure it out yourself sometimes).

The climbing mechanic is clunky, you can climb certain areas but its a bit too specific for my taste. It is entirely possible to get stuck in some parts of the game. 

At one point casting a sign and pressing escape caused the game to lock up during the stealth portion of a mission. You had to calm the chef to prevent him from alerting the guards. I accidentally pressed esc while using the sign, the game locked up (had to forcibly close it).

It is an interesting game, it has a mix of stuff you will find in skyrim and dragons dogma. It is a bit linear at times, but its worth investing just for the story. I just want to finish it so I  can move onto the witcher 3.

Fairly good music that feels appropriate for the medieval RPG setting, and a beautiful and immersive medieval fantasy world.  And yes, it's beautiful despite the game's age. I often found there were cases where I would stop moving around and simply look around at the world around me to take in the world's beauty and attention to detail.  The game aims for a more realistic world with less magical items and that sort of thing, and does a fairly good job of that. Despite a few frustrations I had with the game, I haven't come across many better options for realistic medieval fantasy RPGs.

The gameplay in this game is essentially like a typical RPG, but with a bit more player-involvement.  I mean, in some RPGs, you pretty much just build your character on level-up, and then the game mostly handles the combat for you by using dice rolls and that sort of thing to determine if you land a hit in combat with your sword.  Not sure if the mechanics use that type of system in "The Witcher" games, but they are definitely somewhat different in the sense that the player plays a much more active role in the combat (if they're playing the game as developers intended), because the combat involves an attentive player waiting for just the right moment during swordplay to respond to a briefly flickering indicator on the screen by pressing a button or clicking the mouse to perform counterattacks, ripostes, and finishing blows and that sort of thing.  

Additionally, the game seems set up to allow players to use combinations of things in combat, which can make the gameplay more complex and satisfying.  For example, casting an Yrden sign (a magical trap spell), luring an enemy into it to stun them, then performing an execution on them while they are stunned in combat.... as opposed to just running into combat flailing away with your sword repeatedly hoping to land some hits. 

The game also features non-magical traps Geralt can use as well, but I can only think of a few opportunities I had to use them in the course of my playthrough (because using them pretty much requires that you know about a future encounter before it happens due to the time it takes to set up physical traps -- meaning you can't really set them up during combat), and even then I was only able to use them by loading a previous save before a fight I knew was coming (by metagaming), which detracted a bit from the game's realism.  The developers should consider either taking them out or else finding more uses for traps like these in the gameplay.  

The game also has a few minigames and side-activities... some of which were decently fun (arena swordfighting or fistfighting tournaments, and relationships with Geralt's various beautiful girlfriends), and some of which were pretty uninteresting (dice poker). Generally something you can skip if it doesn't interest you, but a small amount of dice poker was required in one or two cases I recall.

There is a pretty substantial portion of the game that revolves around crafting.  By this I'm referring to alchemy (brewing potions from herbs you find while traveling through the world to provide temporary boosts to your character's combat stats), and crafting weapons, armor, swords, gauntlets, boots, etc.  Many of the best items for combat in the game are acquired by getting crafting schematics (either buying them from a merchant or acquiring them as a reward for completing a quest), then gathering the components listed in the schematic, taking them to a dwarven craftsman, and paying a fee to have him assemble them into your new sword, armor, gauntlets, etc.

Potion crafting is similar, except you don't need to take the items to a craftsman to create potions -- you do it yourself in the meditation menu. It's pretty straightforward.  You just buy the schematic for a potion, click it in the menu, and the game pulls up the handful of herbs from your backpack you need to use.  Then just click the button to brew/create potion, and you're done.  Fortunately, herbs in the game are very low-weight, so I like to just pick any herb I happen to stumble across while playing, and doing this I never found a shortage of a potion ingredient I needed. 

That reminds me of one annoying mechanic that can cause some annoyances for players, and that's item weights.  Yes, it adds to the realism (and this is a game which emphasizes realism to a moderate extent), so it's understandable why the developers wanted to put it in the game... but you have an incentive to collect as many crafting components as you can because it's a significant part of the gameplay, which results in your character being slowed down if you are carrying too much weight in items. This is not unusual for an RPG, but the game's crafting system encourages you to carry around so many crafting components that you end up leaving behind a lot of loot you could carry into a town and sell because it's just too much to carry (in addition to your various crafting components), which is frustrating... particularly given that the amount of money your character makes from the sale of items at town merchants is so small to begin with.  

I have heard there are mods people use to reduce or eliminate item weights, but it would have been nice if the developers put something in the game options to turn item weights off.  Or else have magic bags in the game you can put items into that eliminate item weights or something.

The game also had an annoying tendency to penalize players for not buying/getting something that they later find they need later and can't get.  For example, a certain item you want to use with your sword might have crafting schematics available to create it in the first town you arrive at in chapter one... and then after you leave that town, you won't find any schematics for those items in all of chapter 2, and won't find any more until you finally get to chapter 3 (the final chapter).  Or worse yet, an item that is particularly helpful to complete a quest that you can't craft because you didn't pick up some random component required for that item looted from a chest or box in the course of some other quest you completed a while ago, all while the game prevents you from returning to that area to get the item later once you discover you need it. This seemed like it could have been designed better. Please developers... stop doing this kind of thing!  Granted, that only happened in one instance, but it was annoying.  Considering the annoyance the game imposes on you with item weights, I found this aspect of the game tended to encourage me to want to carry around as much junk with me as I could because of the small chance I might end up needing it later and be unable to get it.

Game maps to identify the player's location in the game world appear drawn in an artistic and realistic-seeming way given the setting of the game, but were often very difficult to read, which is another small frustration I had with this game.

The game did a fairly good job with making the world seem realistic (and thus more immersive) without making the realism seem tedious (like games that bother you with having your character eat in order to continue to play).  The Witcher 2 strikes a good balance between keeping the world realistic and immersive without having the game's focus on realism get taken too far in ways that detract from the player's enjoyment of the game.  I found the game's moderate emphasis on realism and immersion delightful overall.

Despite my complaints, there aren't many other realistic medieval RPGs I can think of that are better than this one that have been created recently, so I'll give the game my endorsement for people who like medieval RPGs with moderate magic and an emphasis on realism. The game is pretty decent overall and gets a lot of things right, despite the occasional nuisance and my various complaints.

This is a terrific follow-up after the original "Witcher." The sword-play is infinitely better - having replaced the chain attacks w/ simple mouse clicks per stroke. The graphics are amazing! In fact, I believe the herbs are *more* colorful in Witcher 2 than in the final game in the series. The monsters are awesome (I've beaten the kayran and it is *TOUGH!* The dialog is great, the voice acting top-notch, and the facial movements are very good for a game of this age. All-in-all, I'd give this an 8 out of 10.

Coming from The Witcher 3, this feels similar but a bit limited in some areas. Really enjoyed my time with it, apart from a few instances where game mechanics or story just lost me.

Performance was dreadful on my PC though, it started off allright, really solid framerate even on higher settings. After that, it randomly started to freeze, mainly in the menus and cutscenes. This really messed with my enjoyment of the game because everytime I'd launch the game to play it, it was a struggle to even load up my save file. That coupled with some of the unbalanced and unfun mechanics like the buy and sell prices, upgrades barely doing anything and some really drawn out sections in basically every chapter make it really hard to recommend this game to anyone that has not already had some experience with The Witcher franchise.

That being said, again, I enjoyed my time with it despite it's flaws.

The game suffers with the passage of time. I didn't find a fix in the internet to solve the freeze and crash issues, but set graphic settings to minimal, windowed mode, and 720p of resolution, that issue fade away (sometimes). Probably, I could recommend the game if I could play it without interruptions.
Good.

In my personal opinion, Witcher 2 is a great game and it plays pretty well even nowadays. Despite some technical issues of Steam version (I experienced crashes way too often), I really enjoyed gameplay and story. It's really fascinating how developers make you to choose side in the Chapter 1 and how dramatically it changes your game later. I really enjoyed playing both branches since they both are filled with good amount of quests and tasks, well written and just great. I don't regret time spent going on both branches.
One concerning piece for me is that game doesn't change too much with difficulty level, and it's just the same, but harder on dark mode. I actually started my first game on dark mode. I was a bit disappointed that the promised legendary equipment was meant to craft, not to find.

[h1] TL;DR: Broken combat, story worth investment [/h1]

The combat isn't just a giant learning curve. The first real fight against enemies is brutally hard. It is much like Shadow of Chernobyl's first mission, the one with just a pistol to take out [b]armed to the teeth[/b] bandits. But it is also broken, very broken. You can hit the enemy, visibly see the sword go through them, but because the icon wasn't focused in on that enemy they take no damage.

After Witcher 2s first few combat encounters, once you learn how to fight, (by quicksaving, Quen and rolling) you get more invested in the story.

I felt really attached to the story because I had finished Witcher 1 beforehand, carrying my save into this game. Which was really interesting as all my choices remained intact. 

There's a few fights where it is incredibly hard, even learning the patterns does little to no use as the combat system is unreliable and broken at times. However, the story is what kept me involved enough to finish it in less than a week. Not just the story, but the characters too. There's so many decisions and conflicts perfected properly, much to Witcher 1s attempt.

If I even finally finish a game, it means it's good. And I finished this in 6 days. Yep, pretty good.

Verdict: Recommended with no issue even with a full price tag. The game holds incredibly well even after 10 years. 

+
Steam trading cards (8 to create badge)
Steam achievements (52, require at least 2 playthroughs or 4 to play without any reloads or sections replays, non the highest difficulty)
The soundtrack is one of the best in gaming history 
The graphics are still holding on surprisingly well
The combat system is much better than in Witcher 1
Incredibly replayable - Chapter 2 and 3 are different depending on who you side with in the first chapter (unique locations, characters, encounters, romances, and quests)
A lot of meaningful choices (the game plays completely different depending on how you decide to roll
5 difficulties (and the last one is worse than anything else as it disables your game load if you die)
A lot of animations depicting the consequences of your stories (and I really loved the drawn ones)
Decisions between games (Witcher 1 - Witcher 2 - Witcher 3) - some unique lines of dialogue are present and characters that died stay dead 
Arena mode
You are able to replay the animations from the menu
A lot of playstyles and their combinations
Exp gain feels really good as it is always 1000 exp to level up
Game scaling is on point (you won't end the game dealing tens of thousands of damage and yet you will feel constantly stronger)
Incredibly mature story
The gags and jokes in the game are still on point and they aged really well (e.g. LotR references) 
The majority of the game is lore-friendly and there are a lot of connections with novels
It really improved everything from the first game
There are no sides that are strictly good or bad and you will understand the drive and motives of every character 
I loved the side quests 
A lot of side lore and fluff in books around the world 
All pieces of equipment are visible 
Save games are much smaller than in Witcher 1 and there is Steam Cloud 
Comes with extras - Soundtrack, wallpapers, world map, guides, comix, avatars, artworks ...

-
The launcher has an issue with some Windows 10 configurations (0xc000007b) and there is no easy solution
The game froze on me several times (~10 times) while loading new tones or alt+tabing
No way to skip the launcher 
All options are in the launcher 
The controls sometimes felt unresponsive 
A lot of open endings that are apparently not solved in Witcher 3 or anywhere else 
Scoia'tael players are screwed both in Witcher 2 (Yaevinn is completely missing) and Witcher 3 (Iorweth is completely missing)
Some dialogues options are really confusing and Geralt often said something I was not expecting 
If you are going into combat from dialogue your opponent "wakes up" before you which makes several combat sequences really frustrating (it is not that often)
I hate the fact that there is a max level (35)
The inventory is horrible to navigate in and there is a carry limit. It is partially solved by the player's chest but that is a pain as well.

+/-
The dark difficulty has some unique pieces of gear
Gear is present and yet not transferred to Witcher 3
You need at least 2 playthroughs (from the ending of chapter 1 onward) to get the full story 
18.49GB download


Disclaimer:
Due to 0xc000007b error, I had to run the game directly from the exe file, bypassing the launcher and steam. Because of that, my achievements and game time were not counted (I have clocked around 30-40 hours doing 100% of a single playthrough).

Well, its Witcher 2... BUT!
A ploughin' beautiful game! 
Combat feels real good and the mechanics are a bit more... complicated compared to the original but I am not complaining
Music is a bit of a disappointment in my opinion compared to Witcher 1 but ok I guess? 
Really good sequel to the story in Witcher 1.

But one small catch.. The PLOUGHING SAVE GAME BUG 
In the beginning its fine, it messes with the loading times a bit
but nearing the endgame its ATROCIOUS 
I could have avoided this if I had followed another reviewer here who said "Disable the auto save and the Steam-cloud sync, after 500 (or something) saves it becomes really bad"
Which it obviously did... 
What happens is the game freezes and crashes every time you do something with the saves (when loading, deleting and sometimes even when saving)

I had almost reached the endgame but I have saved so much that it just would not let me access my save files and would go down taking steam with it.
So you not only have to reload the game again which takes a minute but also restart steam 
Really glad I invested in a SSD, this problem with the loading times of an HDD in just unimaginable 

So I watched the last couple missions on YT. But I really wish I could play it myself, looked really fun...
but I just cannot wait for another 10 minutes to load my save file... 
Oh yeah and, sometimes if you are "lucky" the game can also take down the couple recent saves you made. Yeah... 

Don't do what I did, just disable the auto save and steam-cloud sync and save only when its necessary and don't excessively save after like every cutscene... 
Otherwise the game is really stable and I haven'y suffered any crashes due to any other reason other than this ploughin save problem.

Other than this problem the rest of the game is beautiful and awesome... 
Would recommend 7/10.

After playing through TW1 blindly and coming to TW2 I have to say that its certainly a step up from its predecessor (enjoyed the heck out of TW1 though). My only complaint is that while the story was juicy and the graphics were beautiful, there wasn't as many side quests and contracts as in the first game. The combat is a bit clunky but not impossible to work with. Potions and oils as always help a lot in fights especially against multiple enemies. I also liked the addition of sequenced boss fights toward the end of each chapter. It was nice to see more Zoltan, Dandelion and Triss too. 

Importing my save from TW1 was a good idea because it really made things feel more consistent and like I didn't do everything in the previous game for nothing. I might play through TW1 and TW2 some day to take different paths because there's honestly a fair amount of decisions.

As short as TW2 may be, I highly recommend it if you want to experience more of Geralt's ongoing storyline. Can't wait to play TW3 for as I hear its the best in the series.

As this is the second part of the "The Witcher"-saga, I was curious about how the developers continued the story of Geralt of Rivia. Fights were challenging enough to keep yours truly busy by having to retry some of them for as few times. Setting and story are different from the first part of the series, some characters from the first part reappear though, which gives you the "welcome back"-effect. For me this game was easier to play than the first part. It was also much shorter, at least it felt like it. Recommended for someone, who wants to play a story rich game with fantasy elements and lots of fighting.

I played this a couple of years after playing the 3rd and I'd arguably say that its my favourite of the three

- The story is captivating and the pacing is spot on

- Character development throughout is great and lays some important foundations surrounding key characters and about Geralts past in general

- Combat is simplistic but engaging enough to not be boring/fatiguing 

- The game really rewards preparing before battle in a way the other games don't quite seem to manage, and makes pursuing all the different battle prep oils/potions feel really worthwhile and satisfying

My only main criticism would be that if you played this directly after the first Witcher game, the beginning seems a bit rushed to tie up where the previous game left off and left me a tiny bit confused

Overall this is a very solid entry in the Witcher trilogy and definitely worth playing even if it's just for the backstory!
So far, there's a lot of interesting plot

This game is amazing not for everyone but wow is it so good too bad Cyberpunk 2077 didn't live up. Replaying Assassins of Kings now then The Wild Hunt again. Games where your choices matter the world is fleshed out to a thing of beauty and the combat though clunky at first really becomes deep and satisfying!

The game has many annoyances... weight management a constant thorn in your side, if you don't spam quick save you can lose hours unwittingly and the difficulty balancing is broken from act to act.

But the story is enthralling and is a worthy successor to the 1st game. Now to tackle the most awarded game ever... The Witcher III.

[b]This game shows how CDPR got from the Witcher 1 to the massive behemoth that is The Witcher 3. The game is the shortest in the triology, but that is partly because of the big feature in the game: after the first act or so the story splits in two and you need to choose a side. Much beter than the first game, but still has some much needed polish missing. I finished the game on March 6th but only now got around to reviewing it.[/b]

The graphics are good, they holds up pretty well. You can tell graphics were a priority for CDPR as all games in the series look pretty good even after all this time.

Gameplay has become good, showing the first itteration of The Witcher 3 systems. Audio is also good I'd say, I don't remember any songs but I never switched to listening to my own music during the duration of the game (the game is also pretty short so that helps of course). The audience firmly remains adults. The game needs a decent PC to run and performed good on Nvidia Geforce Now.

As with all Witcher games, the game has some really difficult bosses that need specific techniques to beat them. As soon as you have Googled these techniques, the fight becomes easier. The grind isn't really there as I focused on the main quest and was pretty on-level for most fights during the game.

The story is a bit weaker with the main antogonist ending up {spoiler}, but it's still a lovely story that shows a real-feeling world that makes me excited to replay The Witcher 3. As said in the intro, I took 20 hours to complete the main game with a few side quests sprinkled in, so the game time is about average.

Together with the other Witcher games this game is definitly worth the price, though I'd advice playing The Witcher 3 to see if these games are anything for you.

The bugs can get a bit annoying over time, but nothing really game breaking.

Where do I begin? Hmm... Okay. Previously owned the game on Xbox 360, when it came, it contained TWO DISC! I remember spending a lot of time, taking quest and lost a lot Oren for just playing Dice. It's really hard to jog a memory of a game that I owned in 2013, before even the Sequel got announced I think.

The story is, you play as Geralt of Rivia (NOT HENRY CAVILL OF SUPERMAN, yet), a Witcher, means you hunt and kill monsters for a living. You're a Mutant! Just like Wolverine from the X-Men. Since I only played the first one on GOG that I haven't completed and SKIP it to the third and second game, here's the story. Geralt is frame for the murder of a King Foltest, which he didn't. Your quest is to find the bastard and the rest is spoiler that I can't share.

So, combat. Basically, the game is simple. You Click with your Mouse/Press X & Y with a controller to kill some enemies from bandits, elves and f@#K!ng creatures. You'll take a large range and variety of quest based on your gameplay experience. From sparring or killing a b!tch elves for stabbing you in the c0ck and help a troll avenged his decease wife. You also gathered/loot stuff up from Oren (the game currency), upgrades, plants/herbs to make medicine and craft some armor.

Now, the PC version of this game is FAR SUPERIOR than the f@#k!ng console! There is modding from Indonesian language, Witcher 3 controller setting, Poker achievements and lot of other fun exploits. Problem was, the game exploits in PC often can get out of control and you'll get easily glitched out in numerous ways, unless you load your previous save files. Also, the game is ton of fun exploring just one chapter to take some quest on and playing DICE and ARM WRESTLING.

In AMD A12 9720p RADEON R7 / 12 COMPUTE CORES 4C+8G w/12GB RAM however, the game is only playable in 1280x720 with low setting. Also, if you set it to low, you can't see the details on Triss Merigold [REDACTED], so I guess I need a better PC from now on. I'm not gonna continue it, due to my specs, but if you're higher, then go enjoy the game if you must.

The Witcher 2 is one of the reason why I love CD PROJEKT RED. Even they f@#K!ng it all up with Cyberpunk 2077, which I know it's not ready. But if you felt bothered with that, just go back playing The Witcher 2 & 3! F@#K the first one, that game is really outdated.

I recently got Witcher 1 for free on GOG, so I decided to move over to Steam and finish the other two games in the series. Witcher 2 is an huge improvement over the first game, but it's really tough to get into it. Story is good, I like it, but the combat in this game is atrocious and most of the time makes me want to pull out my hair. Keep in mind I am playing on Dark mode (2nd hardest difficulty), but I've seen people stumbling upon these same problems on lower difficulties as well. As I'm writing this review of the game I'm at the Operator optional boss, who is (what I've heard) the hardest boss in the game but probably for the wrong reasons. As soon as you damage him to a certain point he summons two gargoyles to help him, while shielding himself completely off against any type of damage. If you near the sorcerer at this point he'll use an Aard type spell, dropping you on your feet while the gargoyles charge you. There's invisible pillars around the area as well, from what I know these invisible pillars are there because they got moved in the enhanced edition of Witcher 2. These gargoyles also deal insane amounts of damage, way more than any other enemy up to that point, even their brethren. Just like Joseph Anderson said in his Witcher 2 review, every single combat encounter can be added to a video compilation showcasing the janky combat of the game. Every single confrontation has jank, no exceptions. Anyways, here's some cons in the combat I found annoying:

- Enemies attacking you after a cutscene, without you even being able to move or do anything for a few seconds, just taking the hits in.
- Enemies landing hits that shouldn't even have landed (example being the dragon boss fight and Letho at the end of chapter 1).
- Enemies magically blocking and parrying attacks they shouldn't be able to (for example from their sides or almost behind their back).
- Ranged enemies' arrows and bolts tracking you like they're some sort of homing missiles, sometimes even hitting you through solid objects in their path.

Those were the MOST annoying things I've encountered, but there's more. This was CD PROJEKT RED's first engine, so I don't want to be too harsh on them, but it's really rough. Graphically speaking though, it's beautiful and still holds up easily. 

Can't wait to get to playing Witcher 3 soon !

[h1]Background:[/h1]

I realized some people played both Witcher 2 and 3 because the Netflix adaptation came out. For the record, I have never watched an episode of that Netflix show and I don't intend to. Geralt's (Henry Cavill's) wig alone is enough to turn anybody off to how unrealistic and hokey that show is. I also have a review of Witcher 1 from April 2017 (over two and a half years before the show aired an episode).

I played Witcher 1 for 157.2 hours (I also reviewed it) and then I played Witcher 3 and its two DLCs, Hearts of Stone and Blood and Wine for 256.4 hrs total (I also reviewed it).

[h1]Positive:[/h1]

+Story is really good. It's as good as Witcher 3.

+Story split in two. CD Project Red really created two separate storylines that coincide and give you the other perspective.

+Continuation of Witcher lore and rich characters from Witcher 1.

+Unlike Witcher 3, Witcher 2 gave sufficient time to the freedom-fighting Scoia'tael faction/storyline

+Really beautiful graphics and world

+Replayability. You have to play this game more than once to get the other storyline/side.

+Your choices matter (as explained above, what you choose dictates what storyline you'll play)

+A lot of content. I surpassed the 100-hour mark after two full play-throughs. In Witcher 1, there are five chapters. In Witcher 2, there are 3 chapters but each chapter, especially 2 and 3 are elongated with content.

+Eng-game armor (Vran armor/Elder Blood armor) attainment is more favorable/practical than in Witcher 3.

+Even though the inventory in Witcher 2 could've used a few improvements, it's not as frustrating as the frozen inventory of Witcher 3 where if you have a lot of items in your inventory, the entire screen stalls for a good 5-10 seconds.

[h1]Negative:[/h1]

-There's a glitch in the game where if you have around 300-400 saves, the game no longer saves, so you have to delete earlier saves. Also, the game, especially the introduction lags. Plus, the more saves you have, the longer it will take to delete each earlier save. Not only that, but the more saves you have in the game and try to delete earlier saves, the more likely your game will crash when you try to delete an earlier save. For example, if you have around 300 or 400 saves, you're likely to crash if you delete every two saves whereas if you have like 100 saves, you're likely to crash if you delete every twenty saves.

-Some of the quests are complex to the point where you have to look up walkthroughs. The in-game compass only shows you where to go if the quest is one of the main quests. If it's a side quest, then you have to look it up.

-Slotting mutagens to skills is something I had to look up (just like in Witcher 3), it wasn't really straight-forward. Also, the majority of the sword, alchemy and signs skills don't have mutagen slots, only a limited number do.

-Dice poker (which I explained in my Witcher 1 review). In Witcher 2, your chances of winning a dice poker game are just as bad, It's common to not win a game in five games. And for people asking, "what's the big deal about playing dice poker in this game, can't you skip it?" There are two or three quests in two or three chapters where you have to play (and win) to complete the quest.

-Controls can occasionally (not always, but occasionally) be frustrating, but I felt the same way with Witcher 3, to be fair.

Definitely the weakest of the 3 Witcher games, but still worth playing and a good game on its own merit.

The combat is pretty poor and a lot of the mechanics are dated and VERY reminiscent of the early 2010s, but the story is great and this is probably the better of the 3 games when it comes to exploring the world, history, and politics of the universe.

Witcher 1 is a better RPG, Witcher 3 is a better EVERYTHING ELSE, but the Witcher 2 held my attention from start to finish and I'd recommend playing it despite its flaws.

A must-have for any Witcher fan, The Witcher 2: AoK is a fun, engaging RPG with a beautiful environment, immersive story and great combat.

Cons: 
-Not extremely well-optimized, you may experience some minor lag even on high-end PCs
- The game only uses a certain set of music, and features no unique situational music, so the sounds you hear in the game can get really repetitive
-same goes for the animations: Geralt has like 5 animations for conversation and switches between them during every NPC encounter and every storyline scene, which gets pretty repetitive and boring.
-Voice acting is a bit dull and at times lifeless
-Missing some features for controller support (no sensitivity adjustment or other advanced contoller options)
-A BIG con: not a FULLY open world; once you've finished a story in a certain area, you cannot backtrack to it after you've finished the game, so when you've finished the game, that's it, you can't explore any more.

Pros:
-Excellent story which fits right into The Witcher lore and universe
-Engaging environment, you can interact with every NPC you see, there are a lot of places to loot from
-Exploration is fun, maps are decent-sized
-Grinding for weapons and equipment can be a lot of fun
-Many side-quests to keep you entertained and your coin purse full
-The combat is very well executed, attacks seem smooth, enemies act as expected. Overall, the combat is the most smooth part of the experience
-Often goes on sale (I picked mine up for around 2 Euros, which is a steal

Overall, has its ups and downs, but if you find it on sale, I would definitely recommend it

[h1] An immersive, fun and interesting experience. Overall, an 8/10 game that  has - as all great games should - a very special feeling to it, definitely worth your time and money! [/h1]

[b] Gameplay: 8/10 [/b]
- Combat: Huge improvement over the previous game, combat is fun and very challenging but perhaps too challenging sometimes. Skill trees could be a lot better and diverse tho (more mutagen slots, more actives rather than just passive stuff,etc.) 
- Quests: interesting variety and the side quests contribute greatly to the main quest-line.
- Items and crafting: very well thought out, and great designs for both weapons and armor, could use a little more variety when it comes to the boots, gauntlets, trousers. Menu design and UI is a mess though. 
- Other: The game desperately needs a fast travel option even if the maps are small, running back and forth to the main area every single time can get tiring really fast. 

[b] Story: 8/10 [/b]
The game has an interesting plot and many good characters, but it falls in the trap of focusing too much on one part of the story and ignoring other parts that seem more interesting i.e. I think the game puts too much emphasis and time on the political side of the story and not enough on other things. Also, the game tends to overwhelm the player with names and several new characters at the transition between each of the story arcs.

[b] Graphics/Sound & Art/Technical Performance: 8/10 [/b]
An absolute marvel for its time (2011); gorgeous environments, beautiful music, good voice acting, well designed main characters and armor, etc.

But there are 2 very annoying shortcomings here: 1. re-use of npc faces, and I'm not talking about npcs you don't interact with, I mean npcs which you have dialogs and up close encounters with. 2. Sound mixing is terrible, even when turning the music and sound volume to a minimum, sometimes you can't hear what your companions and others are saying, it can be very disorienting at times. 

There are a few minor bugs here and there such as Geralt not opening doors and game getting stuck, but I only experienced the latter twice, and a quickload would solve this. No quest-breaking bugs experienced here.

[b] Replay Value: Medium  [/b]
While I get that the game is re-playable and has multiple paths story-wise, I just don't feel like it has enough value in doing so, and the main reason for that is combat-related, there aren't enough differences between the combat skill tree builds to make it worthwhile for me personally, but I get that many people would enjoy multiple playthroughs.

I had fun trying to get the best armor and weapons for each chapter, and completed most of the sidequests along the way. BEWARE: the combat system is terrible IMO. very hack slash and roll. The difficulty settings also aren't very consistent. I ended up switching from between normal and easy extremely often, as some enemies were just too easy and boring on normal mode, but some enemies were nearly impossible (for me at least), even on easy mode. These are my only 2 problems with this game. Id recommend this game to anyone looking to play the witcher 3, and doesn't want to go in completely blind.

As it happens, there's also very little reason to play this game unless you have a burning desire to see the story first hand. Witcher 3 already has a save simulation feature built into it, so you can jump straight to that game without ever needing to touch save transfers. The only reason I'm playing 2 again is because I am one of the aforementioned people that want to see Geralt's story firsthand and there's two paths in this game you can take. Even still, the game is just as bad as I remember it being the first time around. When it's not walking simulator, it's Dark Souls Witcher-style, rolling and all.

I am writing this review as a fan of Witcher 3, and someone who enjoyed playing Witcher 1 as a kid back in the days. Unfortunately, I have to give a slight thumb down here, even though I can recommend this game for the story, music and general atmosphere only. The rest of it, especially gameplay and mechanics is just bad. On few occasions I was close to just uninstalling the game from frustration but the story kept me going on.
I started playing on DARK difficulty, inspired to go deeper into theory crafting. I like challenging games and I thought this one can provide it after seeing talent tree, recipes for bombs and different potions as well as gear with various stats. I just couldn’t stand it and in the middle of Chapter 2 I just switched to NORMAL just to finish the game. 
Reason for this is atrocious, inconsistent combat with horrible hit boxes and enemies just fighting and hitting the air few meters away from you, swinging their sword at nothing, which is honestly sad to watch (and yes, you sometimes take damage from them hitting the air).
It is so dull and it is draining all the enjoyment from the game. You knock opponent down with the sign, hit him, and he is up in milliseconds to hit you back and you just die. Next time you do the same thing, finisher animation starts and you kill the opponent instantly at full HP. You dodge roll the enemy swings, get behind the opponent and try to hit the opponent from the back – guess what, he just instantly 180 to hit you back or just parries the attack with the help of the invisible hand of its guardian angel. And forget about the meaningful use of signs and bombs, because they don’t do much to be worth the hustle of stopping mid combat to switch to it. It adds another layer to non-fluidity of combat. This abomination is if you take all the worst parts of Sekiro (my favorite game) and Dark Souls and mix it together without idea what you are doing.
So if you are here as a fan of TV series or Witcher 3 I propose to switch it to normal or easy difficulty and play to experience the lore and story, because it is good and it might be worth it. The music and atmosphere is also on point, and graphics is generally good and can look beautiful at times. What it lacks is a deeper world building and attention to small details. It is mostly linear game and not much exploration to be done so conclusion is that If you are not a big fan of the Witcher series, just skip it.

A very good RPG.

Pro: Two different stories based on the player's choices; a lot of character building; no simple "black and white", that is "good vs. evil" choices; most characters are plastic (not entirely good and not entirely evil) as well, except for maybe Loredo (evil) and Triss (good); more interesting combat than in The Witcher I.

Con: You cannot maintain neutrality; the overall atmosphere is weaker than in The Witcher I; and the combat is more difficult to learn. No need to eat, no need to drink, silly potion making... The meditation and potion mechanics were better in the first part, I even liked the storytelling better.

Overall: This is probably a better game than the first part from a gaming point of view; however, the stories told have weaker atmosphere and therefore a bit lower emotional impact. But well... Guess you can't have everything, can you? Anyway, let's reach for the third volume of this game.

A big improvement over the first game. The Witcher 2 tells a mature story full of mystery and intrigue which is made even better thanks to well written and well voice acted characters within a detailed and immersive world. It's not fully open world but you can explore off the beaten track if you want, which is worth doing as you may find better weapons and armour and even ingredients for stronger potions along the way. There are plenty of -mostly- interesting side quests to keep you busy and the main story can be affected by your choice of dialogue options which result in different scenarios for the story to play out in. The graphics also hold up pretty well despite the games age.

Combat is much better than it was before. It's no longer clunky and awkward. Instead it feels much more fluid and refined. One sword for killing people, a silver sword for killing monsters, traps, bombs, and a multitude of  witcher signs giving you different tactical advantages against a wide range of enemy types makes for very engaging fights. Some of these sections can be pretty tough though. The game doesn't hold your hand every step of the way. Instead it treats you like an adult and expects you to think and work things out for yourself, both during combat and for the story.

There are some things I don't like however. While I get the inclusion of alchemy and the ability to create potions, they can only be created and consumed by meditating and going through menus. This means there is no way to drink potions during combat, which if frustrating, especially when you're in the middle of a tough boss fight and low on health. The UI is messy, there's no fast travel and you will want to manually save the game at regular intervals as the auto save system is completely incompetent, sometimes putting you back as long as 20 minutes.

So the game isn't perfect but certainly improves on a lot of the shortcomings the first game suffered from. It's definitely a game I'd recommend and one that's worth playing more than once in order to see everything it has to offer.

Witcher 2 is a logical follow-on to a breakthrough European RPG action adventure game. By "logical", I mean that it seems the developers thought it best to be on the safe side and make it more "cinematic" in its approach. This means that they needed to take away some of the things that made the original game great, like a deep intuitive (albeit clunky) character development system, a rich card collecting side-quest by taking as many women as possible, and a wide variety of quests and side quests. What we have here in the sequel is a watered down version that seeks to make it more fast paced and fun. They succeeded in much better and fluid animations of fighting, but left me wanting more with limited and almost boring animations whenever he is taking women. This is an area in which fans almost expected an improvement upon the original, but unfortunately it was not in the cards this time around. I haven't played the 3rd game, but I expect it to be more of the same. Why am I droning on and on about this? Because it's not The Witcher without it. You might as well play Kingdoms of Amalur or something. Anyway, the meditation mode was an improvement I liked, which seemed easier to understand, but I never really made any potions, usually just depending on better equipment and spells when fighting. Another thing they could have done better was combining spells with attacks. It was just okay but could have been enriched with more animations and combos. You should be able to use his spells to your advantage in just about any way within the game - at least in my opinion. So in conclusion to my rambling, I recommend it but not highly. It's a lighthearted fun game that takes a closer look at Geralt's past, but ends abruptly and leaves you wanting more. I'd probably rate it a 3/5 and probably wouldn't play it again.

It has issues, and some clunky gameplay, but it is a witcher game, and if you like the world, most of the time it's enough to make it worth.

It's not like Witcher 3, combat is more stilted and cumbersome, clunky potion management, the game is more linear, although it opens up in some parts it's not the same as its successor. As should be expected, the prequel is the inferior product in every way. Witcher 3 is a masterpiece of masterpieces. That being said, there is still a great game to be played here, despite its linearity, offers deep philosophical choice and consequence found in no other games. There are probably only a handful of games you can play 40 hours to the final boss fight and instead of dueling it out, have a polite conversation and go your separate ways. This game will make you ask yourself those kinds of questions. Are my enemies' actions really so different from my own? Am I a morally righteous killer? Perhaps the most compelling feature of the game is that among the many choices you make, there's a big one that sets you on a completely different path to resolving events. You meet and work with entirely different characters and earn entirely different gear. There are hours of unique game play between them. The effects of the choice are so profound that you have to play the game at least twice to experience both paths.

Like probably many of you, I came to play Witcher 2 after Witcher 3. I wanted to know more about the backstory to the WildHunt and I thought Assassin of Kings could provide some answers. Unfortunately, that is not the case. Not a lot about Geralt is revealed in this game and the scope is pretty limited. Your character has amnesia and you get drip fed plot details until literally the final act. There are few interesting world state changes in Witcher 3 that can occur based on choices from this game, but none that have a major impact on the story. The writing overall however is quite nice.

The Witcher 2: Assassin Of Kings is a wonderful sequel to Witcher 1. Perhaps you'll feel downgrade if you played the Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, but definitely not if played only the 1st witcher. When you play both games, you can really see how much work the developers put into improving everything in the 2nd title. I would definitely recommend purchasing this title, but know that it comes with a few pros and cons. I would also suggest reading the witcher books in order to understand what is going on, however it isn't really a necessity. Just makes the overall story a lot more interesting

Pros:

- The graphics looked astonishing for 2011, and still look pretty good in 2021. 
- The story is great, with many intriguing plot-twists
- The game does a great job of conveying the atmosphere of Andrzej Sapkowski's books.

Cons:

- The combat system. I would recommend playing this with the witcher 2 overhaul mod in order to get a better experience. The combat does lack quality unfortunately. Dodging doesn't work that well.

- The difficulty level. I have never seen such a vast change in difficulty levels in any game, probably ever. And it's not a good thing. Easy difficulty is a total walk in the park, while Normal is occasionally harder than Dark Souls. 

- The game's economy. It is quite difficult to earn money here and the prices for most things are outrageous. As stated earlier, reccommend playing with the overhaul mod.

Overall, this game is definitely worth your attention!

Have you seen the Anakin saga of Star Wars...the prequel movies? Whole Anakin story takes place on a political background.

Similar to that, Witcher 2's story also takes place on a political background. Interesting characters, good story, HUGELY improved gameplay compared to Witcher 1, great world design...you still can't jump though (only in specific areas). You get to choose two paths to complete the game. So you can play it again to play the other path and see the other side of the story. You will be bombarded with lots of decisions which will definitely affect your game and eventually the ending. My choices in THIS game even affected my Witcher 3 playthrough! Cool!

A massive improvement over The Witcher 1, especially regarding gameplay, visuals and combat. You can already see the transition towards the style of the third game. The story can be convoluted, perhaps a bit too much (at times it is hard to follow) but at least it is elaborate and interesting. And it is a game that REALLY takes player agency seriously, there are multiple very different possible outcomes for the realms depending on your decisions, and the decisions are meaningful to the extent entire questlines and map regions are available or locked based on the choices you've picked. Bear in mind though that it is a three-act-story with three mini open world maps, which serves the narrative well but may disappoint an open-world enthusiast; this game relies heavily on its story, you cannot just lose yourself exploring the world and ignore the main arch. Overall a solid title that has aged quite gracefully.

I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys open-world action adventure games and The Witcher in particular. A quick Google search will tell you this games main story is 30 hours, I finished it in a little under 23 hours. I admit, I more or less wanted to just get through the story so I could experience the game and get the story so I can begin The Witcher 3. In The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings, you play a Witcher, Geralt of Rivia and after a string of assassinations of kings, you seek out those responsible with the help of many allies along the way. In The Witcher 2, you travel to multiple cities, fight a plethora of monsters and beasts, and if you have played the original, you can simulate the save from the first game so that your choices carry over but I unfortunately was not able to accomplish this. It really wouldn't have affected the game greatly as far as I am aware. All I can say is do more side quests and explore this huge, beautiful world and enjoy the game because it's a ton of quality for a small quantity. I hope you are able enjoy it as much as I did and more. Thank you.
LOVE IT! <3

Quite an interesting game with a [b]deeply worked out plot[/b] and different branches of events depending on the player's choice. There are several directions for [b]leveling[/b] the character with [b]different tactics[/b] of behavior at the choice of the player. Relatively comfortable, but not too varied [b]combat[/b]. There is a lack of bow, although, perhaps, its absence is due to the lore of the game.
Unfortunately, the absolute linearity and scripting of individual episodes greatly spoiled the overall impression of the game.
Most logical tasks can be called logical only symbolically. They usually require minimal use of the mind, some of them are completely illogical or far-fetched, such as the task The Gargoyle Contract, which is almost impossible to complete without knowing where you can get additional information, while the game does not give any hints on this matter. But even after obtaining this additional information, it does not become easier, because its source gives too vague hints about the order of using the runes. But perhaps this is a problem with Russian localization.
In general, the game left a pleasant feeling, has a certain amount of [b]replayability[/b] due to the ability to go through various branches and select different dialogue options, but personally I was a little bored throughout the entire passage and by the end I wanted to finish all the quests and finish the game as soon as possible.
It works on [b]Linux[/b] without any problems, except for the known crash problem with a large number of saves, which is solved by periodically deleting unnecessary ones.

2nd game from the trilogy, continues the story and adventures of Geralt starting in Flotsam, along with the king Foltest, previously saved from an assassination atempt at the end of the last game. This time it starts in the middle of a battle. And im stopping here due to potential spoilers.

    The game is from start superior of the first one. From graphics, to gameplay and combat, with the mention that alchemy works a bit different here, that u cannot drink potions during combat. You have to use them just before the battles, otherwise you cannot use them, except oils which works before them aswell as during battles. If in the last game the signs we're viable few of them, this time all signs have a purpose, but most of the time you will use the Quen one aka the shield. On easier difficulty you can walk through the game without a problem, forgetting about them or, enhancements, potions and so on. On harder difficulty, you have to use all available weapons you can have, from bombs, traps, signs, potions and so on.

    The combat is very different from the last game, its on another level and another learning curve, just roll 'n roll, parry, use shields and run arround to recover a lil bit o HP. Another point, the Geralt in this game is a little bit of cannon glass, you are pretty vulnerable to everything during early and mid game. I personally invest in swordsmanship talent tree and by the end of the game I was a tank.

    Again, dont skip cutsence, dialogues, books and journal, as the previous game, alot of the story and information you'll find here.There are much more to say about him, but I let you to descover it.
   
     Good luck!

However the actual gameplay is just unengaging, harder difficulties force you into a restrictive playstyle of casting a certain magic sign called quen and kiting massive groups of damage sponge enemies around, dodge rolling in, hitting them, getting hit, rolling away, cast quen, repeat. It's the only way to consistently not die on higher difficulties and it's just not fun. Theres no real way to avoid this unless you know what's coming ahead of time and and have alot of skill at the game because the potion system (your main source of buffs) is so obtuse and difficult to use. I reccomend playing on the easiest difficulty to breeze through the combat sections to avoid the headache. Try your best to treat as a really good visual novel with some weird puzzle sections (ie. combat)
