Loving the game!

Ok, a revised review. The game becomes fun in Chapter 2 at least on the Iorverth path. But Chapter 1 is a total misery. Some battles are so ridiculously unbalanced that you'll have to replay them 1000 times on normal difficulty. In Chapter 2, things quickly get easier and in Chapter 3, they are quite easy. Also some of the quests are actually interesting, like the Mystery manuscript or whatever was the name. With puzzles and everything. 
So  the game becomes fun the better equipment you have. And the story really develops and becomes very engaging. And you get laid A LOT. Though they could have bothered to make different animations for the different characters you plough. 
But 1) hte difficulty level in the beginning is ridiculous. 2) there are some bugs, which is very weird for a game that's soooooo old. They certainly had the time the fix them, had they wanted to. They obviously didn't care about it. 3) There are problems with game-saves on Linux. For example, sometimes manual save won't work and only F5 will. I had to replay 1 hour because of that 4) I really don't like how you get some world-building only in Chapter 3. And you get to care about the characters only in Chapter 2. Since Chapter 1 took like 20 hours for me, that's 20 lost hours of very annoying grinding. I don't like that. 5) What is the point of having such a large skills tree if you can use only about 30% of it. Or even less. That was disappointing. 6) Game-play wise, it's super hard to use different spells than Quen. Whoever made this choice, to hide the skills in Ctrl or to shotcut them on the numpad didn't deserve his or her salary. Very bad choice. I've almost not used any other spells, while in TW1 I literally used them all (but Axii, what does it do anyway?) 
There are probably other things, but my point is, I still feel TW1, with it's worst well everything, told a better story. And I guess that's what most of us play these games. Anyway, I liked the game, played a lot of it, so I can't not recommend it. But a note for people who are now considering playing it - for F sake, play it on easy for Chapter 1. Otherwise it's very frustrating. Also, take the time to explore quests - some of them are super fun. Like the troll family one - their lines are hilarious. It's a beautiful game, it's sad they didn't make a better effort to balance the battles in the beginning and to fix the bugs.

The Witcher 2 is not a normal video game, and it's not a normal fantasy. It subverts the old high-fantasy stereotypes even as it employs them. The elves that you'll meet in Temeria aren't charming, ethereal forest-dwellers, they're guerrilla insurgents raining death on humans from the trees. The dwarves, typically cheerful, hard-working sorts, live in a city of worn rock that runs off the fumes of their former industriousness while its current inhabitants drink, joke and fornicate. The various kingdoms are in the on the precipice of war, led by despotic kings who play their personal vendettas out on the battlefields at the expense of their armies' lives.

Went on to play Witcher 2 on laptop, HATE THE CONTROLS, to the point of hating the game. 
Alternated between keyboard-mouse style and gamepad (xbox one, playstation DS4) out of frustration.
> Keyboard-mouse config / layout is horrid.
> Gamepad would have been good if not for the ridiculous "search" feature that does not allow selective looting of items; it forces player to take all items or none at all, causing rapid inventory bloat and over-encumbrance (slows player's movements to a crawl). Questing / Looting / Crafting (and yes, walking-fetching too) becomes a pain when the inventory system sucks.
> A "shift-key" feature on the gamepad config would've been a good way to greatly increase the number of button re-mapping options, eg.
[ X for Fast Attack ]                            vs    [ Left trigger + X to cast Aard spell ]
[ Y for Strong Attack ]                        vs    [ Left trigger + Y to cast Quen spell ]
[ D-pad Down to Sheath Weapon ]    vs    [ Left trigger + D-pad Down to cycle usable items ]
... etc

Steam controller / gamepad re-config interface is equally convoluted and confusing to use.

Looking to buy it in 2021?

I consider it a recommendation if you are still living in 2011.

Any game in this day and age with these mechanics are simply impossible to play for me. I have been playing games for more than 25 years and I can stand the antiquity of a game for nostalgia, yet it was not the case for Witcher 2.

- Fast travel is not to be found and maps are not that small so you waste a lot of time going around. There is no mini map or a quick map key, so each time you have to stop the game go to the map and back.
- You can only view 1 quest on your map at a time so you do tons of backtracking in the same confined areas.
- Carry weight is ridiculous.
- No jumping nor sprinting.
- Menu UI is torture with a controller but the game itself is even worse with keyboard + mouse.
- Many day time specific quests.
- Monsters spawn indefinitely at some locations which if you try to do some research or other activity, it will constantly block your interactions because battling.
- Can not clear an area of quest givers due to "1 quest on the map only" bs.
- Maps are seriously restrictive. If you call this somehow a limited open world then so was Crash Bandicoot and Spyro.
- MANY inconsistencies within the so called amazing story line from start to finish.
- Entire game has this weird orange blue glow filter on it that it made it very weird and aesthetically unpleasing to the eyes at times.
- Story barely means anything and leaves you hanging in the air and almost has no real connection to Witcher 3. You could completely dive into Witcher 3 without playing 1 or 2 and would be doing ok.

Yeah, needless to say that it did not aged like fine wine. Back in its time this was a decent game for its price and an easy buy, not with todays standards. No.

More the time passes, more I think that CDPR is a company who made it all thanks to the master piece Witcher 3 was. Which they didnt had to invent much, considering their game lore, world and almost all of the characters came from Sapkowski s books. Witcher 2 was a "good" game for its time, nowadays, its a pass for me. If you are really curious then go watch a YouTube video on it.

I rage quit and jumped to Witcher 3 when I first started on this game The combat was clunkier than Witcher 1's, it crashes when you have too many saves, and the UI was kinda bad in general. HOWEVER.

I returned to it after playing 3 and realised that its story was the BEST out of the trilogy. The combat sucks and it crashed too often, but all the pain was worth it...the story was that good. I loved how they made 2 different paths with two different stories, with 2 different maps to explore. The character development was deeper, and the political intrigue fascinating. This game should not be judged in its combat, as it utterly fails to deliver; but its deep story where choices make a difference.

Moreover, if you've come here from Witcher 3 and the books, you should definitely check this game out and download the Farewell to the White Wolf mod. That mod is a whole game by itself that uses Witcher 3 assets, but with a Witcher 2 engine. The story in the mod tied up so many loose ends from the entire trilogy and the books, making the mod one of the best I've ever encountered.

All in all,

10/10 for story,
4/10 for combat,
8.5/10 for graphics and environment,
8.5/10 for music (nothing can beat Witcher 3's OSTs for now)

Mouse is bugged. It seems like the game maps mouse DPI directly to screen pixels - the game would be more or less playable at 720 x 480, but at higher resolutions _the mouse cursor slows down_.  Mouse sensitivity setting only affects turning in 3D view.

So _only_ get this game if you have high DPI, preferably adjustable, mouse.

EDIT

Tested with a cheap spare mouse: 1080p is playable but not optimal with a 2400 DPI mouse. 800 DPI is _painful_, hit the turbo button and resulting 2400 DPI is mostly tolerable. Then just turn down mouse sensitivity so that you don't lose precision for in-game turns.

You'd really want a 3200 DPI mouse to be comfortable at 1080p, though.

Quick time events were and still are a bad idea. Making the boxing matches QTE's is bareable, but adding them to bossfights is not.  3 times I "died" because There was a QTE when I assumed I was watching a cutscene.

The level cap. It's 35 in this game as opposed to the first game's 50. And worse yet, in one of the branching paths, you CANNOT reach max level even if you do every single sidequest UNLESS you get a HIDDEN and MISSABLE ability in the VERY BEGINING of the game. Frustrating.

The Cons:

The DLC adds little to this game and short of the mysterious merchant can be completely ignored.
Your item carry overs from the first game are also completely meaningless. They give a VERY small bonus at the very begining of the game and then are worthless beyond that.

Enemy AI isn't the greatest but i've seen worse. Still, I can't give it a pass.


Overall Rating:  7.5/10

A while back I picked up the entire trilogy based on the praise that The Witcher 3 received from both fans and critics, being one of the most universally loved video games of the modern era, and made it a point to play through them as soon as I had a proper gaming PC. Well, I tried to anyway. I dropped the first witcher game after about five minutes as soon as I saw what the combat was like in it, and promptly downloaded this one. I had actually been advised to skip them both and move straight to The Witcher 3, but I simply couldn't see the logic in that decision. After two playthroughs of The Witcher 2, which are needed to get the entire story (you're forced to choose to follow one of two factions near the end of chapter one, both of whom get about half the overall plot), and having finished most of The Witcher 3, I now understand. 

The Witcher 2 is not a bad game, it's just so terribly disappointing. I was expecting far too much from the narrative, which here is barely serviceable and delights in forcing you to make hard choices by making sure that each option you have sucks pretty much equally. There were maybe five times throughout this game where I made a decision and actually felt okay about it, with some negative consequences being unavoidable entirely. To be fair, this was my very first experience with the world of the Witcher, having never read the books or watched the Netflix series, and had no clue what I was getting into. Had I known, I probably wouldn't have spent the money on these games as this just isn't enjoyable for me. I'd imagine most people looking at reviews now have seen the series and are aware of what's in store, but I'd like to try and give somebody the warning I would have liked to have received. However there is one story related flaw I simply can't forgive: Out of all the hard choices you make in this game, only two have any actual impact on the third game if you import your save, and as far as I know you can get by just fine choosing the "bad" options in the Witcher 2. This made me feel like I was forced to sit through hours upon hours of B.S. only to be told it was all a dream or something. It sure helped me understand how angry the fans of HBO's Game of Thrones series were with that last season.

The gameplay, however, saved me from completely hating this game. It's pretty basic RPG fare, but it's very fun and the combat was super satisfying for me. Might be because I'm bad at video games and played on the easiest difficulty setting, but I had a great time beating the crap out of anyone and everything dumb enough to attack me. I only have two gameplay related complaints: One, the chapter one boss battle is awesome and really well designed while the other boss battles just aren't. They're no different than regular enemies, just stronger. Two, it's pretty tough to save up a decent amount of coin and if you don't know when you're getting an upgrade ahead of time you'll waste it all and be screwed. There are only a handful of items actually worth getting once you know where everything is, and you can loot most of what you need for them. After I knew that I didn't mind so much, but that first playthrough was so frustrating I almost dropped the entire series.

I'd give The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition a 6.5/10, and recommend it for informed folks who know what they're in for. Such individuals would likely get more out of it than I did. Otherwise, either skip straight to The Witcher 3 or don't bother at all.

Updated Review: If you have played and enjoyed Witcher 3, you don't need to spend time on this game. I went through the games in chronological order. Therefore, this game felt very enjoyable in my first run. However, when I visited this game again after finishing Witcher 3, I realized that this game has numerous shortcomings that really reduce enjoyment. The meaningless time limit on using the Witcher necklace, the completely senseless combat mechanisms and so on. This is still a very beautiful looking game (in highest game settings I can't believe how a game this old could look so good still). But the fun is definitely not there, anymore. I'm slugging through the game simply because I want to explore an alternative end, but it feels like work.

First Review: Incredible game. I can't describe how much I loved it even though I found the fighting mechanism much more difficult than Witcher 1, even at the easy setting. The inventory control was not very easy, and crafting was mostly useless. The story (and the overall adult theme of the game) was very pleasing to me as I hate games which are aimed towards children. I'm very happy that I played Witcher 1 before this; the first game gives a lot of context. I played the enhanced edition, which was one of the best looking games I've ever played at ultra settings. This game has a lot of replay value, thanks to the many impactful choices you have throughout the game. I intend to return to it after I get a taste of Witcher 3, as well. I want to play all the possible outcomes!

The game is a huge improvement from the first one. The graphic's good, the gameplay's although very different from the first game it's easier to get used to, and the story's memorable and enjoyable; though for some reason I still prefer the first witcher game rather than this one. But this one is still a good game nonetheless.

The Witcher 2 is the sequel of the acclaimed fist game but unfortunately is not a good game. The flaws of the first one can be forgiven, it's an old game made by an inexperienced and fairly small team and was an ambitious game, the Witcher 2 as none of this excuses.
The gameplay has always been the weak point of this games, the first one had a simple and a little uninspired gameplay but as they say "it just work" but the second doesn't work. You can't control the animation of your attacks cause they are random, so you don't know how fast your attack will be and when it will land, this coupled with an absence of a combo system makes the combat system a button mashing. To be fair the first game was too, but it was an old school RPG, the second one want to be an action game RPG, something like a souls game if you want. Hit boxes are a problem too, your attacks will sometimes miss the target even when you're supposed to hit them, this can happen often when fighting short enemies like the Nekkers. Like this wasn't enough, the game difficulty is poorly balanced, enemies can swarm you very quickly and kill you in matter of seconds, especially by using the X2 damage bonus they get by attacking your back, you can't stun lock an enemy by normal means and most of them are damages sponges. This will force a boring and unfair hit and run tactics and will drag most encounter. Some of this problems can be countered somehow by levelling, there is a skill that improve the distance covered by your dodge rendering it usable, and another one that negate the bonus back stab damage monster get, making the game more fair but boring nonetheless.
Another problem of the gameplay is that has lost it's personality, now to follow trends has a crafting mechanics for near everything, there are a lot of boring and silly QTE and as said before the combat now is a bad "wanna be souls like". The dialog choices most of the time don't reflect what you expected them to make you say, so you have to be something of a mind reader, the potions now are near useless, you can't drink them during a fight for..."reasons" but only when meditating (you can now do that everywhere if you're not in a fight) and they last like 5 minutes, so unless you are replaying the game you can expect to use them just for boss fights, now most quests are not indicated on your map and don't contain proper indication to where and how to do them and the controls are bad...like really bad, it's clear the game was made for consoles, near all of your actions will be tied to the same mouse button.
To close the review, i have faith the plot of the game is interesting as the previous one and the graphics is beautiful, but with a gameplay like this you better of watching a gameplay than playing it yourself
It still has that "The Witcher" charm.

Never doubted for one moment that I would play this RPG. It provides the usual crafting, skills and attribute management, which is still entertaining and working flawlessly. However, the Witcher is like a bastard sibling of the Elder Scrolls. It's supported by often complicated, confusing and completely schizoid writing. To read and get into the Witcher's background is like witnessing a group of teenagers trying to describe the financial market after ingesting sugar cubes saturated with LSD.

This game is mostly a reckless on screen delivery. The characters are uninteresting pieces of animated clay. I can normally live with that, but in this particular game, it just leads me to lose attention if anything is going on for more than a minute. Add to this that the combat in the Witcher is limited to mashing the same key over and over without any specific aim. There are combat skills and fancy moves sure, but why bother?

Just mash your single attacks a few times, then don't touch anything and watch Geralt's figure skating moves do the work. It's dumb, boring and gets annoying real fast when it seems the scene you're stuck on isn't ending. Why would it end? I don't know, maybe some lousy quick time events could have been implemented better? Why though? It's an RPG game, why saturate it with lousy game designs like quick time events? Geralt has several skills which I've never been bothered using or even developing because the entire combat game is simplified enough for a cat, stomping on a keyboard, to succeed.

The Witcher 2 or any other Witcher branded product, isn't recommendable. Unless you're bored or out of money and can't play anything better, don't bother. It's a lot of content (15GB) and I'm not sure I'll ever be motivated to go pass killing the same stiff guards around the same ballista over and over.
worth it, great story, not-bad graphics, kinda bad optimization but it was worth it 100%. 2 main game paths, both great.

Second game of the trilogy which perfectly serves as gateway between first and third parts and also tells its own although short but amazing story and introduces several new epic characters to the saga. This part is also first that introduces Dandelion's narrative to the games which I absolutely adore. Overall it's a truly amazing experience which has cool branching storyline and well-made RPG elements with several different endings. My only complain to the series, especially to the third game is that we never saw continuation of Yorveth's and Saskia's story which are two interesting characters second game brings and they definitely deserved a worthy epilogue in the third part.

(Disclaimer: Much like my playtime of the first game, the hours I've put into it have been skewed but in the opposite direction, I played a good chunk of this game long ago in the ancient age of 2015 on an ok laptop, the actual length of the game will probably be more like 30-35 hours assuming you do a majority of the side quests like I did. It might also be in your interest as a reader and consumer to read my review of the first game for additional context.)

Part of the reason I was excited for Cyberpunk was having fond enough memories of this game when I first played but never finished it. That said, I still think Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings was a step in the right direction for CD Projekt Red, whatever its flaws. The creation of their own engine certainly lent the game a much better look than some old engine they borrowed from Bioware, with much better physics, graphics, and general presentation (I noticed a few oddities, but nothing overly distracting like in the first game). The combat is a little more Souls-like and is a lot more fun to do than the first game. I did appreciate that the game makes your choices in the first game matter in small ways, mostly in dialogue but also one particular incident where a character I remembered from the first game sent somebody with a gift for me. 

Witcher 2 also has a far more engaging story overall, with lots of memorable and interesting characters, action set pieces, and compelling drama and dark fantasy. Choices feel like they matter more here and you'll be hard pressed to think that no previous decisions will turn around and bite you in the ass. The music is probably also the best in a fantasy game I've played yet (though I'm sure the third game has some good tunes).

The only issues I have are these: They somehow made Dice Poker even more insufferable than the first game, which is a feat, the level design of Chapter 3 made attempting sidequests very frustrating, and for whatever reason, the game really struggles when there's a lot of save files in the game. For a good while, I had the game crash very frequently when I tried to save scum or reload saves, something the design of the game trained me to do, all because of a backlog of saves from my 2015-2016 playthrough. If you're playing for the first time, this probably won't be a problem, but you will have to be vigilant in deleting all but the most recent save files. 

Other than that it's a pretty good game. I feel reasonably confident in recommending it. Anyway, onto the Witcher game that people actually like!

As another casual that pasted up playing this game back in 2011, I felt the need to play through this game after playing countless hours on The Witcher 3 Wild Hunt. I must say this game is very impressive considering the other titles that came out that year, specifically Skyrim and others. If you’re looking for a cure to an RPG itch - give this game a go regardless of the age!  

COMBAT:
The combat system still is very clunky even after the huge overhaul from the first title.  I think it has done some things right and made it easier to play through. But if you are coming straight from the Witcher 3 Wild hunt the combat system will seem not as polished. 

GRAPHICS:
The games textures look really well for 2011. 

STORY:
The story is very fascinating as someone that knew very little outside of the Witcher 3 main story. It has many turns and twists that the player is left with choices to determine the overall outcome of a majority of the story. It overlaps well and definitely worth at least two times to see each outcome. 

NEGATIVES:

Melee combat is a timed system mashing keys can become frustrating. 
Not able to properly jump, and move around terrain. 
Autosave feature through steam can become broke and corrupt, you can bypass this by saving directly to your PC locally and avoiding this issue from the start.

What is Witcher 2 ?

After watching and enjoying the Witcher TV series on netflix and having the first two witcher games sitting on my steam library for a few years I finally gave them a go, playing both W1 and W2 for the first time this late in 2020 may show a few obstacles along the way which I had many with W1, I understood that W1 was a smaller game budget-wise and CD Projekt Red was still quite young back then, theres a lot of limitations because of age as W1 was released in 2007 but I felt that the gameplay was kinda crappy and hard to get into, I had no fun and I dropped it, I didnt want to start W2 without finishing the first game but I had no choice, so I watched a story recap to not get too lost on the story and then I started my playthrough of 2 with a sour taste due to the offputting experience that the first game was and I had a huge smile because at that moment I knew I discovered a truly good game.

Witcher 2 delivers a really good story with interesting characters, it embraces its RPG-side, theres a lot of decision making that alters the way the story progress and similar to Mass Effect you can carry your save across games, a game mechanic I absolutely adore and wish more games used, unlike the first Witcher, this one has much better gameplay with a combat system that while it has a few issues of its own is much more entertaining, packs a lot of weight and feels satisfying, theres some issues with the targeting system and a few enemy encounters being kinda unbalanced but still I enjoyed this combat a lot, the skill tree gives a lot of options for you to build your character and I enjoyed the alchemy system, the game takes place on open-environments, 3 of them across 3 chapters and a prologue, each area was memorable to me, had a nice atmosphere and the game shines on both sound design and voice acting, soundtrack was amazing, altho the gameplay can get kinda repetitive theres a lot of intrigue on its story to keep the player attention focused on the game and who doesnt like Geralt ? he is a very likable character and theres nothing better than a game with a great protagonist, supporting cast is really good too, no complains here.

Witcher 2 may not be like the best RPG out there but It was a great experience to me and memorable at least, had a lot of enjoyable moments and after hearing so many good things about W3 I cant wait to play it, I cant wait to see how they would improve what they did with W2, I didnt really like the first Witcher game at all but I knew that the franchise had potential, I knew that this franchise was famous for a reason and I knew that some sequels truly managed to not improve the formula set by its predecessor but raise the bar and achieve that hidden potential it had and I dont regret playing W2, I enjoyed this experiencce, I am recommending it and I just cant wait to start W3 and see Geralt again.

TLDR:  Excellent role-playing game, if a bit challenging.

So, I write this a few months after The Witcher series dropped on Netflix, which seems to have sparked an interest in the series as a whole--which is good, because as a whole, the games are outstanding and Witcher 2 is no exception.

The second tale of Geralt of Rivia opens with him in service to King Foltest of Temeria. Unfolding events end with Geralt being blamed for the king's murder and the game is off and running. The game unfolds in three distinct acts, set in three different areas as Geralt keeps trying to piece his memory together and discover the identity of Foltest's actual killer.

Unlike the first Witcher game, which used a licensed Aurora Engine from Bioware, Witcher 2 was developed with CD Projekt Red's in-house engine, REDEngine, and the difference couldn't be clearer. Character animations are (for the most part) clean, smooth, and natural. Ditto facial expressions. I noticed this best in a scene where several bandits suggest vandalizing a certain relic and one character's face reflects such dismay and disbelief at the idea that I was genuinely impressed. The graphics in general are quite excellent, and an enormous step up from the first game. I think they still hold up well today.

The graphics are also quite bloody. Gameplay and cutscene alike display some rather stark violence, not to mention swearing and nudity. Hookers are available, in vivid detail. Geralt doesn't seem to be the gigolo he was in the first game and the number of possible love interests is less, though the cut scenes of...ahem..."romance" are quite a bit more intense. The (potential) liaison with a certain red-haired sorceress might be the most graphic thing I've seen in a video game that wasn't modded or outright porn from the start. As with the first Witcher, not a game for children.

The overall interface was easy enough to use and pretty simple, though the control scheme is quite a bit different from the first game. The player can select a number of skills from trees that emphasize the character's skill at combat, alchemy, or magic. There are good takeaways from every tree, though depending on the character's play style, some will help more than others. Still no jumping to be seen, so once again, Geralt is stymied by waist-high fences and shrubbery, though climbing short cliffs and ladders integrates smoothly with the character's movement.

Like most good RPGs, choices and consequences matter. Seemingly small choices made early on can have repercussions later in the game. Decisions made in the first act will even affect the flow and location of quests and events in act two and three and there are multiple ways in which this story ends, all based on player choices. Fights can be avoided through dialogue choices (or picked, if the player has a grudge against one of the NPCs) and the consequences for both are there. There is even at least one fight that can be avoided if the player played the first game, made certain decisions, and imported their save file! This branching dialogue/decision tree seems to be something CD Projekt Red is excelling at. The story is excellent and many of the cutscenes are well-executed and gripping.

The voice acting, music, and sound effects are all well done and I scarcely noticed any issues, though Geralt's stock pile of combat catch-phrases quickly grows repetitive.

The combat took some getting used to, especially after the first game. Choices between swift and strong attacks, signs, parrying and dodging, tossing bombs, drinking potions--all those tactics return. But it's significantly harder than the first game. It's not "Dark Souls difficult" but it is quite a bit harder than say, Skyrim. The player must master the art of the dodging roll to evade strikes and on anything other than Easy difficulty, must do it well. Damage taken in the back can drop Geralt in one swing if the foe is strong enough, so constant movement and re-positioning are critical and the player should never, ever let themselves get surrounded. Think tactically, keep Quen (your temporary force field) up, never stop moving, and plan your strikes. Despite the rather unforgiving nature of the combat, I found myself enjoying it and I looked forward to it every time I saw a significant fight coming.

You'll need two at least partial runs to get all the Steam Achievements, since some come from one side of the quest line, and some come from the other. I favored the human side over the elf one; not for solidarity, I just liked the quest flow better. (By the way, if you take the human side and let Hensalt live, you're a better man than me.)  I finished two play-throughs with all but one achievement done, which requires beating the game on the hardest difficulty--with permadeath. Knowing my questionable skill level and how many times I died on Normal, I didn't even try it.

There are a handful of other nitpicks. Sometimes, lining up on an object to loot it requires the player to shuffle around a little until the games "radar" picks it up and highlights it with the interaction button and mis-clicking that button can easily lead the player to exit a building or climb down a ladder when they were trying to pick something up. The dice poker minigame from the first Witcher returns and is equally as annoying--more annoying, actually.

But those are just that: nitpicks. Witcher 2 Enhanced Version is a fun RPG, with consequential choices, a deep multi-layered story, and solid gameplay. It's a few years old but no RPG fan should pass this up.

Pros
- Deep RPG experience
- Good graphics and voice acting
- Exciting combat

Cons
- Going to challenge some players
- Minor movement issues, and no jumping obstacles!

Final Score: 8.5/10

This is a great role-playing game. A good story, a dark-fantasy world, interesting quests, good combat, difficult choices, some really awesome NPCs - really enjoyed the game. There were some really small bugs but not the end of the world. Overall personal rating - 9/10

Another absolute banger of a game from CD Projekt Red. Fun game with an interesting story; my only complaint being the clunky combat system that, at times, was very frustrating.

Continuing the saga of Geralt of Rivia and his attempt to remember his past and relationship with Yennefer and Ciri, Assassins of Kings fixes several of the shortcomings of its predecessor "The Witcher" while introducing new shortcomings.

Starting with the bad: in the first title most of the decisions are very personal, with Geralt doing his best to stay out of politics. This isn't the case here. The plotline is interesting, but less personal, much more political. This is not bad in itself, but I felt like Geralt lost part of his identity.

This might be a spoiler to you, but [spoiler]you will start with Triss regardless of your choices in the previous game[/spoiler] which is quite disappointing. I felt like this could have been made better. Regardless, there are enough choices to make in this title that will have consequences (or at least small nods) in the third game.

In spite of that, the pros far outweight the cons. The game is story rich with more than enough action, a balance that most developers are still struggling to figure out, but CDProjekt Red has long mastered. Just like in the first title, you'll be forced to face moral dilemmas and try to choose the lesser evil - which kinda hurts.

The combat system (argueably the worst aspect of the first installment) improved into a proper action RPG. The RPG system was completely revamped and it is quite enjoyable too, with a myriad of combos supporting different play styles. Poker dice is back. Fistfighting and arm wrestling minigames are there too, but are very mindnumbing. No drinking contest anymore :(

Linux port was flawless - thanks for supporting the penguin! Achievements were natural and fun, encourage players to explore different paths and builds. The exception is "Madman", as permadeath is never fun to me. 

Assassin of Kings is a worthy successor of the first title, but hardly the highlight of White Wolf's trilogy. Take this as an enjoyable and necessary step towards the greatness which follows ...the Wild Hunt!

Had to use google during a boss fight, twice. A boss fight where you have to lay traps on the ground so that when you're swatted by tentacles they do the boss fight thing and you chop them off. But not if you're standing in say, the front 60 degree cone of the creature. Because the front two tentacles are immune to these traps. There's a sorceress constantly yelling at you during this fight "THE TRAPS GERALT, USE THE BLOODY TRAPS". So you stand there, trying to lure these tentacles onto traps wondering why the hell it's not working while being yelled at to use the traps that you're using! 

So, after countless reloads (Those tentacles kill you after a couple of hits) I eventually googled it and found out how the game had failed to mention crucial information. But I prevailed, and after much effort, made it to the next part of the boss battle, where you're given no direction whatsoever and the boss throws rocks that 1-hit K.O. you.

Reload, play through this tedium, 1 hit KO. Reload etc etc. Reload. Reload. Google what the fuck I'm supposed to do. Oh, just run over to the side, up a broken column and then the fight ends with a cutscene. Hooray.

I even kept playing for a bit after that, but I wasn't really invested. Turned the difficulty down to easy, since the "challenge" seemed pretty unfun. Gave up when rescuing women from a burning building and died during a QTE. And my last auto save was 15 minutes and 3 boring fights ago. (Boring, because it's you and 8 NPCs vs 8 red NPCs and the only thing epic about it is the music and the people yelling "Oh boy the stakes are really high right now, huh?")

Assassins of Kings is an underrated game overshadowed by its successor.
Cd Projekt Red managed to achieve a significant leap in quality. While I love the first the Witcher game, it was limited by Aurora Engine. The Witcher 2 seems like the first proper CD Projekt Red game from start to finish.
The story is both interesting and twisted, so, much like in its predecessor, you won't know what's really going on up until the very end of the epilogue.
Once again you have two main paths that you choose in the end of chapter I, but there are even more possible endings depending on your decision. Compared to, for example, Mass Effect games there is no clear choice between being a "good guy" or a "bad guy". Each one of your decisions may affect positively one group of people, but prove fatal to another.
One of the aspects of this game I liked the most is secondary quests. They are not only well-written, but there aren't any boring "filler" quests (kill X monsters or bring X stuff). Even the hunter contracts are a bit elaborate as they usually involve using traps/bombs or some additional action.
Well... Actually there is one quest that consists in collecting tons of harpy feathers, but it is really meant as a joke.
The biggest change compared to the first game is the combat system. Instead of a "click-click-click-kill" system the developers introduced a proper action/RPG combat that forces you to block, evade and use your signs in order to succeed. It is especially true on higher difficulty levels, which demand a high level of concentration and precise timing.
The graphics are great (the game aged really well) and the soundtrack has a lot of memorable tracks that really set the mood.
I played the Witcher 2 with original Polish voiceover  and subtitles(I did the same with the first game), because it helps me feel the atmosphere of the game world better. The voice actors of the Polish version did a great job. I'm not sure about the other versions.
My only complaint about this game is that CD Projekt Red didn't use a lot of different faces for NPCs, so there are quite a lot of them that seem like twins.
The Witcher 2 is not a long game. Especially compared to most other RPGs. I managed to finish it in about 40 hours doing all the secondary quests available on my path.
Though, I don't think it's necessarily a bad thing. Modern games tend to be too long, and, as I already mentioned earlier, The Witcher 2 has no "filler" content and no grind, so you enjoy the game from prologue till epilogue.
I definitely recommend this game not only to the Witcher fans, but to everyone who likes their role-playing games with great story and characters, but also with combat that provides some challenge.

The Witcher games are very well received. I played Witcher I Enhanced Edition but couldn't play it trough, all the long distance running and the bad combat system was just too much.

Witcher II Enhanced Edition is definitely an improvement. I enjoyed the combat system and often need to use the signs in order to win. Running around and the distances got better but still it's not very great. For example why can't I go trough bushes, why can't I cross a lake and a river from anywhere I want and opening doors is slow and frustrating. Games from 2001 were already better in that regard!

The story is told in a good manner, the side quests are also nicely made and told. Overall it's a enjoyable game but not a masterpiece. The game is also not really huge. In around 30 hrs one can be trough all the chapters.

A favorite

CD Project Red definitely stepped up their game with [i]The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings[/i] in comparison to the first installment. The first few hours of the game may put you off. You're served a huge, badly explained lore exposition, but don't be fooled by it. Everything after the introduction is juicy goodness.

The Story, narrative and direction are, just like the first installment, absolutely amazing. Environments are stunningly made, and even the minor characters that inhabit them feel alive and real. Quests often multiple solutions (with no real 'good' or 'bad' way of doing so), and these solutions often have an impact on future events. Real decision-making is definitely a thing. The audio is quasi flawless, as the voice acting has received a major upgrade, and everything else has retained its quailty from the first game. The gameplay is unfortunately not without flaw, but many of the horrendous wrinkles of The Witcher 1 have been ironed out, and it is a joy to play the game. Combat has improved with leaps, and the mechanics involving alchemy and meditation have received various QoL upgrades, making them enjoyable to use. I had a few crashes, but those were really minor setbacks in the overall experience.

9/10 Would recommend with all my heart. I'm not sure what today's price is, but if you can get this for €15 - €25 you'll be doing yourself a favor by buying it.

The game is brilliant, Combat has been improved immensely compared to the first game (where it was rather simplistic I must say) and now you really feel rewarded for skill and tactics. Besides simple swords, you now have knives you can fling during combat and all sorts of bombs - not to mention the ability to place traps so you can cleverly lure baddies towards you. All this combined makes it a real joy to engage opponents.  One little flaw compared to the first Witcher, is that you can no longer drink potions during combat which does mean that you'll often end up in a combat situation where you wish you had used a potion before-hand but since you can't predict how hard a battle will be (and a seasoned gamer will conserve potions as much as possible) it does make it feel a tad pointless. 
There seems to be a lot of running back and forth between places as the game has no quick travel, but this works well as you can herb and fight along the way. The alchemy mechanic is fantastic; you can make potions and bombs if you have the correct ingredients which are mostly collected from herbs around the game world. Crafting weapons, armour and traps is left the the smiths around the games worlds town and cities. As for drinking the potions, they each have a unique Toxicity level and if you exceed this limit there are certain side effects.
The story and setting is very fleshed out as well. The game feels very grim and more real than other RPGs in general - it's not afraid to tackle subjects such as racism, sex, politics and putting you in the middle of it all. The occasional nudity only confirms that this game doesn't hold back compared to other games. The characters have a lot of spirit as well and avoid the typical stereotypes that usually inhabit RPGs. Most characters you meet have a certain edge, a hidden agenda and aren't at all superficial. 
 Overall, An excellent game, a brilliant bridge between now and Skyrim.
Definetly the Witcher Game with the most interesting plotline and the best at engaging with the inherent politics of the Witcher Universe.

Coming from The Witcher 1, the gameplay of this becomes more of an ARPG instead of CRPG.

Being an ARPG now instead of CRPG is not exactly a bad thing. In fact I enjoyed it as much as the Witcher 1 both in gameplay and story. In The Witcher 2 you now have a stamina bar which is very different from the first game, the gameplay now becomes more action packed and makes the encounters a bit more challenging. However, The Witcher 2 didn't exactly improve some aspects from the previous game, especially for me who incredibly enjoyed the Fistfight and Dice Poker. In this game those, at least for me, became lamer. The Fistfights are now QTEs instead of actually fighting your opponent and as for the Dice Poker, the NPC's odds are better than yours. From an article I saw online "the system that calculates the dice values is modified to favour the NPC, with the NPC having a greater probability of getting a better hand than the player", the NPC is basically cheating which makes Dice Poker frustrating to play in this game combined with it's confusing UI.

Besides that, everything is great I just really didn't like that the minigames became lamer. Also if you have a Witcher 1 save file, some of the items you have from the previous game can be transferred here which is really nice, makes the game feel more connected, unlike Witcher 3.
If you love The Witcher 3, you should play this one as well. The combat may feel harder, but the graphic is wonderful and sex scenes are crazy!

Great RPG game, with a decent level of difficulty and emphasis on story, characters and dialogue.  Even though the game is quite old now, the graphics are still top notch, and demanding on today's hardware.

*On a quest*

Healer: "If you are here for the syphilis treatment, then you will have to wait in line.."
Geralt: "That's not what I am here for, [i]this time[/i]."

Dialogue, paraphrased from memory, act 2.

In act 2 the game is pretty good, act 1 is so-so. Act 3, however, is annoying (maze where you have to click to get through a door every 5 seconds).

So Witcher 3 is definitely the better game. This one has not aged well, some of the problems: 
- Annoying quick time events, 
- clunky combat handling (you will often get stuck on invisible barriers and die), 
- a pretty unstable game in general (got several crashes or once I could not open the menu any more and had to kill the game and restart..) 
- you cannot even drop down a small step - you have to click to do it,
- if you want to pick up loot after a fight, you have to wait 5 seconds, because the game needs to get out of "combat mode" to switch the left mouse button from hitting to picking up.

The only positives are the characters with their very good voice acting, and to some degree the story-telling.

The game's main story revolves around the player's character, the Dragonborn, on their quest to defeat Alduin the World-Eater, a dragon who is prophesied to destroy the world. The game is set 200 years after the events of Oblivion and takes place in Skyrim, the northernmost province of Tamriel. Over the course of the game, the player completes quests and develops the character by improving skills. The game continues the open-world tradition of its predecessors by allowing the player to travel anywhere in the game world at any time, and to ignore or postpone the main storyline indefinitely.

Not so far through the game, only done approx 15 hours. However there is a glaring and horrendous error and it comes in the form of difficulties. 
If you want to play for the story, which i am assuming most of the "very positive reviews" on Steam were based on then do so on easy mode. Its a great story, great characters, and incredible improvement from the first game.
But even moving up to normal mode, makes this game incredibly hard. I managed to reach the end of chapter 1 on Normal, and had to change to easy. The difference was as follows:
Enemy Damage dealt on Normal: 41, included bleed effect for 3-4 seconds which was another 10 health per second. Thats basically half of your health if you are hit once, which is pretty unforgiving due to the "clonky controls" (which i still love).
Enemy Damage dealt on Easy: 7, rarely inflicted "bleeding" and i could string an attack together that didnt consist of three blows before a half arsed role away before being poked in the rear by his sword. 
I would still recommend this game, i just cant help but feel there is no gratuity playing on easy but anything other makes the game a total sweat fest.

Political intrigues, mysteries and blood: this is the core of the second adventure for the witcher Geralt. A story that will undisclose all the fragile political mechanisms of the Northern Realms, and will change the sorts of the world as we knew it in the first game.
Unlike the predecessor, this second game has a more straightforward structure, but also a very high branching factor for what concerns the possible choiches that can be made during the main quest.

This game was very ahead of it's time in a lot of respects and is still a great game to play. I played back when it first released and coming back post updates is a really treat with all the neat little tweaks they have made over time. It's still difficult and encourages using traps and potions, but you should be able to plan around any big problems you will have if you plan ahead. The core story is still a great treat and it does really stand out how different chapter 2 can be with your different choices. This is what Bioware games always wanted to be in a lot of respects and it's a great RPG to boot. Still have some glitches and some wonky pathfinding, but that's to be expected from this generation of games.

Great game nice story mode

This is a great improvement over The Witcher 1.  Its story is more interesting, the characters are a little bit more fleshed out, the animations are more dynamic, the voice acting is better, and the gameplay isn't as dated.  The first one had a rhythmic combat style where you just had to click at different intervals depending on they style of combat you are using, instead of that it incorporates a better more action oriented combat scheme where you can dodge and use fast attacks and strong attacks to react differently to different attacks.  The skill tree is a lot more involved and interesting with more interesting skills allowing you to make more interesting and differing builds.  Although this story was more interesting since I had finished the first game, it provided a lot of background on many of the characters.

[h1]Genre: RPG[/h1]

Witcher 2 is a game where Lord of the Rings meets Game of Thrones, except it takes [spoiler]100 hits to kill the dragon, and not just 3 arrows.[/spoiler] It has elves, it has dwarfs, it has politics, betrayal and of course sex scenes and a lot of boobs. Humans are the most dominant race, dwarfs and elves are living among them, however they don't really have same rights. So that's why there is Scoia'tael, organization of nonhumans trying to cause civil war, or stuff like that, and fight for their rights. It's basically USA in 18th and 19th century. Now let's get to basics. 

First of all, story. Story is good. You play as witcher, Geralt of Rivia. He has lost his memory and he is trying to recover it. You work as bodyguard for the king Foltest of Temeria. Game starts with civil war, and before that there is sex scene, cause there are 2 things that Geralt knows to do. He does killing and he does women. In Witcher universe, there are 5 important kingdoms, 4 at north and 1 at south, which is bigger than all these 4 together. There are few important choices, but I would say that only two choices are really important, because depending on those choices you will get 2 completelly different games. Sometimes you have only few seconds to choose, sometimes more. Story is good, but I can't say that I've found many other interesting characters. Main villain is pretty cool, Geralt is cool, but not many others.

Now gameplay. Gameplay is okay, it's not bad, but it's not that good either. Geralt has 2 swords, steel sword for men, and silver sword for beats. He can cast 5 signs. Aard - stun, Yrden - trap, Igni - fire, Quen - shield(the most powerful one), Axii - control opponent and Heliotrop which you must develope. I played this game on hard, it wasn't really hard game, but without Quen it would be way harder. I didn't feel like not using Quen since it's in game, but that shield is really OP, so I started feeling like with Quen, Witcher 2 is easy, especially after leveling up a bit. You can activate Quen as soon as you have enough vigor(autogenerate or with potion) and when activated you can take one hit without taking damage, so basically every 10 or so seconds you can activate Quen. It's extremly useful. Except Quen, Aard and Igni are useful too, and Yrden sometimes(Igni is crap in Witcher 3). Before big battles, or whenever you want, you must prepare for battle, by making potions and using them and those potions you make from herbs that you find around, and they increase your attack damage, renegerate vitality etc. When killing monsters you will get your loot, that you can use to craft stuff, or just sell. During whole game, I had a lot of problems with inventory, cause I would fill it up quickly. 

Bosses. First boss was interesting, but the second boss fight was terribly hard for no reason, it was too early in the game and the hardest boss fight in the game, it requires a lot of attacking and dodging in the small place. It's pretty boring fight that gives you little space to make a mistake, I don't mind challenge, but this wasn't fun challenge. Same goes for boss before last, and that one can one shot you, and you have to hit boss like 50+ times, before you reach second phase. Other boss fights are okay. I wouldn't say that Witcher 2 has good boss fights, but they aren't terrible either.

Graphics are good even today. I've heard that Ubersampling kills FPS so it's suggested to turn it off). Music during intro cutscene is indredible, and later on soundtracks are nice. Problem is, it's kinda buggy game. I encountered singleplayer lag, which I've never seen before in my life, where I hit some enemy once and then 2 seconds later it got hit once more and then once more without me doing anything. Random stuff like that happens sometimes. Also interrogation at the beginning really feels like it's off sync. 

Witcher 2 is a linear game, which is probably problem for a lot of people, but not for me. I've always liked games that are more focused on story anyway. When you reach some city or village during main quest, you have one big area that you can wander around, where you can loot stuff, do side quests, buy stuff,  etc. However when you reach part of main story where you must leave area, all side quests will no longer be available and you can't travel back. There is no fast travel here. Chapter 1 is really interesting and pretty good, chapter 2 is the longest one, but I would say less interesting and chapter 3 is just closure. Took me 26 hours to finish the game, while barely playing side stuff.

[h1]Verdict:[/h1] Pretty good story, okay gameplay, good graphics even for today's standards, meh boss fights, and slightly buggy game. Story is focused on one thing, unlike in Witcher 3, and I've found that pretty good. It's pretty good game overall.

[i]Note: This explains how I rate games in my reviews. https://imgur.com/gallery/z9ZjA47[/i]

[h1]Personal rating: 7.5/10[/h1]

Within my first hour of playing The Witcher 2: Assasins of Kings Enhanced Edition I was beaten up by the town drunk. By the end of the almost 70 hours I spent with it, I was sizing up a trio of bandits with a smirk on my real-life face, knowing even together they were no match for my steel and the extensive training I’d received under some of the toughest knights in this beautifully recreated medieval land. This wasn’t merely a change in stats and equipment. Without a single spell or magic sword, Kingdom Come gave me the abundantly satisfying feeling of transforming from doe-eyed scrub to stone-cold killer.
Warhorse’s tale of tribulation and betrayal shines brightest in the little ways it sells the fantasy of living in the Late Middle Ages. Not only are there survival mechanics that track hunger and fatigue, but every aspect of your character’s appearance has an impact on how NPCs perceive you. The biggest example is how clothes will accumulate wear and trail dust as you traipse through the wilderness, leaving nobles less than impressed with your scruffiness.

NPCs' reactions to your appearance extend beyond BO simulation.

This required me to frequently take baths, visit the laundry, and have my outerwear mended by a tailor to make a good impression. Keeping relatively clean isn’t a chore because bathhouses are easy to find, and you can always dunk your head in the nearest trough of water in a pinch. This extends beyond BO simulation: if, for example, you’re trying to be sneaky, wearing clothes that don’t make noise when you move and are dark in color to blend in with the shadows decreases your chances of being detected. Likewise, walking into an inn covered in blood with a sword drawn is a good way to intimidate people into seeing things your way.

All of this takes place in a large chunk of wooded, medieval Bohemia that shows significant attention to detail and is filled with little historical touches that help it feel like a real place. Towns, farms, and logging camps are all laid out with a strong internal logic and built on a scale that makes sense for a real place, as opposed to the standard RPG city in a game like Skyrim that’s designed to feel large, but really isn’t. And there are no loading screens between areas anywhere unless you’re using fast travel, which I always appreciate quite a bit in open-world games.

The fantasy breaks down a bit too frequently under the weight of bugs, though. Some are of the goofy, largely unobtrusive sort you’d expect from an open-world game of this size, like a shopkeeper’s head loading in after the rest of their body. But others are less of a laughing matter because they got in the way of gameplay in significant ways. There seems to be a tendency for staircases to randomly decide, “You shall not pass!” and moving between areas of different elevation in general too often results in getting hung up on invisible walls or even stuck entirety.

Worse, a handful of quests in the second and third acts had either broken triggers or missing quest markers, sometimes requiring me to backtrack to a save I made an hour or more ago and choose a different path through a mission to avoid the roadblock. That’s not unusual for a big RPG, but it’s exacerbated by the fact that just about the only ways to save in Kingdom Come are drinking a rare, expensive type of alcohol or sleeping at an inn or brothel. Autosaves are unforgivingly infrequent. Crashes were rare, but when they did happen the autosave system sometimes set me back just as far.

The combat behind it all feels kinetic, precise, and polished.

To Kingdom Come’s credit, the actors, scenery, and textures do look fantastic on the highest detail level – but unless you have an extremely beefy system, you probably won’t be able to enjoy it that way. The PC version (which I’ve played on exclusively so far) isn’t particularly well optimized. To maintain a stable framerate in all situations, I had to turn down the graphics settings to the point where low level-of-detail models would remain in the scene for certain people and objects for a couple seconds even when I got up close, which was distracting. My PC (a Core i7-4770K with a GTX 1070) can run The Witcher 3 smoothly with everything cranked up, which made this especially surprising.

Luckily, the combat behind it all feels kinetic, precise, and polished. There is a significant learning curve, but I’ve found it to be a lot of fun the more I got the hang of it. Warhorse’s designers seem to have struck the right balance between realism and practicality. Sword fights have a nice tempo and reward technical skill, quick thinking, and most of all patience. Over time, I got the same feeling I experience when I’m starting to master a new shooter or real-time strategy game. My character became a force to be reckoned with because I mastered the systems, not necessarily because my strength stat kept increasing.

The realism extends to the sorts of trade-offs you have to make for certain gear, which added some interesting strategy elements. Plate armor (in addition to making you stick out like a bear in a seafood restaurant as mentioned above) is very expensive to maintain and counts against your encumbrance, so a scrawny character can't even safely wear a full set. Full-face helmets protect better against often deadly headshots, but restrict your field of view and make it more difficult to keep track of multiple enemies. My gear choices were often as much based on what made logical sense for the situation as what offered the best stats, which was another welcome departure from the standard RPG playbook.

Mounted combat feels like an afterthought – ironic, considering the studio’s name.

A few parts of the combat system don’t work all that well, though. I never got any good at the fiddly archery system, but thankfully, I was never forced to. Mounted combat also feels like an afterthought, in that it’s functional but clearly not something Warhorse spent much time refining (ironic, considering the studio’s name).

The story is gritty, engrossing, and complex, though it tends to fall back on some old-fashioned ideas of medieval historiography in a couple of places. Notably, the Cumans, a nomadic Turkic people from the Western steppe, are treated as token foreigners at times and faceless, Stormtrooper-esque bad guy mooks at others. Characters go well out of their way to refer to them constantly as “barbaric” or “savage” – which is certainly how most of the native Bohemians would have seen them. But without ever being given any indication that it’s not that simple (literally every Cuman I met was an enemy who couldn't be reasoned with), it comes across as trying to paint the shades of complexity that made up relations between steppe and settled societies in this era as purely black and white.

By and large, Kingdom Come does the medieval era right.

Verdict
There’s a shining suit of mail underneath Kingdom Come: Deliverance’s authentically medieval grime. Strong characters and storytelling, one of my favorite first-person melee combat systems ever, and special attention given to building moment-to-moment immersion come together as a mighty alloy that ranks among the most unique, memorable RPGs I’ve played in years. While a lack of technical polish occasionally caused me a good deal of frustration having to replay areas due to a bug or poorly-communicated quest objective, it’s the kind of adventure I didn’t hate replaying

Another strong entry into the series.

The storytelling, writing and characters are as good as ever, and a worthy sequel to the first game. 

Negatives: combat is still rather awkward, and I'm not sure about the quick-time cut scenes. The Tutorial is laboured and introduces mechanics not used at the start of the game. Conversely some things are not well explained, like some of the mini-games like arm-wrestling. Finally, some quests deposit you a ways outside of town, requiring minutes of backtracking, although sometimes you're given the option to fast travel back into town.

Nevertheless you can tell that Projekt Red were learning in the process, and if the Witcher 3 is anything to go by, they learned their lessons. I look forward to playing the final part of the series!

[h1]General[/h1]
This was my first Witcher game. I liked it a lot for the plot, many optional quests (sometimes affecting the main ones), a couple of future-impacting choices during the whole game. I rather liked how the characters were drawn (especially their beards and mustaches, though, not their hair, unfortunately). The game has a pretty soundtrack, but the main theme starts annoying towards the end. And I was pleasantly surprised about the fight mechanics quality (remark: it was pretty cool when playing with a mouse and a keyboard. I didn't like playing with a game controller, though I'm not sure this is a game issue, probably it was uncomfortable for me just because it was an unusual experience for me)
[h1]Technical issues[/h1]
Unfortunately, there were some technical issues. Here are the most important of them to me:
- [b]Impossible[/b] to play [b]on Linux[/b]. Though developers claim that the game should run on Linux well, it does not. When playing on Windows I get 30 to 60 FPS in the game on Ultra presets. When playing on latest up-to-date Linux Mint 20 (based on Ubuntu 20.04) with the latest GPU drivers (nvidia-driver-450), I can only get about 15-20 fps on all the graphics quality presets.
- After playing the game for a while and creating some saves, I started having the saves list being loaded slowly. It didn't really affect the game experience, but it was a bit unpleasant to wait each time I wanted to load a specific save
- More time later the game started crashing! Fortunately, this was happening rather rarely, but there were some times when it crashed right before I was going to save, so it was upsetting me a bit. I'm certainly sure that this problem relates to saves too: the game won't crash unless I load saves, and it will crash very soon if I reload the game many times in a row (for example, when fighting with a boss). But this will also happen if I remove a couple of sets in a row, so I think the problem is in the saves list loading (probably something like a memory leak)
[hr][/hr]
But even considering all the issues above, I definitely do recommend this game ([b]unless you're going to play on Linux[/b]), because the gameplay itself was very cool and the technical issues couldn't ruin my experience

Years after they were released, I'm making my way through the Witcher games. After struggling through the first one (which, in 2020, is really showing its age - though it was fun enough to finish it) I came to the Witcher 2. This game is a huge step in almost every way. It looks great, the controls are much better. Witcher 1 sure was a lot bigger, at the expense of certain areas feeling like a slog. Witcher 2 is much more concise, maybe even a little bit too concise - except for the fact that you must play this game twice to get everything out of it.

I don't necessarily recommend Witcher 1 to everyone wanting to pick the games (most notably, Witcher 3). But this one is a lot of fun and feels much more modern. Go play it, and then continue on to Witcher 3 for the full experience.

About half of the game is great. The other half is a boring slog. 

The combat is incredibly dated: floaty, janky, unresponsive and unsatisfying, its difficulty spikes at random parts. The story is hard to follow and not very good: most characters are not built upon enough at all. I didn't enjoy any of the side missions: I did all of them in chapters 1 and 2, but just rushed to the end in the third chapter after so many disappointments.  

It's a shame. The Witcher 2 is a very atmospheric game. The art style is fantastic, the mood is gripping, and the graphics are top notch for 2011. Even the music is incredible. But the experience hinders on the frustrating gameplay systems, awful combat, boring and ambiguous quests, sluggish world traversal, and tedious backtracking. 

I played this with a lot of prior knowledge of the Witcher series world and to get ready to play The Witcher 3. After 10 hours of the third installment, it's already immediately spectacular, and what this game should've been. For comparison, I really enjoyed Mass Effect 1, so it's not like I detest older RPGs. Still, if you can look past Witcher 2's flaws there's definitely value to be found here. It's a very ambitious game, but the developers lacked the time, management and resources to make it work. Fortunately those were provided for the next game in the series.

[i]The Witcher 2[/i] might be impressive both as a technical accomplishment and in terms of its branching, complex narrative, but I cannot for the life of me understand the hype surrounding it.

Following the events of the previous title, players once more step into the shoes of that infamous witcher, Geralt of Rivia. Framed for the murder of King Foltest, he must go on the run to clear his name and bring the murderer responsible, another witcher by the name of Letho to justice. At first blush, it's honestly a pretty hefty, serious affair. Players are immediately submerged into a world of medieval realpolitik and clashing ideologies. Between the nonhuman factions vying for equal treatment, the political machinations of those aiming for power, and the not-insubstantial lore of the game, it's easy to get overwhelmed by the ups and downs of the game's plot. Thankfully, though, the core of the experience is simple: you are a witcher, and you slay monsters. At the end of the day, everything else is secondary. In fact, treating Geralt as a tradesman who's gotten involved in matters way over his head actually makes the game's plot vastly more engaging.

The game is divided up into chapters, each of which acts as a hub zone from which players can venture out to partake in various quests and monster-slaying contracts. And it's here that the cracks begin to show because [i]The Witcher 2[/i] absolutely [i]loves[/i] withholding critical information. One early quest requires Geralt to track down a bookshop to research a type of monster; however, the game refuses to give any kind of direction as to the shop's location, nor the eventual monsters' nest. And this is endemic to the whole game's design - from spells to lore to basic combat mechanics, [i]The Witcher 2[/i] routinely expects the player to intuit the correct path forward. (This apparently was even worse in older editions of the game, which lacked any kind of tutorial.)

This might be forgivable if the game was fun to play, but alas, [i]The Witcher 2[/i] has maybe the single worst combat system in an action RPG I've ever seen. Geralt's swings feel weightless as he manages both his casting resources and his health; though the game offers potion-making and mechanical buffs to the player, they are completely barred off during combat, and in characteristic style for [i]The Witcher 2[/i], the game adores ambushing unaware players. Furthermore, the enormous hitboxes and lack of any i-frames when Geralt dodges make the nitty-gritty of combat feel arbitrary. More often than not, it felt like I cheesed my way through encounters rather than reaching victory through careful observation and precision timing.

Even the writing begins to wear thin after a while. Though the game wields a certain verisimilitude to its dialogue and politics, the artificiality of the experience often exposes itself in awkward times. From hamfisted references to other media (The "Oh My God! You Killed the Kayran! You Bastards!" achievement and the early Assassin's Creed reference in the prologue are both particularly egregious examples.) to the sarcastic dryness of the dialogue to the decidedly painful sex scenes, it feels like [i]The Witcher 2[/i] is trying to look more mature than it is. However, my frustration is really cemented in the handful of truly bad writing choices the game makes, choices which undermine the game's larger themes. For example, should you take Iorveth's path-line in Chapter 2 of the game, you'll find yourself on a quest to recover noble's blood because the blood of a royal is allegedly stronger than the common folk. It's an openly dumb plot-point in a game that is otherwise pretty anti-royalist in its leanings.

There are [i]some[/i] things in the [i]The Witcher 2[/i] that are worthwhile. The visuals, despite being close to a decade old, still look excellent, due in large part to superb art direction. The music is great, and when the writing and the choices offered to the player work in unison, the results are very entertaining. (The fact that the game has [i]two[/i] separate second chapters that players will experience based on choices that they make is frankly astounding.) But the sad bottom line is that [i]The Witcher 2[/i] just isn't very much fun to play. It makes some bold, demanding requests of the player, and the sheer tolerance players need to have for mechanical malarkey is high to get the most out of the experience. CRPG fans with a deep love for punishing and arcane titles will no doubt find something here worth diving into; however, for more casual CRPG fans or for those looking for an experience that synthesizes the mechanics of play with narrative elegantly, look elsewhere.

I finally got around to finishing this game and have finished the first Witcher game a while ago.  This absolutely was a better game and is well worth the current full price of ~$20.  Get it on sale for cheap and it is an absolute steal.  You could blaze through it in maybe 20-30 hours if you wanted to, but I encourage you to take your time and enjoy the experience.

This is a true role-playing experience.  It almost seems like a novel adventure in that your choices matter and lead you to different sides, different paths, and different consequences depending on what you choose. The combat, magic, and crafting is there to enhance the story you are playing out.  

Would I like a more open design? Sure, but don't let that stop you from having a great time with a superb setting, cast of characters, and more depth than most games dig into in today's game designing world.

Having played the first Witcher game just before beginning The Witcher 2, I was so pleasantly surprised by the leap in graphics and gameplay from that to this (although I did very much enjoy the first game). The combat is fun and refined; it never feels clunky and stays true to what you'd believe Geralt the witcher could pull off. The world feels fuller and grander. The characters and the voice acting are improved as well, of course, serving to better immerse the player into their stories. A certain elf rebel leader certainly caught my eye. I love that some aspects of your playthrough in the first game carry through to its sequel, and I see that also applied to the Witcher 3, which I shall be going into promptly! It's a very enjoyable experience overall, and still worthy of being played in 2020.

Well, well, Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings was a necessary stop in my Witcher marathon before starting the Witcher 3. The first thing I will say is this: I urge any players considering playing this game to have played Witcher 1 or at least watched or read a thorough synopsis. While the Witcher 3 heavily distanced itself from its predecessors, The Witcher 2 basked in its status as a sequel. After completing the Witcher 3, I can confidently say that this game im key in understanding the world of the third game. The Witcher 2 is responsible for setting up the political climate of the Witcher 3. Aside from its relationship from the third game, The Witcher 2 is probably the most unique, but mixed game in the trilogy. Here are some pros and cons:

Pros:
-The Witcher 2 possesses a strong amount of replayability thanks to the split path system. 
-The signs in The Witcher 2 are far more balanced than Witcher 1 or even 3 for that matter
-Witcher 2 Geralt has the most loyal appearance to the books in comparison to horseface-Geralt of Witcher 1 or Hot-Geralt from Witcher 3
-The Witcher 2's story kept me on my feet. Besides the droning woods of Flotsam, I was generally kept busy and anticipating new developments in the game. Dull moments were few and far between.
-While the swordplay is still imperfect thanks to jank like inaccurate syncing of choreography and damage-boxes, it is a much needed improvement over The Witcher 1

Cons:
-There are a nearly endless supply of continuity errors that come from the radically different events in the Roche vs Iorveth paths
-The game possesses a sort of burnt quality in its presentation. There is almost a strange saturation of orange wherever you go
-Some of the actions that Geralt can do such as holding Henselt at the end of a sword in the Iorveth path don't keep up to his character at all
-The game honestly places you at the divergence of paths WAY too early (end of chapter 1). The literal few interactions that you have with Vernon Roche and Iorveth before this point make deciding difficult, not because they are so unbelievably compelling, but mostly because you don't know a thing about them. 
-Geralt's amnesia is one of the most frustrating plot devices I've seen. The fact that he suddenly recovers entirely from one conversation with Letho at the very end is unconvincing at best and downright lazy at worst. It feels like CDPR barely remembered that he had amnesia in the first game but realized that they couldn't flat out retcon it so instead they just say "he's cured" to tie loose ends.
-The UI is clearly console-oriented, leaving an unoptimized and time-wasting experience for PC gamers
-The cryptic secret perks don't work to the game's benefit. Most of them feel unearned and a well-versed player like myself didnt even know of their existence until I beat the game.

In conclusion, The Witcher 2 was an extremely ambitious project that brought CDPR into the mainstream. Ultimately, I would say the game bit off more than it could chew. Still, this game is essential for any gamer who wants a complete experience in the Witcher 3. Although this game hasn't stood against the test of time very well, it still holds its own place as the game that shifted the environment of the Witcher. It acted as a transition from the highly-fantasized, even somewhat cartoonish world of the Witcher 1 into the gritty, morally complicated world of the Witcher 3. I believe that the Witcher 2 truly was an improvement from the first game in most aspects. For this reason I find it to be a good sequel.
