G A M E G O O D

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings was not the biggest hit back in 2011. While it garnered sales and praise at its release, it hasn't been consistently mentioned like other games from that year (Uncharted 2: Among Thieves, Batman: Arkham City, Battlefield 3), which is unfortunate, because the game is really good. This game is impressive even still to this day, with some caveats, obviously. But something the game succeeds immensely with is the immersion into the world. It feels lived in and like it could exist in a real place (ignoring the magical factors). The huge trees surrounding Flotsam, the warm beaches and mountains of Aedirn, and the ravished ruins of Loc Muinne creates an inviting motion to the surroundings. The music also helps invest the player in the world, which is bombastic during battle, and hauntingly somber during conversations and slower moments. Even though the character presentation is at best decent, the environments are truly epic, which also translates to the story. The intriguing narrative is focused and ambitious, yet clever and self aware. Playing as Geralt of Rivia hunting down the assassin of King Foltest, Letho, is riveting from start to finish. The story is so good much thanks to the characters. Geralt of Rivia is an all out bad ass, while Vernon Roche is a cunning operator. Dandelion brings in comedic effect with his funny remarks and King Henselt brings in darkness with his tragic family drama. Even the side-quests have some level of depth, not always being as straight forward as you might initially think. The game is based around you the choices make, which unlike most games actually have huge impacts on the narrative. You might never see certain characters or view people differently depending on the actions of Geralt, and it helps make your actions have more weight to them. Even though the ending might occur in the same place, the journey there and the character's positions might differ hugely. The writing is immaculate and impressive, captivating the player and not making the narrative too hard to follow. The only confusing part might be character's names if you haven't played the first game, but if you read the extensive journal, you'll be quickly caught up, and stuck in the game's politics. The only big issue I have with the story is the final boss, which fizzels out disappointingly, however you choose to play. It neither feels rewarding, nor impressive, but that's solely because of the build-up to that moment (during the epilogue). But that's a small nit pick, because afterwards it feels satisfying, and worth the time to get there, it's more about the build-up to the fight. When it comes to gameplay, it's a bit of a mixed bag. All the content is existent, from responsive combat, to dialogue choices, to preparation before battles (from potions and oils), it ties in with the character of the Witcher really well. The problem arises when it comes to execution. Character's might bug to actions, your character get's stuck in the environment sometimes, and brewing portions and oils is confusing at times, much cause from the questionable user interface. Even though the game world isn't massive, it could've helped with fast travel when traversing back to main areas, or level design could've been improved to make it go faster. I don't hate the gameplay, I quite like it actually, it's just rough around the edges and there's room for improvement. The game truly shines in it's writing and world-building, which raises it above some of it's rivals in the genre. The game just sucks you in, and keeps you engaged all the time. While the game lacks in polished gameplay, it makes up for in interesting character's and the interactions between them. It might not be Skyrim, but it's still damn good and worth your time.

I can't really recommend this game for various reasons but I'll make a list of positives and negatives anyway. 

I played it on blind run on Dark difficulty without any guide because the gameplay looked promising for a tactical fighting style I wanted to explore by myself but got hugely disappointed. This game is really frustrating to play at high difficulties, and I say it as a Dark Souls veteran.

Positive:
+ Graphics have aged ok and are still somewhat enjoyable, surely better than the first witcher game.
+ Lore follows the style of Andrzej Sapkowski, author of the books. Even how events unfold, how characters play, it's all pretty much accurate with what the books have to offer. No big changes, even the plot made by CD Project Red to expand the story doesn't drift away from the initial intent in my opinion.
+ Good RPG elements to explore different paths and interactions.
+ Aesthetic monster variety.

Negative:
- I'll start from the main problem with this game: the combat system. Developers' intention was to make a realistic fighting game with multiple options and strategy to handle a variety of enemies in different situations. The problem is they failed horribly. There are some magical abilities that use the statistics "VIGOR" which, for some reason, is shared with the ability to PARRY enemy attacks. It means that, especially in the first half of the game, you are forced to choose between vigor to abuse of your spells or try to parry. Guess which one has less risks? 

The main tactic you want to use is to cast QUEN (a shield that protects from damage) then proceed to hit and roll away. Always. This is because there is no way to know if your opponent is going to deflect your sword hit, leaving you extremely vulnerable. This feature gets even more frustrating when an army of enemies surrounds you, you just end up being gangbanged without any chance of retalation JUST BECAUSE YOU ATTEMPTED A BASIC BLOW. If it's not abusing of QUEN, you just roll around spamming Aard trying to get a lucky stun on enemy to execute a deathblow. Just be sure to roll again after that because your position changes after it without being able to control it.

Furthermore there are several animations for your attacks but you have no control over which one Geralt is going to perform. Some attacks leap and are slower, others more straightforward, but you are vulnerable while attacking and therefore you just get punished by enemies even if you are choosing the right frame to attack. But let's assume you want to parry: I thought it would have had a similar mechanic to the most recent batman, making you somewhat invulnerable when performing the parry. But no, you can do it perfectly on an enemy but then the others might just continue attacking, punishing you for performing the right parry. Absolutely counterintuitive for the sake of a realism which doesn't hold anyway in other situations. 

The game offers you the option to craft traps and bombs to help you in these situations. The problem is that they don't become an aid, they become your main strategy to just spam bombs to keep hordes of enemies busy instead of being a supplement to your sword style. Huge downgrade from The first witcher which was a hack and slash which at least could be fun. 

Game of hit and run and roll as the best strategy, instead of a dancing fighter abusing of parries and different combos on the battlefield. I suspect the developers didn't even test it themselves because I can't believe they purposefully made it this bad.

- Bugs in the hitboxes, invisible walls, unclear interactions. Sometimes spells won't hit because enemies are on a hill or you'll get stuck in the terrain trying to roll. Especially in one optional boss fight in Chapter III. These make the combat system even more frustrating.

- Inventory is extremely confusing, the diagram system unclear cause it goes by alphabetical order and not categories. Either you remember what you wanted to craft or you gotta go through the list of recipes to find it. Let's not mention how annoying it is to deposit crafting materials at the inn and going to a blacksmith just to discover you missed 1 ingredient in the box, why not make the blacksmith show you all your ingredients even if you don't have them in your inventory? It's not like the blacksmiths can be found outside cities so there would be no hidden advantage in that.

- General annoying bugs with hitboxes and interactions but nothing gamebreaking.

Buy it if you really love the series but do not bother with the high difficulties unless you are a completionist.

Absolutely worth buying. You do end up spending a lot of time running around in towns and cities, hunting down whoever you need to talk to, but the story is excellent, combat system is solid and characters are interesting.

Mixed review but overall good if played for story online - very glitchy (at least once every few hours). Average gameplay. Difficulties are not well tuned as normal is very hard (in an unfair way) and easy is too easy. And I don't even want to say anything about the other 3 difficulty options higher than normal. Combat can be boring as you often have to resort to certain abuse to win eg. exploiting the stupid AI. Enemies are hard to kill so it can be very tedious. 

Story is very awesome with 2 major branches that are very very different from each other. Excellent cutscenes, voice acting, It has nice flow to the story that makes you want to play more except the first chapter in Flotsam where it felt too slow. Some sidequests are good (although not on the level of Witcher 3) and some are typical fetch/destroy certain number of enemies quest which are a chore to do. Dungeons are nothing really special and some can be tedious. 

Settings - Nice atmosphere, very colourful. The world is nice and small but has some good memorable locations. It is not open world but the small maps with every corner being different works really well. Music is average and forgettable. 

Overall verdict - Play for story and enjoying the world only, do not expect anything else or else you will be disappointed.

Overall its as almost as good as The Witcher 3, but go in with a open mind and you will have as much fun as I did. DO NOT play on the hardest difficulty, unless you are a Dark Souls fan. Play on normal if you are familiar with this style of game or easy if you never played a game like this. Overall its worth your time, I recommend to wait to get it on sale though. I no longer feel comfortable supporting CD Projekt Red.

After becoming more and more aware of crunch practises within the company along with increasingly hostile attitudes towards the LGBTQ community, I feel I must use what little power of expression I have to speak out.

I have been a long standing fan of the Witcher series and for all my fond memories of wonderful moments from these games I want to say thank you devs :). 

But I am also a Trans Woman and i have seen the harm that trans-phobia causes first hand. The fear, the abuse, the uncertainty. Innocent people expressing themselves for who they truly are only to be beaten down mentally or worse out right murdered simply for existing. 

The attitude at CD Projekt Red is ugly. In promotions for Cyberpunk 2077 they used imagery of an overly sexual trans woman, to garner attention whilst failing to show any trans characters with actual depth (wish they treated us trans people as people and not as objects of sexual fascination) . 

Then in their customisation menu your gender is tied to your voice (what a load of rubbish). It also pushes a gender binary model, not merely ignorantly, but clearly deliberately. This is clear as i understand it because they allow characters to choose their genitals ( even allowing you to have none if you so wish) and yet still demand that someone must conform to being a he or she. This stinks of trans-phobia. Mocking those trans people who are questioning their identity or identify as non-binary, gender fluid and non conforming. Its also made worse by the fact this all happened following promises of allowing gender diversity with character customisation.

I am used to not being represented in any way in any game. Unfortunately being mocked for simply existing is something many trans people have to put up with. But this is a direct attack against the trans community, wrapped up in a flashy game. It goes out of its way to define gender on its own terms, setting up damaging barriers that can easily be used by hate filled groups or individuals to persecute trans people who many people like to ignore are very real human beings! 

PEOPLE.... PEOPLE JUST LIKE YOU! 

REAL PEOPLE!

REAL LIVES!

Cyberpunk 2077 may be a game. CD Projekt may just make games. But trans-phobia is not a game! Its very real and people lose their lives over it! No game is worth that.


#StandWithTrans

#BoycottCyberpunk2077
Good game

I finally got through the game after a 7-year slog that involved lots of leaving the game unplayed and then coming back to only to find myself getting bored or frustrated.  Quests are incredibly tedious. I think it ended up worth it to get to know geralt and his gang to more thoroughly enjoy witcher 3 which was really the goal.

That said, there is some greatness here in-between the tedium.  The prologue is amazing, and I enjoyed act 2 for what it was.  THe characters are great as is Geralt himself.  I enjoy the choices you can make in the game, it looked good and had good atmosphere.  Not sure it holds up today, and the quests are as i said incredilby tedious, but if you like this type of game it's a good one.

Honestly i don't think the game is awful or unplayable, but i feel i could've not played it and it all been about the same.

Firstly this game seemed to be around the time things tried to be cinematic, endless motion blur, lettbox format options so you can see about 1/15th of the screen so the bluured images look really nice and cinematic. So after turning all of that down/off the game doesn't look awful, but certain aspects remained.
The camera tries to pick good looking angles alot more than useful ones; or sometimes as part of starting a scene the game will pan the camera in before giving you control, or it follows you through a dooway as you politely walk through it no matter the situation.
I disliked the camera because alot of times i'd get attacked before i had really regained my controls.

Combat and basic mode are somewhat detached meaning alot of basic controls are locked depending on which mode you're in, this means if you wanna grab something and go, thats not an option if you're in combat, and you'll need to finish the encounter before its done.

Actual combat feels janky because its trying to look nice and therefore has its own psuedo lock-on going on where gerolt which just pick people he's attacking, and his positioning somewhat will determine who it is. It feels weird and sticky and the more clustered a scenario the more difficult it is to fix, now the game has a true-lock on but engaging/disengaging is also weird and costs you more time than its worth if you need to quickly change targets.

The leveling system feels disappointing mostly because you don't have enough points to really go outside of a single tree. And this is a shame because the swordsmanship tree is the best general-use tree, with alchemy and signs being very side-game because no matter how much you use them you'll always have to come back to swordplay, outside of 1-2 segements the game doesn't even really present enough scenarios to make signs worth it beyond breaking someone's guard; and i don't count the jedi-mind-trick sign because i've yet to determine if anything actually governs its success rate, considering i've never actually seen a indimidation or mind control fail in an conversation, maybe i'm just lucky.

The focus meter piece was boring, as you really could only use it on trash or mid-boss level enemies. Actual bosses it would actively disable itself, which was a shame because certain trees let you get buffs for using it; and boss fights generally swapped between rockem-sockem-robots and darksouls dodge-fests(with no real room to actually dodge most of the time), as alot of the larger bosses would ignore most signs and you were just expected to make a few hits, dodge away, and repeat; none of the parry/riposte/ect.. mechanics ever come up in boss fights, and i never saw a good reason to use them in normal combat because an aard would break anyone's defense and let me just strong attack them down.

The story was generally unpleasent, mostly because the route the game considers the "good" end requires generally dumb decisions on you part, and just about every decision that should come back and bite you doesn't, and all the ones that are sound/logical have some random contrivence come out to screw it up. the best i can describe it is a forced replayability scenario; where they seemed to expect the player to make all the logical decisions, get an awful scenario, and have to play again picking all the opposite decisions. It didn't help either than you never seemed to have natural dialoges with people, most of the time you'd be barely lead along just mostly following quest markers because the actual story has giving you so little to work with, and suddenly at the end of the chapter you can ask a NPC about 800 questions, grinding the game to an absolute hault as you now much decide how much you care or just want the game over with.

The game really only has a major choice in chapter 2 where you decide to side with the humans or non-humans. Both are awful. If you side with the non-humans you get a much more interesting cast of characters to work with and generally more story to work with, but it probably has the most awful outcome for everyone involved it seems. On the other side you join the humans and it nearly felt like this part of the game was unfinished, as it was so dull and uninteresting. Taking the human side is generally seemingly treated like the bad option also; even though really you're barely even taking the human side as both you and roche are just there to find the assassin.

The worst part is 99% of this game is the game where Gerolt really starts to remember things, and at really odd moments. The rest of the plot feels like it could've been skipped. I liked the 1st game even though it was a different beast, and plan to try out 3 as it was so highly rated, but i'm half concerned what horrible stuff is going to happen in 3 just because of how little i cared about fixing the consequences of anything by the end of this one and just wanting it to be over with.

I cant recommend this trilogy much. 
It just puts to shame all the AAA developers out there and also takes notice of the problems that arise from a AAA developer. Sure the graphics are top, system ok, but there is no spirit, this is becoming a usual sight be it in Andromeda, Anthem, Destiny and last but not least Bethesda. 
What all these companies have in common they are dying behemoths, Now you see a company like CDPR 
*(originaly a CD vendor) pud every dragon of the industry to shame, For to long they have used and abused the trust of their userbase/customers.  THATS OVER. CDPR is the new standard.
With the rise and release of CYBERPUNK 77, these behemoths, these "dragons" of the gaming industry should soon decide if warming their golden eggs is even worth it. 
A more ambitious, faster and eager developer generation is entering the scene and they aim for headshots everything they click. This are the kinds of CDPR and so many other

THEY SHIT ON THEM ALL, With TALENT! Thats the true Golden Egg the once dragons of industry have lost. 
Its done now.  This is not a console next gen, THIS IS TRUE NEXT GEN, Ideas, Tech and a fundamental progression in the way we look at "Gaming".  Which in my regard should be a term that needs to be scratched from the dictionary, these guys are offering enhanced digital experiences. We are not playing pong anymore.

Bad game. I had to quit playing it at about 20% completed. That's 30 hours I won't get back :-/  The controls are still awkward and the odd sort of boss-battle special moves are just plain dumb. Felt like a cheapo console thing and did not port well to PC at all (press A, B, up, down, now shake the controller or die). I was hoping they would fix the awkward and cumbersome stuff from the first game (which was pretty good for its day, but annoying to play at times), but it turns out they doubled down on the awkwardness. Witcher 1 is the "first" CDPR game, which is actually nice, if rough around the edges a bit.
Then you get Witcher this game. Graphics are better. Story is nice. The problem is that game now sucks at it's essense, i.e. being a game.
Don't get me wrong, I like the expansion of gadgets (Which make perfect sense for a monster hunter, really), but everything feels horrible. 
Bombs take too long to go into aiming mode, which results in Geralt being finally shoved into it when enemy is already at point blank.
Lock switch is awkward, lingering when it shouldn't and dropping when it's not.
Swordplay is brutally murdered by always having different delay in hits, which are chosen randomly. 
Oh, let's help you a bit by having Geralt move as if he wore concrete shoes and strafe as if he wore concrete shoes for 10km sprint before said strafe attempt, that will make game more fun. Yet we will make it impossible to perform tiny steps, you want to get closer to the edge of the wall you hug? Let's eject you in the hallway right into a guard, that surely won't get in the way of your pacifism!
Also, let's turn every power into Charged Igni fireball from W1, why would you want to have crowd control with AoE cone?
Still here? Let's weaken the oils making you wonder why you would ever use these over grindstones other than being a cheapskate. Also, let's make them expire as if they were your ice-cream. Which you gave to your little brother to hold, so you could tie your shoestrings.
You love the fighting anyway? Why offcourse we have more ways to screw you over. Let's start with tying everything to LMB prompt (We were given an advice to have all quest items surrounded by long ladders you can climb, but see, we are not the villains of this story!), then realize that maybe some people want to swing their swords, so let's make prompt areas small, this will not get in the way of players, forcing them to spin camera AND PC as well to try and find that angle so you could finally fall down the ledge.
Let's tie in a lot of stuff to your amulet, yet give it a cooldown, force stop your movement if you dare to use it and make it randomly do nothing, sometimes several times in a row.

I will endure the torture for the story and W3 import, but it's very painful that W2 wasn't able to to be to W1 as what ME2 was to ME1, despite similar platform shift to consoles.

TL:DR Review:
Leisure Suit Larry (Larpers Edition)

Real Review:
I played Witcher 1, couldn't continue after chapter 1. W1 had a great story telling system but that game is just not playable in 2020 due to its combat and exploration system. Witcher 2 is a completely different experience. Same great story telling, very immersive and superb combat, exploration and graphics. It really held up well over the years. If you thought only Bethesda can make great RPGs, think again.

But make no mistakes, this is NOT a free roaming open world RPG where you can get lost for 100s of hours. You can't even jump in this game. It is not like the Elderscroll series. Witcher 2 is similar to the Final Fantasy type RPG where it is pretty lock-step in how you progress the story. You can't really do much exploring or re-visit old areas and the map is chopped up into "chapters". There are some side quests and trivial games to play but the most meaningful thing to do is the main quest. Once you leave an area, you can never go back to it.

However it has a glorious main quest and the story telling is phenomenal. If we are really only judging by main quest story telling, this has to be one of the best RPG ever made. Skyrim doesn't even get close to this level of story telling.

Bonus Review:
Absolutely all the women in Witcher 2 looked gorgeous. No more having nightmares after seeing one too many pre-generated female faces in Morrowind, Oblivion or Skyrim.

Oh and did I mention, you can't jump.

This was a really hard decision. This game is by no mean a bad one. And I overall like the game, but in the end, I cannot recommend it to everyone. 
Let's start first with why it does right:

- The story: probably the one part that kept me playing. Characters are all interesting, they are complex and the narrative is interesting. You will often find yourself relate the characters you thought you would hate, or at least understand their motivations. The writing is good, funny and can be thought-provoking at time.
Also I'm kinda surprised at how many choices that game gives you and how it vastly affects the story.

- The music: Really wonderful work here, although the battle/ combat theme can become kinda repetitive, and it's probably the worst piece of music in the game.

- The graphic: Really impressive for a 10-year-old game, tho it's not half as good as The Witcher 3, the world can look really beautiful and mesmerizing at times, and the character models are pretty good. You can tell that the developers really put in the hard work and do their best with the technology available at that time.

Ok, now comes to what it does wrong:

- The difficulty: Maybe it's because this is my first Witcher game I've ever played, but the game is unreasonably hard. I played at Normal difficulty for the first 8 hours, and I can say that I was not enjoying it. I died probably about 25-35 times, and the game really felt unfair. The game does not explain what you need to do either, not after 30 hours into the game did I realize that silver swords deal more damage to monsters.

Only after switching it to Easy mode, can I really have a nice experience. But then the problem was the IT WAS TOO EASY, you only need to click your mouse repeatedly to beat the game. Meanwhile on Normal difficulty, bosses can kill you with 3-4 hits.

- The combat: the combat is not that terrible, but it feels kinda clunky with, combines with terrible difficulty system and you have a really unenjoyable experience. 

- The bugs: Tho I only encountered these bugs 10-15 times through out my whole 52 hours playthrough, the fact that I had to restart the game and sometime restart Steam itself really breaks the immersion. Bugs are often audio-related, like no dialogue or no in-game sound. Sometimes the game shut itself off too. That happened like 3-4 times.

I bought Witcher 3 on sale today and played it for a couple of hours, and I can clearly tell this is what the game wanted to be, and what it could have been, but alas, it is no Witcher 3. It is as ambitious but not half as good. 
Overall, if you want more of the story of this rich universe, and you caught the game on sale, and you are a really patient guy (or girl) then I'd recommend you play it on Easy difficulty and maybe go one a second run on Normal difficulty. 

I still think this is a good game, but it's not for everyone. So keep that in mind, before you buy it.

If you started with Witcher 3, this is still worth going back to play. It's much more linear than 3, but as a result the story moves along a bit more smoothly.

Pros:
[list]
[*] Graphics are still good by modern standards and there is good mod support to improve them further.
[*] The voice acting is done well and improved considerably from the first game.
[*] The story branches about midway through the game, so it will take 2 playthroughs to cover it all.
[*] Should take anywhere from 25-40 hours depending on if you do both scenarios. Not bad value for money since this goes on sale regularly.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] The combat is similar to the third game, but the potion system is awful. You have to heal before the fight starts which is really annoying if you get caught up in an extended section when you can't meditate or between cutscenes.
[*] Cutscene quicktime events are lame, but fortunately there aren't many of them.
[*] The mini-games (dice, arm wrestling, fist fighting) range from bad to average and really aren't much fun at all.
[*] I had some issues with game stability and crashing become a common occurrence near the end of the game. Save often.
[/list]

It's not as memorable as Witcher 3, but it's still a solid game worth checking out, particularly for fans of the series. 8/10

There are elements in The Witcher 2 that make it my favourite game in the series. The characters and plot are intriguing from beginning to end, there is no filler content and the game feels quite 'full', IMO. The graphics are getting somewhat outdated, but that's to be expected of any game that's nearly 10 years old.

The middle child of the saga and the entry that may be the most out of place in the series, Witcher 2: Assassins of King is nonetheless a near perfect segue from the original game into the beast of a title that is The Wild Hunt. Substantially shorter than it's predecessor, Witcher 2 makes up for a comparatively short campaign with substantial replay value. Choices, being an integral part of the franchise, a player will find themselves in completely different hubs and zones depending on a few integral dialogue options. Witcher 2 is considerably darker, and, in many ways, far more brutal, than either the original or its successor. Cumbersome combat, near impossible stealth, and a frustrating potion crafting system are some of the dissapointing aspects of the title, but don't affect the impact of the incredible narrative, top-notch music and art design which the game offers in spades. Although the most linear entry in the series, there's something about Assassins of Kings that is somehow even more grand and impressive than the Wild Hunt. Massive battles, siege engines and immense and towering Elven forests with monsters larger than anything else from the rest of the franchise are only some the great surprises offered here.

The graphics are way better than Witcher 1, but feel saturated and slightly off to me. The combat at first seemed like a step up from the first game, but ended up feeling very basic and boring. Witcher 1 has repetitive combat system, but it at least kept me engaged. I dealt with a lot of random bugs and glitches, more than I dealt with in the first game actually. I see what they were going for, but it ends up falling flat for me.

Whew, finally beat Witcher 2. What a rollercoaster of a ride. It’s a lovingly crafted game with a ton of attention to  detail. Overall I found it to be a fun and tight experience that I would highly recommend. It’s the second memorable series, that has forced me to play a main character who is an antihero. The story drags you from one shit show to the next, as selfish characters compete in a power struggle ,that pulls the player right along. The game layers in just enough ethical issues, and moral conundrums to make the encounters interesting while not totally enjoyable. I never felt like a hero, just another person wading through other peoples conflicts with my own personal motives directing my actions and driving me further onwards. Its hard to be an idealist in this game, the people in control are shitty, and the outcomes are terrible. While this makes for an engaging narrative, it strikes a little to close to real life for comfort.

Level and quest design was great. I found the UI and Inventory systems to be atrocious, seems like it was designed for console, and the PC port did not make any improvements here. The voice acting and graphics were super good. I am glad there was less utterly ridiculous and  ludicrous sex mechanics this time around but the game designers still like to layer it in heavily. I loved the Easter eggs and mythological references (assassins creed, xena warrior princess, trolls repairing bridges, etc…). The game neatly carried over my Witcher 1 decisions. Supposedly there are 4 different beginnings and 16 different endings to the Witcher 2 but I think instead of playing around with these I would rather see how my choices carry over into Witcher 3 right away.

I really want to finish this game. The story hooked me and the characters are all interesting and unique. However, the game has crashed for me so many times. I wouldn't mind but the saves put me back to where I have to run all the way back to a combat encounter I already completed. No fast travel makes this work.

Game is good.

This game is not good.  The graphics are amazing and the store is great but the gameplay is bad.  The pacing isn't as bad as Witcher 1 but it still has that long drawn out boring mystery section that turns a 25 hour game into a 40 hour game.  Just like Witcher 1 CDProjektRed has no idea how to put a quest together.  "Here is a sidequest but we're not going to tell you where to go, what to do, or how to do it.  We're not even going to give you a quest marker."  At least in this one all the quests are not tied up and jumbled together so you can do sidequests when you want to instead of when the mainquest allows it.  My main problem is the difficulty.  CdProjektRed doesn't know anything about balance.  Anyone who says they beat the game on normal with no difficulty at all is full of crap.  When you start this game you are just pathetic.  I know they have to start you out low so you can be built up but you don't start this game with the skills that you started with in the last game.  You have to add the basic skills back into your character from the skill tree.  The aggression and skill competence the enemies have at the start of the game makes the beginning ruff going.  Especially since the game throws a lot of new abilities at you and you have no time to learn them before going into the fire.  I don't have a problem with this in and of itself but you start off very squishy.  If you play on normal you get many many many 1 or 2 hit kills.  Certain boss/mini boss areas will kill you with 1-2 hits and you will have to restart every 15 seconds.  Ya thats fun.  You will have to use a walkthough or change to easy just to find out or live long enough to learn for yourself what to do.  However, halfway through the game when you can get new armor, weapons, and some skills it is possible to go back to normal mode.  SPOILER:  You must put 2 points into the skill that negates back stabs.  The game is unplayable without that.  Every less than fully successful dodge will be a 1-2 hit kill.  Much of the combat is an overwhelming number of enemies in a small space making back stabs and surrounds constant.  Ya thats fun.  When it gives you some space it is fun actually but thats all this game has.  Nothing about the combat is unique or clever.  Its just small boxes and overwhelming numbers.  Remember potions?  Ya they are useless now.  Maybe they were overpowered in the last game but in this one they are so weak they are not worth using.  Thats a shame since it was such an important part of the first game.  Even worse you can't use potions mid fight anymore.  You have to use it at a save before the predetermined fight and then initiate the fight.  At least it lasts a very long time.  SPOILER: don't put any points into alchemy skills.  With potions being useless alchemy skills are useless.  Last but not least, This game crashed on me like 12 times.  Thats not counting the 3 times I clicked on a ladder or ledge and got stuck on geometry.      

Okay now some good things.  The skill tree is a nice improvement on the level up system.  New skills and abilities allow for more options in combat but you won't use them much because combat does not have unique or clever ways to use them.  The combat system is a huge improvement from Witcher 1.  You actually fight them one click one swing instead of the odd auto combat system the last one had.  Dice isn't weighted against you but it still takes no skill to play or win.  

Only play this game if you want to learn all the back story before playing Witcher 3.  It might be better to just watch a lore breakdown.  Playing this game makes me worried about how good Cyberpunk 2077 will be.

The game has a genuinely engaging and compelling story which never feels forced or superficial. The choices you make matter and have visible consequences on the world around you. The combat system is archaic and definitely shows it's age playing it now but the potion system where you actively brew and consume the potions you think you'll need in preparation for a tough fight beforehand instead of simply pushing a button during a fight to boost your attack or heal yourself is honestly a super cool feature. The main draw of the game is it's excellent story and at no point does it ever dissapoint.

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings takes place in a brutal fantasy medieval world based on Slavonic mythology. You play as Geralt of Rivia, a monster slayer for hire, mutated and trained from an early age to kill savage beasts, who is caught up in a deadly intrigue that will shape the future of the Continent.

The story is mature and intricate, while the characters that fill this world are compelling, very well written and brilliantly voice acted. You will also face difficult choices that will radically alter the plot.

Combat is complex, requiring some planning and preparation by brewing potions and crafting blade oils, that will increase your odds of survival.

The graphics are pretty good, enhancing the overall immersion. The soundtrack is on par, with many wonderful songs.

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a magnificent game and I fully recommend it!

Believe me I'm no Witcher fan boy either - think certain bits are slightly cringe and others a bit too weird but this game absolutely blew me away at times with it's attention to detail, especially animation and visuals!

So yeah, It's absolutely worth a look but just try your best to get past that opening prolouge! 
Once you're out of the that slog the game picks up right away and feels super natural to play and explore to anyone familiar with RPG's





.... also the potion drinking concept is really sweet!

This is a great game. You might need a few mods like the unlimited weight mod to make the game run a bit better, but other than that, the story and the characters are simply amazing. The game however is quite challenging so prepare to die a bit more than witcher 3. The witcher 2 is more focused on humans, so it does seems more political than monster hunting in this witcher game. Overall I really enjoyed the witcher universe and this game has given me another chance to immerse myself in it.

The game is an improvement combat-wise compared to the original, however death will come more frequently and rarely under reasonable circumstances. Entering Act I, the storytelling is interesting, though it has not become captivating just yet. Choices are ample in both side and main quests. Choices do carry over from the first game on PC. So far, I am enjoying myself, though I admit, I did not play the first nor am I playing the second out of enjoyment but rather more under the obligation that I feel in order to appreciate the story in the third. Perhaps, in time, my outlook will change. For those looking for a Mass Effect vibe, that element is present to some extent in this game, though I wouldn't call it identical nor similar enough to warrant spending hours doing extra content. For now, I intend to complete the rest of the game focusing only on the main quest. 

EDIT: Having put more time into the game, the story has finally reached the point of captivating, and there are many, MANY choices to be made regarding friend and foe. The game lives up to its potential, though it takes a bit of time to get going.

Witcher 2 is a deceiving game. The upgrade in presentation from Witcher 1 is staggering and distracts from the very start of the game, with environmental design that fully realises the ambitious scenarios. The world looks alive in a way that puts some present games to shame, a decade after its release. As such, it is easy to go into the game expecting a polished, smooth experience in line with a big budget title. [b]This is not the case.[/b] While Witcher 2 makes many improvements compared to its predecessor, it inherits the same level of inconsistencies. I can't stress enough that if you wish to play this game, you should be expecting a janky experience. That will probably improve your experience a lot.

I won't go into detail in this review, because if I would list all the problems I had with this game, this review would be even longer than it is (though I will mention that it crashed quite a bit and made my computer work a lot; take a look at graphics options before playing!). Instead, I will focus on what I found most important, both in a negative and positive sense.

First, we have combat. The combat of this game is quite divisive, and understandably so. There are misleading animations, with some of them so quick that it is close to impossible to react, which pairs with high damage on enemies to be quite annoying at times. You die quick, and yet you often don't have an awful amount of space to move around, leading to some difficult fights that would probably be almost trivial in an open field. Boss fights boils down to QTE:s or something close to it, ending up lacking choice in tactics. I would call this a difficult game, if it wasn't for the difficulty dropping steadily as the game goes on, making the enemies of the last chapter pushovers.

Overall, the combat has questionable design and a severe lack of polish. There is no arguing that. And yet, I didn't find it bad myself. It starts off rough, but you continually have a lot of options (with exception of the bosses), there is a lot of impact, there is good enemy variety, there is a lot of freedom in the movement system and... well, it just looks pretty good. Overall I found it enjoyable, problems and all, and that contradiction is not uncommon in this game.

Let's move to quest design. The game mainly consists of speaking to characters and fighting, which is contained within the quests. While I will applaud the way that quests weave into eachother, something that is left over from Witcher 1, I can't shake the image of a puzzle where the pieces don't quite fit together. Witcher 1 had quests and characters that interlinked in a way that felt somewhat natural, because of the character interacting with eachother and having their own agency and motivations. In comparison, the way that quests link together in Witcher 2 feels more based on convenience, with characters only being able to act in cohesion with the player or in accordance to the plot. Instead of giving characters the information that would make them act, you gather information from them so that you can act. Only the voice acting and dialogue writing saves the game from feeling like one where you're the only thing alive.

Then there is that plot, that story. Well, if you've read some about the game, you should know that there are some extremely impactful choices in the game, to the point that the game becomes completely different as a result of them. What this leads to, I believe, is a certain lack of depth. While dramatic in theory, scenes lack weight and pacing to make them actually interesting. The execution is almost comical at times, with characters dying for no reason, or dramatically falling to the floor poisoned within five minutes of entering the story. With few exceptions, the main story feels sped up, with nothing quite living up to what it could've been. Nothing is quite lacking enough to be bad, but it shafes constantly nonetheless.

But the biggest problem with the story is also its biggest boon. The entirety of Witcher 2, the core of the main character's motivation, consists of bridging the Witcher games with the Witcher books. What does this mean? It means that as a book reader, I cannot fathom how you can follow the point of this story, its references and its ending, without having read the books. It's not the only thing in the story, as there is still the "political" side of the narrative that has its own value. But the personal side, the thing that holds weight for Geralt himself? I think it's almost a requirement to have read the books to follow it. This is not good for a game to do; and yet, because of it, I ended up caring about the story and its continuation in Witcher 3 way more than I thought I would.

To summarise, I think that Witcher 2 is an overall fine game. I don't love it like I ended up loving Witcher 1, and despite being more polished, I think it's janky in all the wrong places. If you have some tolerance, then I think Witcher 2 is a 50/50 purchase; if you also have read the books and care about the world, then I would gladly recommend it. Without these two things, I would see it as more difficult of a purchase, even if I did end up enjoying it myself.

[b]Introduction:[/b]
I had previously tried to play this game first, but I felt very lost so I decided to give it another chance after beating the first game.

[b]Good:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The Z button is a nice addition to display interactable objects within a certain range.
    [*]Pressing 1 and 2 instead of Q and E for weapons rather than Signs is something I wished for in the first game.
    [*]The CTRL wheel is a nice addition to the interface.
    [*]The game runs better than the first game.
    [*]Mod support.
    [*]Despite preferring the combat system of the first game, the combat feedback feels good.
    [*]The inventory system is improved over the first game.
    [*]Weapons actually have comprehensive stats unlike the first game.
    [*]Excellent soundtrack, as always.
    [*]Allows you to import your Witcher 1 save file to keep some equipment.
    [*]Meditating no longer requires a campfire, and potions are more balanced.
    [*]The talent tree is an improvement.
    [*]The game is stable, even with mods. Only had 1 crash while alt+tabbing.
[/list] 

[b]Neutral:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The lack of coloured names above NPCs' heads makes it more difficult to distinguish quest related NPCs.
    [*]I do not enjoy items having weight in these kinds of games. Feels like an artifical handicap. Luckily, there's a mod for that.
    [*]A lot of the voice actors I'd become accustomed to have been replaced.
    [*]The Quen sign is very overpowered.
[/list] 

[b]Bad:[/b]
[list]
    [*]There are absolutely no settings available in-game. Nothing can be adjusted during gameplay, everything has to be set up before launching the game. You can't even check the keybinds.
    [*]The textures look grainy.
    [*]While a graphical upgrade, the artstyle is a downgrade from the first game.
    [*]I do not recommend starting with this game, as a lot of things learned from the first game are poorly explained, or not explained at all in this one.
    [*]The Signs have no explanation as to what they do, something the first game did better.
    [*]The map is at times difficult to navigate.
    [*]I miss the lack of combat stances (Heavy, Fast, Group) from the first game, which added some reactionary combat depth beyond spamming the mouse buttons.
    [*]The game has a lot of QTE events.
    [*]I am not a fan of corpses turning into bags when lootable. I preferred the Object Names in the first game showing the text "Remains" above defeated enemies when lootable.
    [*]There is no indication of whether books have been read or not.
    [*]Disappointing lack of quests involving monsters - feels like the whole point of being a witcher is ruined by forcing humans to be the main enemy.
    [*]Very little environment variation compared to the first game. You're stuck in only 2 areas for 90% of the game.
[/list]

Update: Steam keeps prompting me to revise my review because they hate negative reviews.   I'm nearly done with the game, and if anything I hate the combat system even more than when I started.  I understand it now, and I work within the ridiculous constraints it imposes on me, but most boss fights are pretty much the opposite of fun.  If you like large doses of arbitrary frustration then this is the game for you.

Pros:  The story is great.  There are a lot of consequential choices, sometimes kingdom ending choices.  I love the gritty atmosphere.  Profanity and debauchery abound.  Lots of dark humor.

Cons: OMG the bugs.  So many bugs.  Game crashing bugs.  The controls, expecially in combat, are awful and unresponsive.  You can't cancel out of moves that you should be able to cancel.  Many important game mechanics are never explained.  The minigames are stupid and boring.  You can't open doors or climb onto/jump off of platforms during combat, even if you're 30' away from your foe.  The inventory UI was designed by drunken monkeys.  The magical "signs" have very non-intuitive names and no other easy indicators of what they actually do in the interface where you select them.  I suppose that's fine if you've read all the books and seen the shows and already memorized them, but if you come into it blind it's yet another frustration.

I'm going to finish the game despite the frustration because it is a fun story, but damn, I would not have bought it if I had known what I was in for.

[b]Pożegnanie Białego Wilka - wrażenia[/b]

Ochłonęłam chwilę po przejściu dodatku i zgodnie z zapowiedzią podzielę się moimi wrażeniami. Pragnę nadmienić, że nie będzie to ocena obiektywna, bo jestem ogromną fanką całego uniwersum i bardzo długo czekałam na ten dodatek. Weźmy również poprawkę na moją nieskończoną miłość do Yennefer <3

Ale przejdźmy już do samej modyfikacji. Jak pewnie wiecie, jest to modyfikacja fanowska (od fanów dla fanów). Główny wątek to ślub naszej (mojej) ukochanej pary: Yennefer i Geralta. Jednak nie dajcie się zwieść! Podczas rozgrywki wcielimy się w różnych bohaterów (Ciri, Eskel, Letho) oraz poznamy nowe historie bądź rozjaśnią nam się wcześniej już znane (jest wiele retrospekcji). Jednak pomimo wielu zadań do wykonania, spędzimy cudowne chwile na weselu młodej pary.

Samo wykonanie dodatku to istny majstersztyk. Świat został odwzorowany perfekcyjnie, a kreacja bohaterów i dialogi to cudo. Oddają one w 100% charakter bohaterów, których znamy z książek czy gier. Wszystko zostało dopracowane na ostatni guzik i sami Redzi by się tego nie powstydzili!

Przedstawiona w modyfikacji historia jest nietuzinkowa i bardzo przemyślana. Wszystko się ze sobą łączy w niebanalny sposób, a dodatkowe zadania do wykonania jedynie podkreślają wyjątkowość tej przygody. Jeszcze bardziej przybliżają nas do bohaterów sagi, ukazują nowe wydarzenia i nową perspektywę. Na uznanie zasługuje także fakt wielu zakończeń (dokładnie 3).

Ja przez cały miałam na twarzy banana od ucha do ucha! Widząc nawiązania do sagi oraz gier, dosłownie skakałam z radości (naprawdę!) i śmiałam się do ekranu. Moje serduszko radowało się jak nigdy wcześniej. Było to istne spełnienie moich marzeń i znaczy dla mnie więcej, niż jesteście sobie w stanie wyobrazić.

A pod koniec łzy oczach. Wielkie krople zasłaniające ekran. "Coś się kończy..". Na pewno kończy się pewien etap. Chcę jednak myśleć, że "coś się zaczyna". Jeszcze nie wiem, co to będzie.
Odczuwam wielką pustkę mając świadomość, że to już koniec przygód mojego ukochanego Białego Wilka, Yennefer, Ciri oraz ich towarzyszy. Jednak nie mogłam wyobrazić sobie lepszego zakończenia tej historii. Pięknego. Wzruszającego. Poruszającego. A jednocześnie radosnego.

Dodatek jest genialny. Twórcy włożyli w modyfikację całe swoje serce, dzięki czemu stworzyli niepowtarzalną i unikalną historię. Historię, którą warto przeżyć samemu. Ale ostrzegam, nic już nie będzie takie same. Być może podchodzę do tego zbyt osobiście, ale taki mój urok <3 




[b]Farewell of the White Wolf - review[/b]

I calmed down a little after finishing this mod and as I said, I will share my opinion about it. I also want to say that it won't be objective, because I'm a huge fan of the Witcher universum and I've been waiting for so long for this dlc. Don't forget about my endless love for Yennefer <3

But let's focus on the modification now. As you may know, this is a fan expansion (from fans to fans). The main story is Yennefer and Geralt's wedding: our (my) lovely couple. But don't misunderstand that! During the gamplay we'll play as different characters (Ciri, Eskel, Letho) and experience new stories or get to know ones, that we already know (there are a lot of flashbacks). Despite a lot of tasks to do, we'll spend a lovely time at newlyweds' wedding.

The creation of the mod is masterpiece. The world is mapped perfectly and the creation of the characters and dialogues is wonderful! They mapped the characters we know from books or games in 100%! CDPRed wouldn't be ashamed!

The story's showed in the mod is unique and very thoughtful. Everything is connected in an original way and extra tasks just emphasise the specialness of this adventure. They bring us closer to the characters that we know from the books and games, they show new events and perspective. Let's also appreciate multiple endings (3 to be extact).

All the time I was smiling from ear to ear! Seeing the references to books or games make me literally jumping up and down with excitement (really!) and I was laughing to the screen. My heart was over the moon like never before. My dream came true and it means for me more, than you can expect.

And at the end tears in my eyes. Big drops covering my screen. "Something ends...". For sure a certain stage ends. But I want to think, that "something begins". I don't know what it is yet.
I feel empty knowing, that this is the end of my favourite White Wolf, Yennefer, Ciri and their friends' adventures. But I couldn't imagine better ending of this story. Beautiful. Moving. Touching. And delighting at the same time.

The modification is brilliant. Authors put their hearts and soul in this dlc, that's why they've created unique and touching story. The story worth experiencing on your own. But I warn you, nothing will be the same. Maybe I'm too emotional, but that's my charm <3
Three words - BEST GAME EVER!

Continuing the brilliance of the Witcher 1 world, this installment delves deeper into the political aspects of the world. You have to make various choices which would lead to the difference in the narrative of the world but won't directly affect the superficial storyline. Apart from that, there are many choices that would lead to different missions. Hence this game needs at least 2 playthrough to fully complete the storyline. Overall great game.

Ratings :
Story : 5/5 Much more mature storytelling, however there isn't the massive final twist like one in the Witcher 1.
Gameplay : 4/5 A progress from the original game in combat which is much more immersive. However, there is a bit of lack of polish (no pun intended) in the combat. Alchemy was also toned down from earlier version but the need of meditation in order to drink potion is much more lore friendly (although a pain).
Graphics : 4/5 It's a 2011 game so the graphics are not as great as the current generation quality. But is quite good for the 360 era. Colours however don't have the consistency; sometimes it is highly saturated, sometimes it's too greyscaled.

Many people, including myself, probably have a strong desire to start a series at the beginning when possible, making it difficult to jump right into a later numerical title. This review comes from the perspective of someone hoping to play the earlier Witcher titles before moving onto Witcher 3. If you find yourself in this same position, I advise you to read on and decide for yourself if it's really worth your time.

[h1]📝What is Witcher 2?[/h1]
Before 'The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt' released in 2015, there was 'The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings' in 2011. Not quite as successful or celebrated as its sequel, The Witcher 2 nevertheless stands out for its unique design and changes when compared to the first game of the series. The player controls Geralt of Rivia - a human who has been outfitted with mutant powers that is generally employed to slay monsters, otherwise known as a witcher. Shortly into the prologue, Geralt is falsely accused of assassinating a king, and must do whatever he can in order to catch the real killer and clear his name.

The Witcher 2 contains strong RPG elements including leveling, a skill tree, crafting, and gear. The witcher profession often requires preparation and knowledge of the enemy, which is utilized in-game by allowing for the research of monsters, deployment of bombs and traps, or the imbibement of potions that grant you a variety of effects. Geralt can also take sidequests and make different decisions in dialogue or cutscenes that will (greatly) affect various things in positive/negative ways, possibly much later in the game.

[h2]🎮Gameplay[/h2]

[b]🔎Interaction[/b]
The biggest focus of The Witcher 2 is on its story and characters. You will spend a lot of time in the game simply conversing with people, making decisions in dialogue, and dealing with the consequences. The biggest difference this makes for the Witcher 2 compared to other games is the potential to branch off quite wildly at certain points of the game, both for sidequests and the main quest. In the case of the latter, there is at least one decision in the game that will send you to an entirely different hub area with different quests and NPC's to speak with, which greatly changes the outcome of later events. This aspect is definitely the highlight of Witcher 2, and it's a shame that it might be the only good part.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2225031380 
[b]🗺️Exploration[/b]
Omitting the prologue, there are 3 chapters in the game that each contain their own hub in which to gather information, gather materials, take quests, and kill some bad guys. Geralt is heavily tethered to the ground, so you will mostly be exploring by walking around and using contextual actions to climb or jump when the game allows for it, though it's somewhat rare. Within each settlement you'll find vendors, craftsmen, and sidequests, all of which will require money and materials from the untamed wilds where monsters roam about. Cave systems and corpse-laden fields seem to attract all sorts of creatures, so you will have no shortage of hostiles to battle. Which leads to...

[b]⚔️Combat[/b]
This part of the game is garbage, and I really mean that. Combat is one of the core components of the game, and it's so broken in so many ways that it entirely turned me away from playing multiple times. In combat, Geralt feels very stiff to control, chooses his melee strikes randomly, and struggles to connect his attacks at all because of an alien sort of lock-on system. Enemies, however, have superhuman abilities that allow them to turn on a dime to block anywhere/anytime, damage you without hitting you, and track you like a heat-seeking missile. When you factor in equipment and the skill tree on Normal difficulty, the game begins nightmarishly difficult with the obtuse and sluggish combat mechanics, and then becomes exceedingly easy by the end as you tank blows and spam whatever you like to annihilate hordes of enemies. None of it ever feels right, and I could go on for much longer pointing out issues, but I think I've said enough.


[h3]✔️The Good[/h3]
+ [b]Interesting and varied cast of characters[/b]
This was my favorite part of the game without a doubt. There are a lot of different people that you can meet and speak to, and you might even miss a lot of them depending on your choices

+ [b]Expansive story with impactful choices[/b]
Many different branching decisions can lead you to view completely different events, people, and places from one playthrough to the next


[h3]❌The Bad[/h3]
- [b]The combat[/b]
Number 1 issue for me in this game, and you spend a lot of time doing it. Clunky, broken, messy, and straight up not fun

- [b]Most of Geralt's arsenal isn't necessary (on Normal)[/b]
Bombs, knives, and traps are sometimes useful, but you can often get by without using any of them. There are also potions and a skill tree entirely devoted to them, but they aren't remotely worth it from my experience

- [b]Tedious and unintuitive UI[/b]
The inventory displays information poorly and often caused much frustration. The quick menu on controller appears radial but actually isn't, and requires deliberate timing to actually select what you want. Combat log in the bottom right corner of the screen is so out of the way and updates so fast that I almost never got useful information out of it. Etc, etc...

- [b]Poorly explained and hidden mechanics[/b]
There are special "talents" in Witcher 2 that are cryptically unlocked by doing seemingly random tasks, often permanently missable, and are never really brought to your attention. Certain things like fatigue are explained maybe once, and you will then be left to wonder for the rest of the game if you missed it

- [b]And the kitchen sink[/b]
The Witcher 2 has too many other issues to go into detail about, but here are a few off the top of my head: awful and contrived stealth sections, Adrenaline meter doesn't always work, medallion highlights empty "lootable" sources, the entire bullshit Kayran, Draug, and ESPECIALLY the Operator encounters, Geralt can't help but interact with everything around him while you try to swing your sword... you get the idea.


[h3]❔Your Mileage May Vary❔[/h3]
~ [b]Lots of politics; not much witcher'ing[/b]
This game's plot heavily revolves around different factions vying for power while trying to sabotage or outright kill each other, and it gets quite complicated. Not a lot of monster related activities were available

~ [b]Minimum of 2 playthroughs to get the full picture[/b]
At least one major decision will completely cut you off from a large portion of the rest of the game. This adds to the replay value, but also means the experience feels like it's missing something if you only plan on a single run

~ [b]Fair amount of female nudity[/b]
Pretty self explanatory. I felt it was a bit gratuitous, at times

~ [b]Mod support[/b]
There are a TON of small issues with this game that can be eased with just a mod or two. Personally, I found the medallion and inventory to be unbearable as-is, and played the game with them slightly modified for quality of life

~ [b]Looks pretty good for a 2011 game[/b]
Aside from maybe the character models, most environments and animations look pretty good for such an old game, in my opinion

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2218980584
[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
Suffice to say, I think The Witcher 2 is entirely skippable as a game. Though it would certainly boost your appreciation for characters and events to come in later entries, I found it so unbearable to play that I think you are better off watching a video or reading up on the events of the game. If you absolutely [i]must[/i] play this game, then I advise that you load yourself up on mods to ease your experience. The Witcher 2 often goes on sale for only $3, but even at that price it took me months to push myself hard enough to see the end.

VERY solid game where your choices do feel like they actually matter. Combat and overall gameplay is generally well done and enjoyable and there is more than just one single way to go through fights. 
My favorite thing about this is the richness of the story and conflict - complex enough for people liking political games and schemes but simple enough for others to understand and enjoy as well, all done in a way that makes you think twice before trusting or siding with someone.
As someone who hasn't read any of the books, I can tell you there will be quite a bit of lore left completely unexplained to you, so it would help to play the first game and read the journal entries in this one if you don't plan on picking up the books. The story is however made so you can still understand at least the most important bits, but if you know the rest of the lore, this is even more of a must for you to try the game.
I'd recommend saving the game regularly, as it tends to crash every now and then and you wouldn't want losing important progress. Saving before spending talent points or crafting a lot of items can also help in case you get stuck on some of the more challenging bosses and you need to change your strategy. Some of them can prove rather difficult even on Normal mode.

Would absolutely recommend it to anyone interested in a story-oriented game packed with action, violence, beauty, deep lore and political conflict.

I started playing this game and logged in close to ninety hours after I have completed the game twice. I even went as far as playing it on 'Insane' difficulty--you can't die or else you have to restart the entire game--and loved every second of it! 

[h1] Pros	[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Amazing story, lore, and characters
    [*]Great open-world with your choices having a direct effect on the outcomes of the story
    [*]Combat that requires strategy and proper preparations as opposed to simply "tanking" all the time
[/list]

[h1] Cons	[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Occasional crashes (although it could be that I'm gaming on my laptop and it isn't the greatest)
    [*]Wished there were a few more side-quests to the game. It is broken into three chapters and once you finish the chapter, the quests available for that specific chapter are marked as "failed" and can't complete them.
[/list]

[h1] Personal Thoughts	[/h1]

'The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt' was my first Witcher game and I loved it so much I  played the previous games and loved them. 'The Witcher 2' also drew me in the same way part 3 did because the characters felt fully fleshed-out and the story-telling quality is superb. The story is driven by Geralt of Rivia who--despite reflecting emotions--shows a lot of character and makes me interested in his journey with the diverse set of characters. I played through the game twice to follow the different paths the game allows and was amazed on how different the game turned out depending on the choices I've made and who I sided with. This is something I feel a lot of RPG's are missing, a sense of direct control of the story that shapes itself to my choices and The Witcher 2 does just that. Overall, I LOVED this game and highly recommend giving it a shot!

If I had played the Witcher 2 before playing The Witcher 3, I would have never purchased The Witcher 3, which is my favorite open world RPG of all time. The Witcher 2 is actually a video movie that tries to be a game. It is linear and clunky and filled with odd puzzles.  50% of you will never finish chapter 1 because of the boss fight. If you are prone to raging and are easily frustrated and have a hard time figuring out puzzles then save your money. This would be a perfect gift to give to your mother-in-law, so you can sit back and get drunk and then watch her throw her computer through her TV set.  Go purchase The Witcher 3 The Wild Hunt, and have a good game that you will be proud to own. On the other hand The Witcher 2 is often on sale for around 4 dollars, so even if you hate it, you haven't lost much money on it.  CHEERS !
This is a great Witcher game. Very faithful to the books, with the same excitement and humour. Love it so far!

PS: The boss fights in this game can go plough themselves.
Best game ever

This game is liked by many over production design in its story telling, cinematic voice act, and choice-matter characteristic. The gameplay begins with a poorly designs tutorial that teaches only the basic control. Yet the game requires the used of skills to manipulate background object to make advance in the game. The game's difficulty requires the player to use crafted potion and other consumable crafted devices to beat, which is also not taught in the tutorial.

The story element of the game makes the gameplay even less enjoybale by throwing the player into dungeon, stripped naked to fight its way out, two to three times in the whole game. Also it puts the player through alternative gameplay that Metal Gear Solid series is known for. As I am in it to slay monster and walk in the condom of the Witcher, I found those quests uncalled for and distastful.   

The cons in details are:

There is a common bug people experience. Where the game runs with more than dozens of saves, the game has a chance to crash everytime the player enters a new area through a door. This flaw is a critical problem in a story-rich and choice matter video game. Real fans would make saves at turning points in the story for future replay to enjoy what would happen  otherwise in the story. This known bug which never get fixed, it prevent dedicated players from enjoy this game the way it should be enjoyed.

The tutorial is poorly designed. I was stuck with the wizard that shoots fireball in it. The game asks me to press number 9 at the summoned beast, but it did nothing. Also the tutorial fails to explaine number 5 to 9 keys are preassigned to each of the magical skills, which are known as Signs in the game. So I was set up to play the game without a full understand on how combat works.

There is nowhere in the game that explains what each of the 5 signs do. No menu that tells you when pause the game in anyway during gameplay. I needed to search online to know what the hell every one  of those signs does. Once I found content that checked out in multiple sources, I printed it out, and then drew the symbol to tell my-self which is which. Because in the game, those magical skills known as Signs are displayed in symbols, and my Open Office does not display those PIC based symbol after I copied and pasted from a website.  That is a lot of evil homework for a video game. All the other games I play allow me to check my skills and their definition DURING gameplay. THIS ONE DOESN"T!!!!! God daXX MOXXXX FXXX!

Why the FXXX can't I remap my keys in game? WHY? Don't develop game if you can't program faeces. Just DON'T!

Hence the game does not allow you to check the list of keys during the game, I tried to learn it by pressing every key on the keyboard. The J key is for journal menu, but next to it there is the H key. If you pressed it, it disable all menu function and disable all the interface based information - map, health bar, skills, inventory, journal. The first time I pressed it, I didn't know what the fORK just happened, I thought I ran into a bug. So I relaunched the game multiple time in attempts to learn what triggered such a bug. Hours into the game, I have run into other problems in addition to design flaw in programing and its poorly designed learning curves. The side quests were designed to prolong chore-like gameplay. A good few side quests had me wandered aimlessly in a large area to run into subject of the quests by chances. Any other ARPG game has NPC that says to the protogonist  "here, let me mark your map", but not Witcher 2. Again the combat is not fun; its slow to play, and dull to watch.

The gameplay offer million crafting choices for the player to use, ranging from potions, trap, to bombs, to temp boost items. However the character can only carry so much. So the player need to spend a lot of gameplay time unload crafting components, and loading needed component after reading what are needed. It's a long list, and only a few items are really useful. A lot of chore, for the least kind of fun in a video game that focuses more on story than on combat gameplay.

THere is a combat roll move, that doesn't cancel attack, and it's heavily needed in the game. That makes me a better swordman than Gerald in real live. That makes any other combat focus game more fun than this one. By the silver sword, what a disgrace? 

The other problem is a minor one. When and where there are multiple NPC fighting along your side, they follow you and they block your path. Enter a new area and run into a few foes? If you fallback, one of the NPCs will block the door, thus disable you from engaging in melee combat. Walked into a corner to loot crate and chest? NPCsssss block you in every directions, good luck loading a save close enough to your current advancement in the game.

WTF is wrong with this game? How is this a good game? It's only good with cutscenes! Right, PC standard! Probably, I was born too early.

A very good sequel to the Witcher series. The improvement to the interface and how quick you could dish out damage was a nice change of pace from the original. It is nice however to see how the old characters from the first game do make their appearance, they certainly remember you. As a straight action RPG this game has a good amount of replay value for those who want to 100% the game and choose all the different amount of choices that does tell a different story as you play-through it. The graphics are preety good albiet a bit dated for 2020 it still will make your GPU work if you set all the bells and whistles in settings. I ran this game on a 5700xt and had no problem running it on 2k res. @ 144hz with everything on max. The sound is spot on and the music is pretty epic, it definitely makes the game seem cinematic, just with the in-game cut scenes alone. Great Witcher journey full of harpies, and all the enemies from the first game and more show up to try and tear you apart. The skills system and socket system keep the game interesting and combat is smooth in part 2. for you can now pause the game and select your power signs and gear on the fly while pausing the game, a la Old Republic. Its a good change of pace, as the first game was pretty brutal and unforgiving, not to say Witcher 2 is a walk in the park. Interacting with the NPC's and finding out all the gossip is great, reminds you of a Tolkien book. Can't wait to continue the story of the Wraiths in part. 3 Really fun game, its worth you time, you won't regret it! Of course the xxx action is back and sir Stallion of Rivia will leave many exhausted women in his path once again :-)

I had a great time with this game! It's not without its flaws but I was so captivated with the story and world-building that they were easy to forgive. Firstly, the game looks gorgeous and the music is beautiful. It's a huge improvement over the first game for sure. Geralt also looks a lot better and not so ghoul like. Secondly, most of the quests seem relevant to the main story and some are very well-written. The story is quite complicated and there are a lot of decisions to make, the main one being very ballsy as it prevents you from seeing a big chunk of the game. I played on Normal and combat was very challenging at the beginning and I struggled with the first proper boss, but it got a lot better after that, especially when I got better abilities and equipment. Still, it's kinda janky and there are bugs and inconsistencies that can be kinda of annoying, but the characters are very well-drawn and the story is super well paced. I am very glad I've played the first two games before finally going into the third one.
