[h2][b]Score: 9/10[/b][/h2]

Action RPGs these days are real iffy due to the fact that they tend to feel to formulaic. They usually have good stories, but the graphics are horrible, the combat is clumsy, and the quest system is yawn worthy. The Witcher 2 takes what was great from the first and makes it even better to form one of the greatest action RPGs of this generation.

You play, once again, as Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher, who got framed for assassinating king Demavend and must prove his innocence. The story is heavy in politics, but is also very deep and feels just like the novels. Triss Merrigold also returns with her beautiful red hair and all. You will also see other familiar faces such as Zoltan Chivay and Dandelion. The new faces are strong, likeable, and memorable characters that you will grow to love or hate respectively throughout the course of this 20-30 hour game. Geralt himself is even stronger this time around with more problems than you can shake a stick at. You learn to respect him more and see just how much this poor man can take. CD Projekt really shows you the roots of both good and evil in humanity in such a realistic fashion, and that's what really drives the characters home.

The combat in The Witcher 2 is better than the first game because gone are the timed sword swings and stances. You now just have light and heavy attacks, but can block, counter attack (when you unlock the skill), and you still use the steel/silver sword combo. Steel is for people and silver is for monsters. The combat was very hard to do when the game first launched, but patches as of late have fixed this for multiple blocking, and faster response. The combat isn't great and is clumsy especially early on when you aren't very strong and towards the end of the game. Combat will make you smash your monitor in frustration in the beginning because you have to learn to just hit once or twice, dodge, run around, hit another couple of times, rinse and repeat 50 times. Yeah, its one of those games in the beginning. After you level up enough you can cut down enemies in just a couple of swings and groups of 7-10 won't really bother you.

Of course you can equip better armor, weapons, and so forth, but The Witcher lets you do other things like equip trophies that are found on bosses that increase stats, use sword enhancements such as oils, whetstones, runes, and armor enhancements (kind of like Monster Hunter?) This adds a lot of depth to the customization to your load out which has endless possibilities. I think the biggest improvement is the resource gathering and alchemy because its so simple and easy now. Just gather resources as you go and you can meditate and create potions that increase your vigor (for signs; more on that later), vitality (health), a potion that lets you see in the dark, damage increasing potions etc. The only problem is you can't drink them from the menu, but you have to use them before a fight. This is my biggest beef with the game because if you are low on health in a fight you're screwed unless you took a Swallow potion beforehand. The premeditated potion drinking is a big flaw in the game, I think, but some hardcore RPG players may like this.

The Witcher is also famous for its Signs use because Witchers can't use magic like sorcerers or mages can. There are six different signs and they use chunks of vigor but recharge over time. These Signs are vital to winning in combat especially against bosses, so learn to use these in tandem with sword combos and you can win even the toughest fights. One last thing you can use in combat are Places of Power which you find with your wolf medallion. Activate it and you may find, out in woods or wild places, signs of power that give you temporary stat boosts. These come in handy early in the game (especially in Flotsam) when you are a low level.

The story also has moral decisions thrown in there that really change the outcome of the story. Of course there are multiple playthroughs (but no new game+ sadly) so you can see what each decision will bring. There are a lot of plot holes in the story that aren't filled until the very end during dialog which I found odd, so if you get confused just hang in there until the final moments of the game. Overall my biggest issue is the potion use, combat, and the huge difficulty spikes. The graphics are groundbreaking with gorgeous lighting, highly detailed textures, and amazing landscapes, as well as varied environments with nice weather effects. The character models look superb, and the voice acting is top notch. This game just shows that indie developers can make games look great. You do need a monster rig to run the game on high settings (especially with Ubersampling enabled you need probably dual GPUs and a high end quad core CPU). Other than that The Witcher 2 is amazing in every way and should not be missed by anyone.

In chapter 2, have no idea how much game time I have left.  Puzzlement mandates I pause and brief.  Unlike The Witcher 1 potions cannot be ingested during battle.  Not so much of a deal breaker except you don't know when battles will take place other than a couple of instances where the protagonist bellows to the effect that his medallion is active.  The number of times I had to reload a prior save to ingest potions before continuing destroys the continuity of this game.  I've read the developers reasons were to the effect that they ran out of time to implement toxicity or some other nonsense.  Deal breaker and a proper mention to the often non responsive combat controls. 

Game design is practically a disaster.  I wrote a detailed guide for new adventurers almost 10 years after the fact detailing significant issues in an important encounter.  You will find the guide in the guide section if you require assistance with the encounter.

Let's talk dice and fighting (hand to hand) matches.  The dice implementation is a huge letdown.  In W2 you manually roll dice where in W1 the dice rolls were automated.  W2 dice rolls can go off the board and you'll not see the dice again though a mod can fix this.  The dice board angle was also changed from W1 for the worse, though a mod can fix this.  In W1 the game told you both your hand and your opponents.  This is lost in W2.  See where this is going.  Fighting hand to hand in W1 was just about perfect.  In W2 the designers made fighting a mini game.  No, this is no joke.  W2 hand to hand fighting is a QTE.

It's wondrous how The Witcher 2 lacks not only the charm of The Witcher 1 but its forebear's design as well.   I miss just about everything that made The Witcher 1 the classic it is.  There are only bones here, not a true sequel.  Thumbs up for a play through but for all the wrong reasons.

Tip: For more seamless combat develop macro's for the signs.  Select sign and use sign and bind to either your keyboard or mouse depending where you bind your sign keys.
[list]
[*]Axii - Sequence macro OnPress(AxiiKey)/WhileHolding(AxiiKey)/OnRelease(AxiiKey)
[*]Igni/Aard/Quen/Yrden - No repeat macro {SignKey}{SignActivate}
[/list]
There is a mod on how to drop the medallion scan from 10s to 1s however if you add any additional mods which effect base_scripts.dzip you'll need to see a modding guide.

FOV adjust is included here (Enhanced camera-724-1-0 )

More than a worthy sequel for The Witcher.
A big improvement in this game is the combat, much more modern and fast, but it is very punishing and the biggest problem is that Geralt has a wide range of animations for fast attack and another fr strong attack and the game decides which one to choose RANDOMLY! That means getting hit because the animation chosen was not the one the player wanted.
The fact that you can import your decision from the first game to this one is SO F****** COOL! Makes you feel that you impacted the world and now is just following the story that you began, it really feels amazing.
The story is a great mystery with a lot of thing to discover, and twists to unravel, all in all a very good story that feels grounded in this universe but still it is not as memorable or as good as the first one. It's definetely not bad, grandier and with more worldly impacts but less personal in a sense.
The music and sound keeps the same beat (hihi) as the first one. The voice-acting in this series is top notch and every character feels himself in this universe.
The graphics are the second biggest improvement, with more money to spend after the first one the team could focus a bit more on this aspect and makes this game a lot better to watch and appreciate.
The biggest improvement is definetely just a well rounded more polished game, a lot of risks were taken in the first one, and a lot could just barely be done to be noticeble, in this one all of them were continued and had much more time to develop, the details of everyday life or simply what already exists and will keep existing after geralt are what makes this universe so appealing.

The Witcher 2 is a linear RPG game like its prequel The Witcher but better in every aspect, the story starts with the murder of [spoiler] King Foltest [/spoiler] , 1 month after the ending of the first game. The game is about Geralt trying to clear his name for a crime he didn't commit, basically. (I won't spoil anything).

 The graphics are really, really good when compared to the first game but there are some optimisation problems unfortunately. I highly recommend you to turn Ubersampling off if you don't have a powerful graphic card, I have a GTX 1660 Ti graphic card and the game's frame rates dropped to 50 FPS (sometimes 40) when the Ubersampling is turned on, (in The Witcher 3, I get stable 60 FPS on ultra graphic settings. When the V-synch is turned off, I get even more.). 

The combat is really enjoyable, it's like The Witcher 3's combat system in a sense but also unique and the finishing animations are really good.

 I also really liked the fact that they really enhanced the game in Enhanced Edition, I have this game also on Xbox 360 (it's not Enhanced Edition) and it's horrible; lots of bugs, horrible graphics when compared to this one, lack of animations and countless other things I don't remember. 

To sum it up, the game is really good, better than The Witcher in every way (except for the story for some people), it's definitely a must-play, to those of you who have beaten the first Witcher game, you WILL LOVE this game. Those who played The Witcher 3 first, you most likely will love this game, but no guarantees...

I started with Witcher 3 in 2017, tried playing withcer 1 recently as well. This has to be one of the best games I have ever played. It has aged exceptionally well. My only complaint so far is some below par voice acting, but the game itself is an absolute dream. The difference between the 2006 Witcher game and the 2011 Witcher 2 game is such a disparity, I can no longer tell that CDProjectRed started as a bunch of Witcher fans who didn't know how to even start making a video game. They had it down somewhere during the development of Witcher 2, and its shows with this game and it's infinitely popular sequel.

Finished this at 49 hours but I accidentally left it running over night once so probably closer to 35. The story was great. The game was okay. Some of the rewards didn't feel meaningful and there was a lot of running around that didn't seem necessary for a non-open world game. I was comparing it to dragon age 2 in my mind as I played because they came out around the same time but it's been a while since I played that game. I do like Dragon age's party system but I guess witcher is more real time action so maybe it doesn't make as much sense. I'd say it is worth playing for the story. I'd probably skip most of the side quests. I've read there are some good quality of life mods but I played without any. Looking forward to playing witcher 3!

Even after so many years The Witcher 2 remains one of the best RPGs.
With a few mods and Geforce Filter the aging visuals can be covered up a little and breath new gameplay life into old Geralt's adventure.

The Witcher II has a good story line that is the bases for much of the game play. Like the first game there are two major paths you will choose between, but some other choices can impact the ending.

The combat mechanics in Witcher II are much better than the first game, and can be fun once you get the hang of them. My personal favorite was to focus on sword skill supported by aard and some use of qwen.

One downside compared to Skyrim is that it is not an open world, so once you progress and leave an area you cannot return to it if you forgot a task.

I also turned off difficult QTES since I am not a fan of button mashing mini games. It still requires some of it with it off, but it is not as bad.

Some clunky fight mechanics but pretty fun game all in all. I completed 8 of the possible 16 endings. I recommend looking up the "Witcher 2 Weapons, Armor and Items Guide" so you can find the good gear and not waste orens. Also, check out the Steam page on "How to get all of Geral'ts (sic) secret passive abilities." I wanted to play The Witcher games in order after watching the Joseph Anderson youtube reviews. Listened to The Last Wish by Andrzej Sapkowski as well. Highly recommend that book/audiobook by the way. I'll listen to the rest of them as well I'm sure. I'm ready and hyped to play Witcher 3 for the first time now.

The Witcher 2 is the next installment of The Witcher game that is entirely different from previous one in term of game play where TW 2 has the newer stunning graphic and animation. It sacrifices the gameplay and become more "consilified" version which makes the game more into combat adventure fantasy game instead of traditional CRPG I knew of. Did I mention the combat system that looks so janky and impractical because poor hit detection and accessing menu and combat enhancement can't be done during the fight. I have to say, I was surprised -- between the three games, this is easily the hardest! The first Witcher's difficulty comes more so from many of the features being archaic in nature. The second game is much better designed at a sheer technical level, which isn't a surprise since CD Projekt Red both had more resources and experience following the first one, but I digress. The difficulty of The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings comes from just being designed to be difficult. While some fights, especially during the game's prologue and first chapter, proved to be frustrating, it is hard to view the game being hard (at least compared to the first and third games) as a detriment. This game is a rewarding experience, more obviously so than the first game, and more quickly than the third game. The second part of CD Projekt Red's trilogy based off the writing of Andrzej Sapkowski is a far more focused entry than its predecessor, and is a game I would highly recommend!

Definitely a game worth playing for any fan of The Witcher. It is definitely more difficult than Witcher 3, even on lower difficulties. This game does not hold your hand like TW3 either, combat can be brutal and unforgiving but very rewarding when you get the hang of it.

While not as open ended as the third installment in the Wticher series, this game still offers plenty of exploration, monsters, and impactful decisions. I only wish it was fully controller compatible, and that the control mappings were more easily found. I find myself switching from gamepad to mouse and keyboard for the dice and arm wrestling minigames.

[b]2 Cents[/b] 

I was already invested in the Witcher lore because of the first game before I began to play The Witcher 2 - which picks up exactly where the last game left off. When I started the game, I was greeted by pretty mediocre mechanics and I wasn't sure if I was gonna like it as a game of its own. I was playing it solely to precede my gameplay of the Witcher 3. 

But boy, did this game come off as a fresh of breath air. The beginning had an AC Brotherhood kinda vibe - which is still among the most memorable beginnings of a game for me. It didn't take very long for the game to pick up, and I'm going to try very hard not to spoil something substantial which happens within the first hour of the game. 

This game follows Geralt's journey as he tries to prove himself innocent of a crime that has smeared his name across the continent - while also getting torn between a nation in the brig of civil war. The story is actually one of the best stories I've seen in a video game - and it doesn't hurt that the gameplay is actually pretty fun and challenging. [I played at Hard and plan to have a second playthrough on the hardest one available]

I loved the monster-hunting side content as well - whether it be looking for Endregas in the woods surrounding Flotsam or wading through the dark caves of Velen. There is a pretty decent variety in the kind of maps you play in, and the missions you do. I wasn't expecting to like this game so much when I began playing - but the lore and the environment successfully manage to submerge you in the world. 

The game is divided into three chapters, and one of the most surprising things in the game was at the end of chapter 1. I'll refrain from spoiling much - but you get to chose to side with a particular group in this civil war. They are not necessarily the polar opposite sides fighting each other - and none of them seems to be philosophically or morally better than the other. This is another incredible thing about the game, of how it keeps every character in the gray area. No one is right, and no one is wrong. Minor spoiler below.

[spoiler] So, what you chose during this point can send you to two completely different storylines. You get two games to play at the price of one, to be honest, and I've already planned to replay the whole Witcher series with a different set of endings and consequences. I decided to go with Iorveth because it felt very natural. I was having a peaceful meeting with him when Roche decided to attack without an afterthought. I handed Iorveth his sword, and it felt very natural joining him considering even Zoltan - one of my closest friends has decided to side with the Scoia'tael. I didn't regret it seeing how beautiful Velen was, and it was pretty fun doing the side missions available there and hanging out with a goofy group of dwarves. But I did feel as if I should have gone with Roche this whole time. He got me out of trouble at the very start and even helped me when I chose not to side with him. Definitely going to see what his side of the story had to offer in my second playthrough. [/spoiler]

Even as a standalone game, it is an incredible experience - even though I would suggest following the lore. Watching the Game Movie of Witcher 1 helps to catch up with everything that happens before this game, and gives you a very required introduction to the series. I suggest this because I know that the first game can be clunky and is not for everyone. 

Take your time to do side missions, they are fun and well worth it due to the upgrades and prizes they carry - get immersed into the world of The Witcher.

I played Witcher 2 before I played the first Witcher game and it's interesting comparing the two. When I first started I found the combat system in Witcher 2 quite difficult to get my head around and found the arena-style tutorial quite difficult as I was also taking in a lot of other information too. However, after a while I really got into it, and I can say it's a definite improvement on the banality of Witcher 1 gameplay, making sword fights far more tense and requiring some actual skill. I played on normal mode as I'm not a great tactician, but I can see how this can be a good challenge for many players.

The story is an interesting contrast to Witcher 1. I haven't read the additional source material or watched the recent series at the time of writing so I have nothing to compare it to other than my expectations and I have to confess that the first Witcher game seemed closer to my expectations than this one - it's more about travelling around hunting monsters and exploration than this. I have to confess the plot regarding the assassination of kings was the least interesting one in this game and I wasn't particularly excited by massive battle scenes either.

The skill tree was also a little confusing at first compare to Witcher 1 but I soon got into it with the exception of the lack of mutagen options. Instead of mutagens being the end of the skill tree like Witcher 1 which you gain by creating and drinking specific potions, they are now attached to upgrading specific attributes which have a mutagen slot. This meant that due to my choices I only ever had one mutagen in the whole game. This seemed like a missed opportunity when it could have led to some interesting skill combinations if it had been thought of more creatively.

There's also a clearer sense of choosing two very different paths earlier in the game which makes for increased playability to my mind than the first game which largely involved deciding on three particular alliances later in the game. Witcher 2 gives quite a distinct experience in terms of story and quests based on the paths you take.

I still have a couple of unresolved issues which the story itself. I really don't understand why someone like Geralt would be so concerned to show deference or give assistance to kings, for example, but this didn't make sense in the first game either. All in all, however, it held together better than that in Witcher 1 with a much clearer narrative so it's a definite improvement. I'm also curious as to why a game which can include magic and dragons, can't stretch its imagination to include anyone who isn't caucasian - we know the Romans had many different ethnicities and there was plenty of trade between African and the Far East and Europe so even if this is meant to be Medieval there's no way everyone would be white.

Also decided for Witcher 3 that in order to up the difficulty I'm going to try as far as possible to live the life of a eunuch. There are far too many women who you can accidentally end up sleeping with simply by choosing one conversation option. I feel celibacy is the last real challenge for Geralt.

On the whole, really enjoyed everything except the stupid cutscene at the start of the game which you have to skip every single time you boot it up!

First let me talk about CDPR, then I'll talk about the game itself.
Let's not forget that time when Witcher 3 GOTY was on sale for 14,99 euro/dollar on Epic Store. And Epic offered coupons of 10 euro/dollar for each game costing 14,99 or more, so we could effectively get Witcher 3 GOTY for 5 euro/dollar. And the coupons were covered by Epic, so CDPR would get the same amount of money, whether we paid 15 or we paid 5 and Epic paid 10. However, CDPR forced Epic to lower the price for one cent, so the price was now 14,98 and not eligible for the coupon anymore, so we couldn't get it for 5 anymore, but we had to pay full 15.
I repeat, CDPR was at no loss here because they would get the same amount of money either way, probably even more if the game was eligible for coupon, because than more people would bought it (me included). So they did it out of pure spite. 
Remember this next time you want to give your money to CDPR. 
Unfortunately, I bought Witcher 2 before all that, so I couldn't refund it anymore

And now on to Witcher 2 itself. And what an utter piece of crap it is. 
It's supposed to be an open world game, yet it is not. You are tied to one small area and you can just go back and forth within that area. I played just the first part, but I assume later you move to the next small area and it's the same.
Navigation is awful. Game is full of invisible walls. You can't go through slightly taller grass or jump below from small height, if the game doesn't want you to. I guess the game would take half the time to complete, if the walking/running wasn't so slow and you wouldn't suffer so much to find the right path that you are allowed to go through

Let me keep it short.
-Story is Fantastic like straight out of a great political fantasy book.
-Characters are amazing. Even the most unimportant characters get fleshed out. Everyone has their own motivation. Everyone is scheming. Don't trust anyone.
-Music while being good didn't leave any major impact on me. Some tracks are far better than the others. Some are even fantastic.
-Gameplay is good. Nothing much to say here. It is a bit of a downgrade from Witcher 1 where exploration was a rewarding gameplay mechanic. Here it is very toned down.
-Combat is shit. It does not work. It's broken. It may lead you to believe it is good but no. I completed this game twice on hard difficulty. Hit detection is shit, dodge roll doesn't dodge the attacks. Potions are toned down, and signs are to. Overall a major disappointment.
-Graphics are actually great for a 2011 game.
-Encountered some minor bugs here and there. Performance is really good. No complaints here.
Overall, even if I have some problems with the game I freaking loved it. Iorveth's path gives you a lot of story, while Roache is just a bro. I love his character so much! I'm glad he returns on Witcher 3. Anyway, love this game, very underrated. Go play it.

i decided to play this game since my potato computer won't run witcher 3 even on lowest graphic settings and it did not disappoint! the story is very good and complex, so complex in fact that you will have to go and check who's who after cutscenes to understand what kind of political drama is going on. the voice acting is amazing, which is probably also due to the fleshed-out characters all with different quirks. from what i've read so far, everybody seems to be complaining about combat and how hard it is but i, a person new to this whole thing who had only played 2 games prior to witcher 2, was completely fine with combat after the tutorial. i mean sure, i did die a couple of times but once you figure it out and get a feel of the controls, it's pretty straightforward. it even gets a bit too easy towards the end of chapter 3 (on normal difficulty). great replay value as well, as the ENTIRE second chapter changes due to your decisions. worked perfectly fine with my controller too, if anyone's having second thoughts about partial controller support. the single problem i have with this game is now that i've finished it, i wanna play witcher 3 even more.

I almost considered skipping this game and going straight to Witcher 3 after I beat Witcher as I've read multiple times that playing the first two games are not critical to understanding the third. I'm incredibly glad I did not skip this game. The story in Witcher 2 is very well done, with rich voiced dialog and a plethora of morally gray situations Geralt can get involved in. Not to mention some great plot twists! The telling of the story itself is fairly complex, with several branching paths you can take (including a branch fairly early on that will tell the story from two very different perspectives.)

Combat is fairly fluid with some sword play mechanics (the ability to parry and riposte) as well as the ability to dodge or throw knives/bombs. You have what amounts to a stamina meter which drains with each parry/riposte, so you can't block forever. The same goes with Signs, too. This limitation forces you to be strategic in combat, so you can't dive into mobs of enemies and expect to make it out alive, especially early in the game before you get some decent armor and weapons.

Character progression is straightforward. Each time you level up, you can spend your points in one of four branches (Witcher basic training, Swordsmanship, Alchemy, and Magic) and effectively build Geralt to suit your play style.

Do yourself a favor and pick up this game. Right now it's $19.99 on Steam and it's worth every cent and more.

I really enjoy my time with The Witcher 2 ! And I highly recommend immersing yourself The Witcher 2 before proceeding on to The Witcher 3 for another momentous yet intense journey with our beloved characters once again. If you have enough time it is worth playing all games in the franchise [witcher 1,2,3] as the story connected to each other. 

Here are what I like and dislike about The Witcher 2. 

[b] Story [/b]
+ Very immersive storyline, choice matters so choose carefully 
+ Very well-written storyline, they had done a thorough research indeed 
+ For someone who said the game is too short it's definitely not, basically you need to play the game twice in order to get the full story 
- Too many names and places that I can't really remember lol But being a fantasy RPG game one must know this is the typical problem. It doesn't really matter though but if you need to know every single thing that is going on you probably need to listen to the dialogue twice 
- Everything is on the dialogue and journal. It's an old school rpg so this was pretty much expected, but sometimes you might got info dump pretty easily 

[b] Gameplay [/b]  
+ Vast improvement from The Witcher 1. The gameplay is now more interactive and action-packed, unlike its prequel that you need to timely click 
+ Signs and items (bombs, traps, throwing knives...etc.) are more easier to use with a shortcut 
+ Camera angle is fine 
- I just hate the potion system that you need to drink before the battle, you can't do that during the battle anymore which is frustrating cause sometimes you don't know when and where you might need the potion 
- The inventory interface. It makes finding stuff more difficult when you divide it into categories like this I prefer the old one in The Witcher 1 where the items are more clumped 
- I don't find the side quests interesting enough to do 
- Unstable FPS + Constant map loading in a certain scene 

[b] Graphic [/b]  
+ Massive development from The Witcher 1 
+ Beautiful cut-scene and animation. Animation is a great improvement ! 
+ Less reusable character models 
- The graphic is too bright and vivid it gave me headache, need to be adjusted 

[b] Sound [/b] 
+ Memorable ost 
+ I love that they blend the local folk song into the music, it really gives the exotic Polish vibe

To be honest this isn't a great game.
It's a very good game and it falls just short of being great.
It's shortcomings are mainly in the gameplay.
For one thing the combat doesn't feel satisfying.
I did not have fun hitting a single enemy hundreds of times,slowly chipping at their health bar.
You don't even feel like you just cut them with sword.
On the contrary most of my opponents were able to kill me in three hits.
Potions do help with this,but the most important and prominent potions usually require one rare alchemical substance and it's hard to come by.
If you want to use these potions you have to look for this ingredient for a considerable amount of time.

The story and the way it is presented is very interesting and very good.
It got me playing through the clunky combat to see the rest of it.

In addition to that this game has character.
Most of the NPCs I met I liked.
Some I've hated.And that was likely the point.

Side Quests are interesting and but when I say this,do not expect a Witcher 3 level of writing.
The voice acting was okay.
I've encountered no bugs or glitches during my playthrough.

I give this game a 7/10.

The full price is worth it,and I bought this game in a sale.
It was definitely worth my money.

Originally was really excited to play through the entire franchise, where the game ports over decisions and the same goes for items from the first to the second. Only to find out the path i chose had absolute no effect on the Witcher 3 : Wild Hunt, none of my decisions mattered, none of them are even mentioned in the next game, nor are any of the items I worked for have an appearance in the 3rd game. After a few hours of gameplay it just feels like a chore to play. The game has it's moments for the first couple of hours, but that's about it. The most fun i had was gambling and fistfighting in bars, which isn't saying much. The combat is terrible, where you get bombarded by several enemies at once and a non-functioning targeting system which in my experience served to only get me killed several times. Playing on the hardest difficulty was a mistake. I love to challenge myself to play games on the hardest difficulty, but this is not one of those games as it is so bugged. I realize i have an excessive amount of hours to write a bad review but about 50+ hours were on my old laptop that couldn't even run the game so I inevitably gave up and honestly I wish I had just left it at that. If you do purchase this game (which I advise against) I highly suggest you wait for it to go on sale for $5 or less.

-story all over the place, characters one dimensional and not interesting in the least, voice acting is pretty damn cringe that I'm always hitting skip once I read the dialogue

imho its one of those games that you keep playing hoping it actually becomes "good" but this never happens, recommend you just play witcher 3, don't waste your time on this one making the same mistake I did. in hindsight, it might be a better idea to read up on the lore online instead.

I am happy to say that after quitting halfway through the Witcher 1, in my eyes a very flawed and inconsistent game, I gave the Witcher 2 a chance. This game turned out to be fantastic. About 30 hours of fantastic story telling and difficult to make choices that radically change the final outcome of the story, and influence the fate of many of its characters throughout. 

All in all, a fantastic game with incredible story and very good combat and rpg elements that you shouldn't skip if you're a fan of the witcher series.

Bought this game on a whim in 2012 after looking up hidden gem RPG's for Xbox 360, and absolutely loved it back then. I remember thinking it looked so far ahead of everything else. Fast forward to 2018 is when I first played Witcher 3 (I had kids in the interim and stopped gaming so much for a while) and of course that game is a masterpiece. Thought about playing this again so got it about a week ago on Steam, and dear god... it still looks absolutely fantastic, but dare I say I enjoy this more than Witcher 3. The character movements aren't so robotic, they move so smooth and natural. I mean that as in during the cutscenes or during dialogue scenes. Witcher 3 had about three different emotes: that explosion thing with their hands, a hand outreaching, and a shrug. I love Witcher 3 but I doubt even the biggest fan could say that Witcher 3 has any environment that is more detailed than Witcher 2. I mean christ, the forest around Flotsam, although not as large an explorable area as what Witcher 3 has, is far more lush an environment. The tree trunks are huge and the trees themselves reach to the sky. I will say this though, it took a bit to get back used to the different controls of W2 after last playing W3. The spells working a bit different was also a struggle at first. But, I promise once you power though you will have an absolute masterpiece of a game on your hands. I actually enjoy playing it after playing W3 recently because I get to connect some dots. 10/10 all the way.

Don't buy this game. It's bad. It is borderline broken and a Got-damb chore to play.

This game has three things going for it: Story, character development, music. 
The rest of this game is a mess. I am going to hit on the major points as there is just so much hampering this title from success. 

Travel:
Geralt is bound by the technology of his time. The entirety of the game play hours is done on foot. There is no fast travel back to the town hub. There isn’t a single mechanism, potion, or spell that enhances Geralt’s speed of travel. The resultant is that Geralt flails about the central township and surrounding medieval metropolis in a frenetic oscillation fetching this, that, and the other to push the story line forward. 

Combat: 
The combat is seemingly unfinished. Geralt swinging his sword does not obtain the results that you would expect given the animations shown. Geralt’s dodge roll, for instance, is only intermittently functional. Likewise, there is no perfectly timed block that can be executed by Geralt.  To block Geralt must hunker down into a static position and wait for the AI to take the hint. You may be given an opportunity to counter attack which may or may not happen if you attempt to follow through. The AI have no such troubles. An AI character can block while moving, block when not blocking and block whilst kneeling. There are several moments where Geralt has beaten a combatant into submission and, is unable to finish the job because the enemy is kneeling and is blocking attacks from all directions. 

The camera angles are not helpful either. Often Geralt's enemies are out of sight of the camera. You may think Geralt is done fighting only to lunge off the combat stage at a set of unseen enemies who have been delivering clandestine beatings from the stage left curtains. This is annoying on normal mode but, unseen enemies in hard mode mean instant death.  

Meditating:
Use of potions are not possible without meditating in part 2 of the Witcher series. This is not the only nonsensical mechanic Witcher 2 has to offer but, it is one of the more baffeling  ones. To this day I have not needed to sit in meditation to take a dose of cough syrup or drink a beer.  The meditation feature should have been better thought out; maybe meditation could give temporary buffs to magic, buffs to alchemy preparation, temporary improved vigor, or negate status effects. 

Leveling up:
The majority of EXP is gained from your quests. In general, combat earns squat experience points. That being said you will gain a few levels from all the running back and forth from town to forest. There are three major skill trees and one minor skill tree. There are a total of 51 skills and each skill can be leveled up 2 times; for a total of 102. Your max level is 35 which leaves you with 34 talents to populate your skill tree. By the end of the game Geralt only can achieve a 33% in Witchermanship. And MAN do you ever feel it.

On a vanilla run of this game Geralt is exquisitely remedial at his profession. Expect to die. A lot. There is little narrative reason for this. Geralt in bread, borne, trained, and neutered for the job of monster hunting. There is simply no good reason for him to suck so loudly. You are forced to put nearly all you talents into swordsmanship but, you will later find out that you can fireball your way out of trouble for almost the last 3rd of the game.

Menus: 
This game’s menus are a god awful mess. The save/load menus are the peak of ridiculous. Instead of having a save game slot that can be saved over, every save makes a new file. If you are like me, you won’t notice this high tech feature until the whole game slows down trying to load all your save files for selection. Do you want to delete the older files and keep the most recent one? No problem. You may delete them…I N D I V I D U A L L Y. 

Buying and Selling is no better. At the shops the buy and sell lists are nearly identical save for the actual items. The highlighting over the item you think you are buying/selling is almost indistinguishable from the surrounding screen. It is difficult to tell who has what, what item is going where, what the items do exactly, and how many items are being bought/sold. There are sub categories of items which attempt to organise items more coarsely for expedience; unfortunately, there is unnecessary overlap of items in each category which results in bloated subcategories of items making the system almost useless. 

The item selection in inventory is equally frustrating. As an attempt to select an item for use may result in you inadvertently unequipping Geralt’s pants or boots, and still not having use the selected item even though the item is highlighted for selection.   

Game play menus are hidden within game function menus. Eg Map and journal are with the save/quit/graphics/audio/controls menu. There is a whole bestiary menu hidden within the character menu accessible via meditation. 

The Economy:
Not only will Geralt be forced to be an incompetent witcher throughout the event of The Witcher 2 but, he will be broke as joke. Witcher 2 sports a savage sell back ratio of 1 to 24. Back in an era where a person could expect to only be able to afford one new set of clothes in his life time, Geralt can sell a sack of magical swords for roughly 20 Orens. Which isn’t enough for him to buy a pair of first tier gloves. The first Witcher had a sell back ratio of 1 to 5 which is much more manageable. 

As with experience, money will come almost exclusively from quests. Combat earns you next to nothing. The easiest way to raise money I found was to arm wrestle. (If that isn’t a euphemism, I don’t know what is)

Inventory:  (FML)
Geralt cannot haul more than 250 lb of crap. Which is strange because witchers need a wide assortment of crap to witch. Perhaps there is some sort of “bag o’ holding” Geralt could employ? NO. Some spell that could help? NO. Perhaps Geralt could hire a mule? NO. But a transdimentional chest that is present in one location per chapter? Brilliant, YES. 

Conclusion:
This game just got worse and worse to play, and by the end I hated it. I just touched on the basics of why this game is awful. I didn’t even get started the dialogue and how much agenda driven slogans are barked at you while you play.  Modifying the game helped with the look, and addressed some of the balancing issues. The game is passably functional once it is modified. I couldn’t recommend this game even if it was free.

[h1] Overall [/h1]

The successor of The Witcher 1, The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings, is a 2011 action RPG developed by CD Projekt Red that continues the story of the Witcher Geralt of Rivia. 
The game is a great RPG, with multiple choices and paths that affect how the story goes. And even though the combat is clucky and most of the times frustrating, the story, exploration and overall awe of the universe are enough to make it a worthy experience. 
 
[b]  7.5/10  [/b]

[h1] Audience [/h1]

☐ Kids
☐ Teens
☑ Adults
☐ All

This game contains a lot of graphic violence, nudity and themes such as murder, rape and racism. The combat involves finishing your opponents with gruesome animations were you get to sever their limbs. Many women wear skin tight clothes with giant cleavages.  There are also explicit sex scenes, with nudity and very suggestive audio. 

[h1] Graphics [/h1]

☐ Bad
☐ Alright
☑ Good
☐ Beautiful
☐ Fantastic

For a game released in 2011, the graphics have aged well. Some areas look really pretty, with giant castles, dense forests and ancient cities you get to explore. Each of these locations are very remarkable and full of detail. 

[h1] Music [/h1]

☐ Bad
☐ Alright
☑ Good
☐ Beautiful
☐ Fantastic

I don’t think music was the focus in this game, but some tracks, like the combat music, are really good. It is a certain step up from The Witcher 1. 

[h1] Difficulty [/h1]

☐ Easy
☑ Average
☑ Easy to learn / Hard to master
☐ Hard
☐ Unfair
☑ Frustrating

The game can be considered difficult, but that’s because of some infuriating design decisions and lack of game mechanics. 
Geralt has a dodge action, but he doesn’t get invincibility frames during it and it is super short, which leads to you getting hit even if you timed the dodge perfectly. 
Various enemies, especially monsters, have lunge attacks that are super quick and have perfect tracking. They will literally turn midair and hit you during your dodge. 
From the start of the game, you can only hit a single enemy with your attacks, which makes no damn sense considering the existence of the group style in The Witcher 1, which lets you hit multiple enemies that are close to you. 
All of these three problems come together when you have to fight 10 monsters at the same time and it’s super frustrating.
The game’s animations are also very clunky and slow. Geralt is supposed to be super quick and agile, but his actions don’t really go well together. When you use a sign or item, it takes a while for to be able to attack or even move/dodge, and you will get hit during these pauses. 
The game does gets easier (or less frustrating) when you level up and acquire skills that should be base (like longer dodges and cleave attacks). It gets easy to cheese the combat by doing hit and run tactics. 
You can also use potions and several items to help in fights, but using them can be super bothersome. And items are usually not worth it, as you have to stop to use them, and mobility is key in combat. 
There is also the fact that after some cutscenes or conversations, the combat will start with Geralt getting hit where you can’t do anything. 

 [h1] Bugs [/h1]

☐ Way too many bugs
☐ A lot of bugs
☑ Few/minor Bugs
☐ Useful glitches and exploits 
☐ No bugs

I don’t remember seeing any bugs other than 1 or 2 times an NPC was floating or twitching, but these bugs didn’t affect the gameplay in any way. 
I didn't encounter any game breaking bugs. 

[h1] Story [/h1]

☐ There is none
☐ Bad
☐ Alright
☐ Good
☑ Very Good
☐ Fantastic

The story continues after 1 month from the end of The Witcher 1. Geralt is now serving the King or Temeria, Foltest, and they are in the middle of a siege. After completing the siege and capturing the city, Geralt and Foltest go after the latter’s children, that are being kept in the temple. 
Geralt and the king get separated and upon finding the children, an assassin takes Foltest life leaving Geralt to take the blame. Now, the Witcher escapes prison with the help of Vernon Roche, one of the deceased king’s loyal agents, to capture the assassin, prove his innocence and find out why Foltest and one other king have been murdered ¬– find out the mystery behind the assassins of kings. 
The main plot is really interesting and there are several choices you can make that affect how the story progresses. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

☑ Frustrating
☐ Sleepy
☐ Boring
☑ Fun
☐ Challenging

The game can provide a good amount of fun, but there are some frustrating aspects. Exploring, you can talk to NPCs and do quests, collect alchemy ingredients and explore locations for loot. 
One thing that was made easier from The Witcher 1 is the meditation, that now is accessible without the need of a bonfire or inn. 
The odd thing is that now time goes much faster and (at lower difficulties) you no longer need to meditate to level up. You can only craft potions and items when meditating, but their use is so limited that I had almost no incentive to meditate other than to wait. 
Because to drink potions, you must be meditating, but you can’t meditate during combat. You will have to reload a previous save and drink the potion beforehand or flee combat. 
Also contrary to Witcher 1, potions are much weaker and a lot of times they have drawbacks (other than toxicity) from being used, which further makes them less appealing. 
The combat is super frustrating, as discussed in the Difficulty section. It does gets better later in the game, but even then, comparing to similar games, specifically Demon’s Souls (2009) and Dark Souls (2011), the combat is simply bad. 
There is no lock on to focus the camera on a single opponent and in the end, it becomes a hit and run game. You cast a sign, run up to the enemy, attack him once or twice and then run back, repeat. This also makes the combat fairly easy later in the game (on normal difficulty). 

[h1] Grind [/h1]

☐ No grind
☑ Isn’t necessary to progress
☐ Average grind
☐ A lot of grind
☐ Way too much grind

If you play every mission and kill every enemy, you will get sufficient levels and money to play through the game easily. 

[h1] PC Requirements [/h1]

☐ Any PC can run it
☐ Weak PC
☑ Average PC
☑ Good PC
☐ Very good PC
☐ High end computer

I imagine average PCs can run this game easily, but if you want to max everything and get high fps you will need a good PC.

[h1] Game Time [/h1]

☐ Really short (0 - 3 hours)
☐ Short (4 - 8 hours)
☑ Few hours (10 - 20 hours) [If you focus on the main story]
☑ Long (40-60 hours) [If you try to complete everything/Explore thoroughly; If you replay the game, making different choices]
☐ Very Long (61-100 hours) 
☐ Extremely Long (101+ hours)

Playing though the game trying to do every quest and explore every place, it took me almost 30 hours of gameplay. I imagine that if you rush the main quest, you should be able to complete it in 10 to 15 hours. 
Replaying the game choosing different choices and paths should provide more 20 to 30 hours of gameplay. 

[h1] Game Price [/h1]
☐ Free
☑ Full price
☑ Wait for Sale
☐ Don't buy

Being almost 10 years old, the game is sold very cheaply and goes on sale with high frequency. 

[h1] Tips and Tricks [/h1]

•	Don’t get attached to any equipment, you will quickly find something better. 
•	Mobility is key in combat – always be on the move
•	Unlock and upgrade the skill that gives longer dodges
•	Also prioritize getting the ability that gives cleave damage – there are many sections with dozens of enemies that can easily surround and overwhelm you
•	Abuse the Quen sign
•	Don’t be afraid to spend money – if you do every quest and monster hunting contracts, you’ll get a ton of money. By the end of the game, I had 10000 gold lying around in my pockets

So playing this without having played 3. Witcher 1 was garbage. Obviously I may just be playing it way too late, but on every level I really didn't like the game. The voice acting was bad, the writing was bad, the combat was BAAAAAD. There was not a single redeeming quality in that game.

Having said that, Witcher 2 I believe is the game they had in their head as they were making the first game. I think that also includes the players themselves. Like, as the terrible dialogue was coming out of your speakers, there are just these fans who were willing to translate what was happening in the first game into what happens in this game. 

"Oh, Geralt is saying something so funny. It's not funny the way he's saying it, but in my head I'll just force it to be funny."

So if you really like Witcher 3, and you're asking yourself if it's worth going back, I can safely say skip 1 and just start here. None of the choices from the first one really matter. None of the context does either. You literally spend the whole game struggling to explore 1/3 of 1 town in that game. This is the game that actually introduces you to the kings, lands, and world itself. I also have never read the books, but have watched the show. This game is the one that FINALLY sold this world to me.

So first the good. Story and world building. This game doesn't ACTUALLY have that much in it, but it somehow makes you feel like so much is going on. It makes you feel like each area is bigger than it is, and more fleshed out than it is. It's like a masterclass in believable world building. The characters also feel super fleshed out. If you've experienced other modern RPGs, especially Bioware ones, you know what to expect here. There's less dialogue, but the character work here is still fun and engaging. Unfortunately they don't hold up 100% because of issues in the last act of the game, but there's a lot to like anyway.

So the bad. The combat is bad. It's not Witcher 1 bad, but it's still very bad. It's clunky, stiff, hard to predict. Every 10 battles you'll suddenly have 1 battle where things kind of click and you can see what they wanted it to be. But the other 9 battles are just twitching nonsense. Dodging is poorly handled, parrying is dumb. Getting consistent behavior on attacks is just a frustrating mess. AI is dumb. Counterplay is all over the place. Boss fights are pathetic messes that just boil down to exploiting 1 or 2 of the same strategies over and over. 

The level up tree is just full of traps and bad choices. Like, instead of offering different playstyles, you just have good choices and bad choices. You could make the bad choice and have fun I'm sure if you really tried or are into that sort of thing, but it wasn't my jam. Oh, actual traps are some of the worst attempts at trap gameplay I've ever seen.

This game is sexist as fuck. Like, if that doesn't bother you, or if you actually enjoy that, good for you. I'm giving the game a thumbs up in the end, but this is just a fact. This game is super duper sexist, and if that rubs you the wrong way, do NOT buy this game. Ignore the fans, steer clear. 

Final bad thing, and I think this is an unpopular opinion, but the split path deal hurt this game overall. At first I thought it was pretty interesting. This is definitely the most divergent I've ever seen a story based RPG attempt to be. Chapter 2 on each path feels like 2 different games. 

But then Chapter 3 happens, and it's a steaming pile of garbage. I've played both paths, I know all the secrets, and I can tell you, this game would have been a lot better if they had just made it 4 chapters. Like, chapter 2 is Roche, Chapter 3 is the other guy, Chapter 4 was the finale. 

I think for people who like to replay games, this last negative won't really resonate with you. But for me, I personally don't like replaying games very much. Like, I used to do it more back when there weren't a million games in my backlog. But these days, committing to playing a game twice, especially back to back, just so I can actually experience the full plot... It was a huge turn off. 

ESPECIALLY since Chapter 3 was so obviously hurt by all of this. Through out the game you're striking this personal balance between crafting gear and finding gear while questing or as a direct reward for questing. Then you get to Chapter 3, and the best swords in the game are just lying around on the ground. Like every other room, there's just a dead body with Excalibur just sitting on it. Oh... does this replace the sword I spent 1200 orens on? Oh... Good I guess. Yay. I guess I shouldn't have bought that.

Characters and quests are the same thing. Each town has this arm wrestling challenge. You find yourself searching high and low, in taverns, homes, everywhere for your opponents. Until Chapter 3. It's just 1 guys, and he's just awkwardly standing in an awkard spot. "Oh hey there, I'm in a Circus! I'm a super interesting character with a fleshed out back story! Don't mind that I'm just standing next to this crate though..."

Everything I said about world building goes into the garbage in the last chapter. There is absolutely NOTHING here, and they've done NOTHING to hide it. Like... Mystic River Quest. I won't spoil it, but that pretty much sums up how stupid Chapter 3 is.

So yeah, I hated a lot about the game. I said the words "This fucking game" a lot while rolling my eyes. But when push comes to shove I'm giving it a thumbs up. If I had to sum it up, it's like they had this really unique vision and really just wanted to go for it. They took risks. Many of them paid off, and many of them crashed and burned. I can easily point out 100 things I didn't like about this game, but the 10 things I did like... I REALLY liked, and I can't honestly say I've ever seen some of it before. And that's saying a lot for a game released 9 years go.

good 
game bois

I'm coming to it nearly a decade late, but the game holds up pretty well. I was able to jump into it without having to remember what happened in the first game, and things ran fairly smoothly (although it definitely has its share of bugs still). More of a politicking to monster-hunting ratio than I was expecting, but the story was engaging overall. At some point, I'm sure I'll play through again to take the other main path.

The tutorial level was less than intuitive, which had me thinking the game would be hard, so I went with the recommended Easy mode... that ends up being much too easy a few hours in to the end. I'm sure some of the crafting and alchemy features would come in handy more with higher difficulties. Even though I didn't use potions much, I'm skeptical of the inability to use them in battle. A lot of big fights start with a cutscenes that don't allow for meditation afterwards.

Solid and definitely has an audience. There are some hard-to-ignore faults, but the experience is fulfilling.

You don't have to play this game to start Witcher 3,but there will be some minor changes if you do import your Witcher 2 save files to Witcher 3.
The environment and atmosphere is definitely good enough to make you feel immersed with its unique fantasy settings.
Expect some QTEs that come suddenly,and with the grimey yellow filter on some maps,have fun with your orange coloured UI which you will definitely not miss.
Combat system is a hit or miss,though it's a hit for me.
You might also encounter some translation errors (P.S: Beehive bomb is the same as Grapeshot Bomb).

This game is not flawless,it may starts slow,and sometimes it may feel tedious.But if you do persevere,you will find one uncut gem,full of potentials.

Like with the Witcher 1, I'm kinda mixed on the Witcher 2 as well. There's a lot about it that's a clear step up. From the production values to the performances to the writing to the weightiness of the combat, it's just better. But there's also still a bunch of small things that frustrated me to no end, most of which just feel like outdated design.

While the UI is an improvement, it's still not as streamlined as I want it to be. Still have to go through different menus to get the information I need. Like why is the info for monster weaknesses tucked away in the character skill tree?!?? While there are more options for sorting inventory, it's still limited and feels like a mess. All the QTEs are just terrible and unnecessary.

I actually enjoyed how much delving into the alchemy in Witcher 1 made Geralt into such a beast, so I was kinda bummed out how CDPR nerfed it here by giving most potions significant side effects, so much so that I mostly stuck with a handful of potions that didn't have big drawbacks instead of experimenting like I did in the first game. Doesn't help that it was also changed that you can't drink potions on the fly anymore! I get the design decision to make it so you have to prepare for fights, but what made it worse for me is how I also don't like that there are many combat instances where you can just die virtually instantly.

The game loves to throw a bunch of charging enemies at you hitting you from all sides that also deal a ton of damage and lock you into deadly combos. There's a sluggishness to the movement and attack animations that never felt quite right to me, and it's mixed into this Arkham-style auto lock-on to enemies without the snappiness and control. 

There's also dodge rolling that seems pretty necessary for every big fight, and that doesn't feel great either. Never bothered to get the dodge roll upgrade, so maybe that would have helped, but I just didn't wanna spend an upgrade point on "better dodge". Although I guess the whole skill tree didn't really have a lot of outright new abilities to offer, so maybe I should have gotten that if that would have made some fights less frustrating. In fact, most of the skill tree is just "get better stats and mitigate weaknesses", so character progression isn't particularly exciting.

I'm a little iffy on the vigor system too that limits how often you can block properly and riposte and use magic. Aard is good, I wish Axii were more reliable, but Quen also felt like such a necessity just to get through the tougher fights. Found myself casting it just to get hit again not long after, so I had to run around a bit to recover vigor to cast it again to survive. Even got most of the vigor upgrades, but that only delayed me getting into that cycle. 

I dunno, I just never truly got into a great flow state with the combat in this game, even though i did have a good number of fights that I still breezed through.

The political intrigue, while kind of hard to get into from the start with all the proper names and storied histories, got me hooked enough halfway through. That stuff in the first game felt more contained and easier to follow, but wasn't super compelling aside from the struggle of the Scoiatel. I do think there's a conservative streak to the political themes of the game, even with its attempts at "shades of gray". Any attempt at changing the status quo is poisoned by ambition and racism and conspiracy that would ultimately lead to chaos. 

While not as directly male gaze-y as the first game (hey no more cards of naked women you had sex with!), the increased graphic fidelity seems to have also been taken advantage of to show off and leer at women's bodies, which isn't great. And yes of course there's no shortage of women here offering themselves up to Geralt!

I regret not letting the peasants dispense mob justice on Stennis, that haughty prick. Iorveth's a hoot. Saskia's cool (although i wish she had more of an active role) and Philippa's an interesting foil. Letho's... got a strange accent. Thanks for the exposition dump at the end, I guess? 

I feel like Triss is wasted potential in this game. I liked her attitude in the Witcher 1, and I was looking forward to her being more of an on-screen presence here but alas! I really hope she gets treated better in the sequel, but I suppose there's gonna be this whole Yennefer love triangle thing for her to contend with!

I'm guessing I would have liked this more had I played it back when it first released. The narrative elements are compelling, and if I didn't have a ton of other games to get through in my backlog, I could see myself replaying it to see how the story would unfold if I made different choices. That's always admirable in story-rich RPGs. It's just that there's also a ton of small archaic design choices that frustrate me, and comparing the action to other much better implemented combat systems in other ARPGs that I've played since 2011 *cough*soulsgames*cough*dragonsdogma*cough*monsterhunterworld*cough*, I didn't have a great time engaging with the game's demanding mechanics. 

While I enjoyed untangling the conspiracies and navigating the dilemmas, I don't think there is anything particularly insightful or novel about the story that makes the game worth heavily recommending these days, especially when you have to tolerate the antiquated gameplay to get to the good parts. Maybe if you are truly interested in the Witcher-verse and want to immerse yourself in the world and see how you can influence the warring factions, give this game a shot.

-The Witcher 2 is a fantastic sequel to The Witcher, you can see how CD Projekt Red took what people loved from the first games story and incorporate it into this game. Amazing characters, set pieces, paths, etc. This game includes  a prologue, three chapters plus a epilogue. Took me less than 65 hours to complete the game doing main quest, contracts, and some side quest. *Played on Roches Path*
-The gameplay is not SUPER great, but it is manageable and quite fun. The combat is not as bad as I thought it would be going into it, it was fair for its time and holds up well today. The only times where I did have problems with the combat would have to be during boss encounters, the dodging was quite clunky and at times the hit detection from enemies would still hit you from a distance away. Your signs are your best friend in combat, same goes with traps and bombs.  
-The UI could of been better but again, it is manageable after a while of playing. I did not like how you had to go into the meditation screen to drink your potions, it was unnecessarily time consuming. 

From what I have seen, Iorveths path is not drastically different from Roches path so I really did not feel encouraged to go into a second playthrough immediately. Maybe a few months later when I have nothing else to play. 

Amazing game overall.

A beautiful game, with very detailed plot and a good graphic engine (for the time it was released).
As a RPG the main story changes according to some of your decisions. Also, there are lots of side quests and hidden stuff or riddles. 
As in every good RPG, there is also the "crafting" part (potion/oils/bombs) and the evolution path that you can decide yourself  on each step. The game also includes mini games like "dice poker", drinking contest, fist fight etc.
The bad side is the gameplay control which is quite hard to learn and the mouse movement which is not very intuitive (very low sensitivity no acceleration, etc.) and cannot be changed. There are some annoying bugs here and there, but in the years that have past most major bugs were fixed.
I recommend !

After completing the game on dark mode (one difficulty bellow the hardest, about 5 difficulties in total) I must say, it's a great game, with some issues. Things aside, if you played witcher 3 or not, it's a good game. The combat feels great, eventhough when you take damage it's sometimes sluggish or you have to figure it out yourself if you did or not. Or in other words, it doesn't feel responsive sometimes. I enjoyed leveling up, getting skills, new equipment, getting better. Gameplay wise, the game is just great. You get to decide what will happen. Things have effect, and there's a lot of choices in the game. Sometimes I felt as if I'm having a big dillemma there, which brings me to my next point. The Emerssion and Story, my lord it's f***ing awesome! it's so good. The story sucks you in and you just can't stop. I won't tell about the story, wouldn't want to spoil anything. However the game ain't perfect, and it also nearly falls short on very good for me, due to the amount of CRASHES. At somepoint you get fastruated. I believe in my 40h game, I got about I'd say 5-10 crashes. And it sure gonna piss you. Another thing I hate, why when I open the door I need to see a bloody animation?! I don't need animation to move through a door, heck EVEN if it's OPEN it does that. It's just ruining for nothing. Here's a big boner, the performance my goodness, it's AWFULLY OPTIMIZED. I'll just put it like that. The game is out for more than 9 years now. And I tell you, my GTX1060 6GB barely handled High on 45FPS, that's right 45!!. Despite it's big flaws in performance and a bit of unwise development choices, I overall Enjoyed the game. And despite it being fastruating at times, I had great fun. And I say it, it's worth the price.

Finding your way around can be frustrating, especially in chapter 3, but the game is well worth it.  You must be patient and learn the combat. The second Witcher game is a fantastic RPG with an amazing story, and great combat mechanics. However, some bosses are annoying QTE events, and some quests are tedious padding.  

The game has an amazing linear story filled with decisions that actually affect how things turn out at the games end. The story and investigations are well designed, so you won't need a guide or outside knowledge to figure out what to do. The game has diverging pathways that radically change the story. Decisions made at right at the start of the game will change the events of the story 20 hours later. 

The combat of this game is amazing, but for some reason this combat is not applied to some boss battles and encounters. The best combat of this game involves going into battle with prepared potions, specialized weapons, and an understanding of monster weaknesses that has been acquired from investigation and following storylines.  Monster hunting and most bosses require dodging, using signs, and exploiting learned weaknesses. On the other hand, QTE bosses are grueling experiences that revolve around pushing the right random buttons at precisely the right moment. Defeating most QTE bosses is required regardless of what story path is chosen and require complete restarts of the fight if failed.  

 Some quests and side-quests are tedious busywork that don't add much to the story. These quests usually involve gathering materials around a safe area or killing easy monsters that don't require any preparation or specialized knowledge. A lot of this is just the developers giving you an excuse to explore safe areas, but some of this is obviously padding. You don't have to do most of these quests, but most of them have minor stories that are worthwhile or offer good rewards that make up for the lackluster gameplay.

the game feels like it tries to drown you with shortcuts, potions, brews, tactics which seem more like a fighting simulation than an rpg, but a few hours of gameplay and you notice none of that matters! than it feels more like a beat'em up game than an rpg. actually it feels everything else but a decent rpg...

and the cutscenes... i've read 4 books from the series, watched the whole season on netflix.  just wanted to play that damned 5 minutes before the next cutscene bores me to death. now the game feels like a mouse clicker game, trying to kill the "skip" button... merely 3 hours of struggle and boredom, than i'm done with this game. thanks for nothing.

Amazing game, finished it in 18 hours. It really stunned me how big this game is (and it was released in 2011). If you want to play Wild Hunt, I'd suggest watch the story of the first game on youtube (the game mechanics are boring, the story is really good tho), then play this one, and only then move on and play the Witcher 3.

I was really hyped to play this, I've seen a lot of playthroughs, I've heard great reviews, this sort of game gels with me really well...  However, I cannot recommend this game to anyone while it's in the state it is.

So I've switched Steam to run as admin, I put the compatibility to Windows 7 and run as admin for both Wticher 2 .exe files, I tweaked the user.ini, I verified the folders...  First I had the issue of the game failing to launch, so bad- in fact -that it would crash Steam as well, and force me to reboot my PC to start over.

Now today, I can get the damn thing to launch, but my mouse, keyboard, and gamepad all don't work, I'm frozen in the menu without being able to select any options.  I have to use the task manager just to make the game shut off!  I shouldn't have to jump through these kinds of hoops every time I want to play this game.

This game is only from 2011, porting it over to PC shouldn't have left it int his kind of state, and going through forums, I'm clearly not the only one!  Why is this game even allowed to be sold here if you can't even guarantee it'll even LAUNCH!?

Avoid, unless someone fixes this mess of a game somehow, it's not worth it even at a discount if you can't consistently play it.  A game that will launch one day, and not the next just isn't worth the money, not matter how much you want it to be.

The visuals are beautiful, especially for a game that is almost ten years old.
I loved the art style, the medieval looking armors and weapons look great and almost realistic. Locations like lush forests and medieval towns, dark ruins and dungeons are a joy to explore.
The story is great, intriguing with your choices having meaningful, long lasting consequences. Basically the Witcher trilogy is like Mass Effect done right. You can even import old saves from the Witcher 1 to continue the story as you left it.
There are good characters, some you actually grow to care about. Voice acting is very good as well (at least the English version).
There are many interesting side quests, but it is easy to miss them, and the game does not hold your hand, so you should explore and think, before moving on with the main storyline.
The fighting mechanics are different, and I think improved compared to the first game.
There are some problems though.
The game seemingly randomly prevents you from saving, mostly around cutscenes or scripted parts. Controlling Geralt feels a bit clunky.
There are some bugs, especially around quest scripting that were annoying, but I did not experience any game-breaking problems. There are a couple of misleading or confusing quest objective descriptions, and sometimes quests can affect each other, so you should save often. Some puzzles are annoying and felt illogical. There were a couple of annoying boss fights and QTEs, but generally the difficulty is not a problem on medium. If you want a challenge, you should go for hard.
Apart from the small annoyances, this is a great game, worthy part of the trilogy and one of the best RPGs I have played.
