Really great game. I recommend playing this after The Witcher 3 (or the 1st, but it's a little clunky gameplay-wise if you're not accostumed to RPGs without modern combat), because starting with this one might be a little confusing story-wise. Witcher 3 is more accessible in that regard and a good introduction to the universe in order to better understand the politics going on in the background.

The outright horrible controls are simply not worth it. I waited a long time to bother with this since I truly hated witcher 1 controls, although I completed the game and found the story somewhat interesting. Decided to give Witcher 2 a try and was pleasantly surprised by the graphics. The combat, however, was a step down from witcher 1, which I did not think was possible. Where in Witcher 1 you had to learn the logic of how the combat mechanics work in the game, in Witcher 2 there is hard to find a logic. There seems to be some sort of automation on which target Geralt locks on, unless you use the locking mechanism. Say farewell to fighting multiple enemies at once (at least in the beginning of the game), as Geralt jumps about the battlefield and you're left to guess where he lands next. When you attack an enemy, and see him attacking you at the same time, Geralt simply can't change the selected course of action, even under the direct order from dodge button. Best description I can muster for the combat is (mockingly) real-time turn based. You start an attack, see someone attacking from the side and decide to abort and dodge. That will not happen. Instead the attack is carried through until someone hits you and you stop. And then someone else hits you as well. Had also a few BSOD happen, but I'd rather blame that on my system, so no hard feelings there.
Rough at first.  But if you have the patience the ride is quite enjoyable.

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings will kill you, but it's mostly a death worth dying.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Set in the fantasy world of the Northern Realms, The Witcher 2 takes place not long after The Witcher.  An integrated save reading system will actually take your save file from the prior game and apply the consequence of the actions you took in that playthrough to the world of The Witcher 2.  None of those choices will serve the main plot of the game but they do help to personalize the world.  After an assassin nearly killed Foltest, king of the country of Temeria, Geralt of Rivia finds himself hired on as a personal bodyguard to the cautious monarch.  Geralt is a mutated superhuman and monster hunter by trade, preferring to march through the wilds of the world in search of paying work, but refusing a king's demand for service is often not wise.  Unfortunately for Geralt, though he was successful in stopping the first assassin, the second strikes far luckier and manages to frame Geralt for the regicide in the process.  Thrown into the nearest dungeon for interrogation, Geralt convinces his captors that he is innocent and is tasked with bringing the true king slayer to heel in order to clear his own name.  What follows after this point is very open to the player's decisions.  In many ways, AoK's story is a bit haphazard.  It's clear the writers wanted to both tell this large overarching tale of political intrigue and world changing magical events that the witcher has a hand in while also wanting to let Geralt do his thing: that thing being the slaying of monsters and breaking of curses in exchange for cold hard gold.  To this end, the game's main quest is often road blocked by fascinating but unrelated events that waylay Geralt's journey and while this makes the story feel pretty scattershot at times; enough of the overall narrative is woven in to each phase of the game to help keep the end goal in focus.  The tale has many twists, turns, and betrayals and even more impressively, effectively has two completely different stories to tell depending on choices made in the game's early chapter.  Friends become foe and vice versa and the strong characters are entertaining and likable if crude to the point of being obnoxious at times.  Perhaps the biggest knock against the game's story is that it ends inconclusively and feels very much like a middle act of a larger story that is begging for more closure than what is offered here.  Still, it's an entertaining ride chalk full of extensive lore and  narrative suspense.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Easily the weakest link in the game, the gameplay of The Witcher 2 is divided between dialogue, exploration, combat, and minigames.  Exploration is pretty simple.  Geralt can mostly only really run around, but certain ledges can be scaled or leapt and weak walls can be knocked down with a magical shove of Geralt's Aard sign.  There's a massive variety of things to be found in the world from plants and alchemy ingredients as well as cash, weapons, armor, crafting supplies, and more.  Dialogue is the backbone of the game's story but many choices made in the game are actions the player chooses to make or not.  Combat is the meat of the game but sadly it's a bit rotten.  Everything the combat needs for success is here but lacking heavily in polish.  Geralt carries two swords on him at all times: one steel for creatures of the world and one silver for monsters and magical beings.  Pulling out the right sword for the right enemy is a rather brain dead operation as the two types of enemies almost never intermingle; a missed opportunity to be sure.  Geralt's swords feature light and heavy attacks for hacking away at foes while a dodge roll allows him to quickly escape danger or reposition for a new strike.  Magical signs can be used to stun, knock down, burn, and even hex opponents, and Geralt can find, buy, craft, or create an entire slew of bombs, throwing knives, traps, and deadly blade oils.  Potions can be concocted and then downed before battle giving a variety of buffs, often with drawbacks for the more powerful varieties.  Finally, Geralt levels up over time and points can be spent on his sword craft, magic, or alchemy skills.  Unfortunately the level cap is quite low and it pays much more to focus on one of these trees than to scatter points only midway down all three of them.  Even more unfortunate is the fact that, despite all of these wonderful ingredients, the combat fails on almost all levels.  Enemies come in a massive variety from regular humans of varying equipment and skill to swarming nekkers, hulking golems, and gargantuan boss enemies.  Geralt, although somewhat fluid, can often be awkward to control and many of his abilities seem at odds with their intent.  His Axii sign can turn enemies into allies, but the only time this is worth using is when fighting several at once, but the only way to use it is to stand still for several seconds while they descend upon you with violence as you try to hex a single of their many friends.  Janky animation will often see knocked down enemies standing right back up and already swinging or stunned mages managing to cast spells anyways.  Disgustingly massive hitboxes can cause enemies swinging wide of the mark to tear hefty chunks out of your health all the same.  All told, the game is best played on the Normal difficulty.  Anything higher is just putting yourself at the mercy of the buggy animations and insane enemy attacks.  The game is already tuned to be hard, and were it more polished, it has everything in needs to be a challenging but fulfilling combat experience, but alas this isn't the case.
Oh, and the fist fighting minigame is a joke even less interesting than the arm wrestling and dice poker.
The game also includes an Arena mode that spans several waves of increasingly difficult enemy compositions and would clearly be a lot of fun were it not hindered by the game's janky combat.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
Good heavens these environments.  The Witcher 2's world, especially its nature environs are dense, colorful, well lit, and just beautiful.  It's honestly hard to describe just how genuine, ancient, and thick the forests, fields, and rocky crevices in the game feel.  Character design is absolutely excellent for the main cast and even the NPC's while often somewhat samey in appearance, feel personable and rustic.  The music ranges from acceptable to surprisingly head turning, but is implemented somewhat poorly; especially in most of the cutscenes.  The animation work, when it functions as intended, is quite good for the most part as are the sound effects.  The piles of lore entries are all written from the perspective of the game's bard, Dandelion, as are the paragraphs upon paragraphs of text describing each phase of every quest in the game; making them flavorful and fun to read.  It's not without issues, of course.  Level of detail swaps happen on a spectrum at all times so objects, especially foliage, seem to be ever shifting as you get closer or further away.  Smaller shadows are very dithery and the game even manages to include several spelling and grammatical errors.  Furthermore, NPC's often repeat the same, bloody lines again and again as you pass by them.  Finally, the game makes ENTIRELY too many save files.  Instead of having a few auto save slots, the game just keeps all of them, which makes opening the Load menu take longer and longer and longer the more you play.  Still, the game's overall package does far more good than bad and is well worth the minor bugs.

[h1]I really want to recommend this game, I really do but...[/h1]
this game has so many technical flaws that eventually made me drop it for a while. By having such major problems, I sincerely would not recommend it.

Before I expose my reasons, I've to say that:
[list]
[*]Probably has the best graphics of 2011
[*]Beautiful landscapes
[*]Awesome soundtrack
[*]Remarkable story
[*]Lots of decisions to make that actually have an impact on the story
[*]Good gameplay length
[*]Good voice acting
[*]General big improvements to every mechanic of The Witcher 1 (potions, signs, runes, armors, weapons, etc)
[/list]

[i]Okay, it's an awesome game, so what are those "technical flaws" you mention that are such a big deal.[/i]

[b]Constant crashes[/b]
The game randomly crashes for no reason, sometimes after a cutscene, sometimes after a zone load and others just because why not. You may think "well, then all I have to do is to save every 10 minutes" but surprise! the game won't start if you have too many save files. And that's not it, neither the auto save not the quick save will work either.

So let's say you have been playing straight for several hours, you've been saving constantly cause you know it sometimes crashes, then it crashes, you try to open the game and it crashes again after the intro, next you delete some save files and finally manage to open the game just to realize that nothing got saved.

Sometimes the save file is just corrupted.

[b]Combat[/b]
I have to say that the overall gameplay is far better than The Witcher 1 yet has lots of issues. Many people has already pointed out that it feels clumsy but that is falling short. The animations are a mess, very often there is no visual correlation between the enemy's attacks and the damage received. The hitboxes are pretty bad, if you roll to dodge an attack, you probably will get stabbed in the back anyways. The enemy's ranged attacks are twice as wide as they look. Sometimes enemies will dodge every single attack despite being cornered and visually getting hit by your sword. The scene hitboxes are inconsistent, in some places you can go through vegetation and over rocks meanwhile in others a single brick is enough to block your movement.

[b]Summary[/b]
Just as I previously stated in the title, I have mixed feelings. I actually liked the game but the amount of troubles that made me went through were displeasant enough for me to not recommend it. If you are here solely for the story read the books.

Once again Geralt is thrown into the world of politics. His king is assassinated and he gets the blame. To clear his name he hunts the assassin and uncovers one plot after another.
Every part of the story is great: the assassins plan, the plots in the background, the politics and Geralts memories.
The game has two big routes, each has a unique plot and each gives new information about the overall story. The routes could be longer, even when doing most or all quests, a route takes less than 20 hours. 
The game features several more choices, most of them impact the ending of the game, but apart from that the game is pretty linear. Most quests and sequences have exactly one solution and those that give you multiple solutions are basically "choose X or Y".
You can import a [i]The Witcher[/i] save to gain some money and some special weapons and armor (if you have them in the save). Sadly the armor and weapons are not much better than your starting gear, which makes sense from a balance perspective, but it ruins the narrative of these pieces. Better give them to us later in the game instead of changing epic weapons with an epic story to have ordinary stats.

Like [i]The Witcher[/i] its successor features romances, this time with actual sex scenes. The dialogue leading up to the scenes is good and the actual scenes, albeit most being a bit short, look nice. One of them is probably one of the best love scenes in gaming history, you will know which one I mean when you get there.
While the romances are nice, Geralt seems to be a sex addict in this game. He was a smoothtalker and womanizer in the original game, but now he seems to be thinking about sex all the time, even in very inappropriate (not in a good sense) situations.
Also there are less available (and willing) women compared to the predecessor.

Combat in this game is just awful. On lower difficulties it is boring and on higher difficulties it's frustrating as long as you miss some vital skills. The old combat system is gone, instead we got an ordinary one. You can attack, block, roll, cast signs(spells) and use items (traps, bombs, knives).  Blocking reduced the incoming damage from the front and is generally useless until you improve it with skills, rolling lets you dodge some attacks but is of limited use until you buff it. Rolls dont have iframes and combined with a short input lag kills you more often than it helps you (thanks to 200% damage in the back... which also can be reduced with skills). 
Signs are great and essential on higher difficulties, but they fatigue. Fatigue decreases your damage output which unnecessaryly prolongs fights. You can reduce the fatgue gain per Spell by gaining vigor, which is gained by leveling certain skills.
Items are great as long as you have them, they are expensive and crafting is constricted compared to [i]The Witcher[/i]. (needed components are more specific)
Once you have the right skills, fights are less frustrating. There is just one Problem with skills: you only get 34 skill points with max level, with more than 100 skills in the skilltree.
If you get the right skills combat is easy, even on higher difficulties, if you got the wrong ones, you might as well start a new game.
If you play on hard or dark difficulty you will also notice that autosaves are rare, better quicksave every 5 minutes.

Fistfights and arm wrestling get boring very soon, but they are not worse than [i]The Witcher[/i]s fistfights. Poker got worse and it wasn't very good before.

If it weren't for the story, characters and dialogue, Witcher 2 would be a shitty game.

After playing the original Witcher, this game is a big jump in quality in a lot of areas. I originally played this game years ago and somehow breezed through it (i'm guessing just doing the main storyline). But this time, I went back and played Witcher 1, with intentions to finish 2 again and then 3. But I simply cannot play this game any longer. I play with a controller so pulling up the map takes a lot of time just to get to, and then at the same time the map is not detailed anyways so it's just a lost cause. And I know it is probably just my monitor but I cannot find a good brightness/contrast setting that helps me in any way. I really enjoyed this game. I decided to replay the whole series and it is a welcome change from the gloomy graphics and awkward combat system of TW1, which is a good game in its own right as well. The graphics are the first thing to be noticed, but that's to be expected as the years go by. The main draw for me, was the combat. Instead of the antiquated timed system introduced in its predecessor, TW2 is much more akin to TW3 in how it handles combat and just felt more immersive and challenging in the mere fact that it gives you more options in how to attack and defend against your opponent(s).

As for the story, it really is great. The beginning absolutely reels you in from the start and doesn't let go. I won't spoil anything, but the way the story branches at a certain point almost guarantees a second playthrough if you want the full version of events. The characters are interesting, have reasonable motivations that seem to spiral and spiral on, and inspire you to learn more not just about them, but also about the world around them. The game's ending plays out based on your immediate choices in a way more tangible than TW1, imo, and has more immediate consequences. As I left in a review for TW1, playing this is a must if you want to know more about certain references and characters that are left behind in TW3. (happens frequently enough...IORVETH *cough*)

The game is great fun, very interesting quests, characters and dialogue with a well thought-out combat system. A lot of options for different playstyles, although I always find myself focusing mostly on swordplay. Great learning curve for the melee combat, and good variation in fights and enemy types.

The story starts out strong and takes some interesting turns, but the main antagonist is not a particularly compelling character, starting with his ridiculous physique. By the end the game has lost or moved away from the initial conflict and antagonist, to the point where it makes perfect sense to just let the kingslayer go. And no matter what you do as the player, the end is quite dark and makes it seem like a lot of what you did was in vain. It's not terrible but a better central conflict between Geralt and the kingslayer could have helped a lot. I compare this to Witcher 3 where the central conflict is much more focused and compelling.

Still I would absolutely recommend this game to a fan of the series, even if I prefer its sequel overall.

Second entry in the award-winning RPG series based on the homonymous fantasy books. I just finished it, after being released 9 years ago (...) and the game stands the test of time as a solid, mature RPG experience about choices and consequences.

Pros
+ A mature theme and topic where choices play a very important role. To such a degree that after about half way the games splits into two distinctly different sub-plots.
+ Excellent characters whether they are secondary or primary with well worked background and stories.
+ Nicely designed graphics and environments including character and monster models.
+ Very good music and voice acting. 
+ Using gamepad the control is good and battles, after you get used, flow in a natural way.
+ 3 different paths to choose, with distinct skills, variety of weapons, upgrades, crafts and armors.
+ Gerald is definitely one of the best protagonists to appear in a video game.
+ Very clever idea the existence of a [spoiler] non-combat [/spoiler] ending.

Cons
- Technical issues, prominent among them the memory overflow when a lot of saves are stored. Unacceptable not to have this fixed after so many years.
- The global story and politics with 1000 different names are very hard to follow to the point that I failed to understand them. Not that I bothered as I found the stories and conflicts between characters much more attractive.
- Some difficulty spikes, for the example the first time you encounter the arch-enemy the battle is way more difficult than near the end (well, one could suggest this is a plus point as it depicts the growth and strengthening of the character)
- Act 3 seems a bit unbalanced and rather unfinished as you end up finding a ton of armors and weapons one after the other only to realize that the best build has been used for 2 (or 1 depending on your last choice) battles. 
- Preparation is important but can happen only before battle. In many instances long sequences of events lead to battles finding you completely unprepared. 

All-in-all excellent RPG game, very highly recommended even after so many years after its release. Looking forward to play the final part.

Good game overall; however, if you are coming from the witcher 3. The mechanics will seem a bit dated and the game will seem a bit more unfair. Some of the quests require some googling to be done really and some weaknesses of enemies are not obvious.

Story is as rich as ever, every character has a backstory that sticks to the grander one, your choices you make as you progress may or may not have a impact down the road, there is no way to tell, it's full of surprises, just like RPG games are meant to be, you can never experience the full story on one play-through, every human being is different and they will make different choices and the story will adapt to those choices.

Yes of course this game is really good and you should play it. Normally I would write a more in-depth review, but you guys know about The Witcher already. It's not as good as the third game, but it's still absolutely worth your time.
Plot of Letho was amazing.
Storyline and progress is similar to the first, but combat is much different. It takes a lot of getting used to at first but eventually you quit cussing and wanting to throw things.

I suspect Witcher 3 managed to be so good because it's the exact opposite of this game.

Horrible environment design - Oversized surroundings with tiny playable spaces.

Horrible combat - over sized hitboxes, difficulty either super hard or god mode, no drinking potions in combat, dodge doesn't make you immune, enemies just swarm you all at once and there is always loads of them.

Good story overall but the characters and dialogue is usually poor. Wouldn't be interesting at all without the 2 games surrounding it.

There are also only 2 proper levels which are both very small and dull.

The cherry on top is the inventory which is literally just a list but it's also zoomed in loads making it extra hard to find items than you want.

Having just completed the first Witcher and wanting to continue the story up to 3 now I have a machine capable of running them. I thoroughly enjoyed the first game, but unfortunately this sequel cannot hold a candle to it.
Geralt handles like a brick on a string, making basic tasks like walking around town or going through doors very annoying, nevermind moving around in combat and getting stuck on invisible barriers or the godawful forced stealth sections. 
Dialogue has options that have Geralt say things totally different to what's written, much unlike the first game. 
The game has a tendency of throwing you into immediate combat after long cutscenes. Granted, this is a sin the first game also commits. Not only does this leave you annoyedly skipping through if you die, but it means you're forced to flee or take on several enemies that are spawned surrounding you. Given how much less forgiving the combat is in 2, this can lead to pretty much one initial guaranteed death with each such encounter. 
Arm wrestling controls are incredibly floaty, and unfortunately this is required in the main quest if you don't want to give up a whole bunch of gold. 
For some reason, they totally changed the controls from 1 to 2 and transitioning from one to the next is incredibly difficult. You can no longer drink potions without meditating, and the game is stuffed with extra features which it honestly could do without. What's more, many of these aren't explained. The aforementioned arm wrestling is never explained, and many random symbols and aspects of the HUD are also totally unexplained.

Combat, minigames, navigation, HUD, journal, inventory and crafting are all a huge step down from TW1. The only improved aspect are the graphics (which do look phenomenal), and the story and voice acting (from what I've seen - and that's saying a lot). Story and cinematics alone can't carry it though.

A depressing step down from the first game and what I've heard of the third. Don't bother. Just watch a plot summary or the cinematics on YouTube and you'll get a better experience than this.

EDIT: I've heard it's a lot better on console. The game definitely feels like it's geared that way.

While this game improved upon the downright awful combat of Witcher 1, this game is in sore need of a remake when it comes to the mechanics. Downsides include

No visual, sound, physical feedback for being hit. The health bar is tucked away in the top left so checking your health is not natural. Dying by surprise is not uncommon. 

Sword play is garbage. I played for a majority of the game on hard, but the meta is to spam magic and roll around. It's not rewarding to interact with the block/parry mechanic. There is also not a stamina bar, so rolling around cost nothing.

Magic and blocking are tied into the weird combined "stamina" like bar, however running and rolling do not effect it. You can use a point of this "stamina" to block or to use magic. What this does is discourages player from using both dynamically, and instead focusing on pure sword play or pure magic. The meta is just to roll around and spam igni. 

Quick time events. I'm glad they fell out of favor. 

Boss fights are not rewarding or sporting, one is finished off using quick time events. Another boss fight randomly calls down off map abilities to pumble you, during those off map abilities he cannot be hit. 

This game story is great, meaningful choices are amazing and the graphics standup, however the combat is so annoying, meaningless and unrewarding you feel like it's a slog to get to the next part in the story.

This game is an exciting, well-made intro to The Witcher. The set pieces are still impressive and I found myself surprisingly invested in the story by the end. If you're looking for a good RPG with combat, story depth, and difficult choices this is it. And its a really great primer for The Witcher 3, which takes many of the same gameplay and story ideas and explores them much further and better. You can also import your save from this game to 3, impacting 3's story based on your decisions in 2.

One thing to watch out for: It's somewhat difficult and long for a video-game campaign.

Having heard such great things about the Witcher 3, and having played and completed the Witcher 1 with some enjoyment, I decided to give the maligned 2nd game in the series another shot. This was probably my 3rd or 4th start on the game, with me abandoning my prior runs primarily due to difficult gameplay that I didn't really understand. This time I made sure to use an Xbox One controller and keep some game guides handy in the event that I needed them. I'm glad I did.

The TL:DR here is this - If you've been looking for a "Bioware-esq" RPG with branching dialogue, choice and consequence, that cinematic experience with fully voiced characters and lines, and plenty of "we'll bang", then the Witcher 2 is exactly what you're looking for. Its on sale on Steam at the minute for a couple bucks and is really never too expensive anywhere, so buy it.

The game centers around Geralt of Rivia, a legendary Witcher (a modified human made to hunt monsters) in a pseudo medieval world that is rife with Game of Thrones style political machinations between numerous factions (The Nilfgard Empire, Temerians, Redanians, Kedwenians, Adernians, rebellions, dragons, elfs, dwarves, humans, sorceresses, and on and on and on). Geralt, using a well worn fantasy/rpg trope, is suffering from amnesia and looking to find clues to his past life, but given the ending events of the prior game has found himself in the service of a king.

The game definitely does not hand-hold on the story telling elements much, perhaps in a ploy to get the player in the same "amnesiac" shoes as Geralt, and I sometimes found it difficult to follow who or what the characters were talking about. The game really embraces the concept of "this character knows you, and clearly has a history with you, but you know nothing about them". Nevertheless, I felt compelled to keep playing as the plot of the game unfolded, as the intrigue from the GoT style politics as well as Geralt's past were cleverly interwoven to keep the lead firmly in hand pulling you forward. My only critique here is while the prologue and the first two acts are packed with things to do, the game does definitely run out of steam and really narrows the scope for the third act. I didn't really mind however, as by that point I was ready for the game to wrap up and reveal its secrets.

The game also has some entertaining villains, the best kind that possess some elements of nobility and logical goals that just happen to be in the way of what you're trying to accomplish, never devolving into "I'm the bad guy because every game needs a bad guy" and always feeding the core plot.

The plot also branches significantly after the first act, where you're forced to choose between two sides of the same conflict. My understanding is you still visit the same places, but get a different set of quests, dialogue, and options to continue the story.

As mentioned earlier, the gameplay had always been my biggest hang-up with the game. This run however, it finally clicked: don't try to play this game like Devil May Cry or another hack and slash, you'll get absolutely thrashed early on. It takes a much more deliberative approach to combat (although it remains third person and real time) involving a attack/block/parry/position mechanic. Dodge and roll like crazy, hit and run, and make clever use of your signs (magical abilities), and get behind the enemy to backstab to turn the tide of battle. Having tried to use the KB+M in prior runs, I found using a controller really suited this game well and felt much more natural to use.

Unlike many of the game's ilk, the potion system is also a bit unique. With regard to potions, you need to consume them prior to entering a fight (potions can have you deal additional damage, or increase you health regen, or even have you see in the dark) and which only have a limited duration (usualy 5-10 minutes). This can be a bit frustrating if you're just strolling around and suddenly get jumped by a horde of monsters. All the same, i actually kind of enjoyed the minute or two of prepwork involved in getting together a mix of potions to consume prior to descending into some horrible place where there be monsters.

In a somewhat frustrating nod to the RPG elements of the game, some very useful game mechanics are hidden behind the leveling/skill system. You cannot use throwing knives until you unlock the skill. You cannot parry attacks until you unlock the skill. Eneregy recharges almost pointlessly slow until you get some skill upgrades. Enemies backstabbing you will eat through your health in one or two hits until you get some skill upgrades. You cannot attack groups of enemies at once until... well you get it. After you've acquired these skills, and gotten some better gear, the game substantially eases up in difficulty and plays more like the hack n' slash you expected than something like Dark Souls.

Technically speaking, the game is an absolute gem. This is basically DX9 taken as far as it could reasonably be expected to go. The game is beautiful, full stop. The art direction is gorgeous. The environments, the characters, everything is richly detailed and an joy to drink in with the senses. The music, sound design, and voice acting are all generally top notch. The game was well ahead of its time, and easily stands the test of time in a way many games do not.

Occasionally, the environments did become a bit confusing to navigate. The gameworld is deceptively small, and to make the game look larger the devs clearly implemented some tricks to make sure that your view distance is always fairly limited (but they were smart enough to do it in a natural way). I also always felt that the game had us linger a bit too long in each of the environments given their relatively modest size, but never for too long. At the end of each chapter, I was always ready to move on with the scenery but was never completely burnt out on it thanks to the art direction and clever level design.

Performance on modern systems is great. Played between my laptop (Mobile i7 processor and mobile GTX 1050; 1080p/60hz) and my desktop (6600K and GTX 980ti; 1440p/144hz). Laptop handled high settings fine with some minor slowdowns, while my desktop was able to crank up to Ultra no problems, buttery smooth. I did encounter some crash to desktop issues on my desktop rig in during some very specific segments of the game (very end of the first chapter and very end of the second chapter) where there were substantially more characters/action on the screen.

So to reitterate: If you like the Witcher Universe, if you've been looking for another "cinematic RPG" in the vein of Bioware's Mass Effect in a fantasy setting, if you just want a good game to play and you don't have a bunch of money in your pocket, The Witcher 2 is right here, waiting to be played. By all accounts it has been overshadowed by the mountains of praise the third installment of the game has received, but it is a great pseudo open world game in its own right with a tight story, entertaining characters, and gorgeous graphics.

Played this on Xbox when released  and replayed it remember if it was still good, lets just say it's still worth playing before or after Witcher 3, just look at my [url= https://steamcommunity.com/id/calibrojosh/recommended/292030]Witcher 3 review[/url] to get the vibe and have the major differences below

[h1]My Score:[/h1]
[b]A[/b]

[b]Paid: $3[/b]
[b]Completed in: 40+ hours(on XBOX)[/b]

[h1]Compared to Witcher 3: [/h1]
[list]

    [*]Same Story/character/mission quality just less of it

    [*]Basically same combat system, but witcher 2 is slower and more animation based akin to dark souls

    [*]Obviously graphics worse

    [*]Not open world, Hub based instead

    [*]Choices at one point give you two entirely different middle acts, which is dozens of hours of content, and different stories/quests and leads to unique endings

    [*]Not required to play Witcher 3, but adds so much in terms of lore and meaning to certain characters as a lot of the cast carries over, but story is self-contained and offers a lot of different experiences you don’t get in Witcher 3 like waging factions and choosing sides, lots of unique settings and enemies, and does tease Witcher 3 in a way at the end, that built hype for when it was announced and actually delivered on it, a rarity rarer than winning the lottery.
[/list]

Playing this game after the endless torment that Witcher 1’s combat system brought upon me was a blessing. First of all, a sensible combat system is commendable, but that’s not really why I love this game. Witcher 2 starts you off in an epic battle that heightens the pace of the plot. Compared to Witcher 3, this comparatively short game has a more coherent and more exciting plot. It gives you an insight into the bigger picture, a more complete view of a world that is at its turning point. Although admittedly the plot could be expanded to more than having only 3 chapters, this short yet compact story is the soul of this emotional adventure. From the dense canopy of flotsam to the grand walls of Loc Muinne, Geralt closely follows and changes the fate of this world. As the herbalist in Vergen described, Geralt truly is the greatest contemporary hero of the Witcher universe, and journeying with him in the witcher 2 surely will not disappoint you.

A must play for fans of the 3rd game.  That said, The Witcher 2 does show its age, and not always in a charming fashion.  Unlike the first game, which is enjoyable in part because it is quirky and old, The Witcher 2 feels more like an iterative steps towards the masterpiece that is the third game.

Is it worth playing?  Absolutely.  Is it worth sinking hundreds of hours into?  I don't think so.  I'd recommend fans of the series play through The Witcher and The Witcher 2 to experience the story.  Keep the difficulty low, and hack and slash your way through while focusing on the dialogue and roleplaying elements.  Then import your saves into a fresh play through of The Witcher 3 for the ultimate Witcher experience.

[h1]The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition[/h1]

What can I say about this masterpiece. CDPR surely outdid themselves with this game. When it first released, the graphics were astonishing and they still hold up to this date. The story is just perfect albeit shorter than the first game but in my opinion this is quality over quantity! Combat has been marginally improved since the first installment the voiceacting is much more believable and realistic and overall it's just gorgeous! I'll get a bit more in-depth into the pros and cons of this game but for those of you who don't feel like reading a wall of text, tl;dr at the current price you should absolutely buy it. It's literally a steal!

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]

- The story: It's a witcher game made by a pro consumer dev, what could go wrong right? One playthrough isn't gonna cut it. You can replay this game at least 2 times and you are going to see 2 different stories branching out in front of your eyes. It doesn't last long but choices really matter and it shows!

- The graphics: To this date, graphics have aged really well. I was really impressed launching this game for another run and seeing it really close to the Witcher 3. They won't disappoint!

- Sound: Lots of ambient sound. I play my games with music turned off and you should try a playthrough without music too! You will notice a lot of things from birds chirping, villagers chatting and tons of other goodies. Granted it does get repetitive especially with NPC dialogues and this issue also appears on the Witcher 3. For the latter game you can use mods to disable random NPC chatter which is a great workaround but I'll expand more on that on the cons.

- The combat: It feels like a different game from its predecessor, the combat is more fluid and if you modify your binds a bit you can also use insta-sign casting on your keyboard. I have used a similar layout to the Witcher 3 and it came really close to it. Other than that, Geralt has a wide variety of arsenal on his inventory, oils, bombs, potions you name it! Speaking of potions.....

- Preparation: Gone are the days that you could chug your potions mid battle, you can no longer consume swallow potions every time your health drops to a critical level. You want to be prepared at all times and think twice before engaging in an area which has unknown opponents.

- Customization: Armors have been improved a lot appearance wise, they feel really witchery and there's a vast variety of armor sets you can acquire. Dark mode also adds its own dark sets which have an interesting questline to back them up.

- INSANE difficulty: Perma-death, you die once your save is ruined. That's a great mode for the hardcore veterans who want to test their mettle in combat. You are going to have to be extra careful and know the attack patterns of each boss and enemy by heart. This mode can be unforgiving and quite frustrating as sometimes you can also die from pretty silly situations (attack missclick, getting damaged during dodges, enemies blocking your way etc...)

- Side-quests: Other than contracts, the side-quests of this game are very well thought-out. They do a great job following the whole gray morality that the series portrays making it very hard for you to pick a choice that feels best, because there isn't one!

- BUTTSECKS: What would a witcher game be without sex? It has less options from the first game but boy oh boy, this game gets waaaaay more intimate with your different romance choices. And even though I'm team Yen.... that Triss scene was something else to say the least back then! (Thank god no one walked in on me during those parts)

- Minigames(?): Some of the minigames are hit or miss. I'll focus on the best one in my opinion:
[u]Dice poker[/u] makes a return to the 2nd game. This time around is more interactive as you can move your dice around and overall control the speed of them, you also run through the risk of throwing some of them off the board if you aren't careful.

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]

There's no such thing as a perfect game and sure the Witcher 2 is no exception. Some of the cons can be very nitpicky but I'll have to include them on this review!

- Performance: If you don't configure this game properly, it can struggle even on a high-end gaming PC. The executable itself is limited to 2GBs of ram usage but thanks to 3rd party tools you can make it large address aware and increase the limit to 4GBs! Look it up on google. Another thing is the stutter, whenever changing regions this game hangs for a while to load the next chunk of the map. It can be really infuriating although, if you install the game on an SSD you can fix that issue for good.

- Loading screens: They are everywhere, there are tons of things you might want to explore but you'll think twice before entering every single house in game and waiting a couple of seconds for the loading screen each time you do it.

- Navigation: Unfortunately this game doesn't have a sprint button. You have this really sluggish jog and you have to be really patient if you want to go from point A to point B. Also backtracking will make it even more painful. Most players invest on footwork right off the bat just to spam that dodge button to cover the distance. It breaks immersion but it's the only viable alternative.

- Stealth: Honestly, this mechanic shouldn't be in this game. The NPCs during stealth segments are either brain-dead meaning that they won't see you even if you stand in front of them for a couple of seconds or they have bat echolocation abilities. You can literally turn off all the lights and they can randomly notice you even if you aren't in their line of sight! Another minor issue is when you leave from a stealth area and go right back the enemy markers disappear, another minus!

- Economy: Unless you play on Dark Mode and grind on those sweet dark sets, you'll manage to amass a huge amount of money. By the end of Act 2, I already made 10K+ and I didn't exploit any enemy spawns, I just sold all my junk to merchants.

- No contract bosses: This time around there aren't any special boss monsters you've got to kill. Sure you get to kill a couple of queen endregas in Act 1 and 3 trolls, but those are the only unique contract monsters you can find. Oh and the succubus if you count that one as a contract and end up killing it.

- Fist fights/arm wrestling: They might as well have removed those minigames as they don't offer any challenge. Fist fights at least have a very interesting quest in Act 1 and in Act 3 (on Roche's path) but once you beat your first opponent they become extremely easy. At least the animations are good so I give them that! Arm wrestling is just pointless. I have never, not once moved my mouse during arm-wrestling sequences and I ended up winning. If they made it a non interactive cutscene it could have been more dramatic and better looking in general (the game could check your intimidation skill and according to its level it would determine the percentage to win RNG I know but much more believable).

- Sounds (AGAIN?): Generic dialogues get very repetitive. They can drive you insane going up and down and listening to the same voicelines again and again. Even some scripted events like the blacksmith on Act 1 who is approached by a shady fellow, it happens all the time. Things like that should be a one-time thing and disappear!

[b]- BIGGEST CON!: CAN'T FRICK SASKIA! -5/10[/b]

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]

This game is just great to play. Your choices matter and they will heavily affect the epilogue of the game. One playthrough won't cut it and this just adds into the replayability. It's a very poetic game and no matter what you do it will make you question your every choice. This game is definitely worth buying even from a player who is not acquainted with the books or the franchise.

Thanks for taking your time reading this review and have fun Witchering!

i cannot recommend this game for the causal player who likes a story driven game.  The first main enemy, the Kayran, is extremely hard to beat and requires multiple tries as you get the in game given clues on what to do and figure out how to do them.  I got this game when it first came out and there was a lack of online gamer guides to help.  I quit playing it at that time because I could not beat the Kayran.  I restarted this game on Steam and I am sad that I did.  I dislike games that cause the player to have to make multiple attempts to succeed at some task.  This is one of those games that even at the easiest level I am on my fourth try to beat the Kayran again.  This game lacks a lot of in the form of in game directions on how to do things.  The Kayran battle is not the only instance.  If you play this game, you need to look at all the available crafting patterns and understand that you can upgrade your armor and create new armor.  There are a lot of points in the game that you can do things that really do not have anything to do with the plot and are not a logical thing to do, yet reward you with achievements.  I would save my money and get a different game if I had it all to do over.

Witcher 2 is a game worth playing, despite it being my least favourite of the three games.

An ambitious effort at modernisation from Witcher 1, the combat is more complex and challenging for the player. While there are aspects which are not done well (for example, oils and potions are useless because of the need to meditate), the game plays well all the way through.  

The minigames are weaker than both those in Witcher 1 and 3, but the arm wrestling is fun. The upgrade system is complex and interesting, especially focus points balancing sign usages. The decision to have two separate Chapter 2, with numerous endings, makes a second play-through like a second game from a story perspective.

Good RPG where decisions matter and carry over into the Witcher 3. Graphics are good for 2011. Most of the characters are very interesting and the story is very compelling throughout most of the game. Combat is deceptively simple but still requires skill and timing. Some of the mechanics like the crafting or signs don't make much sense design wise but I never felt much desire to use them anyways. 

Much more linear and self contained than the massive world of The Witcher 3 but very worth playing if you want to get into the third game.

Another game really great for its time. The combat is a little bit rough around the edges, but as with Witcher 1, playing this has historical value and is worth it, since the stuff you do here can impact the next game.

I have to mention Letho, of course, as he is one of the best "villains" (if you can call him that) in the Witcher series and one of my favourite characters.

Excellent Game!

This game is an odd one. On the one hand, the deep, immersive worldbuilding and storytelling CDPR is so good at is here as always, but on the other hand this game confused and frustrated me probably more than any game I've played. The story is given as huge dialogue dumps and cutscenes that reference things you may not have seen for hours, or not at all if you didn't play TW1, and I found myself coming out of cutscenes having no clue what had just happened and having to read the journal to figure out why I was doing anything, and even then I was still confused at the ending as to why I did or did not support certain characters. I feel like a second playthrough will definitely be useful to figure these things out, especially since the entire 2nd chapter can change based on a decision you make at the end of chapter 1. I likely won't be doing this second playthrough because of my second big problem with this game though: the combat. I played and completed this game on dark mode, the hardest difficulty that doesn't have a permadeath function, and my most common mission ended up being "Game Over! Do you want to load your last autosave?" I don't mind difficulty for difficulty's sake, because that's part of why I play games, but the combat system is really broken imo and it led to me dying due to random chance or things that weren't really my fault. Part of this has simply to do with the design of battles, with you often being thrown into encounters at a huge disadvantage because you are surrounded by high dps enemies without a group style attack from the first game, leaving you to lose almost all of your vitality before you even gain control after a cutscene and end up spending the rest of the fight dodging in circles like an idiot trying to get a single hit in. It's certainly difficult, but it didn't feel very strategic or lore-appropriate. Potions and oils were pretty much useless as you're so underpowered that a simple 10-50% increase in some number isn't going to make that much of a difference. Even swallow I found pretty pointless in this game because it's regeneration is a snail's pace compared to the last game.
Overall, I'm glad I fought through the combat mechanics, even after I got halfway through and realized you can't change the game off of dark difficulty because of the dark-specific armor sets that I crafted. The actual story and world of this game make it all worth it and after understanding it some more I feel like I'm ready to go into the 3rd game with a more complete knowledge of the series. So should you buy it? I say yes, but I definitely understand wanting to skip it if bs game mechanics frustrate you, but looking past its problems it really is a great game that I had tons of fun with.

[h1] A master piece of a RPG [/h1]

The Witcher 2 possesses all the elements that make a game an absolute MUST HAVE!

Story wise, the plot continues the story from the first Witcher, where you, the famous Geralt of Rivia, is trying to uncover a conspiracy trying to eradicate the kings of the northern kingdoms. 
To that regard, I highly advise to play the first Witcher before hand, as several of the decisions made in the first game are showing consequences in the Witcher 2. Yet, if you are unwilling or simply don't have the time for it, you'll find some recap videos in the "Extra" menu, so that you get up to speed on the prior events before starting the adventure. 

The story unfolds itself in 3 chapters (+ an introduction chapter and an epilogue), leaving you with more or less 20 (if you rush) to 100 hours of gameplay (if you are a completionist) to finish the story from both paths. (follow Roche or follow Iorveth)

The characters are very interesting and far more developed than in the Witcher 1, and we get to learn a lot on the world in which the hero, Geralt, evolves in.

[b] Follow the witcher patch [/b]

The gameplay has also evolved compared to the first episode, and is way more responsive. The combat in particular leaves you with a very satisfying feeling of being a badass swordsman, cutting through your foes graciously and stylishly while casting here and there a few signs (magic powers for the witchers). 

You have basically the choice to develop 4 axis, being core competences, swordmanship, signs (magic) and alchemy. Each of those will deliver various benefits and abilities, so youz can shape your Geralt as you see fit.

Yet, some elements of the gameplay have been made too simple IMHO. For instance, in Alchemy, the first game let us explore the recipes and invent some more powerful version of the potions depending on the ingredients mix. Here, you can't do that, you can just do the recipe you have. 

Another simplified aspect is the combat, while being more dynamic, it also removed the possibility to develop a fighting style more than an another, like in the 1st game (fast, strong or group style).

[b] A beautiful journey in the realm [/b]

Graphically speaking, while being a game from 2009, the game is just splendid and can hold its own when compared to more recent rpgs. And of course, you can mod the hell of it if you want to push it further.

Regarding modding, I highly recommend going with the improved textures and most importantly the Master Witcher 2 Redux mod. It definetely improves the gameplay.

[b] Buy it, simply [/b]

One of the best game I had the chance to play, and definetely a must have if you are an rpg fan and/or planning to play the Witcher 3.

If you're like me and your introduction to the Witcher franchise was the Witcher 3 and are now working your way through everything else Witcher related in the world, you may be pleased to hear that the Witcher 2 is about as close as you'll likely get to the Witcher 3 in terms of gameplay.
The game features a similar style of combat and overall game mechanics to what you're probably used to, and the writing is just as superb as everything else associated with good old Geralt of Rivia.
The game is shorter than the other two in the series but offers a huge amount of variation based on choices made in the game. There are 8 endings, and you would need to play the game at least 3 times to experience everything. The choices made at the end of Chapter 1 make the second and third chapters wildly different.

The game looks pretty good despite being almost ten years old now, but it is not without it's technical flaws. It's still kinda clunky and buggy in some places and overall just not as refined as the Witcher 3 in a lot of ways.
The thing that pissed me off the most was the map. The overall map and the minimap is completely useless. At first I was wondering if this was because you could purchase or find map upgrades, but nope, it just sucks all the way through.
The inventory system isn't great either and the UI can be a little lacking. It surprised me that this game was made for PC first since a lot of this feels like it's more tailored for consoles. 

Also, the game is hard. Really hard. Which I'm not a huge fan of. I played through the Witcher 3 on Normal difficulty but even playing this on Easy there were a few fights where I was stunned by the difficulty. Some people love that sort of challenge in games, especially if you like how the Witcher games can force you to consider the monsters you're fighting (like a real Witcher) but for me, I wasn't a huge fan of the difficulty.

I haven't talked about the story much but it has a very different feeling compared to the other games or Witcher media. The whole thing is steeped in the politics of the in-game universe, and if you're not as familiar with the Witcher world, it might seem a bit off-putting, but if you are, there's a lot of good lore and story development to digest here. Also, this game really bridges the gap between the story of Geralt from the novels and the story of Geralt in the games, and answers the last few remaining questions I had coming from the Witcher 3.

Overall, this game is definitely worth your time if you're a fan of the Witcher, but if you're looking for an introduction to the series I'd recommend playing the Witcher 3 first.

If you're looking for an exceptional story, the Witcher series is a no-brainer.

Witcher 2 has to be one of the best games I have ever played! This game is the second one in the Witcher series. While, it may not be as long and polished as its sequel Witcher 3 it is still a damn good game. I decided to replay the game after a long time wanting to see if it holds up even in 2020 and I can gladly say that the game still stands on its own. The story is fantastic with meaningful choices which affect the game endings and the characters are really interesting and multifaceted. The side quests though short are thoughtful and are well designed. Also the game is beautiful and the graphics are very good even to this day standards. 

The story essentially is divided into three acts with a prologue and epilogue. There is even a story focused tutorial and also an arena mode where you can spend time fighting monsters and honing your skills. Another cool thing is that the second act is essentially two acts divided based on your decision you make in the first act. This adds replayability and both the acts are well designed and interesting on their own.  

Regarding some the cons, the combat controls can be a bit wonky and can be a little difficult to get used to. The lighting in the cut scenes can be too bright and this can be quite jarring when you are suddenly brought back into the game. Also the finisher animations though cool removes the control from you and can leave you open to damage when you’re brought back.

Overall this is a must play game for those who have not played it. If I had to rate it, I would give it a solid 9/10. I thoroughly enjoyed playing this game again and would definitely recommend it!

It's pretty good.

Before playing, I highly recommend to download and install the Training Skills since Level 1 unlock mod: http://www.nexusmods.com/witcher2/mods/648/?

This mod basically unlocks all skills under the training tree, so your leveling points are better spent elsewhere. In addition to this, the mod also greatly reduces the delay it takes to pick up item from a fallen enemy. I don't find this mod to be a cheat because I don't find it logical that Geralt don't even know how to parry with his sword after all his adventure in The Witcher 1. 

On to the Review.

Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a 2011 direct sequel to the 2007 video game The Witcher. Like its predecessor, the game is based on The Witcher series of fantasy novels by Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski. Witcher 2 improves upon almost everything that was wrong with Witcher 1, and surpasses it in many ways.

The gameplay of The Witcher 2 is a very different from its predecessor. Player movement is accomplished solely through the keyboard, and the much hated combat has changed from the rhythmic minigame style of the original game to a more fast-paced action style. Combat now feels very smooth and natural and is a joy to handle. It also ditches the old game engine with a completely new in-house developed one. To be honest, it almost feels like a completely new game.

As for the story, while it is not necessary to play the earlier game to understand this one, it is highly recommended as there are little references that the NPCs make which will only make sense if you had played the original. The story now feels very cinematic and the whole thing feels almost like a movie. Those looking for a good story will not be disappointed, as like its predecessor, is full of plot twists and intrigues. In fact, there are 2 different branches which you can pursue, which has noticeably different plots and even locations. 

Art style, looks super crisp and sharp even in 2015, and it is still extremely beautiful to behold. Everything from the character faces, to the world environment has been given a 360 degrees complete overhaul, and the  whole thing looks like a fantastic medieval tapestry come to life.

The soundtrack is as epic as ever, but the most improved aspect has to be the voice acting. Gone are the bored actors that sound like they're reading off a script. The voice acting here is top-notch and high quality, and adds alot to the atmosphere of the game.

While the game is undoubtedly a hundred times more improved then Witcher 1,
there are some flaws to it.

The world may give an illusion that it is an open world game, but in reality, you are actually tied to the area and access is blocked off with invisible walls. The game doesn't even let you jump or climb unless you are at specific points on the map. 

Speaking of the map, I find it quite frustrating that the mini-map itself isn't very helpful in pointing out directions to objectives. Sure, I understand that the developers wanna let players experiment and discover by themselves but I feel alot more could be done to make quests easier to track. 

I also dislike that you do not get any mounts or fast travel in the game, and instead got to run on your feet all over the place, which is obviously used as an artificial way to lengthen its total gameplay time. It also doesn't help that Geralt's default running speed feels kindda slow.
Compared to the original game, Witcher 2 is a noticeably shorter game with lesser side-quests lasting around 30 hours or so and feels alot more linear.

This game is also somewhat buggy. Lots of times I will encounter character conversations to just simply freeze, and only a Alt-Tab back to Desktop, and back again to the game will solve the issue.

Overall Rating: 8 / 10
No longer hindered by a dated game engine, this is an excellent sequel that improves upon almost everything that was wrong with its predecessor. Its a perfect introduction to anyone who may be interested in the Witcher saga. While there are some flaws / bugs that hinder it from being a true great masterpiece, this is still one of the best RPG around.

While The Witcher 1 was a big first and successful attempt to bring the world and feel of adventure of Witcher books to the video games, Witcher 2 wanted to up the quality. Tell an even better story, look better, play better… Which might’ve worked if not for all the issues this game had during the development, issues that are felt throughout the rather messy experience The Witcher 2 is.

They did succeed in making it look better, obviously, but the look actually aged a bit worse due to the colour filtering choices and the fact that for all the looks it achieved, the world feels smaller, more cramped, more boring to look at. Not everywhere, of course, act 2 has few locations that look nice and the opening scenes can be impressive, but most of the game just looks like a mess of drab colours.

It tells the story in a more interesting way, but the story itself is less interesting. It has more nuances, it has some very exciting global implications on the game world and choices feel more natural, are provided in a more personal way. It does bring even more wit and humour from the books, it evolves the characters. And it is the very best thing about the game. Although, it seems, that in Witcher 3 most of the choices are invalidated by events out of your control anyway. Oh and if you do play for story – just go with Iorveth. While Roche path has some pretty interesting (and also mostly invalidated in TW3) choices, all of Act 2 and most of Act 3 will be extremely boring, as Roche gets the most boring locations, quests and dialogues in his path, seemingly mostly due to the fact that this path was developed last.

As for the gameplay… If you play on Normal, it’s not bad. If you try the Full Combat Rebalance 2 mod it might make some things more interesting. If you play Dark mode or something like that, then don’t try the FCR2 mod… Actually, just don’t play Dark mode at all, or any other higher difficulty. Despite some attempts by CDP RED to make gameplay fun, gameplay is mostly pretty frustrating and is either simply not fun, or in some cases maddeningly broken. A lot of ideas, with recipes, crafting and such are just a mess (and Dark mode only “benefits” depend on those). In addition, all those small animation limitations, you encounter everywhere and things like that make The Witcher 2 to be not a particularly fun game to play.

But the story can be worth it. And was for me, twice. Just, don’t expect to like anything else.

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition Review

The adventure became a whole lot grander…

Some key points that this game offers:

1.	Every DLC and game improvement is included in the Enhanced Edition.
2.	Dark Mode.
3.	Official Soundtrack.
4.	Game World Map.
5.	Quest Handbook.
6.	Digital Comic Book.

Gameplay & Controls:

For the PC players the game has partial controller support, enough to make use of a controller and to actually enjoy the use of a controller, but for the masters of the old ways the keyboard path is there as well, fully accessible and a wide range of keys for you to make use of.

Under the hood are numerous other settings that can be customized for your experience, such as the QTE difficulties for example. 

If you recall The Witcher 1, it experimented with a new combat mechanic, which at first required getting used to, but we soon master that way of the sword. The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition’s combat mechanics have been changed again, this time to a more hack and slash variant, once your weapon is drawn of course. 
The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is a massive step up from the original with a much larger world and tons more to see and do. We still have a Fantasy RPG at heart here and this time around there are even more choices to make as you progress through the game.

Our inventory has also received a major update, giving us the ability to collect much more items, weapons and gear to sell or make use of, a feature we did not have in the original.  We no longer need to use flint or a fire to start the waiting or meditating progress, making things much easier to do on the go.

A lot has been updated and changed with The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition, and all in the right ways. CD PROJEKT RED did an outstanding job with The Witcher one, but they went and surpassed that standard tenfold with the release of this amazing sequel.

Graphics:

Beyond beautiful! The REDengine at its best here, providing a fully living and breathing world that comes across as so realistic that one can’t help but find the entire experience believable. 
Every location was given a great deal of effort to ensure that they were created with as much realism as was needed to sell this beautiful work of art. Whether you are running down the streets of a small town, or through the woods the experience is memorable. 

The architecture behind the cities and villages are so accurately done that the medieval theme is brilliantly presented with pin point accuracy, fully creating the atmosphere for you to explore and do your business in. 

The forest and wood areas have received the same amount of gorgeous detail. Woods never looked more alive as they do now. The tree branches dancing in the wind, the rain lighting up the skies as you hunt down beasties, the experience is beyond realistic and so memorable, one easily forgets the cause and simply pause to witness and enjoy the magical visuals that the game presents us with.

And that is far from it all, character design is just as stunning, facial features that change as the conversations mood changes, adds to the already realistic atmosphere that the game offers. That combined with the beautiful character designs makes for one unforgettable experience. This includes not only Important and Key NPC’s, but also general NPC characters, in their own ways they were all uniquely and beautifully created.
We have numerous settings to fully customize how this amazing game runs.

Sounds:

Making matters that much more is the stunning background and sound effects that have been added to the game world. Whether it is the falling rain, or the screeching of a monster in the distance, the sounds are there bringing your game to life in a whole new perspective.

Character voice overs were done brilliantly, on par with the high standard that the game has set for itself. The soundtrack is another winning choice here that enhances the overall experience of the game, whether you are out shopping or tracking down some monster, the music will never fail you.

Replayability:

This game has so many choices for you to make that you have to replay it several times to fully experience all that the game has to offer. There is a total of 16 different endings for you to experience.

MGR Gaming’s Conclusions:
Spoilers Ahead:

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings Enhanced Edition is through and through a marvel of a game. CD Project Red took everything that was good from the original and used that as building blocks to ensure an even greater sequel.

Let’s face it not every sequel is always better than the original, it is just the way the cookie crumbles, however The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is the exceptional exception here. This game has breached new levels of beauty, and realism, and that coming from and RPG Fantasy says a lot.

The story line with its numerous choices constantly changes how you play the game; you can make each playthrough unique and exhilarating if you make the right decisions and in return the game will provide you with different outcomes as you play through each act. You’ve never had this much freedom to a main quest line as you have now and it is one stunning experience.

The story itself has been beautifully written and the way it plays and pans out in the game is marvellous and dangerous, every decision has a consequence and more often than not it is that we were not prepared for it and that is what makes all of this so amazing. The game has numerous side quests to add to this already beautiful world and they share the same sense of choices that you will experience with the main quest line.

A new fun past time quest has been introduced into the game, Arm wrestling, granting Geralt another method to prove that he truly is the best.

The levelling system for The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings is a step up again from the original, a welcome and rather easy to get into system and grants you the means to fully customize how your Geralt will turn out and specialize in being a Witcher.

The change in combat mechanics is a welcome sight to any sequel, it might be completely different from what it used to be, but it fits in perfectly with what the sequel offers. The new inventory system is another welcomed sight which adds to the RPG look and feel. As long as we can carry it, we never have to leave good gear behind again.

There is so much more to mention and highlight on, but spoiling all the fun is no fun, experience it for yourself rather.

Definitely worth your time, but marred by some glaring issues.

Pros:
+ The writing is incredibly sophisticated and mature, full of nuance and complexity
+ The story is complex, filled with moral greys, memorable characters, and branching choices
+ The visuals (stiff character models aside) have aged incredibly well with beautiful lighting, colourful locations and strong visual design
+ The game has tons of replay value because of how wildly the game splits after the first act.
+ Played in conjunction with Witcher 3 adds a ton of context to the following game's story

Average:
> The combat system is serviceable, but definitely nothing special.

Cons:
- The inventory system is absolutely godawful, and there aren't even mods to help it
- The map is barely functional, and most times incredibly unhelpful. 
- The story is complex to the point of being incomprehensible: many of the locations and characters that are referred to repeatedly are never seen, and the game doesn't even provide proper geographical context to the larger events. As such, many dialogue exchanges end up as mere gobbledygook, because the player is never given enough information to understand them. This is part of why the game warrants multiple playthroughs.
- Multiple mechanics are straight up pointless: crafting is never needed, because the results are only marginally better than what questing gives out. Traps are useless because combat is almost always sprung upon the player with no time to prepare. These might serve more purpose on higher difficulty settings though.
- Many combat abilities that are defaults in other games (like blocking and dodging) are gated behind skill points, meaning the combat doesn't even become properly functional until a few levels in.
- Some quests are ridiculously obtuse for no reason, giving the player practically no hints where to go.

Some major complaints aside, the strengths still outweigh the flaws. This game regularly goes on sale for about the price of a bottle of soda, so what are you gonna lose there anyway?

Should I play this game? What/Who is a Witcher?
(For those already on The Path, skip this paragraph, for what you seek is beneath.) 
It's entirely feasible that this might be your first Witcher game. Maybe the 1st game was too old for your liking, maybe you didn't like how it looked or maybe it felt clunky (I feel you there).
Witcher 2 is brilliant tale of a man investigating the murder of a king. It is also covers the story of world war, civil war and inter species war. It is also the story of a character, with many shades of greyness, shades that you choose. For there is no black and white in this world, there are choices, choices that sculpt the RPG character as per your taste, choices that affect the ending, the whole story, and choices that will make you regret for ever trusting your gut. Oh and did i mention, there's swordplay, magic and mythical monsters too? (And sex and arm wrestling and fist fights, if you're into any of them.)

The only downside of this game is that it has a little steep learning curve, when it comes to the gameplay and lore. But surviving through that, is worth it. So should you get it? Yes, a resounding YES. Play it, and then play its sequel, and then  try to find meaning in life post witcher. (there is none)

At a point in time where Bioware had clearly lost its touch, Bethesda were abandoning theirs, and Obsidian's games came with hearty recommendations paired with long lists of caveats and warnings, CDProjekt RED came out of the gate swinging hard with a game that did it all and made them an international household name.  A followup to the relatively (at the time) obscure PC exclusive The Witcher, the Witcher 2 Assassins of Kings outdid everyone.  Its world was more convincing than any Bethesda game, it did the morally ambiguous story beats Obsidian made their staple like they weren't even working up a sweat, dialog was fast, snappy and fun in a way a Bioware game hadn't been since Baldur's Gate II.  And it was gorgeous, top to bottom, in ways none of the big western RPG wheelhouses could even approach.

The Witcher 1 was a PC exclusive built in a fork of Neverwinter Nights' Aurora Engine, inheriting all the dreadful quirks of a toolset that never left pre-alpha, jawboned into trying to create a game miles away from what it was built for, in service to bringing to life ideas that didn't quite gel between production value limitations, script translation issues, mountains of bugs (see also: every other game ever built in a fork or mod of Aurora) and mechanics that were interesting to think about but so bizarrely implemented that it's impossible to talk about them in a straightforward way except to say, 'good idea badly put together'.

The Witcher 2 is the polar opposite.  Everything just works, and works so well.  The wonky animations, models, engine problems, glitches, translation issues, sound problems and all that are long gone.  The gameplay is a complete overhaul from The Witcher 1 with combat drawing from inspirations like Gothic and Demon's Souls, with the setting's own nature informing lots of unique spins.  It's not quite the breezy Arkham-with-more-difficulty of The WItcher 3, prep work is immensely important to surviving even average encounters, picking bonuses on level-up is a much more cerebral affair requiring some careful long term planning, particularly on the Dark difficulty.  The developer clearly wanted to show off what their team could do when they weren't beholden to the limits of Aurora and whether it's draw distances that would make Grand Theft Auto V envious, close-up detail that The Witcher 3 had to pare back for the sake of scale, soundscapes that feel expressive and alive and just right wherever the player goes, or future-proof elements like ubersampling it utterly dazzled and delighted gamers and blew the competition out of the water.

It's very much worth a playthrough and it often goes on sale.  Don't miss it.

Here something I should say about this series as a whole, as well as some other series. It is a TRUE rpg, And I don't mean in the case of only having dialogue options, multiple endings, or level-ups. It is an rpg that makes player choice matter in a way that twists the game so much you NEED to replay it again for seeing the alternatives, like going back in time to change history. A lot of triple-A rpg's fail at this aspects, A LOT, because it is like they need to make bull-crap excuses to work around alterations in the narrative. 

Take Mass Effect for example, you are forced to go through three whole games, some really likable character's die, some political figures get blown up, but what really changes? "Oh, did Legion die? Well here is Not-actually-legion, but really looks like them although they aren't. Also, here lets see if you did enough to unlock your third ending choice." It is so cheap and lazy. (Don't get me wrong, I still love Mass Effect. I just don't like it.)

This is why I have come to the conclusion than non-american RPG's are often the most superior. They let your decisions matter. You feel the impact, and the weight of your mistakes knowing you have to continue with it's cause and effect, and feel the satisfaction when your choices actually pay off. You DON'T get to pick an ending, you EARN one. CD Project Red doesn't coddle you with your decisions, and are willing to make you feel uncomfortable and learn from it. 

10/10: My hat's off you CD Projekt Red! Looking forward to Cyberpunk 2077!

The hugely successful follow-up to 2007's The Witcher brought the series into the mainstream. With a vastly improved and frankly, actually competent combat system, and graphics that still impress even NINE years later in 2020. 

A far more intricate and adult story than the previous game, Assassins of Kings is filled to the brim with political drama, betrayal, romance, and heartbreak. The main story is probably the weakest of the series, but that's not a negative mark in a series known for it's excellent story-telling. The only true weak-link of Witcher 2 when you compare it to its prequel and sequel are a distinct lack of side-quests. There are only a handful, if that, of side quests in each chapter, with the entire game 100% completion taking about 40 hours in my second play-through. 

The combat is far improved over the first Witcher, with a now action oriented combat system most gamers will find themselves familiar with. While not as graceful or effective as Witcher 3's combat system, the combat in Assassins of Kings is exciting enough, but in the end, nothing to write home about. 

In the end, play this game if you enjoy dark fantasy, and want a story line that dares go far FAR further into fictional politicking than any mainstream RPG would ever imagine.

CDPR accomplished a lot in The Witcher 2, including but not limited to a very high quality story and laying a  large amount of ground work for The Wild Hunt. If you've played The Wild Hunt prior to Assassins of Kings you'll quickly realise the major differences between 2 & 3 but I'd wager those differences are what gives the second entry to the franchise it's oomph.
