I can't say for the life of me what others see in this game. To say the combat and leveling systems are half-baked would be charitable at best; fights from beginning to end are often boring, unfulfilling, stunlocking slugfests with most combat skills being worthless without heavy investment of points. Most worthwhile gear items are acquired through random loot, with unique legendary blades being found in sacks while items you are rewarded with via quest are supplanted within the hour by the next schmuck you happen to stab in just the right way.  Even with frequent revisits to the journal pages (which are a pain to navigate with a gamepad, but that's just me), the quests are often frustrating to follow, so a spoiler-free guide would be your best friend if you choose to play this.  Crashes upon loading saves are common, and I had to frequently purge old save files to keep things running smoothly.  Bugs occur with regularity, with my favorite being the inputs either not registering or double-registering, so that's a fun lottery to take part in.  The only reason I can think of to play this is to experience the story and setting first-hand, which are okay and unique, respectively. 

I am only at the end of the second chapter and can hope to god that this experience will be validated upon continuing to the third title, but for now I just have to slog through it and hope the gameplay doesn't distract too much.

If you have started the path of completing the trio of the witcher games, no. 2 will seem a sudden departure from the 40odd hours you have invested in the first game. The story is all of a sudden more fleshed out, your choices in the first game mattered, you even brought along your swords. People remember what you did. And the choices you make in this one will also be remembered. There is a way of playing the withcer, just blaze on through the main story and miss all the intricacies, or completely imerse yourself in the lore and all the options. The character builds are many as are the weapons and the armour. The combat style is a complete departure from 1 and seems more suited to where modern games have gone. Or i suppose this one of the ones that inovated in this way. If you indeed played 1, this will take some hours to get used to. Critical commands have been moved and in the first hour i saw myself misclicking many many times. The graphics are so far from the first one as well. No matter what choices you make, this games brings more gravitas to it all. Everything seems so high stakes. In terms of the mechanics there are certain aspects that are bugged and sometimes the game will crash, i had to validate my files a few times but all in all it flowed pretty smothly. This game ended up being almost half the legth of the first one while i maintained a similar style of doing as many extras as possible. It almost functions as a bridge between 3 where it introduces a more modern play style so the transition would not be as jolting. All in all, this game is not paramount for you to play to get into 3, but it is a delight to go through, and really gives you a good run down of the story and what choices you should make in the future, as well as train you well in the game style and what might be expected of a succesful run.

The middle game in the series, the good the combat is a improvement along with looking a lot prettier, it still holds up well(20/5/2020), still has a rough start with combat that is tricky to understand and unforgiving and trying to plot dump and tell you of all the new systems in one unmanageable dump. Like the first game it improves in the second chapter and once you get some power and things start to make sense. QTE fights are the worst in the series along with other QTE events which are a shame as the third game dealt with those better in a more tradional manner. Morally grey character and people doing the right things for the wrong reasons and opposit is still here. The two very different stories in the middle section are very interesting as well and really force difficult choices when it comes. 
Shortest game in the series and choices do follow from the first and do follow on into the last, like mass effect but less significant. Navigation is not great had more trouble finding where to go or who to see than any of the rest of series, as lots of ladders identical looking streets and forests that look the same, along with gullies. Introduces trolls as characters who can be talked to and reasoned with which is one of the best changes as they are so wonderfully characterised. 
Last area felt a little under baked as seemed to be lacking in stuff to do compared to how well fleshed out the other prior areas were in comparison. 
All small nit picks recommended along with the rest of the series.

Even more dark, bloody and artistic. The Witcher 2, offers an experience like few other games can even get close to. 

It improves very much over the original game, the combat system for instance is replaced with a more action-like pacing, yet it still retains an RPG under the shell.

Unfortunately unlike the first game, it's farther from the story found in the books, but still a better story IMHO than Witcher 3 which was more mainstreamed and rushed. The choiced matter plot device works even better. The significant decision at the end of Act I decides what content the player gets Act II and III, locking the player out unless the player makes a new game afterwards. Provides new perspectives on the story. 
Unfortunately, the sexism got worse. Women as a reward are more ubiquitous. Does not help at all. Significant deviation from the canonic material in The Witcher saga. I'm not talking about the sex scenes though. I'm talking about the damsels in distress in this game. It's easily the stupidest quests in from the first game. The sex animations are same for every other sex scene so it doesn't matter much anyway.

The soundtrack is a more high budget, blockbuster stuff. Great for the most part.

Pros:
- Great use of the best mechanics for choices from Bioware games.
- Brilliant writing. Even better Scoia'tael perhaps. A shame it doesn't matter much in Witcher 3.
- Game is not as slow as Witcher 1. 
- Very good soundtrack.
- Best politics in The Witcher series ever. An improvement over Witcher 1. Witcher 3 simply downgraded the entire thing into a gross oversimplification. Your choices will have no impact on the world in Witcher 3. So, enjoy it while it lasts in Witcher 2 I guess. 
- Very solid story and atmosphere. More brutal than Witcher 1 in some respects.
- Achievements.
- Arena mode added in the Enhanced Edition to practice fighting and compete on the highscore leaderboard.
- Multiple endings. About 20 various combinations depending on choices.

Cons:
- Mediocre tutorial compared to the first game. Uninviting start of the game for new players.
- A good but very flawed try to make sneaking work in this game. It's frustrating, hard and unforgiving. Nonetheless, at least it helps make the gameplay more varied from plain combat.
- Combat still imperfect though many functions from the first game were simplified.
- The endings and the choices from the first game, don't really carry on to this game except for one of the three endings and a couple of isolated situations. No way to input the choices made in Witcher 1 so that they can be in force here if the player does not have the save file. In this respect the choices from Witcher 2 don't have much of an impact over Witcher 3 neither. Only a couple of character encounters. Some quests. That's it. Others are never heard from again. The Scoia'tael are the most disadvantaged in this regard in Witcher 2 and Witcher 3.
- The sexualization of female characters is way too overkill. One can argue that the game strays too far from the source material. But the player has the option of not giving in. As Geralt from the books would have. Occasionally.
- Disproportionally short final Act III compared to the rest of the game, despite a free update with the Enhanced Edition.
- All endings to Witcher 2 are abrupt and appear to be as rushed as Witcher 3 is. Nonetheless they are good if you have no problem with getting Witcher 3.

Recommended to acquire on GOG, depending on your region, the price might be better: https://www.gog.com/game/the_witcher_2

The game is definitely good, but it's nowhere near the first installment. Unfortunately it is riddles with so many bugs that I was debating with myself for a long time if they merit a thumbs down review. Here's the major points:

Story: The story is strong, as can be expectred from a Witcher game. The characters are very well written and you definitely end up "knowing" them by the end. The problem is that unlike the first one, this one gets too much into political power-plays and not as much on the main character. This means that the game expects you to know the names of rulers, locations, events etc. before sitting down to play and that can be a pain and can end up alienating the playter who is expected to be emotionally invested in things he is unfamiliar with. there is good story branching which means you can replay it a few times and you'll end up playing a very different game by making different choices which is a plus. Unfortunately the focus on "witching" is hardly there. It feels as if Geralt is just a pawn in a much larger world of political intrigue, and not really the hero. Overall I was let down especially bythe ending which is basically the same regardless of what choices you made and how you think you influenced the world, making it feel like your actions didnt matter at all.

The combat: I was very let down by this as well. While it is way more developed than in the first game, there are glaring bugs which made me roll my eyes multiple times. From your allies being completely impassable blocks and much of the combat taking place in restricted spaces (meaning you roll supposedly away from an enemy only to bump into your ally's outstretched toe and get hit anyway) to skills and stats bugging out making "builds" pointless unless you know all the glitches and can plan to avoid them. Then there's the potions. Unlike in the witcher 1, here they last for a very short while meaning you literally have to know when you're going to get into a fight to drink a potion. Not to mention that in many fights (including boss fights) due to the amount of cutscenes before ther fight you never get the option of drinking a potion so relying on this mechanic (which is essential to Witcher games) is bothersome. 

The achievements: Here I have a big gripe with the game. If you're a completionist like me you will be gritting your teeth a lot with this one. Luck based achievements to get 5 of a kind in poker? We got that! How about a "beat the game without dying? We got that! I'd usually have no problem withthe second type of achievement but this game has the tendency to insta-kill the player in a variety of way - for example the floor and crumble under your feet with no indication (near the end of the game mind you), or you can walk up a path near the end of the map and suddenly warp to an insta-kill fog location. Or you can enter a cutscene to fight a boss, with your weapon drawn, only to end the cutscene with your weapons sheathed while the bosss is in mid-swing towards you. And on the higher difficulties bosses can easily one-shot you. Or entering a conversation where picking the wrong choice ends up with you dying in a scripted event. Overall it was not at all well thought-out. 

Then there's the smaller annoying mechanics. You can craft many things, but it is always cheaper to jusy buy the finished material from a vendor so after you figure this out crafting becomes obsolete unless it's for a legendary weapon/armor. The overall flow of the game is insanely choppy. For example the medallion scan mechanic is not bad but in order to use it you have to come to a full stop which takes a second. So if you want to scan an area you have to run, stop, scan, run, stop, scan etc. When you drink a potion you have to do it in "meditation mode" which you can not enter at all times. And once you do drink the potion Geralt has to either crack his neck, or wipe sweat from his forehead etc, which is unskippable and takes a few seconds. If you have a build which relies on potions (as Witcher games usually funnel you into doing) this get annoying very quickly. 

Yet, even after all of that the game does feel good. I think it is the story and strong characters which save it. It's definitely something you should pick up, but I strongly advise any future player to enter this playsession armed with a lot of patience. The second installment is definitely not as good as the first.

[b] Verdict [/b]

First off, know that The Witcher 2 is not a game that will hold your hand. If you're thinking about purchasing this, know that to get the most out of this game you need to be prepared to fully immerse yourself in the experience and pay attention to what is going on. This a game which deals with many adult themes such as politics, racism and sex to deliver a mature and complex game supported by rich lore and stunning visuals. 

The writing and storytelling is exceptional throughout and the moral ambiguity and choices are second to none. The gameplay, in particular the combat, is an acquired taste but offers a refreshing level of depth and potential for improvisation when compared to games in a similar genre. Sound design and voice acting is also of high quality, with the environments coming to life through impressive visual and audio support and characters each sporting distinct personalities and prejudices.

It is also worth mentioning that if you have played the first Witcher game, your choices and gear will be reflected via an imported save in The Witcher 2, however the choices have limited effect and it is not necessary to play the first game to enjoy the second (however you will be at a slight disadvantage in some situations).

In my honest opinion the experience as a whole is unparalleled, and The Witcher 2 is easily the most enjoyable and immersive RPG I have played in recent memory. I would also advise reading the books by Andrzej Sapkowski as these offer an interesting insight into the protagonist's past. But back to the game, overall I would highly recommend The Witcher 2 to anyone with at least a passing interest in the RPG genre, it is the definition of a complete gaming package with spectacular production values and a lasting impression.

The Witcher 2 is a mix of positives and negatives whose positives ultimately far outweigh the minor complaints I have with the game.

It shares some of this roughness with its predecessor, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/greatjon_umber/recommended/20900/]The Witcher, which I find to be so rough as to be almost unplayable nowadays[/url]. The Witcher 2 had similarly convoluted, poorly designed levels which make it a chore to navigate to and fro while completing quests and exploring. The forest outside Flotsam is guilty of this. It's exceptionally difficult to get where you need to go without circling around hedges and trees and carving through numerous cannon-fodder caliber enemies. Additionally, looting and interacting with the environment is a huge chore given the cooldown on your amulet scanning ability, and the way the game locks out looting for what feels like an eternity once combat starts. Crafting and inventory management is a gigantic chore due to the obtuse user interface, which I felt like I had to fight with constantly. I also experienced a few lock-ups in which Geralt would get stuck in an animation, and a few crashes here and there. Transitions into different areas of the map are bothersome as well. There are numerous small complaints like this that show some of the roughness the previous game also exhibited, albeit far less of them overall.

But there are significant improvements, too. This game looks beautiful, especially when compared to the previous game. I was surprised by how high a quality some of the textures were, and the art design in general is noticeably improved from the first game. The character and monster designs are fantastic, with some of the sorceresses and Geralt's outfits being particularly stunning. Even just the background of the dice poker board, or the deranged drawings on the wall of the burnt out asylum are artistically impressive. Due to this mix of artistic prowess and a powerful new engine, a lot of the visuals on display in Witcher 2 still hold up today, nearly a decade after its original release in 2011. This is made more impressive by the use of developer CD Projekt Red's in-house REDengine, which they developed and used for the first time with this game, to glorious effect. Although I dealt with a few crashes, the game otherwise runs superbly (I'm near 150 fps at all times with max settings) and it still looks great despite being nine years old. It's a pretty impressive achievement for what was a small studio at the time to develop such a solid engine, and the game is made much stronger than the first Witcher, which used the ancient Aurora Engine, licensed from BioWare.

The combat is also substantially improved, ditching the previous game's ridiculous and shallow faux-rhythm system for classic third person combat which is far more satisfying to execute. It feels a bit loose to me, especially when compared to The Witcher 3, but it's still miles better than the first game's combat and far more intuitive. Enough depth has been added to make things more interesting throughout.

Where The Witcher 2 really shines, though, is in terms of narrative, quest design, and providing the player agency. The strongest thing The Witcher 1 did was weaving its quests together, so you feel especially detective-like once you begin uncovering all the pieces. This is also true of Witcher 2. For example, in Chapter 1 you very quickly obtain a series of side quests very early, simply by talking to people. Almost all of these quests turn out to be intertwined in some way: An incense-maker turned fisstech dealer and a drunken troll turn out to be related. Sounds far-fetched, but the common ground not only turns out to be reasonable and compelling, but also teaches you more about the political situation in the game's setting of the Pontar Valley. And if you're looking for a game in which you have the power to impact the story with your choices, then look no further—The Witcher 2 features perhaps the best example of "your choices matter" that I've ever seen in a game.

CD Projekt Red took a massive chance in the way they designed this game, because there's a significant choice to be made at the end of Chapter 1 that leads to two nearly exclusive routes through the plot. Meaning that no matter your choice, you will end up missing out on about a third of the story content in this game because the two paths moving forward from this choice are so different from one another.

It's a ballsy choice by the developer, because these people had to be designing these entire areas and questlines knowing that half of their players would likely never experience them (unless you're a nerd like me and replay the game to take the other route). The consequences of this choice further reinforces the fact that you are actually impacting what is occurring in the narrative. Few games take player choice to this extreme, and the fact that CD Projekt Red did makes The Witcher 2 something special for that reason alone. Furthermore, the choice is packaged appropriately—you likely won't even realize that you just made a game-altering choice, even though you still realize the gravity of the choice when you made it. The game won't pause and give you any hint that a massive choice is about to occur, which I love. It's an exceptional, ambitious move that is perfectly executed and it makes this game far more memorable and impactful than it'd be without it. Bravo to the developers for making the difficult decision to include two branching paths like this.

If for nothing else, this game is worth playing due to the quality of its narrative. It's a politically-driven game with strong social commentary and genuinely interesting characters, and it gives you the opportunity to pass judgment and act within this world as you see fit. It's constantly satisfying in this manner and it left me thinking about my own moral code regularly. Although The Witcher 2 does not feature the classic, epic story that is featured in Witcher 3, I appreciated the narrower scale and the stronger focus on the political machinations of this world's elites. It might take some concentration, but once you grasp what's going on in the narrative, it's quite compelling.

The Witcher 2 is not without its warts, but it shows a staggering improvement over its predecessor and it remains more than enjoyable today. If you're in the mood for a good story, check it out. You'll probably be well-satisfied.

If you'd like to chat, Discord server is [url=https://discord.gg/4wXvBUQ]here[/url]

Ok so I'll preface this by saying this. My initial exposure to The Witcher was "The Witcher 3" three years ago on ps4. I loved that game and 100% it. I was left satisfied and didn't play any other witcher games or really dive anymore into the series for the next couple years. Fast forward to a few months ago to the witcher netflix series. It got me to fall back into love with the series. Since then I have read all of Sapkowski's Witcher novels (including all three short stories as well as the series). And now with quarantine, I put it on myself to try to go back and beat all the old witcher games. 

So with all that said I'll try to evaluate this based solely on gameplay and story. If you're a newcomer whose either only played the first game, or this is their first witcher game, this will most likely be extremely confusing. Narrative and plot points are thrown at you quickly, with them expecting you to know every kingdom and remember names. It's extremely confusing and if I had not read the books I would have been absolutely lost. There is some lore in books and dialogue but in my opinion the game does a poor job of conveying it to you. However, the story you do get is intriguing enough. There's lots of dialogue and plenty of quests and side quests to keep you occupied for at least 20 hours. I took more as I went out of my way to do everything besides the dice poker (I still have no idea how that works). The game does show its age in that the majority of choices don't really have an affect on the story or the world. There's about 3 choices that really matter throughout the entire game and they for the most part won't effect the ending minus one. That being said, I can appreciate the linearity of the game and keeping the focus on the main story. Yet, because of that and its age it suffers from a fetch questy nature. Most of the mission revolved around going to point x, retrieve y, fight through obstacle z, and come back. The game does however try hard to make that obstacle intriguing. I found myself laughing, serious, and frustrated many times. In 2011, I'm sure this game was excellent as skyrim had yet to be released at the time of this game. I will argue this game does provide a more gritty, grounded, and focused narrative than skyrim does with tighter gameplay. However, this game cannot match the freedom and the sheer size and scope of skyrim, and due to that skyrim is superior to this game by quite a bit. If you're looking for a game to give you some elder scrolls vibes (which I know many are) this is simply not the game for you. 

Let's talk about the game play. So this game is now pretty old, 9 years old here to be exact. I can't expect it to be as refined as titles today. But to be blunt, it's begun to age pretty poorly. The controls are... passable. It just feels clunky and animations feel very odd. There's clipping issues, hitbox issues, sometimes enemies will look like they're standing still and you hit them and all of a sudden they slam you to the ground and you get murdered by a mob who aren't even near you. There's a lot of times I was frustrated as the game just doesn't have smooth controls, to the point where when I was done fighting I was like thank god. This isn't dark souls level difficulty (Ive played all the souls games as well as bloodborne) but at times it can feel like you're ability to win depends on whether the controls do what you want them to do. Furthermore, the menu's feel clunky and odd. I constantly tried to drop junk and ended up dropping my sword, leading to me having to come out of the menu, pick up ALL the items I dropped to get my sword as I can grab things individually, then repeat the process of slowly using the controller to drop all the items again. Furthermore, there's no quick way to navigate menus. If you want to go to your inventory, then to your journal, you have to open up the pause menu, scroll to your inventory, close it, repause the game, then open up your journal. Or when going to a vendor, you can't buy and craft from the same menu. You have to talk to the vendor, ask to buy, LEAVE the dialogue, talk to the vendor again and open up the craft item menu. A scroll option would have been nice, or just not leaving the dialogue when leaving the buy option would have been preferable. Furthermore the inventory management SUCKS. especially in the beginning of the game. If you play the game, when you get to flotsam GO TO THE BASEMENT OF THE INN AND TALK TO THE BARTENDER. Seriously I don't know why the game fails to mention there's a storage bin for all your crafting junk and gear there. I didn't know until about halfway through the starting area and it was a pain in the butt constantly micromanaging every bit of gear that I got, down to alchemy ingredients and twine for my gear. It will still remain annoying even with the storage but at the very least you know you can just dump it all somewhere later. 

All in all, there's lots of little things that reallllly drive me to almost not recommend this game. However, there are quite a few standout and fun parts, as well as dialogue and choices that make this game fun. If you're in quarantine and want to hop back into this game, this isn't a bad one to jump into. The fact that this regularly goes on sale for like $5 definitely helps as well. Just understand that you're going to be playing a game with dated game play and some very ok graphics. For newcomers.... Maaaayyyybbee just watch some story breakdown and hop into 3. This game may sour your taste and give you the wrong impression of three. However, if you have the time, and want to play through the story and it's on sale, go for it.

Assassins of Kings is not like Wild Hunt, but that's one of the most appealing things about it. I hear a lot of people ask if they NEED to play this game in order to enjoy Wild Hunt, and honestly the answer is no, you don't. But you absolutely SHOULD play this game by merit of it being just as much of a masterclass CRPG as its successor. The engrossing story that can see wildly different outcomes based on your choices, the fleshed out and worthwhile side quests, and addictive and rewarding combat and in-depth gear management that are staples of the Witcher series really start to come into form here, and it's an absolute joy to play. While it's true that some things about Witcher 2 fall a little bit short-- especially in comparison to W3-- i.e. the close camera angles causing eye-strain and motion sickness for some, the nerfed skill point allocation system not always allowing you to go down a character path you truly want to take (both of which are quick fixes with some very simple mods-- mod support being ample and readily available via the game's launcher), and the "Ubersampling" feature causing some serious performance issues when enabled, even on modern day machines, all of these shortcomings are more than made up for by just how impossibly fun Witcher 2 is to play. The story will grip you, the choices will really make you sit back and think, and the rewarding combat and questlines will leave you wanting more. If Wild Hunt is a 10/10, Assassins of Kings is an easy 8/10. This is a decent enough place to start if you're interested in the series, and you'll be so glad you took the time to play it.

I was a big fan of the first Witcher game so I really looked forward to digging into this one. Its shorter and feels like it has less side quests, like its just there to push the story towards the next game. However its still a good game, just not the best one, in my view. It looks lovely and the combat is much faster, its a bridge between the 1st and 3rd games. I would recommend playing the 1st game as your save files will carry over, this is something I very much enjoy about the Witcher games. You have to live with the friends and enemies you've made in the 1st game. This makes the game fun to play many times, that may make up for the game being shorter for some people. I would recommend this to someone who wants to really get into the Witcher but I wouldnt recommend it as a starting point. Start with the 1st or watch a youtube video to get up to speed then jump into the 3rd game. Take that for what you will

Superb gameplay and superior in every way to its predecessor, The Witcher 2 is a masterclass in role gaming games. 

Story - slightly hard to follow but excellent. Massive replayabiliy since a major decision in the game will lead to two entirely different Chapters in the game.

Graphics - Beautiful; complete with lots of high end graphics options and overall creates an immersive and impressive game to look at.

Gameplay - Combat is fantastic, despite some initial critisms at the game's release. In a time of hand holding and casual combat systems, The Witcher 2 doesn't mess around and will punish you early game for just button mashing against enemies. 

Not much else to say, with the games frequent 85% off sales there is no reason to not pick up this game if you are a fan of the genre. 

Time taken to beat: [u]40 hours[/u]

Score: [b][u]8/10[/u][/b]

I decided to play the Witcher 2 originally not because I had played the third game, but because of all the hype back in the day. Originally, I didn’t get past the first Chapter because of the clunky controls, but completing the Witcher 3, watching the Netflix series, and starting to read the books got me back into the Witcher 2 to see what all the fuss was about.

To play the Witcher 2 is to appreciate how much of a quantum leap forward Witcher 3 was. The amount of streamlining that the developer, CD Projekt Red (CDPR) did for the third game was just astounding. The Witcher 2 caused me no end of frustration with the pointless stealth, horrible doors, clunky merchant interfaces. While the handy Configurator did let me change the controls to match the Witcher 3 more closely, the rest of the interface killed the game for me.

Another disappointment was the quests in Witcher 2. While the main quests were spectacular, the noticeboard quests were simple puzzles or pointless killing quests, such as the Endrega, Drowner, and Harpy contracts. This is another aspect where Witcher 3 was leaps and bounds ahead of its predecessor. 

What the Witcher 2 does deliver is an amazing story. I won’t spoil it, but regardless of which path you take, you will never know the true story completely. The effort the team put into craft the branching narrative is truly astounding.

Another appeal of the Witcher 2, like its successor, its sparkling characters. I played Witcher 3 with a lot of confusion because I didn’t quite understand why Zoltan, Dandelion, Roche, and Triss were so friendly with Geralt. (I also didn’t realise Zoltan was my true brother.) Witcher 2 gave these series stalwarts life, and also introduced some other fantastic characters: Saskia, Henselt, Phillipa Eilhart, and Iorveth. It’s a credit to CDPR that they made a good Witcher game without fan favourites Yennefer and Ciri. Or Roach!

Geralt’s character is also beautifully illustrated in Witcher 2. While he had amnesia through the game, his principles, distrust of politics, and his decency, were apparent in his actions. 

Witcher 2 hews more closely to the books than Witcher 3 does. There’s a greater emphasis on potions, as Geralt can’t take potions or eat during fights, only while meditating. Potions and bombs also don’t magically refill after meditation. It’s more realistic, but it’s not as dynamic as the system in the Witcher 3.

I also enjoyed the soundtrack. While the great Percival (of LE LE LE LE LE LE fame) didn’t feature in Witcher 2, it has a nice folksy vibe to some of the quieter tunes.

So can I recommend Witcher 2 or not? Mass Effect 2 it is not. Its mechanics and side quests are horribly dated and pretty much every aspect of it was improved in Witcher 3. I think this game is for completionists, or those who want to build their connection to Triss, Zoltan, and Dandelion. For all others, use the discussion in Vizima to determine what happened in Witcher 2 without having to play it.

How does this compare to the first Witcher?

[h2]Combat:[/h2]
Witcher 1 had quite an archaic combat mechanic even by its year of release standards, so the move to dynamic combat was the right choice. It's still rough around the edges as you're often animation-locked and Geralt doesn't always respond to sign casting, which sometimes can be a matter of life and death.

Speaking of death, in [i]"Witcher 2: Prepare to die™ Edition"[/i] Geralt is very squishy in the Prologue and the first chapter. The best way to survive is to cast Quen and roll a lot. It gets a little better in Chapter 2 and 3 once you level up some combat skills.

This is the only Witcher game where drinking potions is blocked by the need to meditate, an odd design choice seeing how applying oils is instant.

The parts where you don't fight as Geralt are garbage as you lose all your abilities, they should've just been cutscenes.

[h2]Skill Tree, HUD & Signs:[/h2]
A much needed improvement over the conundrum that was in the first Witcher, signs like Quen and Yrden are actually useful now.

[h2]Visuals:[/h2]
The leap in graphical fidelity between the two games is huge, a lot of detail was put into making the world and characters look alive. Some effects like bloom, depth of field and sharpening can be a bit much, but luckily you can turn them off.

[h2]Story:[/h2]
This is where things take a dive for me. Compared to the first game the plot and characters in this game are all over the place, especially in Chapter 2. The game is about 15 hours shorter, but manages to do a worse job of conveying the narrative with you needing to read the journal after every quest. Not sure if it's designed to be that way, but it only made sense in the end (which comes rather abruptly).

The big difference however is that there is a certain decision you have to make in Chapter 1 that changes the entire game until the end. You should definitely check out the "second" path, but be sure to import the correct saves once you start Witcher 3.
A massive step up from the last game.

What a shame. The game is beautiful, the story is well-written and deep, Geralt is always Geralt and his companions are as enjoyable as in the books, and so are his enemies. So why in the name of the Gods did the developers decide to curse this gem of a game with a combat system that is beyond horrible? Let's see, 4 out of 5 encounters work like this: I stun a foe, hit him so the killcam plays, another foe hits me from behind for 700 dmg BEFORE I regain control of Geralt, end. Or, I riposte a foe, I take damage anyways from hit during the riposte animation, BAM I lost 75% HP. Or, suddenly the game decides I took a backstab when the foe is 3 meters from me! I think the game engine randomly decides I take hits on the higher difficulties, just to keep things interesting. Too many times the hitboxes simply don't collide, and I'm hit anyway. Dodging doesn't give invincibility frames, rather when you're hit during a dodge it counts as a backstab, and anyways the game likes to pitch you against encounters in crammed spaces which are meant to make you use parry/riposte (but see above). And there's the odd boss battle in which you gain control of Geralt hugging the boss, and he immediately decides to do a 180° sweep attack with more reach than you can roll away (backstab, see above). I'm no stranger to action games and have put quite a few hours in this one, but I'm seriously considering giving this up, it's just unfair and too buggy.

It took me a while to figure out the combat mechanics--they're more aggressive, and conservative, than I'm used to in a game like this. It's not a power fantasy. A few goons with swords can wreck you no matter how big your boots are supposed to be.

That said, I enjoy the character interactions tremendously. I enjoy the combat. I like the RPG aspects. I love the character and monster designs, the investigation and open ended quests, and the grit of the world; the Continent is an ugly place.

The one thing I don't like, and this carries over from the books, is the world itself, which for all its complexity and depth, I still don't feel familiar with, and never really got my head around how any of what's going on in the story matters. This is a story (so far) about clearing Geralt's name. Why so many people care is beyond me, especially since as a character he is supposed to dislike Court and royalty.

However, as an experience, beat for beat and hour by hour, I love this,

An immersive RPG experience, let's list some pros and cons:

Pros:
- Ones learned how to properly use the combat system is an immense improvement to the witcher one and can be put next to the combat system of the witcher 3.
- Very nice story/lore, not as much freedom as I'd like to have in it though.
- More refined RPG elements as the witcher 1.

Cons:
- Less lengthy as the witcher 1, though in my opinion more immersive. It doesn't drag on like the first one at some moments did.
- Really bad prologue imho. Everything in the prologue felt either scripted (because when not played accordingly dying was almost inevitable), meaning what they had in vision for this game was close to making reality, just not fully yet. After the prologue the game opens up and everything gets more immersive, this includes the (more witcherlike) environment. This is imo not a story about kings and castles, but about what happens in between.
- Not so userfriendly tutorial, which may have made a lot of players uninstall the game for it's clunkyness. Do not do this, the game has a lot to offer, it's just a little rough to get into.
- One of the worse inventory systems in games, everything is hard to find and confusion to look at, this was better and simpler executed in the witcher 1 and has been completely remade and refined in the witcher 3.

Lastly I'd like to point out that this review is spoken from game experience, I enjoy the witcherseries for it's combat and RPG-lore, it's not based on facts and such matters.

Really, really liked this one. And now I can understand why people who played one of the newer games first and then tried to play Witcher 1 found Witcher 1 so irritating lol. Witcher 2 is a definite improvement on a lot of things. I was fine with the combat system after I spent about an hour in the game. It's for sure a little overwhelming feeling at first and the changes in how meditation works (compared to Witcher 1) threw me off at first, but after that first hour of playing, I felt pretty comfortable.

The story and choices were SO GOOD. I liked that choices really mattered and that there were a few choices that were timed so you HAD to make a decision quick. I felt pretty invested in/connected to the choices I made. I felt really satisfied after each accomplishment in the game and by the end because the story kept progressing and I kept learning interesting things. Main and side quests were both interesting and fun to play through. The game was also much nicer to look at than the first one, but that's obvious lol.

ALSO I appreciated that this installment (in comparison to Witcher 1) had waaay less "get that lady in bed" options. It was still there, just much less and much less annoyingly. And like while there were one or two expected scenes, when it came to quests, it was never a choice you had to make to complete a quest, at least as far as I found during my playthrough (there was one quest in the first game where this was the case). Though I'd mention it in case it matters to someone else, too.

The menu is a little weird the way it works, but whatever, it doesn't ruin the game for me. There's tons of different ways to build your stats and there is no way to max out on all of them by the end of the game, which can seem frustrating at first, but there's really no need to max out all branches to be able to play well, so I don't think it detracts from the game too much.

The journal was done pretty well in this iteration, I think.

Editing to add a note on difficulty: I played on Normal (almost) the whole way through. The first couple bosses are weirdly tough, but once I figured some stuff out and looked up some advice, I was still able to beat them on Normal. I tried one of those fights on Easy bc I got frustrated, but then it felt way too easy so I went back and did it on Normal and did fine lol. I did complete one boss on Easy (the final one) because I just wanted to finally find out what happened next in the story, I was doing all the right moves, and it was just taking forever of getting so close and not making it. But I don't think any of the big fights are impossible on Normal (and I am totally not good at the combat part of games in general!).

I cannnot figure out what people see in this game, it is one of the worst gaming experiences I've had. It is technically bugged. Textures sometimes need 10 seconds to load (not even in places were you'd expect problems), I've had multiple crashes. But I could see past these issues if the game was great. But narratively it's just strange that you have this extremely long introduction, the game should start after all this king murdering thing. I was already bored when the plot really started because I saw no reason for caring about anything I had to do. This title removed all the good things from Witcher 1 and keeps all the weird things. I loved Witcher 1 for its atmosphere, sadly there is little of that to be found in this title. The music is serviceable at best and the combat theme annoyed me greatly. There really should've been better transitions between music. Movement feels horrible! I get stuck on tiny little objects that I shoule be able to walk over without any problems all of the time. The world design feels extremely restrictive, I've no problem with games that don't grant you certain freedoms in gameplay, but the witcher simultaneously signals that you should walk around and explore while it has all these areas you cannot traverse. I don't care about the characters very much, and I can't even fathom how little I'd have cared if wasn't already aquainted with many of them from the predecessor.
I don't know if I approach this game the wrong way, but why the f... do I pick up anything? 99.9 percent of the stuff you pick up is basically trash and because there is stuff everywhere you won't even remember where you got the one great thing you found, making ressource gathering incredibly unrewarding. I had a horrible time with this game, I cannot stomach playing it anymore. I am sooo frustrated that I cannot derive even the smalles amount of enjoyment experiencing the good moments in the story (and there are many of them). At this point they'd have to pay me to finish this title.

I started off playing the Witcher 3 a couple years ago. I don't know why I've never played the 2nd game in the series until now. Maybe because I did not think it could compare to the 3rd game. 

To my surprise, It gives the third game a run for its money. There are some differences, like the scale of the exploration, amount of upgrades and some minor and major gameplay mechanics. However, once I got locked in the game I had just as much fun playing this installment. I believe the 2nd game is more challenging in a lot of ways making it more enjoyable. 

If you are about to dive into this game, then take this advice with you. keep a stored inventory of looted items, especially the drops from the larger monsters. They will be needed for quest down the line.

CDPR have really outdone themselves with the Witcher IP, it is clearly one of the best action RPG in the videogame history. Just go buy the 3 Witcher games and support CDPR developers!

It's Witcher. Just saying that should already make you curious to play it.

In this second volume of the legendary series we follow the White Wolf in a quest he wants to have no part in. I won't give any spoilers, as any slight detail could reveal parts of the story which would make your jaw drop and I want to let you review reader experience it in full.

The game is re-playable at least 2 or 3 times, as I recommend you do each of the skill trees entirely. I highly suggest choosing one tree at the beginning of the game and heavily investing your points only in that one, with maybe 1 or 2 points in another. I personally took the mutations/alchemy and a couple of points in the swords skill tree, and I had a fucking blast, having a full-on Witcher experience.

The game follows the pretty common, but not boring classic of mage, rogue/alchemist and warrior skill trees, having one for casting spells (which is fun as hell, if you invest in the right points early) , one for using potions, oils, bombs, traps and other tools to overcome your opponents, truly testing your craftiness to the limit and one for using your sword (but fear not, you will have PLENTY of combat options making you feel like a true badass of sword combat)

I personally was always the rogue-ish, crafty type, making the most out of my surroundings and knowing my maps and foes weaknesses perfectly, thus the alchemy tree (middle one) suited me like a glove.

The game offers also 2 main paths (which is pretty obvious in the first chapter) when you have to choose your path between 2 main characters. But this is the amazing part, both parts are almost ENTIRELY different. So you will literally feel like playing 2 different games.

Combat could be clunky at times and you do have to not get cornered to be able to do anything at all, but that's also what makes it challenging and fun. 

All of the above said, that's why the game deserves 2 runs for the story and a third to try all the 3 trees, thus all the 3 builds. 

CD Projekt Red did an amazing job with Witcher 2 improving on all aspects of witcher 1, from combat to story and the fact that your save will influence Witcher 3 makes it even more amazing. I truly believe this game is close to a masterpiece, a worthy successor of Witcher 1 and a great red carpet for Witcher 3. Enjoy it!

Assassins of Kings is not like Wild Hunt, but that's one of the most appealing things about it. I hear a lot of people ask if they NEED to play this game in order to enjoy Wild Hunt, and honestly the answer is no, you don't. But you absolutely SHOULD play this game by merit of it being just as much of a masterclass CRPG as its successor. The engrossing story that can see wildly different outcomes based on your choices, the fleshed out and worthwhile side quests, and addictive and rewarding combat and in-depth gear management that are staples of the Witcher series really start to come into form here, and it's an absolute joy to play. While it's true that some things about Witcher 2 fall a little bit short-- especially in comparison to W3-- i.e. the close camera angles causing eye-strain and motion sickness for some, the nerfed skill point allocation system not always allowing you to go down a character path you truly want to take (both of which are quick fixes with some very simple mods-- mod support being ample and readily available via the game's launcher), and the "Ubersampling" feature causing some serious performance issues when enabled, even on modern day machines, all of these shortcomings are more than made up for by just how impossibly fun Witcher 2 is to play. The story will grip you, the choices will really make you sit back and think, and the rewarding combat and questlines will leave you wanting more. If Wild Hunt is a 10/10, Assassins of Kings is an easy 9/10. This is a decent enough place to start if you're interested in the series, and you'll be so glad you took the time to play it.

Still a very enjoyable game years later. Writing and characters are top notch as you'd expect from the series but the combat, game balance, and bugs can hamper the experience somewhat. 

Combat is not at all action based despite how the animations may look. Its fun in its own right but it works very differently from a Souls or Arkham game. Alchemy tends to be pointless and finnicky more often than not, a shame considering your role as a Witcher. 

Lastly the bugs range from minor to funny to game breaking.

WARNING: Regarding saves, keep a close eye on how many you accumulate. Each time you save a NEW file is made, the old remain in the folder and pile up over time. If the number of saves gets too high you can find yourself unable to save your game at all or at worse losing all your saves.

Aside from that major point the rest of the bugs tend to involve audio when playing the game fullscreen and using alt+tab to shift programs, and some minor visual hiccup.

Still a fantastic game worth a playthrough or two to see the myriad story changes.

So, overall I give it an 8.5/10.
Pros :
- Beautiful environment that runs quite well (30 fps) even on 4 gigs of RAM.
- Story is very interesting, and easy to follow.
- Worthy, and fun sidequests, no boring monotone fetch quest.
- Minigames! Well the only minigame I like is the arm wrestling one though because the other one is based completely on luck, and the other one is just QTEs lacking any difficulty whatsoever. But still, a good way to pass the time and get some easy orens.
- Pretty nice skill development tree, though the Alchemy tree is useless.

Cons :
- Very few boss fights, and none of them are pretty challenging. Basically, dodge, strike, repeat.
- Romance is very very confusing in this game. Like, there's no romance option at all, other than probably to Jev, Jek or whatever her name was. If you want to romance Triss, well done, you only get to meet her at the start and at the end of the game. Basically, only 1/4 of the game.
- Combat is, idk hard but repetitive. It's really easy to be overwhelmed at the start, since there's not much of an instruction to combat anyway, but it's really about the weapons. Once you get to Ch. 2, where it'll be easy to get a decent enough kit, you'll find it'll be easy, but still repetitive. Though the animations are quite well.
- It's kinda a, half open world I guess? You can't come back to the map before, so if you missed some side quests, you'll miss it for sure. Also, *SPOILER* in Ch. 2 the map is divided again in 2 parts, before-portal and after-portal. You'll get to explore the after-portal part just one time, so if you forget to explore anything, well too bad.

But still, worth it for the story, and since it'll be very cheap when it's on sale, I recommend it.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
Simply put, the combat is deeply satisfying and hectic, but ONLY when you level up enough, and when the combat works as intended, which it doesn't sometimes.
You know, when you start playing Dark Souls for the first time, you have the capacity to make the combat be the incredibly amazing experience it was intended to be, from the very get-go. You have everything you need from the very start: Rolling, and a sword. That's all you need to experience the combat as it was designed, and it doesn't even get much different from there. There's no need to cheese or exploit the AI at all. The only limit was your own capacity to learn, from the very moment you start the game.
This is not the case regarding The Witcher 2. Unless you're playing at an easy difficulty, you'll have to cheese the hell out of your first battles in the game. You'll have to drag them out. You'll have to exploit the AI by baiting one soldier at a time. The combat basically becomes a chore with no fault to the player at all. No, it's simply bad design.
And I've seen this in other RPG's too. You start out as a completely underpowered character, but the AI and the combat system is built for a fairly leveled version of your character, so the combat feels bare bones, very limited, and you have no choice but to cheese the fights by casting Quen, baiting enemies, hitting them one time, retreat, and repeat. That's basically your only choice when you're under-leveled and playing on a high difficulty.
You might be thinking, "Well, of course it's like that! It's an RPG! You're supposed to be weak at the start and get stronger as you progress through the game". Absolutely, I agree. That is probably the foundation of an RPG game, but this is not the issue. You see, there is a way to make the full experience of the combat system available from the very beginning of a game, even if you start out weak. There is NO excuse for a game designer to not design the combat this way. You just have to look at Dark Souls for this, as I just described before. You can fight through everything in the early part of the game very easily with just the starting gear, if you know what you're doing. Dark Souls succeeds at handing over the full experience of the combat to the player since the very beginning, while being considered an EXTREMELY HARD game by most people. Do you see where I'm going with this? Me playing The Witcher 2 at Dark difficulty does not excuse the fact that I had to cheese all the fights at the start of the game. And believe me, I had to. I was getting one-shotted by mob monsters. It would be perfectly fine if I had a way to dodge all of their attacks, but you can't. You can still get hit while rolling, and unleveled rolling is pretty bad. When you try to strike one enemy, the others will attack you, and you can't do anything about it sometimes because the game will randomly decide what sword swing animation to use. Some take really long to be executed, which leaves you very vulnerable, and some don't (I'll talk about action consistency later).
This could have been fixed if the game simply provided you with more skills that should have been there by default, like "Whirl". 
Despite this, when you leveled up enough, the combat is truly awesome. You'll be: dodging attacks, parrying attacks, trying to get that juicy backstab, combining signs and sword play, planning out your battles by drinking potions before combat, setting traps to get an advantage, chaining sword combos through beautiful animations, thinking of who to attack first, and much more. The combat is dynamic and you get a good degree of freedom to approach it in your own style. Killing a whole group of enemies in 30 seconds after you leveled up or upgraded your gear feels really, really good.
I think what elevated the combat from being "good" to "great" are the signs. They add variety to the combat in a way that sword-only combat couldn't provide, and an opportunity to come up with different strategies. You get five signs, each serving a specific purpose. I found all of them to be useful, which is a great achievement for a game. I've seen very few games where they provide you with these kind of options, and they turn out to be balanced. No, one or two often completely overpowers the rest. Not in this game. You can find a good use for every one of these signs throughout the whole game. And man, they're fun to use. Throwing enemies off a ledge with the Aard sign might be the most hilarious moments I've experienced in the game.
The Witcher series’ spin on character buffing is somewhat unprecedented, at least in my own gaming history. There are potions and blade oils you can apply to you and your swords, respectively. You get them by crafting them or looting them. The twist is that the game doesn't let you get buffed in the middle of combat. You can only drink potions outside of combat, and on top of that, you are very limited in how much substances you can have on your system at any given time. You can lessen the effect of these limitations by leveling up the Alchemy tree. Either way, what these limitations do is prevent what players often do in games like Skyrim or Fallout when they’re about to die in a tough section: They drink and eat whatever they have to get healed and buffed, seconds before they get their final blow. Can’t do that on The Witcher. This teaches you that there are consequences for being rash and careless, and it forces you to think and prepare before going into fights, and to pay more attention while fighting. I appreciate the game for doing this, because having the ability to immediately stop the flow of time whenever you want and heal in the middle of battle crushes immersion, the flow of gameplay and the sense of realism and challenge. Dark Souls solves this problem in a slightly different way: Healing leaves you extremely vulnerable for a long time, and you literally can’t pause the game.
The game has a lot of flaws both in design and in execution, but when it works as intended, it’s significantly enjoyable.


[h1]Closing thoughts[/h1]
Over all, it's a great game worth your time. Flawed but satisfying combat, deep character progression, beautiful visuals and an engaging story. I cannot wait to play the third one. I didn’t talk about The Witcher 1 here, but just to give you some perspective, I found the combat to be nothing short of ABYSMAL. I couldn’t take it anymore, so I quit the game after 22 or so hours. If the difference of quality is the same as the one between Witcher 1 and 2, then 3 must be the best RPG ever made. Fingers crossed.

I wasn't expecting this game to be this beautiful. After finishing Witcher 1, which was highly enjoyable because it reminded me so much of KOTR, I fired up Withcher 2 and imported my save. I downloaded 4K texture packs and modded it a bit before doing so, but what the actual hecking flip this game looks insanely good. Keep in mind I have been modding Skyrim, which came out on the same year, for 8 years off and on. I have about 600 hours with 500+ mods on that game. I'm, err, an "experienced nerd". When I fired up Witcher 2, I was just blown away by how it looked and felt with just about 10 or so mods. Compared to other games from its time, it's the best one I've ever seen. Even when compared to games made now, it's a diamond in the industry.

The world is simply breathtaking. I can't explain how I felt when I entered the first village in the game, seeing the gigantic trees towering over me. Then the monsters came out of the woods, and I kept dying because I was so fascinated by their design. The voice acting is actually GOOD, every item is hand drawn, the environments  are soaked in depth and feels so real. Everything is just awesome. It's no wonder people trust CD Prokect Red so much with the task of creating Cyberpunk 2077. If they can create games like this, they can do anything.

Thank you CD Projekt Red. You are a beacon of light in this crazy world.

Despite a somewhat laborious prologue and some questionable directions, The Witcher 2 is an excellent role-playing game. With a dynamic and demanding combat system, sumptuous semi-open game zones and attractive graphics, it is as pleasant on Xbox 360 as on PC. The game is not devoid of some more or less annoying defaults, but they ultimately do not weigh very heavy in the face of the monstrous pleasure it provides. The captivating atmosphere, the mature tone and the involvement of the player through the many possible choices are not unrelated. So this is an essential purchase, likely to restore faith in the genre to the most jaded gamers.

One of the things I like best about the Witcher games is how different they are from each other. Not just in mechanics, combat system, and characters, but also the feel. Witcher 2 is a very interesting story that pushes the plot from where they started in Witcher 1, perhaps intending that to be the only game, through into the wider world of the Witcher 3. You have complicated plots and twists and turns in the story in this game and you have some very real choices to make.
Less important is that this game has my favorite character from the Witcher games in it, Iorveth. He does not appear in the books, but a large part of this game involves him and you are able to understand the plight and struggle of the Elves through his eyes.

Played Witcher 2 after playing Witcher 3. It was hard to get used to, at first but once I got used to it, it was fun.

The game has a great story, the maps/playing-area is small, and you've to think a lot sometimes - especially when solving puzzles. Choices play a major role.

However, the game has no fast travel (which might not be necessary since the maps are very small), and it's a lot "harder" compared to wticher 3.  Getting money and managing the backpack can be quite challenging as well.

All in all, I would recommend the game (GREAT EFFING STORY MAN, THAT'S WHAT MATTERS IN THE END :P) and would advice you to play this before playing Witcher 3.

A much much better sequel to an underwhelming game. If I had not already been sold on the Witcher series this game would have done it for me.

-The combat is leagues better than the first game's, and in some cases in believe it is better than it's successor. This combat system makes you feel like a skilled fighter, strategically dodging and countering at the right times mixed with sign usage. However potions can only be used outside of combat, which can happen in the spur of the moment with no clear indications.

-The crafting system makes most shopkeepers useless as long you find the right diagrams.

-I felt more attached to the story than I did that of the first game. The characters are well written and so is the story this time around.

What I didn't like so much

-You can't drink potions during combat.

-You aren't told that you will need certain expendable items in chapter three if you want to complete optional quests.

-It is extremely difficult and tedious to make money in chapter three

-Chapter two on Roche's path is very empty and kind of boring.

-Lacking in side content.

-Feels like only a prelude to a larger story, lacks good closure.

-Felt very short.

None of my gripes truly ruined the experience for me, I genuinely enjoyed this game and highly recommend it. 7/10

I've selected 'Yes' to recommend but this was a complex experience. Let's just say I'm glad I opted to play with a guide one more time. I couldn't beat it fast enough.

The mechanics weren't good enough to carry the narrative & vice-versa. It was polished but short. The books have less pages. It felt more empty especially mid-way in the Dwarven city. There were no quests or reasons to enter the homes. The NPCS all have names so it's hard to know which one has a unique dialogue or interaction.

Does it make sense that a lot of charm was lost in 'getting with the times'? My swords carried over from the first game but were only good for the prologue sequence. The 'sex cards' are gone, replaced with a few playful scenes of naked Triss. 

But being this attached to Triss makes me wish I picked 'Shani' in the last game since it clearly doesn't matter anymore. There are no whores or horny women to help for sex except for one tomboy slut. It's all about getting the 'most action' out of a mere fraction of quests, charm, mystery, & character from the first game.

The combat was re-designed & it changed everything. I only got used to it doing a quest where you had to fight off difficult wraiths past a time limit. the combat is unforgiving in that back-stabs are lethal and quick attacks suck you into an enemy past his friends. You have to save-scum & then become increasingly greasy until you win. You have run everywhere and set traps.

You get ambushed all the time in random places. You have to equip grenades, set traps, and drink potions to win. I can't imagine doing this on the 'permadeth' difficulty. There are so many opportunities to die immediately by accident.

I felt confined to a linear track. You can't just zip through bushes. What felt like far travel was just a short distance on your map. It was a maze to learn.

Getting new armour & swords, they always look great. But what is carrying through to the next game? More or less? Is it going to get better? Arm-wrestling was novel but the fist fighting was easy and Dice poker became annoying.

This was a small novella compared to the thick fantasy novel that was the previous one. Maybe it was this game that made me question how well a game could borrow from a book franchise. How many things can you borrow from rival franchises without losing your rich soul? Without becoming generic? 

Certain important characters (main antagonist especially) had too much context to force into dialogue. 

There was not enough to do. The most exciting & developed parts were the beginning & end but my choices didn't seem impactful. I'm always kind to Dwarves & Elves when I can be, but I'll never side with Squirrels. There was no incentive for mercy or cruelty.

My first hour was like 'this is gorgeous' and my last hour was like "this was it?" Where is the wholesome little 'know-it-all' girl? Where are the gnomes? Where is the jam-packed intrigue per chapter?

Last on my list of nit-picks is how violent the epilogue was, visually & narrative-wise. Not even Game of Thrones depicted a full scene of graphic impalement and female murder by soldiers.

Great intro-cinematic. Franchise is baller. I'm thankful they made a third one which I've begun playing. I'm not sure if I'm being too hard on this title but it is certainly not as memorable as the first game. Go figure.

"Pull up a chair, and let Dandelion tell you a tale of unfairness, foolhardiness, and demolished expectations: The tragedy that is the death of our very own Geralt of Rivia. The man who was once the brave and fearsome warrior of Vizima inexplicably became a fragile mewling kitten seemingly overnight. The silver and steel blades that had decapitated many a foe were suddenly reduced mere feather dusters. Why, you might ask? It's an answer we may never come to know. What we do know, however, is how the great Geralt of Rivia finally met his grisly end at the hands of a common soldier.

On a fair and sunny day, Geralt wandered into a Kaedweni camp in search of the kingslayer. He had many a business to pursue during his stay: One of which involved untangling a web of conspiracies at the behest of the king's right hand man. During this investigation, Geralt quickly realized that the legendary sword bestowed upon him during his days in Vizima was a mere children's toy compared to the regular common sword carried by the soldiers of Kaedwen. Geralt shrugged it off, thinking to himself that perhaps it was a matter of relativity, and strung the common sword to his back.

Eventually, Geralt came face to face with a foe who was unlike any other he had faced: A man who was responsible for gathering the conspirators in the camp who had donned the mythical armor of a soldier that, in his own words, described in his own words as armor that "made him practically invincible". Expecting this confrontation, perhaps a vision of alternate timelines where Geralt had fought this foe and lost, Geralt downed many a potion that would bolster his strength, and applied a vigorous amount of oil to his common Kaedweni sword that he knew would be the perfect solution for slaying mere humans.

Geralt swiftly struck the man over and over for what felt like many an eternity. After a long, arduous battle, Geralt gracefully swinging his sword in a manner one could only describe as befitting of a ballerina of death, the man wearing the armor of legend had been felled. Soon thereafter, Geralt discovered this legendary armor just so happened to suit him perfectly, and began wearing it for himself.

Shortly after, Geralt had discovered that he played a part in a plot that would soon turn the entire Kaedwen army against him. Wearing the legendary invincible armor, Geralt unsheathed his Kaedweni blade, ready to fertilize the soil with the blood of those who dared oppose him. Unfortunately, Geralt had just witnessed a cutscene, and could not attack for reasons beyond this plane of knowledge, so he was struck down and killed by a common Kaedweni soldier in a mere four hits. As Geralt lay dying and bleeding out, his only thoughts as his consciousness slipped away were: "How did it take ages for me to kill a man wearing this armor with my Kaedwen sword, but these common soldiers wielding the same sword killed me in so few hits?"

It mattered not to Geralt. In fact, soon nothing mattered to Geralt. As his tired and weary eyes closed shut, sensing the weight of a million timelines collapsing onto each other, he soon drew his last breath, thus ending the story of Geralt, the Witcher of Rivia.

A sad tale, true, but perhaps if the gods of our world had created a balanced and fair combat system and paid attention to their own lore, maybe it wouldn't have happened. In fact, this is just the tip of the ice burg of all the inconsistent rules of our world, but this one stands out as the most grievous of all. Where Geralt once masterfully slayed monster and foe alike with the expert knowledge of his Witcher combat styles, every encounter ever since saving King Foltest had him barely surviving and on the brink of death.

Perhaps somewhere, out there, another universe exists where Geralt had succeeded in his quest to hunt down the kingslayer. In fact, I firmly believe he did; however, by the end of his quest, instead of excitement for what he had gone through he was instead deeply disgusted and unsatisfied with what he sacrificed along the way to reach his goal. Unfortunately we do not occupy that timeline, and for us, this is how Geralt of Rivia's adventure ended."

Depois de ter jogado recentemente os dois caminhos disponíveis no jogo, eu posso finalmente fazer uma review decente.

Não só porque sou uma grande fã da franquia, mas porque ele tem realmente uma boa história. Ambos os caminhos são únicos com personagens e missões únicas, mas depois de jogar ambos os lados, você vê como a história se fecha numa coisa só, mesmo tendo resultados diferentes.  Um complementa o outro, já que você só pode saber de várias informações jogando um lado de cada vez.

Mas o que mais gostei foram os personagens, até mesmo os que o jogo quer que você odeie. Acho que o jogo fez um trabalho melhor nesse em relação a deixar todos eles em "tons de cinza" ao contrário do primeiro que por mais que tenha nuancias de interpretação, ainda é um pouco bidimencional demais. Nesse aspecto, também gostei como a "fama" de alguns dos personagens são até bem erradas em relação ao como eles realmente são. Eles são na maioria carismáticos, ou os clássicos "amo odiar ele".

O gameplay é divertido e pode ser desafiador dependendo de como você jogue, e tem missões bem legais, algumas sem graça, e algumas bem interessantes até.

Mas se tenho que criticar algo, são três coisas: A primeira é a forma que o mapa é feito, ele é bem confuso na maioria das vezes salvo alguma excessões. Dois, esse jogo crasha muito, principalmente quando você está salvando ou carregando um save. Três e pior de todos, ele tem um número limite de slots para salvar, mas o problema é que ele não te avisa isso, o jogo "salva" mas não salva realmente, apenas o quicksave. Se você salva com frequência, você tem que ficar deletando saves antigos para abrir espaço. Na maioria dos jogos isso não é problema, mas esse como ele não avisa, é bem fácil você perder horas de jogo sem querer.

Pessoalmente, gosto mais do caminho do Iorveth, por lidar com temas que gosto mais e pela campanha dele ser maior, também acho que se encaixa melhor com o que o meu Geralt faria (baseado no meu primeiro jogo), mas não quer dizer que o do Roche seja ruim, ele só é menor e lida muito mais com política/história do universo.

Concluindo, eu recomendo ele, da mesma forma que recomendo o Witcher 1 e 3 :)

8/10 Provides great backstory to The Witcher 3.

Good
-Story
-Prologue was a fantastic intro
-Characters
-Voice Acting
-Beautiful graphics
-Awesome time era and setting
-Great Development of both story and characters
-Boobies!!!!
-Arena mode is not bad
-Huge improvement in combat from the first game
- Some customization with upgrades and different swords. 
-Alchemy system still good
-Characters upgrades are not bad.

Bad
-Missions were you follow AI
- AI slamming door in your face
-Prompts to jump two feet of off a tiny ledge
-Prompts could be delayed
-Perhaps there was a mishap going into the epilogue from Chapter 3
-Chapter 3 location is a bit dull and wasn't my favorite
-Chapter 2 location could be a maze at times but it was cool
-Difficulty between easy and normal seems like a huge step but provides a good challenge 
-Meditation ability I wan't a fan of. Having to use that to consume potions was annoying. Plus potions would wear off before I really got into a boss fight or combat in general.

Things to also note
-Story is somewhat short if you don't go and find side-quests or do Witcher contracts. The contracts, however; are in depth, give branching options, and are well thought out for the few that I did.
-Story doesn't mention Ciri that much but does mention Yennefer a lot more throughout which I found interesting.
-No fast travel. Didn't bother me to much.
-I also had issues with the ending cut scenes that bugged out and lost the voice over.

Overall this game's new engine at the time and story make for a wonderful sequel to the first game. 

Verdict: 8/10

Ok so i played through three times, two times on dark the other time on normal. I played dark mode first and hated it, I recommend normal mode cause my two deaths on that mode were my fault. The game in general has pretty bad auto saves so on dark mode when i died to a boss it would load right in front of it without my weapons out so it would get a free hit on me. Which is a big deal when you can only take about two or three hits on that mode. The leveling is locked to the story so you can only grind a few level until you progress the story so if your having trouble with a boss you just have to get good and hope you didn't waste your skill points. Despite all of that i had a blast on normal mode feeling all powerful compared to dark mode feel great. Other than the difficulty the game it self looks pretty good for being nine years old at the time of this review there are a few spots were you can see through the map but other than that it's great. The story just like the first game is good to I like the Elf path cause it has more things to do on that path. So all in all pick normal on your first play through then play dark or insane if you want but i'm not going to torture myself, but it's a pretty solid game with a good story to tell just have to work around the bad game mechanics.

The second game in the trilogy based on Sapkowski's "Witcher" book series.

The story and the lore are great, but the best part about the game is that your actions actually have consequences, so while the game is by no means a sandbox experience, it is certainly not linear.

Witcher, your main character (a monster-hunting castaway mutant) falls somewhere between your typical hero and anti-hero, but that serves to emphasize the main trait of the entire series: the lines between good and bad, right and wrong are often clouded and you're nearly always treading the fine line between what is acceptable and what may be too much of a compromise.

The fighting portion of the game still holds up well in 2020. The game's inventory management is as bit debatable and you can no longer use potions mid-battle, but this does not take away much from the game itself, which is every bit as playable and decent-looking today as it was back in 2011.

you ever feel like you really suck at a game, and then realize it's not you that sucks, but the game? This is how the combat system in this will make you feel. I'm daniel. I just beat deus ex mankind(a pretty hard game) on the hardest difficulty my first time picking it up. So i'm no slouch. But this game is impossible. And it's not because i'm bad, it's because the game is. The lowest tier of nekkar (a common early gmae unit) one shot you from behind. And because of the terrible targeting systeem, your guy is likely to dash in the middle ofa bunch of them quite often. Prepare to need to save before even facing a few mobs. The evasion system is trash too. The best you can do is roll, but you can't roll anywhere the game doesnt want you to go which is A LOT of places, including even down a gently sloping hill because "thats not the path of the game" you also can't jump. The combos your guy does seem totally random, sometimes totally wrong for the situation, and putting you in peril. Wild spins that expose your back and take a long time, strange lunges that shoot you in the midst of many mobs all caplable of one shotting you.......

This is a game I really wanted to like. I tried really hard becasue everyone said it was so amazing. But this game has the clunkiest most retarded UI I have ever seen on a game. Graphics are good for it's time, story is cool, but you will be incessantly driven mad by ridiculous things like geralt not doing charms when you tell him to because he couldn't lock on enemies properly, terrible AI that has to rely on cheating instaspawns right behind you, and the like. I am currently in the dungeon mission. The camera continually gets stuck behind objects and you cant see your guy. You try to swing your weapon at guards and instead geralt contniues putting out and restarting torches on the wall becuase it's the same button and you die. You cant even jump!!! and there are so many places where a .5 foot ledge shoulid be possible to jump onto or down from but you cant. You have to find the sandboxy path that the devs came up with for you rather than going where you see as an obvious path. It's just annoying, reminiscent of very old games for n 64 or xbox. This game is pretty bad. I'm going to play it, becasue like I said the story is good, but this is a game with ridiculous combat mechanics where all you can really do is spam roll all over the place to evade enemy swords and it doesnt even really work. It's also kind of annoying that you have to constantly buff armor and make potions, meditate etc before fights. I've played lots of medieval combat sims like mount and blade and stealth FPS like Deus Ex, and this game really could have benefited from going first person.
This game is  insane, with how many options and choices there are, all of which effect the outcome. A really impressive game, even compared to witcher 3

Witcher 1 and 3 are absolutely great games, I wanted to keep playing 24/7 and I was in tears when I reached the ends. However, Witcher 2 makes me want to cry when I launch it and I hope I'll reach the end... soon. I've played only 4 hours and it's been enough. Combat is terrible, targeting sucks and while you clumsily beat up one monster you have 10 others killing you, inventory etc. are one big mess, you can't use potions during the fight, dialogues are boring and I'm not sure which one breaks from all clicking sooner, my mouse or index finger. "75 reasons why The Witcher 2 sucks" on Youtube really says it all.
